The dragon says that Felix doesn't deserve to know
112121211212122221.content:
"A name?" The dragon growled quietly, his eyes stopping as he glanced. "I suppose that's something you humans get early on..."

"Early on? What's that supposed to-"

"Nothing you need to worry about!" The dragon snapped a bit, not wanting to remain quiet for even a moment. The human had already seen him distracted before, and he didn't want to give him another reason to be suspicious.

But there wasn't that much he could say. The dragon simply didn't have a response. He was still a child, and he wasn't old enough to be of worth yet. Until he could prove he was a strong individual, he would simply be called a child. If he couldn't prove himself... Then nobody would give him one.

But there was no way he could say that to the human. He had already shown enough of himself, and there was no way he would admit to anything else. The human would just use it as another excuse to lecture him, and he simply couldn't accept that. He would try to earn it, just like everything else. He would take charge of it himself, and prove he was worth it to everyone.

He shook his head a little as he suddenly saw the kid watching him. He growled quietly, hoping he wasn't distracted for too long. "What is it? Felix, was it? Why are you staring? Just want to take a good look at me?" He grinned a bit as he spoke, a bit of pride clear in his voice.

Felix hesitated for a moment before responding. "So... You're okay with calling me that?"

The dragon scoffed a bit as he growled. "Better than calling you human all the time. You're... a bit different from the rest." He snorted a bit, a tiny bit of smoke coming as he did. "I might as well know the only person I'm actually talking to here."

"Ah... I suppose that's one way to describe it. So, what's yo-" Felix started to speak before he saw the dragon's muzzle starting to move. Though he wanted to move aside the moment he saw the motion, he held in place as the dragon simply turned to the cart. He was rather rough in pushing against it, knocking its contents about as his muzzle made contact. However, though Felix was relieved that he wasn't going to be harmed, it was still rather nerve-wracking for him to see the dragon snapping a bit.

"Um... Could you please be careful?" The dragon stopped, growling quietly. Although Felix was nervous to ask something of the dragon, any punishment he would receive wouldn't be any better than what the dragon might do to him. "If the cart gets damaged, I..." Felix hesitated for a moment before figuring out what he could safely say. "I probably wouldn't be able to come again." The dragon growled quietly for a moment, his eye turning to Felix.

"Fine. Get the stuff off. I'd rather not lose the bit of entertainment I have in this place." The dragon grumbled quietly as he barely pulled back, there barely enough room between him, the cart, and the wall. Felix swallowed a little as he had to move close just to reach the cart.

Even as he walked up to the cart, he felt the dragon staring at them. He could even feel himself sweating as he saw a bit of smoke around him. The dragon was clearly watching him closer than he would like, and there was more than enough trouble. Though he had been close before, it wasn't like this. It felt like he could snap at any moment, and the wounds that he had from the first attack were still firm in his mind.

The dragon even gave an amused snort as he saw Felix so close to panicking. A small puff of smoke was enough to make him tense a bit, and the dragon chuckled quietly as he saw Felix so jumpy. It wasn't a surprise that he tried to hurry through, and it only took a couple of minutes before a bit of meat and water were both on the ground.

After the experience, Felix didn't feel too comfortable speaking immediately. He quickly moved aside after he was done, still barely in the line. However, the dragon wasn't speaking either, more focused on his food.

"Um... I don't think you ever answered me..." Felix broke the silence rather nervously, not sure if he should stay within the line, or if he was better off further away. "Um... Do you have something I can call you?"

Although he had been thinking about it in the back of his mind, he had to make a decision. As he finished swallowing the bite of food he had, he opened his mouth to respond.

1121212112121222212.content:
The fire dragon didn't want to admit that he had no name. This could give the human ammunition for his arguments. Plus, the dragon didn't want the human feeling sorry for him. "It's bad enough that I'm starting to rely on him for help and comfort from my loneliness," the dragon thought, his thoughts stinging his pride like venom. " I don't need the human feeling sorry for me as well," the dragon continued, "I don't want to be pitied. I've gone through too much for people to think I'm weak. I..."

"You do have a name, don't you?" Felix interrupted the fire dragon's thoughts.

The fire dragon had to think of a reply quick. The dragon automatically gave into his prideful side since it was the first to think of a reply in that short time. "I do have a name, but a small human like you isn't worthy enough to know it," the dragon growled. Normally, the dragon's two sides would have thought of a compromise between them in order to think of a clever lie that wouldn't hurt his pride and wouldn't harm Felix. However, the dragon's gentler side couldn't think of a good enough reply that wouldn't reveal he didn't have a name.

Felix was truly hurt by the dragon's reply. Felix had thought that he was at least getting through to the dragon a little bit. He could even explained away some of the dragon's other actions that was done to purposely scare Felix. Those action were only to show dominance over him since dragons, at least fire dragons, wanted to feel strong and the dominant species. Even if it did prove the dragon was dominant, the dragon seemed to make those actions, seemingly light heartedly, as if the dragon wanted to show Felix that he could do whatever he wanted with him, but choose not to harm him. Though the dragon was acting as though he was a powerful and mean creature that cared nothing for humans, Felix had thought there was something in the dragon that was kinder and gentler he could befriend.

However, after such a comment from the dragon, Felix felt as though all those hopes were dashed away. Felix had been nice to the dragon and had even saved the dragon's life by feeding it, even after the dragon had injured him. Yet, none of that seemed to mater to the dragon. It seemed as though to the dragon, Felix was nothing more than some insignificant creature that could amuse him.

The fire dragon saw how much his comment had hurt Felix's feelings and started feeling... "No," the dragon thought as her turned his head away and looked down at his food which he started eating again, "I can't feel that way, especially not to a human. I mustn't feel sorry for such a weak creature. Predators don't feel sorry for their prey. So, why should the strong feel sorry for the weak?"

However, something deep inside the dragon felt sorry for the human whose feelings he had hurt despite trying to hide it from himself. The reason he keep from looking at Felix was so that feeling deep inside didn't grow. "Why should I even feel this way?" the dragon questioned, "Is it because the old me, the me that was banished, is still in me? Is it because I've been alone for so long that I've become lonely and this human is the only one who has cared about me in such a long time? What is happening to me?"

"Not worthy!? Not worthy!? Not even to know your damn name!?" Felix yelled, too angry to care he was screaming at a dragon that could easily kill him, "Do you realize how nice I've been to you? All I'm required to do is make sure you're feed, but I've stayed to talk and keep you company. I have saved your life by feeding you when you were too weak!"

"I actually felt sorry for you," Felix continued, "You've been abandoned and outcasted by your own clan. You've had to live all alone. You've become so lonely that you want to still be with the ones who abandoned you and change who you are just to prove yourself to them. They could care less about you and you try to be like them just to gain acceptance. I even felt a connection between us, because we have both been abandoned by those who were meant to take care of us. We have more in common than you want to believe, yet I'm not worthy to know your name."

The dragon lifted his head and moved it directly in front of Felix with his lips curled upwards and his teeth showing. The dragon growled, "I don't want your pity, human! Having such a weak creature feel sorry for me is a disgrace and so is the strong pitying the weak. Save your attempts, human. We are not alike and we will never be equals. Now quiet your tongue or I will..."

"You'll what? Kill me? Go ahead and kill me!" Felix demanded, "I wouldn't mind dying this moment. It would be better than having to live through this shit."

The dragon was surprised by the human's response. All their other past discussions were about pressing on and doing what ever it takes to stay alive. The human used to promote hope, but now it seemed like he was giving up on life. "You said surviving was an act of strength to fight another day, that dying and giving up was the weak action," the dragon responded.

"I've been here for five years and I can't take it anymore. So, if you want to kill me, than do it. It would be doing me a favor. No one cares about me, and no one would ever miss me in the slightest. I am nothing. I'm not even considered a person to my own kind. I'm just property to my own species and just an insignificant bug to you dragons. I am absolutely nothing, and no one would ever remember me. So, is the fate of all who are abandoned and become slaves."

The dragon examined Felix and saw that Felix truly had no more fear of death. The dragon had to admire such bravery even if it was only because Felix had no more care about life and just wanted to give up and die. The dragon had never seen such sadness before. The dragon sighed, "I'm not going to kill you."

"Why not? I'm not even worthy to be stepped on or eaten by such a mighty fire dragon?" Felix replied angrily.

The dragon replied...

11212121121212222121.content:
"Would you just shut up!" The dragon quickly snapped out at Felix, a bellowing roar forcing him to step back a bit. It would be simple for him to kill the human, and part of him knew it. He knew that he had caused plenty of injuries to the other humans that had come in, and this one wasn't even close to threatening him. His maw was wide open as he shouted, his eyes glaring over the kid as muzzle pushed him onto the floor. However, though he was a bit shaken from the move, Felix's expression remained the same.

"Just kill him! One quick bite and the problem will be gone for good!" The dragon reached his claw around, holding Felix down, pinning him effortlessly as he pushed towards him. However, despite what his mind was telling him, he hesitated. His anger was still clear and his glare was still threatening, but even before he had found a reason, he had stopped himself.

"You don't want to do that. You don't want to get rid of him when he's the only one who's not out to get you around here."

The dragon's roar quieted to a growl as it just glared at Felix. "He's going to keep doing this! He's going to keep acting this way as long as he's around! Just take care of it now, or else you're going to stay weak and vulnerable the entire time! Dealing with him is what's keeping you weak!"

"Dealing with him is what's kept you alive. Like it or not, if you had tried to act strong and independent, you would've already starved and died." The dragon's breathing slowed, his expression fading slightly. "He's helped you survive. He's helped you a lot more than anybody else."

The dragon kept growling, but moved off of Felix, quietly moving back further into the cell, curling up slightly as he stepped back. "I'm not going to kill you..." He spoke with a bitter tone, and continued to glare at Felix as the kid slowly got up. "You're..."

"I'm what? Just say it!" Felix shouted back, his voice still clear despite his situation. He was getting more and more upset at the dragon, not even caring about the danger anymore. His life had always been at risk ever since he had become a slave, and his

He hesitated. There were plenty of things he could say. Even without killing the human, the proud part had already found half a dozen ways of responding. However, none of them sounded very appealing, and the dragon knew it. The other part of him, however, seemed to be quiet, only a few faint thoughts in his mind. "You could just tell him what you're thinking... He's already seen you in worse situations. He's fed you, and he's already seen you after you got the brand. There's nothing left that could make you any weaker in his eyes, is there?"

"What you're worth has nothing to do with it." The dragon spoke quickly, even coldly, just trying to get everything out before his doubts silenced him. However, as he continued, his voice fell in tone, becoming quieter, and turning unsteady. "You're... helpful..." The dragon strained himself to admit that much, nervously speaking. He didn't even know what he was trying to say, much less the way to say it. "You're a human, but you've been... good." He was visibly quivering, a large part of him hesitant, even scared to say that much. He half-expected the human to burst into laughter at him, or to start taunting him, though he wasn't even watching or listening for any reaction at all. "I won't kill you... I like having you here."

The dragon turned away quietly, closing its eyes and just curling up in the corner. He clawed a bit at himself, the brand on his arm stinging slightly. "You idiot... You'll never be a true dragon if you keep acting this way!" He scratched harder at himself, clawing a bit more at his his arms, even wanting to punish himself for his admission, but felt unable to do enough. He wanted to find an excuse, to say Felix was a possession, to do anything to cover up what he had just admitted to, but he wouldn't let himself make a sound now. All he could think of was how pathetic felt after what he just did, but he didn't want to risk driving Felix away any further. He couldn't show his pride, his weakness, his sadness, anything.

He turned quietly, eyes closed tight and clenched shut forcefully. He almost wanted to cry, but no matter what, he couldn't do that either.

112121211212122221212.content:
Felix stood motionless as he watched the large fire dragon curl up and look away from him, quivering and fighting his emotions from emerging. Felix's anger started depleting once he heard what the dragon had said to him. "The dragon actually likes me around him? But the way he acts... He's just conflicted with who he is and what the other fire dragons want him to be like," Felix thought, "That half of him that wants to be like the other fire dragons is strong inside him. It's clear when it took so much to admit to me his true feelings. He needs help, but I don't know what to do for him."

Felix sighed, "I have to try something. He's very confused and lonely. If he knows it or not, he needs someone's help, and I don't think anyone else around here will do it."

Felix slowly approached the curled dragon who shill had his eyes clenched tight as he tried to fight off his emotions. Felix knelt beside the dragon. Felix wanted to help the dragon and calm him down, but Felix didn't know what to do or say. Felix placed his hand on the dragon's bicep which was the only thing he could touch from that position since the dragon was curled away from Felix. Felix was hoping stroking the dragon would calm him down, but the dragon only growled when Felix placed his hand on him. Felix quickly took his hand away and the dragon stayed curled. "I want to help you," Felix informed the dragon, "But I don't know how to. Every thing I can think of saying or doing would easily comfort a human, but it would only seem disgraceful to a fire dragon. Usually when a human touches another human who is distressed, it's to show the distressed person they're not alone and there is someone there for them. But dragons would want to be touched by a human. Even if that human was only doing it to comfort the dragon, the dragon would see it as a disgrace having a human touch them, am I correct?"

"You are right human," the dragon replied with his eyes closed and head still turned away, "It would feel as a disgrace to us dragons."

"I want to help you, but I don't know how to. Is there a way I can help you?" Felix asked.

"There is no way to help me," the dragon muttered, "Just the act alone of helping makes me feel weak, makes me not a dragon. But that may be too late for me. I've already proven that I weak. The fact that... I like... having... human company shows that I am weak. And all the other things I've done is an embarrassment to my species. I'm now dragon. The dragon was struggling with those words. Part of him didn't want to say them, ordering him not to say things, but the dragon was sad and his thoughts and feelings were too strong to hold back. At least he wasn't crying and his voice was emotionless.

"You're not weak and you're still a dragon," Felix informed him.

"I... appreciate that, but I'm weak and not a dragon. You had to... help me. A dragon being helped by a human. It's weakness. With weakness, I can't be a dragon," the dragon replied.

"You're still a dragon no matter how you act," Felix told the dragon.

"I may have a body of a dragon, but I have to act like a dragon too to be a dragon," the dragon stated.

"I haven't gone through what you have, but I can tell you're conflicted, like there are two parts to you. I can tell their clashing with each other and you think you're weak. But think about it. Which part was stronger? Which part of you is winning the fight inside you, shouldn't that be the stronger half? Wouldn't that mean that the winning part of you is the strong one and not listening to it makes you weak?" Felix questioned.

The dragon was silent, thinking of an argument that would make the human's statement false. "Listen, I like you too. We could be friends if..." Felix started.

"I can't be friends with a human," the dragon interrupted, "It's forbidden. It's not dragon-like."

"Yet we like each other. That's friendship. If you were a human, would we be able to be friends then?" Felix asked.

"But I'm a dragon and not a human," the dragon argued.

"I believe there have been stories of humans and dragons becoming friends. I believe it is possible. You may think that friends make a person weaker, but it makes people stronger. No matter how weak or small, friends make a person stronger. They have more knowledge, power, and numbers. Friendship is not a weakness," Felix explained, "I have many plans on escaping this place, but I was never able to do any of them whether is was because I wasn't physically strong enough, didn't have the numbers, or other reasons. With your help though because of your strength, size, and abilities, there might be a plan that we can do and we might be able to escape together."

The dragon didn't answer, he just collected his thoughts. "I have to go know. I'll talk to you when I bring your next meal," Felix informed the dragon before he left.

1121212112121222212122.content:
Time passed slowly. After all that had happened, the dragon felt too tired to even force himself to move. He could barely even manage a growl the few times that a guard looked into his chamber, and had to settle for simply lying there. It was painful to hear them speak and laugh. Though they hadn't guessed the reason, it was clear that they thought he was broken. Though it was not their master who had done it, the thought of being treated like a failure of a dragon still felt worse than anything else he had experienced the entire time in his prison.

He didn't even know what he could do. The only time anything seemed to change in the room was whenever someone came in, and he didn't know how long it would take. It could've been night for all he knew, but despite his exhaustion, he didn't feel like it was the right time to sleep. All he could do was wait, and perhaps something might happen for the better the next time Felix came in...

"You're pathetic... Letting a human capture you, and then letting another one get to you like this... You were supposed to teach yourself to be a dragon, but instead, you've just become even weaker! If you keep going like this..."

"If you keep going like this, then you'll actually have someone as a friend."

The dragon clenched its claw, scratching at the ground as he did."You can't have him as a friend! Humans will never be close enough to dragons to be friends! He's not even important enough to speak with you! He's just a servant! Having such a human a friend is unacceptable, and even if humans weren't weak to begin with, dealing with such a small one is ridiculous!"

"Human or not, you want to speak with him more than anybody else, don't you?"

"Useless! Talking with humans is useless! You know that they can't do anything!"

"If he was as weak as you believed, then he would have died the first time you struck him." The dragon's body tensed a bit at the memory, uncertain as to what he should feel about it, and whether or not Felix was injured by him. "He's the one who decided to stay after getting hit. He's already done a lot more than any other human, hasn't he?"

"All of them are weak! The moment you escape, all of those cowards are dead!" The dragon gave another weak growl as he tried to move, to force himself up from the ground. "There is no way you can just sit around and wait for him to return! Just get out on your own!" He shook his head slowly as he let his claws grasp at the ground. He barely managed to push himself off the floor, trying to get into what he thought was a strong stance. He felt a slight bump as his head brushed against the ceiling, growling a little louder as he felt it. "That's right... You're a dragon. You're bigger and stronger than any of these puny creatures, and you can prove it!" His growling amplified as he put more effort into it, trying to gear himself up for a roar, but as he started, his voice faltered. He heard the door open, and he only managed to give a small one when he saw Felix walking in again.

Felix quietly looked at the dragon, his expression still shaken by the roar. However, after a moment's pause, he resumed moving into the room. The dragon stared back for a moment, trying to continue growling, but it fading completely as he saw Felix's steady approach. Felix pushed the cart up to the edge of his reach and barely paused for a moment before quietly continuing over the boundary, pushing it close to the dragon once again.

The dragon hesitated. It was his reflex to strike at Felix for his audacity, but he felt as though he would fall if he tried to force his limbs to move again. "Don't you dare collapse again! You've shown enough weakness! Just get this creature away before he does any more!" He grunted a bit as his claw move towards Felix, but though he felt the back of it make contact, he couldn't make himself push any further.

Felix looked up to try to meet the dragon's eyes, letting himself step back as he was nudged. "If you still need time, I can leave. But that probably won't make any of this easier." He let himself move a bit more, reaching down to grasp at the dragon's claw, but pausing before his hand touched. "But I don't think either of us want to stay here, so... If you ever become willing, let me know."

"I can't... I can't accept help from you..."

"Because you have to be strong, and because you have to be the one to handle everything." Felix quietly moved back to the cart, getting the dragon's meal off of it. "Is it that important for you? To be a proper dragon?"

"You wouldn't-"

"I haven't gone through exactly the same things as you, but that doesn't mean I won't understand." Felix sighed as he sat down quietly, looking back up at the dragon. "You have a lot to deal with, don't you?" He looked at the dragon, only to get a slow nod in response. "Whatever happened to you in the past isn't making this any easier to handle. Are you certain that you have to do this?" The dragon didn't even move this time, and all Felix could do was wait for a response, watching as the dragon seemed to lose himself in thought.

"He's trying... But maybe it's too much for him to take in. He wants to be my friend, and that part of him is obviously stronger right now, but the other part of him won't allow it, and it keeps holding him back. Should I ask him to ignore that part? It hasn't worked so far, but maybe with support, he could learn to block it out. On the other hand, he's probably been like that for a while, and he only started talking to me when that part of him was satisfied. Maybe I should try satisfying that part of him, too. If it's enough to let us talk, and to get him to listen, maybe it's worth a shot."

Though he had decided on what he wanted to try, Felix didn't speak immediately. He wanted to give the dragon enough time to decide something for himself if it was possible. However, after another minute, it was clear that the dragon was still arguing with himself, and Felix spoke to snap him out of it. "If it's too much for you to accept my help, let's do things on your terms."

The dragon stopped for a moment to look at Felix, uncertain of what he might have meant. However, both parts of him were listening carefully, both eager for any advantage that the boy could give them.

Felix quietly placed the food down at the dragon's feet, going back to the cart. As he noticed the confused look that the dragon had upon its face, he paused to speak, his hands still on the water bowl. "For now... What if you help me instead? If you help me, and I agree to serve you or something in exchange?"

The dragon was quiet for a moment as he bent his neck down, picking up his food but keeping his eyes on Felix the entire time. Servants were definitely allowed, but dragons should kidnap them or threaten them, not bargain for them. However, even seeing the opportunity seemed like enough to satisfy both parts of him. "It... It might work, but not for long. Humans can serve for a while, but they don't tend to live long if they do."

Felix put the bowl of water down nearby, speaking from a short distance away as the dragon kept its head near the ground. "I'll take my chances. I'd much rather serve a friend than serve William."

"We wouldn't... We wouldn't be friends." The dragon shook his head hesitantly and pulled away. "I can let you serve me, but we wouldn't be friends." His words were half-hearted as he said them, not wanting to admit them as they escaped his mouth. Even if Felix could accept that, the dragon didn't know if he could. It was the best solution for one part of him, but the other was saddened at the thought. Even if they could get out together, if it meant losing what seemed like the first friend he could make for years, he didn't know if it was worth it.

11212121121212222121221.content:
Felix sighed, rubbing his face. He sat down on the cold stone floor, the dragon watched him with his bright eyes.

"Humans. . . humans and dragons. . . are not that different you know."

The dragon let out a growl, but Felix didn't even flinch.

"I heard this story once. It was about a young dragon, maybe about 11 or 12."

Felix closed his eyes, remembering the story he was told by one of the older slaves. She had been the closing thing to a mother until she died two years ago. The dragon snorted, but settled down, listening.

"It goes that the dragon was flying home during a storm, and even though he was strong, the storm threw him around until he crash into the ground."

The dragon stared at Felix, wondering why he was telling him this story. Felix just sat on the stone floor, eyes closed as he recalled the story.

"A man that lived in a small hut with his wife nearby saw the dragon go down and went out and took him home. The man nursed the dragon back to health inside his barn. The wife, though, kept telling her husband to kill the dragon. For if he didn't, it would surly kill them when it was healthy again."

The dragon snorted, thinking how the wife was correct. No dragon would let a snack go, even if it did help him. The dragon stopped though, his eyes landed on Felix. The dragon could not see him seriously hurting this human. Felix continued the story.

"When the dragon was healthy again, he offered the man to come to his lair and to take some treasure, a thanks for helping him. The wife had screamed and yelled at him to stay, and that when getting to the dragon's lair, the man would surly be eaten. 'You will stay here!! The dragon trusts you and while he is not looking, slay him!! We shall take his head to the king and be rewarded' the wife had screeched. Unknown to her and her husband, the dragon was listening in."

Felix moved from his sitting position to laying down on his back, arms behind his head. The dragon looked at Felix and spoke

"Let me guess, the man agreed but the dragon killed him and his annoying wife."

Felix smiled slightly and snorted, his eyes still closed.

"No actually, the dragon was about to kill them both but the man spoke to his wife 'I shall not kill him, for he is my friend! If you can not see that we can be friends, then you are not the women I thought I married.' The dragon, who was still hiding was touched. His human friend had stood up to his wife to protect the dragon. The wife, though, was outraged. She quickly grabbed the knife on the table and brought it down on the man's shoulder. The dragon lept out from where he was hiding and quickly killed the women. Lifting up the man, the dragon flew quickly back to his lair and took care of his wound. When the man was well again, the dragon turned to him and said, 'My dear friend, your wife is dead and I'm sure the village near by had bunt your house down so. . .' The dragoon circled the man and playfully swished his tail by the man's feet. 'so you are my prisoner now and you shall live here. I brought several servants to do what ever you want' and at that time, three beautiful young ladies walked from around a corner. The man smiled and the dragon, the man, and the three ladies live happily together."

Felix finished his story, laughing inside at the dragons face. The dragon had a confused and skeptical look in his eyes.

"Why are you telling me this?" Felix cracked open one of his eyes before closing it and shrugging.

"Just 'cause, I mean the dragon and the man become friends even though both of their species are telling them not to. They even save each others lives." The dragon looked at Felix, so many emotions swirled in his eyes, they couldn't be told apart.

"That Dragon was stupid. If he had his own lair and had human slaves, then he lived alone, no clan at all. He was probably poor and soon died after this story." Felix stood up suddenly, and turned to the dragon.

"You know what!! You are weak! You're just a weakling who can't do anything for himself" Felix yelled at the dragon, his own anger flying out in waves. The dragon growled, how dare a human, even Felix, yell at him as if he was better then him.

"You want to know the reason you're weak? It's because you wont accept friendship!" Felix now paced in front the dragon, just out of reach.

"You probably wouldn't even make friends with another fire dragon because you think all emotions are weak, but that itself just makes you weak." Felix turned on the dragon again, his eyes ablaze. The dragon growled out in anger and thrashed his paw out, trying to at least injure the boy, but Felix was out of reach. Felix glared before turning and stomping to the metal door. Just before he opened the door, the dragon called out

"What was this dragons name? The one from the story." Felix didn't turn his head or even move to say he had heard, but he answered.

"The Dragon's name was Freith and the man was Rodoc" Then Felix left.

Freith and Rodoc?

The Dragon's eyes widened.

Freith was the elder from his old clan, and he had told stories of his friend named Rodoc.

Was Rodoc human? Freith had never said he was human, but he never said he was a dragon either. Freith had said he was small and could not breath fire or fly, but I always thought Rodoc was just a small, old dragon. . . could he have really been Freith's human friend?

Felix could tell it was hurting the dragon by saying what he did. The dragon's two sides were still fighting amongst each other and the dragon was still trying to make a compromise between them. By letting Felix become a servant, to the dragon, it would comfort both parts because the dragon would be closer to Felix, but still satisfy the fire dragon side who sees humans as weak beings that could only serve dragons. The fact that the dragon couldn't bring himself to see Felix as a friend showed that his stubborn side still was strong enough to make decisions for the dragon.

"I've seen people with conflicting sides within themselves before. He wouldn't be able to chose the other just over night, and forcing his to chose one side won't work," Felix thought, "The process has to be gradual. I have to satisfy both sides and the dragon will chose a more preferable side eventually. The more I stay with him, the more likely he might realize I'm a friend and that it's alright to befriend a human. That side of him is strongest at the moment."

"I wouldn't mind," Felix answered.

"You'd still be my servant, even if I can't accept you as a friend?" the fire dragon asked.

"You may not be as accepting, but I see you as a friend, even if you are sometimes stubborn and dominating," Felix informed the dragon, "Besides, I'd rather serve you that Lord William. Believe it or not, but Lord William is a worst master than you."

"You don't know that, you never had a fire dragon for a master," the fire dragon said. He said it as if he was trying to convince the human not to be his servant. Sure, he wanted to be closer to the human, but he was worried would his other side might do to a human servant. He was worried he might be a cruel monster and too demanding of the human who had the possibility of being his friend.

"If you act the same way you do to me now, then I might be relatively safer than with Lord William," Felix stated.

"Because I'm too soft and weak," the fire dragon muttered.

Felix wanted to assure the dragon he wasn't weak for being kind, but had explained it too many times and needed to wait for the message to sink in and for the dragon to figure that out himself. "Also, you're the closest thing to a friend and I feel like I need to escape with you, even if I have to be your servant to do it. You're the person I trust the most. For some reason, being near you gives me hope of escape. I don't know if it's because you're a strong, powerful, and defiant creature, or because I feel semi-comfortable around you, but I do feel like we have the power to escape," Felix told the dragon, "Besides, I've seen masters become friends with their servants. It's never happened to Lord William, but some of the other Lords that have visited had friends who were once servants."

The dragon was surprised that the human trusted the dragon and still had hope that they could become friends, when the dragon himself didn't have much hope. "And if that never happens?" the fire dragon asked.

"I can't force you to do anything. You have your own mind and you're far too powerful to boss around. I now you have two conflicting minds and over time, you'll decide for yourself which one is your true self. You're the one who chooses who you are and all I can do is wait for your decision," Felix informed the dragon.

"So, you'd still be willing to be my servant?" the fire dragon questioned.

"Yes," Felix answered.

"Then so be it. Lord William is no longer your master and when we escape, you are mine," the dragon stated, "Now, how do you suggest we escape this place?"
