"Just keep following paths large enough for you to go through," Felix said, "We'll come to the great hall soon after and we can get through the doors easily enough."

"Will there be much resistance?" Rathnait asked, seeing some guards coming now.

"Probably," Felix said, worried they might be captured.

"Good," Rathnait said in an arrogant tone before charging at the soldiers, roaring once more. The three men who stood in her way were run over and one would not rise again. The others were injured and knocked out but alive.

Rathnait continued dealing with the oncoming guards. While they had superior numbers, being forced to fight in a narrow area against something that filled much of it left them to be nothing more than pins for Rathnait to bowl over.

-------------------------------------------------------

"Where are my elite guards?! Where is General Ethan!?" Lord William bellowed at an aid.

"He is off in the providences collecting taxes," the aid said as they heard another crash, whether it was items on the walls being destroyed, doors broken open or men's armor clashing against the others, Lord William didn't know but grew more and more furious with every second they failed to capture Rathnait.

----------------------------------------------------------------------

"Those are the main doors!" Felix yelled, pointing to two great doors, twice Rathnait's height. Rathnait smiled and charged at the doors, scaring the two guards watching them away as she ripped at the doors before feeling something hit her legs. She stopped and looked at the soldiers gathering around her. She turned about and felt the power surge once more.

With the release of her steam stream many guards were severely injured, the few remaining were too close and would soon die from the injuries.

While her head was dealing with their protection, Rathnait jumped up on her forelegs and kicked the great doors open. In their defense, these doors were strong enough not to be smashed by Rathnait's power, only dented them. Feeling the warm sun rays on her for the first time, Rathnait turned about and ran outside, jumping into the air. Her wings flapped and she was soon flying once more. Felix was holding on with dear life on her back.

"Thank you for your help," Rathnait said, as she flew higher to the clouds.

"Thank you for bringing me with you," Felix said, "Where are you headed to?"

"I'm heading home. My mother and father are probably scared senseless by now, wondering what happened to me," Rathnait said, "You're welcome to come with me. I woudn't have been able to make it out of there without you."

"I have no where else to go. I'll come if you want me to," Felix said.

"Then you're coming with me," Rathnait said happily.

--------------------------------------------------------------

"Sire, what do we do now?" the aid asked Lord William.

"Send General Ethan after them right away. I want that dragon," Lord William said,

---------------------------------------

After a few hours of flight, Rathnait come to view the mountains of her birth and she cried while laughing in joy. As she approached . . . .
1151212211221221211.title: Escape.

choices: Only her siblings were there, because her parents were out looking for her.
Her whole family was there, and they were all relieved to see her!
11512122112212212111.content:
No more obstacles got in Rathnait's way, but if they did, it wouldn't stop Rathnait from getting through them. Her determination and spirit were too great, and nothing could stop her from getting back home to her parents and her many brothers and sisters. Rathnait missed them all, and it was sad that it took being held captive for a couple of months to realize how much she truly missed them all.

Rathnait flew as fast as she could to get to her parents mountain cave. Felix had to hold on tighter by grabbing around the back of Rathnait's neck, while as much as he could wrap around. However as Rathnait got higher, the air grew colder and thinner. Felix was getting very cold on Rathnait's back. Sure the neck in front of him was blocking some of the wind, but her head was slanted slightly and almost level with her back in order to fly faster. Felix was getting hit by the very cold wind of the mountains. Also, Felix was having troubles breathing at the higher altitude.

"Rathnait," Felix said almost to a point of wheezing. Rathnait didn't hear him and kept going upwards. "Rathnait, Stop!" Felix yelled as loud as her could which hurt his throat.

Rathnait suddenly stopped when she heard how bad Felix sounded. Rathnait hovered in the air continually flapping her wings and she did her best to look around at Felix. "Felix, what's wrong? You're voice sounds terrible," Rathnait asked worriedly.

"I'm cold... and I... can't breath," Felix said while still gasping for breath.

Rathnait finally realized her mistake. Felix wasn't ready for the thinner and colder air of her home. He wasn't adapted for it yet. Rathnait had to teach him how to properly breath. Rathnait flew to the nearest ledge that was large enough for Felix and herself. Rathnait landed on the ledge and lowered herself so Felix could slide off onto the ledge. Felix bent over coughing and gasping as well as shivering.

"Felix, you need to keep your breath deep and steady," Rathnait explained.

"But... I can't," Felix replied, "There's no..."

"There is, there's just a little less of it," Rathnait explained, "You just have to take deeper breaths to obtain it. Breath slow and deep. If something as big as my parents can live her, then you can too."

It took a great amount of effort, but Felix started breathing deeper and slower. Surprisingly after a few long minutes, Felix was back to himself again. "Are you felling better?" Rathnait asked.

"Thanks," Felix thanked, "I owe you."

"No, I still owe you. You did a lot more for me than you could possible imagine," Rathnait explained, "If only we could do something about your clothes."

"More like rags," Felix replied as he looked at the shredded and dirty clothes that wasn't protecting him from the snowy and freezing wings.

"My dad has human gold. He can go to the human village in the mountains that respect us dragons and buy warm clothing for you," Rathnait informed Felix.

"He'd do that?" Felix asked.

"I'm sure he will, he's never had a problem with humans, though he's sometimes cautious of them. Plus, once I tell him everything you've done for me, am sure he'd help you and let you stay with us as long as you want," Rathnait said, "Now, until he gets the clothes, me and my siblings or my parents can keep you warm."

"How many siblings do you have?" Felix questioned.

"Seven," Rathnait answered, "Four sisters and three brothers, all from the same hatching."

"How big are your parents?" Felix asked, a little nervously.

"Actually, I'm still just a baby in dragon standards, and they're much, much larger than me," Rathnait explained, "But they are friendly, they wouldn't harm you unless you provoke them. However, it take a lot to provoke father."

Felix nodded, but he wasn't entirely without fear with seeing some much larger than Rathnait when he thought she was already the largest creature he had seen in his lifetime. "In order to keep you warm during the flight, I'll have to carry you close to my... um..." Rathnait said, but hesitated slightly to remember with humans called the area, "chest."

Rathnait lowered her hand to Felix, but she didn't pick him up. Instead, she let him get in her hand, because he was another intelligent being, and Rathnait knew it would be a little frightening to be picked up by something large without consent. Felix leaned his back against Rathnait's palm and she curled her four fingers around Felix and then brought him to her chest. Felix could fell the warmth a few feet before he even touched the softer surface of Rathnait's underbelly.

Rathnait leaped off the ledge and flew towards her parent's cave once more. Who would be there when she arrived?
11512122112212212111.title: Felix's Troubles

choices: "My mother"  Who was returning to the cave and met in midflight
"My father".  Was the Lord he was after Lord William?
115121221122122121111.content:
Felix was amazed by the world around him. Above and below were clouds of white, disrupted only by the large mountains, some peaks and some mountains breaking the ceiling clouds. Then, out of the corner of his eye, he saw a movement in the clouds but then nothing.

"Rathnait, are there other dragons around us now?" Felix called.

"Yes, we're upon the outer edge of my clan's territory, but because I'm young compared to them, I'm flying much slower than them," Rathnait said. Felix couldn't tell for sure but it sounded like Rathnait was embarrassed by the fact she was so young to her species, compared to Felix being a child. She didn't say much else as she directed herself to one of the larger mountain ledges. She soon landed and Felix was in awe of the size of the cave entrance.

"Five Rathnaits could stand on top of each other and still not reach the top," Felix thought as he heard Rathnait saying something in her dragon tongue.

"Hello! Mother! Father! It's me, Rathnait! I'm home. Is anyone home?" Rathnait called, walking into the domicile. Felix heard nothing then what sounded like a chorus of noises.

"Eldest Sister!" Rathnait heard in response, followed by the sounds of many feet on hard earth. Soon seven dragons larger than Rathnait, but not too much larger appeared, bombarding Rathnait with questions.

"What happened?" "Where were you?" "Why do you have a human with you?" "You're smaller now!" came at Rathnait quickly.

"Calm down, this human is my friend Felix. He helped me out while I was away," Rathnait said, "I'll tell you the rest when I tell mother and father. Where are they?" This quelled the questions and brought an awkward silence amongst the other siblings. Finally the eldest child Alastar, hatched just before Rathnait, spoke up.

"They went to find you," Alastar said, "Father came in and told us humans had heard of a silver dragon being held captive by a human lord. He went after there to investigate it. Mother went to the village to see if any other information came up. They were both very worried about you."

"Father went after a human lord?" Rathnait responded, wondering if it was her her father heard about. "When did he leave?"

"A little under an hour ago," Alastar said.

"I have to stop him before he causes trouble," Rathnait said, turning back to the entrance.

"How? He is much faster than you. It's doubtful you could find him in time," Alastar said.

"But you could go and look for mother. She might be able to catch father," one of Rathnait's sisters said. Rathnait nodded. Females were generally faster fliers then males, while males more agile. She nodded before jumping off the cliff.

"Rathnait, what's going on? Was it the wrong cave?" Felix asked, completely left out in that conversation.

"That was the right cave but my father and mother weren't there. They're looking for me right now, but they're in different locations," Rathnait said.

"All right, so which are we going after?" Felix asked. Rathnait paused for a moment before answering Felix.
115121221122122121111.title: Short Reunion

choices: Rathnait's mother comes back with the father.
Rathnait's mother doesn't come back with the father.
1151212211221221211111.content:
"My mother," Rathnait answered, "She's at the human village in the mountains searching for more information about me. I have to go to her because she's the only one that might catch up with my dad."

"And where is he?" Felix questioned.

"He's went after a lord that supposedly has captured one of my kind," Rathnait informed Felix.

"You don't think that he went after..." Felix began to ask.

But Rathnait knew what he was about to say and interrupted, "Yes, he's most likely flying towards that evil man, Lord William, and dad could be in trouble if he confronts them. That's why I need to get mom so she can go after him."

Suddenly, something very large came out of the clouds, but it wasn't moving fast enough to be a blur like the other dragons that were passing Rathnait and Felix couldn't get a lock on. This one was slowing down and looking straight at Rathnait. Felix quickly became afraid of the dragon. It was a little frightening enough to be among seven other dragons that were around Rathnait's size, but this one was far larger. It was true what Rathnait said about being a baby compared to the dragons, because this one could easily have a head about the size of Rathnait's whole body! (This was also a female which meant it was slightly smaller that males!)

Rathnait cried something in dragon which was "Mom!" and Rathnait flew towards the giant dragon. Felix pressed himself into Rathnait's underbelly (chest) as if he was going to hid by sinking into her. This was the only thing that reminded Rathnait that Felix was in her paws, because she had been so overwhelmed when she had seen her mother. Rathnait stopped and her mother continued. "Mom, we can't hug just yet," Rathnait informed her mother using the human language, because she knew both her parents knew the language.

Rathnait's mother didn't hug in midair, which was possible, but she did nuzzle her daughter's head and cried, "I was so worried about. Your father and I were worried. We thought you could be dead after running off like that, and when have you learned human and why are we speaking in it."

"I have human company with me and I don't wish for him to be left out in a conversation when he doesn't have to be," Rathnait informed her mother.

The larger dragon lowered her head to where Rathnait's human was clinging and shivering in fear. "It's alright little human," the giant dragon assured, "I know I must be scary to you but I don't harm humans. You've made a right choice in befriending this family. What's your name?"

"F-Felix," Felix answered.

"That's a nice name Felix. Mine is Shanaye, and it's a pleasure meeting you," the dragon introduced. Shanaye then turned her attention back to her daughter and asked, "What happened while you were gone. I must know everything."

"We don't have enough time for that," Rathnait told her mother, "You have to stop Dad from getting to the lord. That lord is dangerous and he could be captured like I was or killed."

"You were captured?" Shanaye exclaimed.

"Yes, but Felix helped me escape and we can talk about this later. You have to stop Dad," Rathnait pleaded.

"I will do what I can," Shanaye replied, "You will go back to the cave and wait with your brothers and sisters. None of you will leave the cave. Then you will tell us everything that happened and don't think you're not in trouble because we were worried sick about you. You'll still be punished in some way for leaving on your own." With that Shanaye flew off and Rathnait flew back towards the cave.

Rathnait came back to the cave and her brothers and sisters were waiting impatiently. When she landed, they all crowded around her, but Alaster was the first to speak and he asked, "Did you find Mom?"

"Yes, she's going after Dad now and we are to wait in her till she gets back," Rathnait replied.

That was when she noticed the two youngest girls and the youngest boy were crouched low to see the human being held under Rathnait. The youngest boy and girl were twins since they came out of their eggs at the same time. Their names were Eshne (the girl) and Egan (the boy). Both their names meant little fire. The second youngest girl came out a little before the two of them and she had always been a playful and curious dragon. Her name was Soscelyne.

"I'm guessing you all wish to see Felix, but remember he's a person just like all of us. Not some pet or something," Rathnait warned.

"Of course we know that, we're not three months old or something," Sorcha, the middle female, said.

"I'm only saying this because Felix is my friend and I don't want any of you to harm him," Rathnait explained.

The dragons nodded and Rathnait whispered towards Felix in human, "Felix, I'm going to set you down so that my siblings can meet you. I told them not to harm you and I'm sure they'll listen, but if you still scared, you can stay close to me."

"I understand," Felix replied.

Rathnait set Felix on the ground close to her. She then lied down on her stomach and Felix stayed close to her chest. All the other dragon lied down as well and formed a semi-circle around the front of Rathnait to see the human. Felix sat down and leaned against Rathnait's chest as Seven sets of dragon eyes were staring in amazement at him. (Rathnait was looking at everyone else.) The dragon had never seen a human before, but they had been told so much about them from their parents.

Alaster was the first to speak and surprised both Felix and Rathnait when he said in human, "My name is Alaster."

"You can speak human?" Rathnait asked in dragon.

"Mom and Dad taught us a few phases and sentences in human. They were hoping we could help search for you by asking humans questions about you. We don't know too much of the human language, but we can properly introduce ourselves in human," Alaster explained to Rathnait.

Rathnait nodded and told Felix, "My bothers and sisters can speak in human, but only a few phases. However, I believe they wish to introduce themselves to you."

"My name is Allehe," a female dragon said. This particular dragon was the third to hatch after Rathnait and looked a lot like their mother.

"My name is Sorcha," Sorcha introduced.

"My name is Brodee," the second son and fifth child said.

"My name is Soscelyne," Soscelyne said. (The sixth child.)

"My name is Egan," Egan said and the last dragon soon said her name was Eshne shortly after Egan.

"Those two are twins," Rathnait informed Felix.

"My name is Felix," Felix told all of them, "And it's a pleasure meeting all of you." (Rathnait had to translate the last bit to them.)


Choice 1: Rathnait's mother comes back with the father, but it takes a long time. Meanwhile, the siblings have questions for Felix and Rathnait has to be the translator for most of it.

Choice 2: Rathnait mother comes quickly. Rathnait's father had either been captured or killed by Lord William before Rathnait's mother could get to him.
1151212211221221211111.title: Back to the Cave

choices: One of the guards appears and stops them.
They ignore any guards calls to stop and keep going.
11512122112212212111112.content:
"So how old are you?" Egan asked. Rathnait translated for Felix.

"I'm ten years old, a child to humans," Felix said.

"He's ten but for humans, that means he's a older than us," Rathnait explained.

"Why are you wearing such little clothing?" Sorcha asked. Rathnait was about to respond when all eight dragons looked to the entrance. Felix looked as well, then heard a roar. Suddenly the entrance went dark when Shanaye landed and entered.

"Mother, what's wrong?" Rathnait called, seeing a near feral rage in her mother's eyes. Felix saw this too and was scared by the look.

"Humans have captured your father. I came back to get help in killing the bastard humans who did this," Shanaye growled. Felix noticed shocked looks on many faces and they quickly turned to anger, even Rathnait's.

"Rathnait, what happened?" Felix asked.

"My father was captured by human," Rathnait said, "Do you think it was Lord William?" Hearing her daughter speak a complex sentence in human made Shanaye look down and remember Felix was there.

"Did your mother see any marking on the soldiers?" Felix asked.

"Yes," Shanaye replied, making Felix jump, "One of them had a snake eating its tale with a large eye in the middle of the enclosed space." Despite being so small, she saw Felix's eyes grow wide. "You recognize this symbol, don't you?"

"It's General Ethan, Lord William's most powerful soldier," Felix said. He could feel Rathnait quake in rage and her body growing hot by the second.

"Mother, how did these humans capture father?" Alaster asked, wondering why his mother had returned and not taken vengeance on these humans.

"They had a dust in the air that made me feel woozy and your father was barely awake on the ground, yelling to me it would paralyze me and make me sleep," Shanaye said in dragon.

"That's how they caught me," Rathnait growled, "That dust won't come off easy on its own. But water will help a lot."

"Rathnait, where is this human live?" Shanaye asked.

"Five hours my flight," Rathnait said, "West of the human forest called Breen. It's the only castle in the area." Shanaye nodded.

"None of you are to leave this cave. I will be back with your father," Shanaye said, "Disobey and you won't know the meaning of the word punishment." Felix saw the anger in the young dragons turn to a fear from the words and glare their mother had given them. Shanaye left and Rathnait and the others went to the entrance and watched their mother.

Shanaye let loose a terrible mournful wail and within moments dragons her size, some larger and some smaller came from the clouds.

"Rathnait, what is this?" Felix asked as the dragons congregated. He lost count at thirty dragons present.

"That roar my mother made is called the Rashinko, roughly translated, it means call of duty. It's done when we are in trouble or danger. All dragons who are of age are meant to respond and aid in the calling dragon's plea. Normally my mother wouldn't have made the call to save my father but she's worried about being captured by that dust," Rathnait said.

Felix nodded and saw something amazing. Around the mass of dragons, the air seemed to become wavy, like when you look above a fire and the vision of what's beyond it shifts a little.

"Is that their body heat affecting the air?" Felix asked, amazed. Rathnait nodded.

"My father and mother are well respected for their size and diplomacy with humans," Rathnait said, "Now watch and you'll know who is going to journey with my mother to help her."

"But I can't understand drag-" Felix said before nearly every dragon present lifted its head and breathed fire into the clouds above. Then, with blinding speed Shanaye led those who breathed off to Lord William's castle. The remaining ten went off in another direction.

"Those who remained will now watch over the territory to protect from possible invasion," Rathnait explained, "While my mother rescues my father and will probably kill every human in that castle." Rathnait then lowered her head to the ground. "And if anyone dies, it's my fault," Rathnait said in dragon tongue, crying slightly.

"What do you mean?" Alaster asked.

"I mean because I ran off to begin with and was captured by that human, it led to father being captured and possibly killed," Rathnait said. Felix didn't understand what Rathnait was saying but saw a deep sadness in her eyes the likes of which he had never seen before.

"Rathnait, is there anything I can do to help?" Felix asked, feeling woefully inadequate at the moment. Rathnait looked at Felix and shook her head.

"Just sit near me. I'll feel better once my father's returned, everyone else is safe and hopefully that evil lord is dead," Rathnait said. She saw Felix's face come alive with realization.

"They don't know what Lord William looks like!" Felix said, "He could try and escape and then come back after other cloud dragons. He knows where you come from, so he could set a trap for others." Rathnait's eyes widened as well as she got up.

"Sister, what is it?" Eshne asked.

"The man whose responsible might have made a trap for other dragons or he might escape from punishment," Rathnait said, "I need to tell mother."

"You can't! We were told to stay here!" Alaster said, moving in front of his sister. Rathnait looked at her elder brother.

"You will move brother and you will move now," Rathnait said with a look that put fear into Alaster's hearts. "I have to do this."

"Then tell one of the remaining adults and they can try to catch up," Alaster said.

"They don't know what he looks like!" Rathnait said, grabbing Felix and running past her brother and taking flight. Rathnait held Felix close to her chest as she flew harder than she had flown before.

"Rathnait, where are we going now?" Felix yelled.

"To catch up with the force to tell them what he looks like and it might be a trap," Rathnait said, pushing herself beyond her limit.
11512122112212212111112.title: Call of Duty

choices: Some bad news.
Really bad news.
115121221122122121111121.content:
"Rathnait! Stop!" a dragon commanded.

Rathnait tired ignoring the command and kept flying. Although Felix didn't understand the language, he did hear it and he questioned, "Rathnait what's going on?"

"One of the guards is trying to stop me," Rathnait explained.

"Maybe you should stop and tell the guard what Lord William looks like. The guard will be able to catch up with the others faster," Felix reasoned.

"But we'd have to give a good description on what Lord William looks like and hope he can remember and..." Rathnait started.

"Is it better than getting into anymore trouble that you're in now. It looked like your brother Alaster tried to stop you before you left," Felix replied.

"Mom ordered us not to leave the cave," Rathnait informed Felix.

"Then it might be best to tell a dragon and let him carry the message," Felix explained.

"You sound just like my brother," Rathnait said as she slowed to a hover.

"Think of it though, wouldn't it take you much longer to catch up to them? They're faster than you and the battle could be over by the time you get there," Felix added, "Lord William probably would have escaped and you'd just be in more trouble."

"You're right," Rathnait sighed, "But it's just that I..."

"You rather do things yourself. You like to be as independent as possible," Felix finished.

"How'd you know?" Rathnait asked.

"You're spirit is far stronger than I've ever seen in a person. I kind of guessed when it took you a long time to trust me," Felix explained.

"I get it from my mom," Rathnait told Felix.

"I kind of guessed it when she got so angry," Felix replied.

The dragon guard flew in front of Rathnait and hovered in front of her. The dragon's name was Scilti. he was about a hundred years old and just become of age. Scilti's parents were good friends of Rathnait's family and Scilti sometimes helped watched Rathnait and her siblings when her parents were away. This was probably because he was an only child, something extremely rare in the lives of dragons. Usually they would lay three to ten eggs on average per batch.

"Rathnait, where do you think you're going?" Scilti questioned.

"They don't know what the lord looks like and if he escapes..." Rathnait began to explain.

"I'm sure he will die. With the way your mother is acting, she'll kill everything in the castle. She will not miss anyone," Scilti tried assuring Rathnait.

"Can we give you the description anyway and you can catch up with them to relay the message?" Rathnait asked.

"Sure, but whose we?" Scilti asked.

Rathnait lowered her hand from her chest and held Felix out towards Scilti. Scilti wasn't as large as Shanaye because Scilti was much younger. However, he was still very large to Felix. "Greetings human," Scilti said in human and he spoke in human the rest of the time along with Rathnait.

"Felix, you know the lord better than me, could you tell him the description?" Rathnait asked.

Felix nodded before explaining, "Lord William is a tall man, taller than anyone in the castle. He also has a descent muscular structure with long blank heard down to his shoulder blades and a long beard a little past his neck. He is apparently a cunning and strong warrior, but he tends to let others do his work unless he has no other option. So, he would be in the castle during the battle. There are supposed to be secret escape routes from the castle that he might escape through if the battle isn't in his favor. I don't know where the passages are. You must give them, these warnings."

"I shall relay the message," Scilti replied.

"Also, not all of his subjects are willingly under his rule. He has many slaves and most of his soldiers only do his bidding because they have no other choice. There are many innocents under his rule. The only ones that are willingly on his side are the generals and General Ethan's troops, plus a few of the guards," Felix warned.

"So, there are many innocents, as well. I shall tell them this so that can be careful about who they kill," Scilti replied. Scilti then looked at Rathnait and ordered, "Go back home with your brothers and sisters. I will tell your mother that you just called from the cave to give me the message."

"Thank you, Scilti," Rathnait said before he flew with great speed towards the dragons that had left for battle.

Rathnait flew back to the cave wondering the outcome of the battle.

Choice 1: Some bad news. Scilti was able to relay the message before the attack. This saved many innocent casualties. However, Lord William still escaped through a secret passage.

Choice 2: Really bad news. Scilti didn't make it in time to relay the message before the attack. Many innocent people were killed because of Scilti not being there in time and Lord William had plenty of time to escape.
115121221122122121111121.title: Warnings

choices: They decide that is punishment enough for her behavior
They decide on a much lighter punishment for her behavior
1151212211221221211111211.content:
Minutes seemed like hours and hours felt like days, and so for the dragons and human in the cave, eternities had come and gone. No one spoke much, given the severity of the situation. Felix sat near Rathnait, who was keeping a vigil near the entrance, hoping her message had made it in time. Praying her father was rescued safely and no dragons were harmed. And while she was indifferent personally about the other slaves at the castle, for Felix's sake, she hoped they weren't slaughtered.

"Sister is very close to that human," Eshne whispered after some time.

"I suspect he was her only friend at that evil human's place," Alaster replied. He was about to speak more when he, and the other dragons as well, heard a roar.

Felix saw Rathnait suddenly stand up.

"Rathnait, what is it?" Felix asked, rising as well

"They're back!" Rathnait said, straining her ears. "Mother and father are both back!" Felix felt happy for Rathnait, when suddenly, she pushed her head against him. "We need to move back so my parents can enter," she said.

"Oh yeah," Felix said, recalling how large a space Shanaye took when she came in. He hurried back with Rathnait as the cave suddenly went black. He looked up and saw four eyes in the dark, a pair of silver and a pair of green. Felix then heard all the dragons seem to say the same phrase.

"Father!" the children exclaimed. Bringing in their wings allowed for more light in the cave and the parents walked in.

"I'm fine," he said, "That human dust just takes a lot out of you." His eyes looked over his children and came to Rathnait. "Welcome home daughter," he said.

"Father, I'm so glad your all right," Rathnait said, crying tears of joy that her family was all together once more and safe. Her father and Shanaye smiled as well.

"It was also thanks to you that I am child," he said, "And your actions helped save many human lives."

"It was actually Felix who realized mother didn't know what Lord William looked like," Rathnait replied. Shanaye blushed a little from embarrassment, while her mate lowered his head to look at the tiny human. Felix stared into the deep green eye.

"Thank you for your aid young Felix," came a deep calming voice. If Felix had been scared by this dragon, he knew this voice would have helped calm him. "I am Dracus."

"Hello," Felix said, waving a little. Dracus shifted his head and spoke in dragon tongue once more.

"Now for your punishments for running off and leaving the cave," Dracus said, "I feel your leaving the cave earlier was done for the right reasons, so no punishment will be given. But for leaving us like you did, that will take some time to decide a proper punishment." His gaze turned to Shanaye. She nodded.

"I agree with your father on this," Shanaye said when they heard Felix yell something.

"Um, excuse me, but what about Lord William? Is he dead? And what did you do with the other slaves?" Felix said loudly.

"After the fall of General Ethan, some of the slaves saw him fleeing through a passage way leading underground," Shanaye said, "He escaped us just as we attacked the castle."

"As for the human slaves, after some discussion we knew we would be wrong to free them and give them little chance of survival without becoming thieves, so they are being transported to a village we have ties with and ask the ruling lord to give them a place to stay," Dracus said.

"Thank you for that," Felix said, "And are you going to punish Rathnait for what she did?"

"They said they'd forgive me leaving the cave today, because it helped them but me running away won't be," Rathnait whispered to Felix.

"But you were tortured and beaten by Lord William, shouldn't that be punishment enough?!" Felix replied before noticing Shanaye and Dracus become rigid and seemed much warmer than moments ago.

"They tortured you?" Dracus asked slowly in human tongue, he didn't want the others to know that fact just yet. But the rage contained in his words were recognizable in any language. Rathnait nodded. "For how long?"

"For as long as I was there, over a month," Rathnait said. Shanaye and Dracus exchanged looks.
1151212211221221211111211.title: A Reign's End, A New Beginning

choices: They have to think about it.
They are glad to let Felix stay with them
11512122112212212111112111.content:
"What sort of torture did they preform on you?" Dracus questioned, still using the human language. It was a question that Shanaye and Dracus wanted the answer to as well as didn't want to know. They wanted to know how much hurt their baby received so that they could help her, but they also didn't want to know that their daughter had been tortured by the wicked lord and his minions.

"They tortured me everyday," Rathnait said sadly with tears forming, yet the tears never fell, "They would do many different things. Things such as whippings, cutting me with axes, chaining me and imprisoning my in a dark cell with little light. They did many more terrible things, but they were too horrible to remember," Rathnait answered in human. Rathnait knew there was a reason her parents were speaking in human.

"And why would they do that to you? Why would they imprison and torture you?" Shanaye growled. Her anger grew just as fast as Rathnait's anger when it grew. Shanaye wanted to rekill all the evil humans she killed in the battle as well as find Lord William and personally rip him to shred, or maybe torture him for a month like he had done to her daughter.

Rathnait didn't answer for a while so Felix spoke up. The only thing giving him the strength to talk to such large creatures was that he was right next to Rathnait and they were her parents. "They wanted to use her as a tool," Felix explained, "They didn't know dragons had intelligence and they thought they could train her to be loyal. However, his way of training something as by showing his dominance through abuse. It didn't help when he thought Rathnait was only an animal."

"Those monsters," Shanaye hissed, "Didn't they see she was only a hatchling?"

"It's a little hard for us humans to believe Rathnait's age when she is so big compared to us," Felix admitted.

"And to think we are one of the smaller species of dragons," Dracus said.

Felix had troubles imagining something larger than Rathnait's parents, but he couldn't even wrap his mind around something larger than them. "Does Rathnait still need to be punished?" Felix asked.

"I've learned my lesson," Rathnait informed her parents, "I realize now I can't do everything myself. I'm still too young."

Her parents realized how much it hurt Rathnait to cut into her pride like that and they knew that what Lord William did to their daughter was far worse than any punishment they could think of. Dracus looked to his wife and she nodded. Understanding what Shanaye meant, Dracus answered, "You have learned your lesson and you won't be punished, but if you run off again."

"I won't, I promise," Rathnait quickly interrupted. She didn't think she could ever truly recover from what she was put through and it would always be a reminder that she couldn't do everything alone. She even needed a human, which was far smaller than herself, to help her. She was still far too young.

"Now, will you tell us exactly what happened?" Dracus asked.

"Do you wish for me to speak in human still?" Rathnait asked.

"Yes, we'll decide what to tell and not to tell your brothers and sisters," Shanaye replied.

"About three days after I left, those humans found me. It was during morning and I was still asleep. They must have used the dust that they used on you father, because the next thing I knew I was in a large cage. The humans then chained me in a dark cell and tortured me to try and 'tame' me," Rathnait said, "I fought every human that came in my cell and tried my best to fend them off, but i couldn't stop them all the time. I realized that I could be trapped there for a long time. If that was the case, I was worried they would break me and I would be their tool they could control. There was only one option left to try and keep my spirits up."

"What was that?" Dracus asked.

"I had to make a friend. I had to befriend a human that would be able to comfort me and rekindle my spirit if it were to ever be broken," Rathnait explained, "I choose to try and befriend Felix because he was different from the humans that entered. He was the one who had to come in to feed me and give me water. He was afraid me and only entered because he was forced to by Lord William. I realized this when Lord William beat him in front of me."

"It took a while but we became friends," Rathnait continued, "I probably wouldn't have been able to make it in that place without him. He taught me his language and he was there for me when I needed him. he was the only hope I had in that hopeless place." Rathnait paused for a moment to nuzzle Felix who was sitting against her chest once more. "Thank you, Felix. I don't think I could ever stop thanking you for what you've done."

"How did you escape?" Dracus asked.

"They figured out that Felix was befriending me," Rathnait explained, "but they weren't entirely sure and they experimented with their theory. They whipped Felix in front of me and I could stand seeing him hurt. Not after everything he's done for me. A new strength erupted from me and I was able to break the chains as well as use stream breath to kill the man whipping Felix. I then broke his chains, he uncuffed me, and I forced my way out with Felix on my back."

"You are your mother," Dracus commented, "When those she loves are in trouble, she gains a powerful strength and determination that none can match."

Dracus turned his attention to Felix and said, "I would like to know your story, young Felix."

"Well, I've been a slave to Lord William since I was five years old," Felix replied, "I never knew my parents. I don't even know if they sold me into slavery, if they died, or what. I'll I know is that I've been a slave for as long as I could remember. I'm sure you wish to know why I helped your daughter, right?"

"Yes, we would like to know why," Shanaye answered.

"Well, at first I thought Rathnait was just an animal, because I knew nothing about dragons. However, when she started acting different towards me, I was able to get closer. When I tried communicating to her I realized she was intelligent and when she healed my back I knew she could be a friend. She was like me in many ways. We were both being held by Lord William against our will and being tortured by him as well. We became true friends and I had to help her," Felix explained.

"Mom, Dad, can Felix stay with us? He has no where else to go and he's my best friend." Rathnait asked.

115121221122122121111121111.content:
Dracus looked at Shanaye as she looked at him.

"We'll think about it. Humans sometimes don't adapt well to living with us," Shanaye said, "Because of their size and inability to fly, we must carry them and make sure they have access to goods that they can eat."

"Also, it isn't like we are alone in the mountain range. There is the human village nearby that we could arrange for him to stay in," Dracus added.

"Excuse me, but how did you become so friendly with a human lord?" Felix asked.

"The current lord, Lord Michael, when he was a young boy, he and his family were traveling through the lower parts of the mountains fifty years ago," Dracus explained, "He got seperated from them and was lost in the mountains. I came across the young Michael and took him back to his family. Up until that point we had an unspoken live and let live policy. But rescuing his son, his father realized we could be more aquainted than before and we started conversations. They have helped us by not allowing any dragon hunters to make camp in their towns and we have helped them by aiding to protect them when they were attacked or if they suffered a famine and we had food to spare."

"And Lord Michael even helped us look for you Rathnait by sending out people to look where we could not," Shanaye said, "It was how we learned of a young dragon being held captive by Lord William."

"He told me he would help us find you or die trying to repay that debt long ago," Dracus said.

"So that's why he was so accepting with you bringing in the former slaves?" Felix asked.

"Well .. . that was made more business than a personal thanks," Shanaye noted, "We'll need to give him some gold to help cover the food, clothing and shelter for them until they start working themselves."

"It sounds like I'll be a burden on you either way," Felix said, "Because I doubt Lord Michael would accept another former slave for free."

"We'll come to that path if we need to," Shanaye said, cutting Felix off, "Because right now, you are our guest for all the help you gave our daughter." Dracus nodded then looking at his children who had been left out for the past few minutes.

"All right, Eshne, Alastar go cut up enough meat for your siblings and Felix," Dracus said.

"Father, may I ask what you got so angry about?" Alaster asked.

"No you may not, now go," Shanaye replied sternly, "That goes for the rest of you as well." Rathnait didn't look back at her siblings right away, instead looking down at Felix.

"We're going to have dinner now. It's a long way to the main part of the den. I think I should carry you so my siblings don't eat your share of food," Rathnait said, blushing a little as she squatted down.

"Thank you Rathnait," Felix said, climbing on her back. Rathnait rose and sarted off. "What's for dinner?"

"Either basilisk or hydra," Rathnait replied, licking her lips, "I can smell both right now. I really missed this type of food."

"Are those safe for me to eat?" Felix asked with concern.

"Yes Felix," Shanaye said as Felix turned to face her, "We can cook the basilisk with our fire to make it edible for you. And hydra is fine once cooked as well." Felix nodded, then had a look of concern on his face.

"Are either of them intelligent creatures?" Felix asked. Dracus nodded slowly.

"Yes, but they are more instinctual creatures than intelligent like us or humans," Dracus said, "So it would be no different than a human eating a dog." Felix was going to say humans viewed dogs as pets but resisted.

"All right. Thank you for the clarification," Felix said before turning forward. As Rathnait walked on, Dracus and Shanaye slowed to talk quietly.

"Rathnait truly sees Felix as a friend," Shanaye said, "For her to grow in strength like that." Dracus nodded.

"I just wish he was older, but he's young and can still learn much from other humans," Dracus replied, "He would grow up away from his own kind."

"Considering how his kind had treated him, he may want to," Shanaye replied curtly.

"But you know there are good humans. Michael and his adult son Adam are two such people. They have never broken a promise with us, at least not intentionally," Dracus replied. Shaneye sighed.

"So what do we do?" she asked.

"We should at least give it a night to think on it," Dracus said, "Because if we take him from Rathnait, she might be very up set and try to stay with him." Shanaye nodded.

"So if its decided he would be best with humans, what then?" Shanaye asked.

"Adam has only one child, a daughter Felix's age. If we think he should live with humans, I will ask them to take Felix in to raise and educate," Dracus said, "He would be close and safe to the point I think Rathnait won't try anything immature."

"Wise as always my love," she said, nuzzling his neck the way he likes it nuzzled.

1151212211221221211111211112.content:
When Rathnait arrived with Felix on her back, her siblings were cutting up two large creatures to get there share. Felix was starting to get used to seeing giant creatures. The hydra was about the size of Rathnait's parents, but it hand many more heads than just one. In fact, the hydra had close to nine heads. It's necks were long and there heads had the likenesses of a dragon and a snake in one. The hydra's body was like a dragon with four legs, but it had no wings and the spikes on its spine were different.

The basilisk was a very large green snake. Its eyes were cut out which was so that it couldn't turn the dragons into stone when it had been alive. The giant snake was large and its height was about the height of Rathnait and her siblings. Yet, the basilisk was much longer than Rathnait's parents making it look enormous.

"All that meat to feed a small village," Felix thought, "Yet it's just a meal for this family of dragons. I'm glad there are other creatures as large as dragons or they'd have to eat a lot humans' game."

Felix watched as the dragon children walked up to what they wanted and cut enough meat for a good helping with the sword-like end of their tail. They would then bring it back to a place to sit and eat. Felix was glad that the dragons were civilized enough to do that. He was a little worried that they would just all tear into the food like a pick lions eating a kill or something along those lines. However, they still did eat raw meat and eat their share of meat like a "savage" animal. "What do you wish to try?" Rathnait asked Felix.

Most of the other dragons looked up from their food and wondered what Felix was going to choose. They didn't know what Rathnait had asked from the human language, but they guessed that Rathnait asked Felix what he wanted. They were curious what Felix would choose. "Well, I've never had either of them and wouldn't know what to choose, because I have no idea what they taste like. What would you recommend?" Felix asked.

"I personally like hydra better, but I can give you a little of both if you want. I'm sure I can give you both, because a mouthful for us probably would be many helping for you, right?" Rathnait informed him.

"Yeah, there's no way I can eat as much as you and your siblings," Felix replied. It made him realize how small he really was compared to the dragons. It also surprised him that such large creature could act that he was there equal. Rathnait took off a little of the basilisk for Felix and a large chunk of the hydra for herself. Once she went to her normal spot, she took some off the hydra piece for Felix as well. She kept Felix to her side, because she didn't want him anywhere near her food or mouth in case something should go wrong.

Sorcha, Joscelyne, and Egan and Eshne the young twins, came a little closer to Rathnait and Felix. They were very curious of Rathnait's new friend. Shanaye cooked Felix's food and Felix gladly thanked Shanaye for her help. However, he felt like he was a burden for her. He wished he could make a fire himself so that they would have to cook his food.

The dinner was quiet and there was little talk. Once dinner was over, it was the children's bed time. Rathnait's parents allowed Rathnait to have Felix sleep with her, mainly because they realized how attached Rathnait was becoming to Felix. Rathnait's parents only hoped Rathanit would understand if Felix had to live with the village.

Rathnait laid herself down on her stomach and she motioned Felix to lie against her side. "Is it starting to get cold for you again?" Rathnait questioned.

"Yes, it is. I'm going to have to get warmer clothing as soon as possible," Felix said as her approached Rathnait side. Rathnait's body heat was warm, but Felix still shivered slightly.

"What's wrong with Felix?" Eshne questioned with concern.

"He's cold," Rathnait explained, "Humans don't have an internal flame like us."

Eshne, Egan, and Joscelyne, who were still close by because they were still curious for Felix, approached closer. "Should we sleep next to you too to keep him warm?" Joscelyne asked.

Rathnait craned her head to Felix and asked, "Do you mind if Egan, Eshne, and Joscelyne sleep next to us? They're a little worried about you being too cold."

"Do they roll around?" Felix asked.

"No, we're all still sleepers, most of the time," Rathnait informed Felix, "You can sleep closer to where my front claw will be. That way I can cover you with it like a shield or blanket."

"Tell them I don't mind and I sleep next to your claw in case," Felix replied. Rathnait relaid the message and the three dragons slept close when Felix was safe near Rathnait's claw. The dragons positioned themselves against each other, but in places where they wouldn't harm Felix accidentally. Eshne, Egan, and Joscelyne fell asleep quickly. Before Felix and Rathnait could fall asleep, Sorcha approached them with one of her front claws closed.

"Do you wish to sleep with us too, Sorcha?" Rathnait asked.

"No, I'll sleep with Alaster and Allehe as usual, but I wanted to give Felix something," Sorcha explained. She lowered her paw and slanted it towards Felix. Two strange looking rocks rolled off and in front of Felix. "Gift," Sorcha was able to say to Felix in human.

"I'm sure he's wondering what they are, because I don't know either," Rathnait said.

"Tell him if he hits them together, sparks form and he can make a fire," Sorcha informed.

Rathnait relayed the message and Felix asked, "Why did you give me this? I'm glad you gave me a gift and I'm thankful, but why?"

"You seemed to have help my sister greatly," Sorcha answered once Rathnait told her what Felix said, "I'd like to thank you, and I saw how embarrassed you seemed when mother cooked your food."

Once Rathnait told Felix what Sorcha said, Felix thanked Sorcha again and Sorcha left to sleep with Alaster and Allehe. However, Allehe was talking to Brodee when he suddenly growled at Allehe to back off. Allehe slept with Sorcha and Alaster as usually.

"What's wrong with... um...?" Felix hesitated, trying to remember the dragon's name. It was hard to remember such strange names, but it was harder trying to tell the difference between the dragon children.

"That's Brodee, the second son," Rathnait explained, "He like to sleep alone. I don't know why. No one understands why he does this."

Felix left it at that and fell asleep.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- --------------------------------------

Dracus woke up early in the mourning before his children and wife and set off for the village. He knew Adam was an early riser and Dracus might be able to converse before the children woke up. Dracus flew down to the village which was still deep in the mountain range. They lived in a more manageable altitude for humans though and the part of the mountains they set the village on were still fertile and they could grow crops, (just think Incas in Chile, but not necessarily the same government and religion as Incas, because it still run by a lord.)

Dracus knew he had to land fairly far away from the village. He was simply too large to land close the village otherwise he might blew too strong of a wind when landing. Dracus walked the rest of the way till he came to the wall where a guard was waiting. "Hello, Dracus," the guard greeted, "Are you here to see Lord Michael?"

"No, I'm here to talk with his son, Adam, as well as finish our agreement," Dracus informed the guard while handing some bags of gold to guard who knew where it was supposed to go.

"I'll give word to Adam and he'll come," the guard said.

"I'll wait in me normal spot," Dracus told the guard. Dracus was too big to go in the village and had to wait outside the gates. Dracus waited and eventually Adam arrived outside the gate and climbed to where Dracus was positioned on a small mountain.

"You wish to speak to me?" Adam asked as soon as he sat on a ledge near Dracus.

"Yes, my mate informed you about a human my daughter came home with?" Dracus asked.

"Yes, what about him?" Adam asked.

"The boy, Felix, was a former slave of Lord William. Felix was the one who helped Rathnait escape and helped her keep her sanity in that place I'm sure. They've grown close, but I don't think Shanaye will be able to care for him. He's still too young and I don't think it's best for Felix. Shanaye and I wouldn't mind taking care of him, because he is a nice boy, but we don't want to force him to live away from his own kind. He can still learn from humans," Dracus explained.

"I think I know where this is going, but why do you need me?" Adam asked.

"I was hoping you could care for him and raise him. He's the same age of your daughter. However, I'm sure I'll still have to pick up Felix from time to time with he and Rathnait wish to meet, but I don't mind that. Could you take care of Felix?" Dracus asked, "If not, I'd understand and we could care for Felix."

"Could you give me a day to think it over?" Adam asked, "I'd need to say what Ashley thinks about having a brother."

"Then I shall come back tomorrow around this time," Dracus informed Adam.

11512122112212212111112111122.content:
"That should be enough time," Adam said, "And I am very thankful you found your daughter. I couldn't bare to think what I would do if my Ashley ran away like that." Dracus nodded slightly.

"It's a feeling any loving parent would dread to feel," Dracus said. Adam nodded as well and waved goodbye to Dracus, picking up the gold the dragon placed near the bottom of the hill. As Adam passed through the gates of the town, Dracus turned to walk back to the landing zone when he smelled someone close to him but behind his position when he was talking with Adam. He saw a human figure shimmer from behind a tree, like moving a glass and how the image is slightly distorted. Dracus paused slightly before focusing on seeing only body heat and the figure became clear. Dracus lowered his head and growled.

"Who are you?" he asked in human tongue. While he wouldn't say it crassly, given his friendship with Lord Michael and his son Adam, Dracus saw the village as part of his territory and disliked invaders into it. Normally he wouldn't take control but as this was no normal human, this was a special case. He felt warranted for a short time.

"A being with magic," the figure said, dropping his cloak and revealing himself. He was tall by human standards, past six feet. He wore a black cloak on top of grayish shirt and black pants. Dracus couldn't place the man's position in the human world because his clothes were hard to place. His face was clean shaved and his black hair was short. But his eyes were a brilliant blue. His expression was blank as he moved from behind the tree.

"And what business do you have listening in on a private conversation?" Dracus asked.

"I live in the area," the man said, "And I was on my normal walk when I saw Sir Adam conversing with you, so I hid. I assumed you didn't want someone to suddenly walk by while making business deals." Dracus growled slightly. He didn't like this man's tone nor his scent. There was something inhumane about it.

"By what magic can you hide from human eye?" Dracus asked quietly.

"There are many magics that can give someone the power to hide from certain sights," the man said, "I can use a plethora." He gave a cocky smile, before returning to a straight face.

""Then why do you not call yourself human?" Dracus replied.

"Some mages and druids consider themselves not human because they are capable of magic," the man said, "But look, I mean this land no harm. I'm simply in the business of hunting certain hard to catch game because of my abilities."

"I do not trust this being. I question if he is human or not. His scent . . . . I can't place it. It smells of human but that could be because he lives near them. If I attack him and he is a good human, it could damage my relationship with Adam and trying to get Felix to live here," Dracus thought. After careful thought, Dracus finally spoke.

"I'll take your word but if you ever cause harm in this village I will personally hunt you down and kill you," Dracus growled at the man.

"Well that would be interesting to see. Good day," the man said before walking towards the gates but he didn't aim right at them, instead he walked to the side as though he would walk around the village. Despite his desire to follow the human, Dracus went to the landing zone and jumped into the air, flying back to his family.

----------------------------------

Back at the cave, Felix had discovered there was not much variety in a dragon's plan for that morning they had what they had last night for dinner.

"Will we be having the same thing for lunch and dinner?" Felix asked Rathnait as he clicked the rocks together, making a small fire.

"Yes," Shanaye said, "We don't like to waste food, so we will eat a kill until it is bones."

"What do you do with the bones then?" Felix asked.

"Oh sell them to humans sometimes. The bones are very hard and not easily broken. In fact, one of the outer walls of the village is made from hydras' bones," Shanaye said.

"That's probably a sight to see," Felix said, shivering slightly. Rathnait and Shaneye noticed Felix shivering again.

"Don't worry, once Dracus returns I'll take you to the village to find some decent clothes," Shanaye said.

"Mother, may I come with you? I haven't been to the village in a while and someone may try to steal from Felix," Rathnait spoke in human tongue.

"If anybody is foolish enough to steal from Felix, they'll won't get very far," Shanaye said simply. Felix looked confused.

"Why do you say that?" Felix asked.

"Because you are our personal friend and if that is known and you are attacked, both Lord Micahael's men and us will want to find the human quickly. And they would be better found by other humans inside their village, or face our wrath," Shanaye replied.

"And Lord Michael has no issue with that?" Felix asked.

"He understands we take attacks to ourselves, kin and friends very seriously," Shanaye replied, "He knows we considered them guests to our lands because they are kind to us and live very close by. But he also understands if someone offends us and they are outside his jurisdiction, they better have a very good reason for it." She noted his fire wasn't very strong. "Would you like some help with your breakfast?" Felix looked at his tiny fie, knowing it was too small to cook on.

115121221122122121111121111222.content:
Felix looked at the small fire before him and he realized he had made a mistake. Instead of lighting and starting the fire with the dry grasses, he used the wood. So, when the fire was finally going, he had used most of the wood Shanaye had offered, The dragon's for some reason carried much wood and dry grasses in another chamber of the cave. This was in case they had human company that needed their food cooked, but they hadn't had company in a long time before Felix had arrived.

Felix knew he could ask for more wood, but it seemed worse and more of a burden for Shanaye if he asked this of her. She would have to go back and get more wood which would interrupt her breakfast more than just cooking it for him. Felix sighed at his mistake and failure and said, "Could I please ask for your help again?"

"You sure may," Shanaye replied before breathing fire to cook his meal with a constant steam of intense flame.

"Next time, I won't make the same mistake," Felix thought to himself, "Next time I'll be better prepaired."

Sorcha watched Felix and knew all to well what he was thinking. Sorcha was always good at sensing others, even humans who were different from dragons. "Mistakes are meant to happen. Otherwise, we can't learn from their lessons and can't be better," Sorcha muttered.

Rathnait was close enough to overhear and she turned to her sister. She was surprised by the wisdom her younger sister already had. Sorcha was always more mature for her age even though she was close to the middle of the batch that hatched. "Do you wish for me to relay the message to Felix?" Rathnait asked Sorcha.

"No, I can tell he understands the meaning of mistakes already. I can see the determination on his face," Sorcha replied.

Felix had heard his name being said. He felt a little uncomfortable about the giant infant dragons talking about him in their own language. Even though he knew they would never truly harm him or say such bad things about him, it was still uncomfortable for a large creature to be talking about him in a foreign language. "What were you talking about?" Felix questioned Rathnait when she turned her head back to her meal between her front legs with Felix siting against the other side of her legs.

"Nothing," Rathnait answered, "Just that we have confidence that you'll make a better fire the next time."

The breakfast was much like the dinner last night. The dragons didn't speak much. It seemed dragons were much different about meal conversations with family than humans. The dragon paid more attention to their food, while human families took more time talking than eating, or that's what Felix had heard. Felix was gladdened there wasn't much talk. Not only did he learn it was better to eat instead of eating from his life as a slave, but he also knew that is long conversations happened, Rathnait and Shanaye would have to translate what was being said and their meals would take long to finish. Then again, it wasn't like their food would get cold.

Felix's meal took the longest to eat since he had to wait for his food to cool enough to hold and he didn't attack his food as viciously as the dragons. Eshne, Egan, and Joscelyne were playing their dragon games which looked like a form of tag, which Felix didn't know because he never knew any games while he was a slave. Sorcha and Allehe were talking and Alaster, being the big brother type, looked over his siblings carefully. Brodee, as usual, was alone in his own world. It wasn't that the other dragons shunned him, he was just a dragon that liked to be alone. Shanaye had a watchful eye over her children and Rathnait stayed with Felix as he finished eating. Rathnait even placed her head to the ground and formed her body in a C as Felix was allowed to lean against her side.

Felix was glad to have such a good friend. It was the only thing Lord William had ever done that benefited Felix. If he hadn't have captured Rathnait, Felix would still be trapped in the terrible place and he would have never met Rathnait. "Funny how things turn out," Felix realized as Lord William had given Felix the greatest gift he could ever want without realizing it, friendship.

Once Felix was done and Dracus flew back into the cave, Rathnait asked her mother, "Can I come with you and Felix to the village? You're too big to walk through the village, but I could if I'm really careful and I could help Felix find the stores and..."

"We'll see," Shanaye informed her excited daughter, "I must talk with your father first." Shanaye looked at her oldest son and commanded, "Keep a watch on your brothers and sisters."

"I will, mother," Alaster replied as Shanaye and Dracus spoke in a private area in the cavern.

"What was Adam's answer?" Shanaye asked right away.

"He said he wishes for one more day to think about it. He needs to know what his daughter thinks as well," Dracus stated.

"That's understandable. Adopting someone is a big decision," Shanaye replied.

"There is something else you should know," Dracus told his mate, "Someone listened to my conversation with Adam. He claimed he was only out for a walk, but I fear he was out just because he had interest in the matters."

"Who is he?" Shanaye asked.

"He claims to be a villager, but there is something strange. He smells of human, but only because he has been around them for so long. There was another scent underneath it. Something both similar and foreign at the same time," Dracus informed her.

"What could it be?" Shanaye asked.

"I don't know, but he could become invisible to the human eye," Dracus added.

"What does he want? Do you think he wants something from Felix?" Shanaye asked.

"I don't know, but if he truly has lived in the village a long time and never caused harm to us, there might not be cause for alarm," Dracus explained, "Yet still..."

"We should be careful and keep a watchful eye," Shanaye finished, "Should we let Rathnait come with Felix and I? We were leaving to help buy him warmer clothes. If Rathnait comes, she can be closer to Felix if trouble should occur. All I could do is stay on a close by mountain top that could watch over the village. If trouble should occur, I couldn't help Felix like Rathnait could. However, that might put Rathnait in trouble. I have a preferred suggestion, but I want to know your take on it as well."

What did Dracus believe was best?

"If we have Rathnait stay and something happens to Felix, she won't forgive us easily," Dracus replied, "But if we let her go and something happens to Felix, she will probably fight tooth and claw protecting him. We also need to consider that man. If he can be seen only by dragon eyes, then we would need one close to warn Felix and the only one who speaks enough human and could walk with Felix down the street is Rathnait." He took a breath. "So, in the worst case scenario, only Rathnait can protect Felix adequately."

"But she was just learning to see that way," Shanaye replied, "Do you think she can sustain it while she's with Felix?"

"We don't know how her abilities matured while she was held captive. While her physical growth may have been stunted, her dragon abilities may not have been," Dracus replied, "After all, she was able to produce steam powerful enough to kill a human, while the others haven't been able to make anything more than warm air." Shanaye looked away.

"I was going to say we should let Rathnait stay," Shanaye said, "But with this unknown human in the mix . . . it seems the best option for Felix is to have Rathnait go with him." Dracus nodded.

"Then we will go tell them she can go with him," Dracus said, following his wife back.

-----------

A few minutes passed and Rathnait was grinning ear to ear after being told the good, to her anyway, news. Her brothers and sisters exchanged looks for a moment.

"Mother, isn't this a bit of a reward considering her behavior recently?" Alaster asked.

"No," Shanaye replied, "Your father and I choose to consider what happened to Rathnait while she was gone punishment enough for her actions." Alaster nodded.

"If you say so," Alaster replied.

Felix watched the talk from Rathnait's chest. "Rathnait, what's going on between your mother and Alaster?"

"It's nothing important," Shanaye replied, "Shall we head out?"

"Yes please," Felix said, before looking at Rathnait. "You may pick me up." She nodded and reached down, pulling Felix to her chest. Dracus handed Shanaye a small, to them, sac of gold and Rathnait followed her mother out of the cave and they took off.

----------------------------------

"Rathnait, your father and I were wondering something," Shanaye said in dragon tongue as they flew.

"What is it mom?" Rathnait asked.

"How is your eyesight developing?" Shanaye asked.

"It's coming along all right. I was able to use it a few times at Lord William's to see when the guard was close to the door or not, but I couldn't do it for long," Rathnait replied, embarrassed by this failure. Her mother caught that tone.

"Now don't say that. The fact that you could breath steam so early is proof you're coming along nicely. It's just some dragons see before they breath and others breath before they see," Shanaye replied.

Felix knew they were talking but he didn't feel safe asking about what. They were flying faster than the day before and he didn't chance to speak for fear of throwing up.

"I haven't had that much to eat for two meals ever," Felix thought as his body was getting used to eating more food. "I hope we land soon."

His wish was granted as a few minutes later, Shanaye landed in the landing zone and Rathnait landed soon after. She pulled Felix from her chest and set him down.

"Are you all right?" Rathnait asked, seeing Felix's woozy expression.

"I think I ate too much for breakfast," Felix said, dropping to his knees. Rathnait recalled one of their talks in her cell, when she learned "more" and "food" and said how she needed more food and Felix confessed he also didn't eat much.

"Well, if you can't walk, you could ride on my back," Rathnait replied. Shanaye's eyes narrowed a little. For her, it was one thing to carry a human in the air but another to act like a horse or mule. It was very degrading and people might think less of her if she did that. But thankfully Felix shook his head.

"No, I can walk. But thank you," Felix said, not wanting to be a burden on his friend. Rathnait sighed.

"All right, this way then," Rathnait replied. Shanaye waited to let them get ahead of her before walking.

After a brief chat with the guards as to why they were there, Felix and Rathnait entered the human village, the gold on Rathnait's back.

While looking for a tailor...

11512122112212212111112111122212.content:
Felix was amazed by the human village that was before him once he past the gate with Rathnait. The entire village was built on the side of the mountains. They had carved deep into the mountains and to make rodes as well and houses against the mountain wall before the roads. The roads went up in a spiral all the way up the mountain and were wide enough for a young dragon to walk on, though dragons a little older and bigger than Rathnait would take up the whole road. This spiral upward building was one at least five mountains and a stone bridge connected the other mountains to each other. In the center mountain was a large stone castle in the center which was even bigger than the castle Felix had lived in for five years.

Felix also noticed that the outside walls of the villager were built to the bottoms of the villages. They were only structured around the bottom level. However, the walls still protected the village because it was strong with many guards on it. Plus, if they were to be attacked by humans, a human army would have to climb the mountain to get to the wall or use the path for the main gate. Felix also noticed farming on the mountains as well which seemed impossible to him. Only one of the mountains had this and the crops where on what platforms that jutted out of the mountain like steps. They had been caved in and replaced with soil for the crops. Felix could only imagine how long it took to built such a wondrous place.

Seeing Felix wonder, she knew he was contemplating how this village was possible. "My clan helped this village once we arranged a truce with each other," Rathnait explained, "Apparently, the village was basic then because they couldn't carve into the mountain, but the adult dragons could and it had helped them out a lot."

"Is that why the roads are large enough for you?" Felix asked.

"They used young to stand on the roads to judge it was large enough for the humans. It wasn't necessarily meant so that we could, but humans don't mind us and father's such good friends with them that it does happen from time to time," Rathnait explained.

"Should we start going now?" Felix asked.

Rathnait looked up at a higher mountain first and saw her mother perched on top of it. Shanaye could see the entire village and was making sure everything was fine. However, she knew that if something were to happen, she wouldn't be able to interfere. Rathnait then looked back down and Felix and said, "Let's go, most of the shops are on this mountain."

So, Felix and Rathnait walked up the spiral path, looking for shop that would sell clothes. Rathnait was extremely careful where she stepped, not wanting to accidentally step on Felix or anyone else for that matter. Neither of them expected to run into a friend of Rathnait's family.

"Rathnait," a man called.

Rathnait looked up from her feet and stopped while Felix stayed a little closer to her front legs. A man was walking down the path in expensive clothing, but nothing like Lord William's clothes that he liked to show off. The man also had a sheathed sword.

"Adam," Rathnait remembered. "Felix, this is Adam, the son of the lord father saved long ago."

Felix understood he was a friend of Rathnait's family, but he was still a little nervous being around a son of a lord. So far, Felix hadn't had any good experiences with nobility which made him nervous around Adam. "So, you're the Felix Dracus has told me much about," Adam said with a friendly smile.

"Y-you know about me?" Felix asked.

"Dracus told me much about you when he came into town for the payment he promised. He told me you save Rathnait from a terrible man and you helped her escape," Adam answered.

"She did all the fighting, I just unlocked the chains and taught her to speak human," Felix replied.

"He's just being modest," Rathnait told Adam, "He did a lot more than just that, and I'm very grateful for everything he did for me." Rathnait lowered her head to nuzzle Felix a little.

Adam was a little surprised about how affectionate and close Rathnait was to Felix. "Rathnait must have been through a lot of torture, and Felix must have been the only light in the darkness for her to be so close and affectionate," Adam realized.

"It's kind of ironic," Adam stated, "Your father saves mine and now a human saves you Rathnait and both were saved from being lost."

"Yes, and it would have been more ironic if it was one of your bloodline saving me," Rathnait replied.

"That is would," Adam agreed, "What brings you here Rathnait and Felix?"

"We came to buy warmer clothes for Felix," Rathnait answered when she saw Felix wasn't going to.

"Be sure to buy warm clothes, Felix," Adam stated, "It gets very cold in the mountains, especially at night and especially at the altitudes the dragons live."

Felix nodded and Rathnait asked, "May I ask what you're doing down here and not at the castle?"

"The traders are coming to the village soon and I always like looking at the things they sell. It is interesting to see what can be obtained miles away across land and sea," Adam told Rathnait, "Be sure to be careful when you leave in case they come before you leave. I don't know how many have seen a dragon before."

"I shall be careful, Adam, thank you," Rathnait said before she let Adam pass and she and Felix started walking again. They soon came upon a shop with human clothes and Rathnait said, "Go on in, Felix. I'll be waiting out here."

Felix nodded and walked in the store. The store had many warm clothing as well as fine and expensive ones. A large and portly woman soon noticed Felix walk in the store and rushed to his attention. "Oh you poor thing," She said, "Look at those rags on your back. You must be freezing to death. Come, come, let's get you some warm clothes."

The portly woman quickly wrapped him in one of her own coats and let him sit in a chair. "What happened dear?" she questioned, "Where did you come from?"

"I'm one of the slaves that came from evil lord," Felix explained like it was no big deal.

"And nobody's attended to you yet?" the woman asked.

"I've been with my friend the whole time," Felix explained, "We haven't had time to come to the village until now?"

The woman was slightly confused till she looked at the window to see a large dragon eye looking in on them. "Oh, you're friends with the dragons," the woman realized. She then called to Rathnait, "Don't you worry, I'll have warm clothing for him in no time."

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- -------------------------------------------------

Kaage walked out of his home, well the place he paid rent to live in. it was a place he had lived for five years, but the woman he lived with didn't mind. Kaage opened the door to see a baby cloud dragon three houses down looking into the window. Kaage stayed still by the door with his black cloak's hood still over his head.

He watched for the longest time and saw a boy and the store keeper come out to the dragon periodically. The boy was asking for the dragon's advice and listening to it to find the right clothes for him. it had been five years since he had seen the boy, but Kaage recognized him right away.

Kaage quickly opened the door and walked back in the medium's store. "Kaage, I thought you were going to the marketplace," a woman who seemed to be in her twenties asked. (She wasn't actually twenty, but an immortal and a true medium as well as fortune telling, telling the future, and many other forms of magic.)

"You could have told me Felix would be here today, Rhian," Kaage replied.

"You didn't ask me if you would see Felix in your recent future," Rhian informed him.

"Do you think he remembers me?" Kaage questioned.

"I'm not sure, I can't tell the future of someone until I meet them?" Rhian replied.

"Adam might be taking care of Felix, but I don't think he's decided yet," Kaage said.

"I know, you already told me that. Why don't you care for Felix yourself? Wouldn't his parents would have wanted you to...?" Rhian began to ask.

Kaage interrupted, "I can't. He needs to be with humans. If he is with me, Felix and I would both me in danger. They recognize me, but they wouldn't recognize Felix. I'm always in danger, but I can't let Felix be in danger too."

"You haven't encountered them, the ones who chase you and wish to kill you and Felix, in quite some time," Rhian informed Kaage.

"I still can't risk it," Kaage told her, "I also have to get Felix away from those dragon. Seeing a dragon and being with dragon long enough might make him remember me. He might want to be with me and I can't let that happen."

"Kaage, I sense someone is coming, hide," Rhian ordered.

Kaage stepped away from the door and turned invisible right away. Who walked in?
