115121221122122121111121111222122.content:
Rhian smiled a little as Adam pushed open the door and closed it.

"Sir Adam, welcome," Rhian said, bowing slightly. Her brown curly hair bouncing as she did. Adam waved his hand.

"Please, I do not like being called Sir and you know it," Adam replied, "I use that title only when I need to." Rhian giggled slightly and lead Adam to a medium round table with the faces of the moon embroidered onto it. And one chair sitting at each phase. Above was a chandelier casting light down on the table.

"True. Now what may I help you with today? It's not near your wife's anniversary or birthday and you don't know what to get her?" Rhian said, sitting at a new moon seat. Adam took the customary full moon seat.

"No. I'm sure you noticed the number of people in rags yesterday and today," Adam said. She gave an affirming "Mmm" and nod. "Well I was wondering about the fate of one of them."

"What is the person's name?" Rhian asked, as she sensed Kaage drawing close to the table.

"Felix. Dracus asked me a personal favor to raise the boy personally," Adam replied.

"Well, you know I can't see on the unknown," Rhian said, picking up her cards and started shuffling them, "Have you even met the boy?" And this was true as well. Her visions of the future were clouded if the person didn't know much about what they were asking or looking for.

"Yes, not an hour ago. He was very close with Dracus' first daughter," Adam said, "She actually nuzzled him in a public street." Rhian's eyes widened with true shock. She had known many dragons in her ages and rarely had she heard of one who was openly affectionate with a human. Even considering Adam and Michael's close relationship, the most they ever got was a bow and lick when they were younger.

"And you wish to know if it is right to separate that friendship with the distance between their domain and this town?" Rhian asked. Adam gave a nod.

"It is conflicting. Not only because I do feel after living a slave for that greedy bastard Lord William, Felix needs some strong human figures in his life. But also, at his young age, trying to live alone with dragons can be very difficult. I doubt many of the other dragons, even Dracus or Shanaye would like their daughter becoming so open with a human. But in the same breath, I remember twelve years ago on a trip with my father, we stayed at Lord William's keep. Every servant had some bruise or injury. The atmosphere was dark. He also inquired greatly about the dragons up here and how my father 'tamed' them. He didn't believe my father when he said the dragons would die before being broken."

"So, what happened?" Rhian asked. It was not often Adam spoke of his past to her.

"For the next two years, Lord William's men ventured to the lower parts of these mountains, only to leave when faced with my father's guards. Father and I thought he had given up but . . ."

"Something about my last reading gave you cause to look at him as Rathnait's holder?" Rhian asked.

"'An old thorn of noble man from old woods has risen again to ensnare what was desired for many turns. Only by finding light in shadow, can fresh air be found,'" Adam recited, "The old thorn of noble man meant someone who had antagonized the dragons or my father. We have only few nobles who live by old woods. Lord William was the only one who fit both. I can only assume the second part was about Felix and Rathnait finding each other there." Rhian nodded, her eyes darting behind Adam for a second.

"That seems likely," she said, holding out her hand. Adam took her hand and waited for the other to start calling on her powers and show him his fortune.

************************

Kaage moved behind Adam, listening intently. With much focus and control, he made only his head visible.

"Make him believe Felix should go with him, regardless of what the cards tell you!" he pleaded silently. Rhian looked up at him and gave a cold glare informing him at once, not to insult her by asking her to give false predictions. Kaage flinched from the glare and hid himself once more.

1151212211221221211111211112221221.content:
Before Rhian started, she told Adam, "I will first start off with looking into the recent future if you should decide to take care of Felix and try and read your future even farther to gain more information about him through your relationship with Felix. This is because I have to look through your future since you are the one here."

"I understand, and I understand that the more you dwell into the future, the more cloudy it becomes," Adam replied still holding Rhian's hand.

"This is because the future is not truly set. Humans and other intelligent creatures have free will. They have choices. The more choices, the more the future can change," Rhian explained.

"That is why everything you say is a possible future and not a set one. However, you possible future is the most likely path that would be chosen," Adam said remembering what she told him every time he asked her to see the future.

Rhian nodded and began calling her powers and the help of the spirits. After a few minutes, Rhian's head tilted back and and shook before dropping her head and drooping it over the table. Adam waited anxiously as Rhian prepared herself for the sight. Suddenly, Rhian's head raised and her eyes opened, revealing pure white eyes. "Dracus has given you one day to decide, and you shall not obtain Felix until that time. I can see your second meeting with Felix, now," Rhian said in her predicting voice that sounded like many people speaking at once, female and male.

Rhian drew a card. It many needles covering his a human brain as well as a heart. "There will be some emotional pain for Felix being separated from Rathnait," Rhian explained the card. She picked up a knew card showing a man on top of a mountain with his arms stretched out to his sides at shoulder height. "Yet, Felix will overcome this pain," Rhian said before drawing a new card and saying, "Because he will accepted easily as a family member." The third card she drew was of a family embracing each other. A fourth card was drawn showing a woman on a balcony with a man climbing to her. "And Rathnait will visit Felix and he will visit Rathnait frequently."

"However, there seems to be things that will inevitably happen to him," Rhian continued. Rhian drew a card that showed a man kneeling on the ground with his hands reaching out to a women being pulled away from his by skeleton hands. "He shall suffer great losses and many he loves dearly. No matter which path he follows loved ones would inevitably die before him." Rhian drew another card. This card pictured a man with a dark cloud over his head and following him. "He has a dark past he will eventually figure out and he will proceed to try and find the truth of his existence."

Rhian drew card number eight which featured three heads. "He will meet three men that will become important. All will be men he had met before. Two from his distant past, he can't remember, and one from his recent past." Rhian drew another card with a man comforting a troubled soul. "One is a friend and only wants to keep Felix safe from harm. A man who also wants Felix to forget his past only to shield Felix from pain and a dark evil." Rhian draws a card with an executioner. "One from his distant past wishes to kill Felix. he is the man the first is protecting Felix from." Rhian revealed a torturer at the third man Felix would meet. "The third is some who wants to torture Felix and enslave him, because of a great power Felix has without Felix realizing it."

"Felix's future as a good possibility of being dark and full of loss no matter what, but there is still hope he will not succumb to the darkness," Rhian informed Adam. "This is because..." Rhian drew her final card which showed two dragons.

Rhian hesitated for the longest time, but Adam didn't interrupt Rhian, fearing she might lose her concentration. "His friendship will be strong and it will pull him out of many dark situations."

With that, Rhian reverted to her normal self with a bit of a headache. "Is it best I take in Felix?" Adam questioned.

"You might as well," Rhian replied, "The inevitable cards will happen to Felix no matter what. He needs a family right away. if he stays with the dragons, it would take him longer to be accepted as a family member, but with you, it would be sooner. I fear the inevitable is a recent future."

"And what's considered recent?" Adam questioned.

"No more than a few years," Rhian explained.

"Thank you for your time Rhian," Adam said before trying to hand her a bag of gold coins.

Rhian shook her hand and said, "This one if free, Adam. It is a very unusual fortune."

Adam just nodded and left. Kaage quickly appeared and asked, "I'm the one shielding Felix, right? Is it truly inevitable that he's going to learn who I am and about his past?"

"It is true. If he stayed with the dragon's it would have been sooner," Rhian explained.

"That last card is something I've never seen before. It means something more than what you said, doesn't it?" Adam said.

Rhian nodded, knowing Kaage should know since he was part of Felix's future. "It's the bond card. A magical bond that will occur between Rathnait and Felix. You know all too well what that means," Rhian said.

"I do. Rathnait is already showing the symptoms as well as Felix I'm sure," Kaage said.

"It's happening already. The only question is when will Felix and Rathnait realize it," Rhian stated.

"Thank you, Madame Ruth," Felix thanked as he looked in the polished stone mirror. He doubted he would have recognized himself. When he came in he was a scrawny boy in rags. But now he had a pair of leather pants and shirt, made apparently from hydra hide. He was told they would help him keep warm higher in the mountains but probably be bad in warmer temperatures, and that was why in a sack, compliments of Madame Ruth, he had some clothes made from wool. Felix looked down to his rags he called shoes.

"You're most welcome," Madame Ruth, the tailor, said smiling. She knew better than to cheat a friend of the dragons and also this boy had been very kind and patient while being measured. She noticed his glare. "There's a shop up the street with a cobbler in it. Warm clothes will do little for your feet," she said. Felix nodded.

"Thank you again," Felix said, walking to the door. He grabbed some gold from Rathnait's bag and returned. "Is this enough?" Felix asked. Madame Ruth had to hold her shock seeing the boy give her three times the gold his purchase cost. She shook her head with great effort.

"No, half will suffice," she replied. Felix nodded and gave Madame Ruth half of the gold in his hands.

"Okay, thank you once again," Felix said departing.

"Please make sure you tell any of your friends about me," Madame Ruth called as Felix and Rathnait continued up the street.

*********************************

It didn't take long for them to find the cobbler.

"Ah, good day sir," Mr. Pebbles said, welcoming Felix into his workshop. "Are you here to deliver some hide from the dragons young sir?" Felix was taken back by how the man addressed him, judging by his outfit to be something like a goods seller for the dragons. But given what he was wearing and Rathnait looking in the window again, Felix could understand the man's assumption

"Uh, no. I need some shoes sir," Felix said. Mr. Pebbles looked down at the rags.

"I see. And what type of shoes do you require?" Mr. Pebbles asked.

"Ones that would do well in mountains sir," Felix replied. Mr. Pebbles nodded.

"Well, let's get you measured," Mr. Pebbles said, picking up a two rulers. He moved Felix to sit in a chair and measured both feet.

"Interesting. I have something in stock now that might fit you," Mr. Pebbles said, "Otherwise, all I can do is give you much larger shoes until your pair is made."

"I'd like to try them," Felix said. Mr. Pebbles nodded and went behind a counter and pulled out a pair of basilisk skin boots.

"These were made for someone of your size but when it came to pay, they just tried running off with them," Mr. Pebbles said, kneeling before Felix to put a boot down, holding the other. Felix took the rag off to reveal a hard, tough skinned foot. He slipped his foot into the shoe and was amazed at how soft the inside felt. There was some soft material inside that cushioned the foot while the hard outside was tough and ready for rocky ground.

"It's great! My foot fits like a glove," Felix exclaimed,

"No room for much movement?" Mr. Pebbles asked, happy his work was appreciated.

"None at all," Felix said, smiling, but Mr. Pebbles coughed and was holding his hand out, glaring down at Felix.

"Then payment please," Mr. Pebbles said. Felix pulled out the other half of the gold he didn't give to Madame Ruth and looked at Mr. Pebbles. "Is this enough?" he asked.

"I'll take this much," Mr. Pebbles said, pulling only a few gold coins, leaving a good many left. "This will cover this pair and the ones I will make for you." He placed the second boot down and went to his money box.

"Why do I need more than one pair?" Felix asked. Mr. Pebbles heard a growl from outside as Rathnait was listening in.

"Because young sir, you are still growing," Mr. Pebbles said, ignoring Rathnait's growl, "After a short time, those shoes will be too tight on your feet. The ones I make will be big enough so you only need to come every few months for new boots." Felix nodded.

"That makes sense," Felix said, "When will my other pair be ready?"

"Oh a week, depending on other orders," Mr. Pebbles said.

"The I'll see you then," Felix said, walking in his new boots, leaving the cobbler.

Rathnait looked down at Felix and could hardly believe he was the same scared little kid in rags she snapped at almost two months ago.

"Shall we go head off to my mother?" Rathnait asked. Felix nodded and they started back the way they came.

*************************

The walk back was peaceful until they heard a scream.

"Dr-Dragon!" cried a man in rich looking clothes. A man in mercenary gear moved forward and saw Rathnait and attacked her without thinking.

"Wait!" Felix cried out, moving in the man's way. But it was a small ten year old boy against a fully grown adult, the result was instantly clear.

With a quick shove, the mercenary moved Felix to the side, sending him to the ground where he felt a snap in his left arm as he gasped in pain from the break. Rathnait surged with anger and quickly smacked the agressor and shoved him to the ground, ready to kill him.

115121221122122121111121111222122121.content:
Rathnait pinned the mercenary down with her right front paw while lifting her left paw for the kill. Though she was an infant dragon, all dragons had little troubles killing. They had the logic and reason of humans, but they also still had animal instincts. Those instincts knew killing was a part of life and animals had to fight and kill to survive. Plus, when someone harmed a friend of a dragon, the dragon would do anything in its power to protect and save their friend, no matter the cost or cause. Rathnait's animal instincts, the same animal instincts that helped her kill the guards and snapped at Felix when she first met him months ago, was now taking over Rathnait as she lifted her left claws to slice the mercenary.

However, something Rathnait could not explain and she didn't understand happened at that moment. When she lifted her paw high, she felt an intense pain between her elbow and paw. Rathnait backed up while favoring her left front leg and roared as the pain as her pain worsened. The pain was too great to ignore and she had to turn her attention to her front leg, but when she looked down, there were no bruises or cuts. There seemed to be nothing wrong except that her bone was in unbearable pain.

Felix painfully rolled on his back to see what was going on. he didn't bother looking at his wound, because he knew his bone was broke. In fact, his bone was actually protruding out of his skin. Yet, Felix didn't care about his broken bone. he cared about Rathnait, and he became worried that the mercenary would kill Rathnait.

Felix saw Rathnait looking at her leg while the mercenary approached her neck with his sword. A crowd was all around them and Adam was trying to push his way through to save Rathnait, but he wasn't going to get there in time. "Rathnait, look out!" Felix hollered.

Rathnait looked up right away, which suddenly ceased, once Felix yelled to her. She saw a sword swinging towards her neck, but there was nothing she could do to stop it. It was way too late. Rathnait shut her eyes tightly and waited for the blade to kill her. Instead of feeling a blade, she heard two blade clang against each other. Rathnait opened her eyes and saw the mercenary's sword had been blocked by another blade. The other blade was being held by a man in a black cloak with his hood up.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- -------------------

Kaage had gone to the marketplace, despite Felix being in the village. Kaage went, because Kaage felt that Felix still probably wouldn't recognize him with his hood on. "Then again, Rhian said our meeting would be inevitable and he will eventually know the truth about me and his parents."

Kaage soon thought about the last card that was drawn. He looked around and saw Rathnait and Felix heading for the marketplace to leave through the front gate. "The magical bond between them will inevitable happen. of all the dragon species, he bonds with a cloud dragon. I never thought it was possible for a cloud dragon to bond with a human. Because like fire, gold, and frost dragons, cloud dragons are very proud creatures and they only tend to bond with other dragons of their species. Yet, Rathnait is bonding with Felix and even nuzzling him in public despite being a proud creature. She and Felix must have been through very dark times in their imprisonment and Felix and Rathnait must of been each other's only friend in that place for the bond to start so quickly. Then again, Felix isn't a normal human. His father..."

Kaage's thoughts were interrupted when he heard a trader scream. Kaage noticed one of the trader's guards, a mercenary, begin attacking Rathnait without thinking. Kaage hated such people who blindly followed orders without thinking. However, he hated dragon slayers worse. Dragon slayers killed dragons because they thought they were monsters. However, all dragons had intelligence, it just that some didn't speak like humans making them seem like blood-thirsty and mindless monsters.

Kaage watched as Felix was pushed to the ground and his frail arm snapped with the bond protruding the skin. Kaage clutched his fist upon seeing Felix in such pain. He wanted to kill the mercenary right then and there. However, it looked like Rathnait had it under control and it was best not to show himself to Felix unless there was no other choice.

Suddenly, Rathnait's left front leg hurt her and she backed off before she could deliver the final blow. "They can already feel each other's pain. Their bond is developing quicker than I've ever seen before!" Kaage realized. He also noticed the mercenary ready to kill Rathnait. "If they can already feel pain, what will happen if Rathnait dies?" Kaage wondered, "I can't risk it. I can't let it happen.

Kaage quickly teleported to where the mercenary was and blocked the mercenary's sword with his own sword. The mercenary was shocked by the sudden appearance and Kaage could easily kick the mercenary to the ground. Kaage placed the tip of his sword on the mercenary's neck and glared at him. While Kaage was doing this, Rathnait walked to Felix and formed a circle around him to protect him.

"Why are you protecting that beast? It's going to kill us all!" the mercenary screamed.

"Most dragons don't attack humans unless their provoked," Kaage explained, "You probably think dragons are mindless beasts right? You thought this dragon was attacking the village?"

"Why else would a dragon be here?" the mercenary questioned.

"She had business here," Adam interrupted when he finally got past the crowd, "She was here to buy cloth for her friend. The same human you pushed down."

"You see dragons are intelligent like you and me," Kaage added, "Their not just some blood-thirsty monster. And don't tell me you were just following orders from that pathetic trader. You could have at least waited your blade. If you would have done that, maybe you'd figure out she didn't mean your paranoid friend any harm."

"Kaage, I believe I can handle this," Adam stated, "You can use magic. I know this since you live with the only other magical being in this village, Rhian. Can any of your magic be used for healing."

"Yes," Kaage answered.

"Then help Felix and Rathnait," Adam ordered.

Kaage nodded and walked to the protective dragon. Rathnait growled as Kaage approached. "Easy Rathnait, I mean you and Felix no harm," Kaage explained as he held his hands up and kept his hood up as well.

"How do you know are names then?" Rathnait questioned. The traders that never seen a dragon before, especially the trader and mercenary making the trouble, were shocked upon hearing Rathnait speak.

"Adam told me your name," Kaage explained, "Please, let me help."

Rathnait opened up her circle and only let Kaage through before closing it again. Kaage approached Felix who had brought his left arm close to his chest. "Felix," Kaage said, "I'm hear to help you. I can heal your arm, but you mustn't be afraid. My magical powers look like dark magic, but it isn't dark magic. This will still cause more pain on your arm, but it is to heal you. You both understand this, right?" Kaage had included Rathnait, because he knew she would become very protective if he were to hurt Felix.

Rathnait and Felix nodded and Kaage started. "I'm going to have to put the bone back in and it will hurt. However, if I don't, it will never heal," Kaage explained. Felix understood and Kaage's hands turned back like a shadow. Felix and Rathnait were a little frightened by the shadow hands. They were able to pass through Felix's skin without pain, but they grabbed around the bone and moved it in place. Felix had to fight back his screams and tears poured down his face. Kaage noticed Rathnait feeling the same pain and saw her place her head next to Felix.

Once the bone was in place, Kaage used a spell to keep it in place and heal the wound. "Your arm can be used now, and it will only hurt if you use it too much. You have to be careful and not over work it. It might break again," Kaage informed Felix.

"For how long?" Felix asked.

"For at least two or three weeks," Kaage explained, "You can still use it, just be careful not to strain it."

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- --------------------------------------

"How can you accept a beast like that in your village?" the trader asked with his mercenary on his feet now by his side.

"You haven't traded her before have you? We have a truce with the cloud dragons. We're neighbors and help each other out when in trouble. We accept each other and cooperate," Adam informed the trader, "The guards should have told you."

"But that monster is..." The mercenary explained.

"Rathnait is not a monster. She is the daughter of a good friend of mine and I will not have you insult her. Her mother wouldn't like it either. I assume she can hear our words," Adam said.

Before the trader and mercenary could ask, Adam pointed to a mountain top near the village. They saw an enormous dragon perched at the top growling menacingly at the two men. "You see," Adam explained, "The dragon you attacked is just an infant dragon. They're the only ones that can fit on our streets. Dragons are very protective of their friends and family. Of all the crimes you can commit against a dragon, harming one of its friends or family is the worst. That is why it is against our law to harm a dragon or a friend of a dragon. Since this crime happened in this village, the dragons will accept whatever punishment my father agrees upon. However, if you leave the village, the dragons can do what they want with you. You don't want to the dragon's punishment for such a crime. Like I said, you have committed the worst crime to a dragon."

The mercenary looked fearfully up at the mother dragon before he drew two knives. He used one to kill the trader before anyone noticed what was happening. With the speed of an highly trained assassin, the mercenary threw his knife at Adam's throat. However, Kaage had already left Rathnait's circle and caught the knife with telepathy. He then twirled the knife and threw it back at the mercenary with the flick of his hand. Adam turned to Kaage in a little bit of shock and Kaage bowed his head before saying, "Glad to be of service to you, future lord." Kaage then walked off to look at what else he could buy from the marketplace.

"I think it's best I walk with the two of you to the landing zone," Adam suggested. Felix and Rathnait agreed and They all walked to the landing zone.

Adam walked on Felix's left side as Rathnait was on his right. He looked down at the young man, impressed by how different he looked dressed like he did.

"So, besides those men, did you have an easy time with your shopping?" Adam asked. Felix nodded.

"It was nice to not be the one waiting on others. These clothes are warm and my boots, well, I really like them," Felix said. Adam noticed a mark left in Felix's imprint.

"So you went to Mr. Pebble's," Adam said, recognizing the man's craft mark, "He's one of the best and cheapest in town."

"Good. I was worried Felix might have been cheated," Rathnait said. Adam looked up at Rathnait as they approached the landing zone.

"Rathnait, if you don't mind me asking, what happened back when you had that man down?" Adam asked.

"I don't know. I just felt a pain in my front leg between my elbow and paw," Rathnait said as a loud thud came before them as Shanaye landed. Adam saw a look of shock on her face.

"You were hurt by that man Rathnait. What happened?" Shanaye growled.

"No, he didn't even touch me long enough to harm me. I just felt pain," Rathnait said, looking away, confused by what had happened. But Adam continued looking at Shanaye and after knowing her and Dracus for so long, he knew from her expression something big happened.

"Shanaye, will you be going after the others in the caravan or if they leave with a small punishment, as it wasn't them who attacked Felix or ordered the attack, will that satisfy you?" Adam called. Shanaye shook her head.

"Given that they didn't harm my baby, I'll leave it for you to punish," Shanaye said, before noticing Felix wasn't clutching his arm.

"Rathnait, I'm impressed your healing skills could heal a broken arm," Shanye said approvingly.

"But I didn't do it. A human mage did it. His hands turned into shadows and pushed the bone back in and healed Felix," Rathnait said, "My leg also felt better." Shanaye nodded.

"Well, why don't you take Felix home. I want to say a few things to Sir Adam about some business dealings," Shanaye said. Rathnait nodded and gently picked Felix up in her right paw and took off. Once gone, Adam looked at Shanaye with a serious face.

"Would you mind telling me what's happening between them?" Adam asked. Shanaye glanced at Adam.

"It's a dragon issue," she replied curtly. Adam was used to the tone. Whenever he broached a subject the dragons felt was too personal, the dragon would answer the same way Shanaye had just answered to him.

"Well, unless you're rescinding the offer for Felix to live with me, I feel I have the right," Adam replied. "And add in that I feel I will take him in, it seems I should get some explanation." Shanaye sighed, realizing Adam had a point.

"It seems Rathnait is bonding with Felix. This means they will grow closer and closer to the other," Shanaye said, "Shared pain is a symptom of it."

"I see. Will Felix being far away hurt them?" Adam asked.

"No, it will be inconvenient and they will long to see each other but nothing serious should occur," Shanaye replied, "So, why did you choose to let Felix in so quickly?"

"He's a smart, brave young boy," Adam said, "Not many would stand up to a mercenary like he did."

"I see. Well, Dracus and I will talk to Felix this evening and tomorrow, we will let you know if he is coming to live with you," Shanaye replied before taking off as well. Adam turned and walked back to town scowling.

"Rhain, did you not tell me everything?" Adam murmured.

11512122112212212111112111122212212111.content:
"Felix, what do you think happened to me?" Rathnait asked Felix while holding him firmly to her chest as she flew high in the mountains, "Did you see what might have caused the pain in my leg?"

"I don't know what happened," Felix answered, "I didn't look up until after the pain and when the mercenary was coming after you. I thought he had injured you and then was going for the kill."

"But he didn't even touch me," Rathnait told Felix, "The pain just happened."

"Where did you say you felt the pain?" Felix questioned.

"My front left leg between my elbow and paw. Just the bone hurt," Rathnait answered.

Felix was silent for a while as he thought about what had happened. "My left arm had been broken by the mercenary and it was at the same spot Rathnait described her left leg hurt," Felix thought, "Did she feel my pain? But how is that possible?" Felix had no idea what magical bonds were. So, he couldn't come to that conclusion. Instead, Felix thought, "She mustn't have felt my pain. There has to be some other explanation for it. But, should I tell Rathnait about the theory? Could she know what could cause someone to feel another's pain?"

Before Felix could ask Rathnait anything, Shanaye caught up with her daughter easily. "You sure both of you are alright?" Shanaye asked both Felix and Rathnait with almost equal concern.

"We're both fine, thanks to that man in the black hood," Rathnait told her mother.

"Man in the black hood? You mean the one that blocked the sword that was coming at you?" Shanaye questioned.

"Yes, he healed Felix," Rathnait said.

Shanaye soon remembered Dracus saying he had encountered a strange human-like creature that morning. The creature had smelled human and looked human, but Dracus knew the creature wasn't human. The cloaked person who saved Rathnait from the mercenary was exactly like the creature Dracus had described. Shanaye hadn't been concerned at the time and didn't realize it looked like the creature Dracus described, because she was too concerned with the safety of Rathnait and Felix.

"How did the man heal Felix?" Shanaye questioned. She had no idea what the cloaked creature did, because her anger had been focused on the mercenary and the trader. All she knew was that Rathnait had curled around Felix protectively as she looked upon the trader and the mercenary with furious anger.

"His hands turned to shadow," Rathnait explained, "His hands then went through Felix's arm."

"His hands went everything except the bone," Felix interrupted, "His hands wrapped around the bone and then pushed it in place. Even my bone seemed to go through my skin once he touched it. My bone didn't become physical again till it was in place."

"He could pass through whatever objects he wants and also turn other thins he touches into that shadow-like substance as well?" Shanaye questioned.

"Yes, that sounds about right," Felix replied.

Shanaye looked away and thought to herself, "The man sounds like he's a shadow dragon! He might be a shadow dragon in disguise as a human, but why would a shadow dragon live in a human village. They're usually very reclusive. Also, Shadow dragons don't live in this parts. They're from a distant country."

"Is something wrong?" Rathnait asked her mother.

"Nothing," Shanaye replied as she shook her head, "Let's just get home."

It was silence the rest of the way to the cave in the mountains, and Rathnait and Shanaye decided to fly faster. Felix was just glad Rathnait held him, because he feared he would be able to hold on if he were to be on her back. Shanaye and Rathnait arrived at the cave and once Rathnait landed, she carefully placed Felix on his feet. Felix looked around the cave and the dragon siblings were in there usual groups. Alaster, Allehe, and Sorcha were together, Brodee was alone as usual, and Joscelyne, Egan, and Eshne were together. Joscelyne, Egan, and Eshne were playing with there father and climbing on there father.

Once they noticed Shanaye, Rathnait, and Felix arrive, all the dragon siblings approached Felix to see his new clothes. As usual, Joscelyne, Egan, and Eshne were the most curious and they were down low sniffing Felix and studying him closely. "He smells like Felix," Egan stated in dragon, "but he doesn't look like Felix."

"I have to admit, Felix looks very different in his new clothes. Are they hydra skins?" Sorcha questioned.

"They are," Rathnait told her sister, the grouped was still talking in dragon since Rathnait was the only sibling who could speak human well enough. Rathnait looked down at Felix between her front legs and said, "They say you look like a different human with those clothes," Rathnait told Felix.

"Well, I feel like a new person myself," Felix admitted.

"Do you think Felix would wish to play a game with us?" Eshne asked Rathnait.

"Well, it would have to be a game that a human could play," Rathnait informed her sister, "Humans are much smaller than us and we wouldn't want to harm Felix, would we?"

"Of course not," Egan and Eshne said together.

"Also, he mustn't strain his left arm too much," Rathnait told them, "He was injured in the village and..."

"What happened? Is he alright?" Were some of the concerned and worried questions the seven other siblings asked.

"A man tried to attack me and Felix tried to stop him. That terrible man broke Felix's arm. Luckily a mage healed Felix, but he can't strain his arm too much or it might break again," Rathnait warned.

"I'm sure we can think of some kind of game," Joscelyne said, "Where's mother and father?"

"They went to the back of the cave," Alaster informed the group, "They must have something important to talk about again."

"Most likely about what happened today at the village," Rathnait said.

Choice 1: While the dragons and Felix play a game, something else happens that is proof of the magical bond between Felix and Rathnait.

Choice 2: While the dragon's play with Felix, Dracus and Shanaye have many serious things to talk about...

Shanaye knew Dracus would be disturbed by the day's revelations and she was affirmed by his rigid form right now. She saw he was pushing hard into their stone floor as she finished telling him everything.

Dracus was taking a few breaths, organizing what he knew into the proper priority.

"So, first off I was right about this mysterious man," Dracus said, "He wasn't human, but do you really believe he is a shadow dragon in human guise?" Shanaye nodded.

"He would have to be. It is the only thing that fits. The next closest is he's actually human who knows shadow healing magic, but you discounted that because he didn't smell human," Shanaye replied.

"True. Did you tell Adam about this?" Dracus asked.

"No, it wasn't brought up in our brief talk," Shanaye said.

"But this man was known by Adam and others it seems. Otherwise Adam would have brought it up and asked if we knew this man," Dracus replied.

"True. Adam is very observant about things around him. Do you believe Felix would be safe if he lived in the town?" Shanaye replied.

"I believe so. Shadow dragons were never ones to pick fights and if he has made his home there, like he proclaimed, then I doubt he would attack from within," Dracus replied.

"Are you sure?" Shanaye asked. Dracus nodded.

"Yes. My grandfather was a shadow dragon and the only person he opened up to outside of his blood was my grandmother," Dracus replied. "He didn't open much to his own grandchildren. That's why Brodee likes to be alone. He's his great-grandfather reborn."

"All right but what about what's happening at this moment to our first daughter?" Shanaye asked.

"You mean bonding with Felix?" Dracus asked, looking at his wife.

"Yes. Do you think we should stop it so she doesn't . . . ." Shanaye replied before Dracus shook his head.

"I understand you wish it wasn't a human she was bonding with. But you must remember this means that even if Rathnait hasn't said it, she is gaining absolute trust in Felix and Felix, likewise, is gaining a similar trust in her. And if it wasn't for that trust, our daughter could have been broken by that human lord," Dracus replied.

"Yes. . .yes, you are right. I guess part of me is also worried because once she bonds, she may never find a dragon to mate with," Shanaye replied. Dracus nodded.

"Not if they keep together like they are now. But maybe if we let them grow up without each other, the bond won't become so great and they can each find someone they care about," Dracus said.

"Wise as always my love," Shanaye said, nuzzling Dracus, "So, do you want to talk to Felix alone or with Rathnait near by?"

Dracus thought carefully about the two options. He could either just talk to Felix alone, but he knew that he shouldn't leave Rathnait out of the conversation. "We might as well tell both of them. This news concerns Rathnait just as much as it concerns Felix," Dracus answered.

"Agreed," Shanaye conceded, "If we were just to tell Felix and bring him to Adam's tomorrow without telling Rathnait previously, she might do something rash again."

"Besides, if we were to talk to Felix alone, Rathnait would most likely listen in," Dracus concluded, "We need to figure out what we will tell them and how we'll go about it."

"What do you mean?" Shanaye questioned.

"Well, we obviously have to tell them about Adam and what we were planning to do. Rathnait might not like what we were doing behind her back, but we'll have to explain why Felix needs to live with humans," Dracus said.

"Surely, Rathnait and Felix will understand our reasons," Shanaye replied.

"Yes, but this bond changes things," Dracus informed his mate.

"Are you getting second thoughts?" Shanaye questioned.

"Maybe," Dracus said, "Who are we to separate those with a magical bond? Even if it is a bond with a dragon and a human, should we be the ones to stop it?"

"Well, it will never stop. Once it starts up, there's no way to reverse it," Shanaye informed Dracus.

"Yes, but separating them from each other at a critical moment..." Dracus replied, "It could deeply affect them if separated, especially during the starting stages of the bond. Maybe we should tell them about the bond and let them decided what do do."

"Really?" Shanaye gasped.

"It would be better for them if they willing choose to separate. If they were forced away, it could cause pain to their psyche," Dracus explained, "They could then successfully live separate lives even with the strong bond."

"What if they choose to stay with each other?" Shanaye questioned, "They couldn't live normal lives then, could they?"

"Just because a magical bond happens, it doesn't mean love. Use cloud dragons usually are too proud to bond with other species and we bond with our mates. But, magical bonds between different species has occurred before, and it doesn't normally cause those bonded to fall in love. it is possible that Rathnait and Felix could only stay very good friends with the bond, even when they live together. However, that usually results in trying to find another pair that is bonded and..." Dracus trailed off.

"You're saying that if Felix and Rathnait decide to have Felix live with us and that Felix and Rathnait stay good friends, they can still have a normal life?" Shanaye asked.

"Felix wouldn't have a normal life if we raise him, and he won't find a human mate up here. he'd have to find one that accepts him and Rathnait and Rathnait's mate would have to accept Felix, even if Felix should choose to live in the village, because the bond would still be strong and noticeable," Dracus stated, "Also, Felix would gain some of Rathnait's abilities with the bond like magic, tough skin but still human skin, and dragon aging. He will live as long as a dragon and if he was to choose a human mate, she'd die much sooner than him."

"This bond makes everything more complicated," Shanaye agreed.

Eventually, Shanaye and Dracus decided on what to tell Rathnait and Felix and they walked back into the main chamber. Rathnait, Felix, Sorcha, Egan, and Eshne were all playing a game together. They were having fun and it seemed a safe enough game.

Choice 1: Shanaye and Dracus decided to let the human and dragons play the game. They would talk to Rathnait and Felix alone after lunch.

Choice 2: Shanaye and Dracus interrupted the game to talk with Felix and Rathnait alone

1151212211221221211111211112221221211122.content:
"Excuse me children," Dracus called. Felix heard Dracus's voice but didn't understand his words. His children quickly stopped and looked towards their parents. "Rathnait, would you bring Felix over here, we need to talk about some things."

"Does this involve our trip to the market earlier?" Rathnait asked.

"In a way, it does," Shanaye replied. Rathnait nodded and walked away from her siblings, answering Felix's inquiry as to where she was going. Felix climbed onto Rathnait's back so her parents wouldn't be made to wait.

Rathnait followed her parents to a back part of the den, where they could talk privately.

"So, do you wish to hear more about what happened with that fight?" Rathnait asked, still in dragon tongue.

"Yes," Dracus replied in human, "But we have something else to talk about as well."

"What is it?" Rathnait asked.

"Rathnait, I know you're young but remember what your mother and I told you. Felix broke his arm . . . and you felt his pain," Dracus said, "What does this mean?" Felix slid off Rathnait's back and watched her face go from thinking to surprise and then she looked upon Felix with realization.

"What is it?" Felix asked, "Is something wrong?" Rathnait shook her head.

"No," she said quietly, "It's just that we're becoming bonded."

"Bonded?" Felix replied.

"It's a magical process dragons go through when we find absolute trust in another. But those feelings must be reciprocated," Shanaye answered, "It's rare for a human and cloud dragon to become bonded."

"Does this mean Rathnait and I are going to be in love and have kids?" Felix asked. Rathnait looked away, embarrassed by Felix's realizations.

"No. Being bonded doesn't mean being in love," Dracus said, "But you will gain some traits of ours."

"Like what?" Felix asked.

"You will be able to do the same magic Rathnait can, as well as have tougher skin and live for a long time," Shanaye replied, "And that last one is troublesome."

"What do you mean?" Rathnait replied, feeling hurt. It sounded like her mother disapproved of what was happening.

"This is the other thing we wished to talk with you about. It involves Adam," Dracus said.

"What about him?" Felix asked.

"Felix, do you think it will be easy for you to live here with us?" Shanaye asked in a polite tone.

"Well, it may be troublesome, especially with meal times. I mean, I won't be able to eat raw meat, will I?" Felix asked.

"In cases I've heard about a human bonding with a dragon, no, they didn't acquire a taste for uncooked food," Dracus replied.

"Meaning you would need to make a fire or have one of us cook it for you," Shanaye said.

"I wouldn't mind doing that," Rathnait said.

"You also couldn't travel anywhere outside the cave without one of us," Dracus replied.

"I could carry him," Rathnait replied.

"I think that's their point," Felix said, "I'd be dependent on you for a lot of things." Rathnait looked at Felix.

"Are you saying that's bad?" Rathnait asked.

"I don't know if it's bad, but it doesn't feel right to me," Felix said.

"You want to be self sufficient for the most part, correct?" Dracus asked. Felix nodded.

"Yeah, I do," Felix said. Dracus smiled a little.

"That is why we asked Adam if he would take you in personally and raise you," Dracus said.

"But what about this bond?" Felix asked.

"That will still be formed, regardless of how far you are away from each other," Shanaye replied, "But you've had so many hardships because of so many evil humans. Dracus and I felt you should live with some good ones. And possibly, when your older, you can choose where you want to live." Felix looked down.

"Felix, we don't have to do as they are asking. It's just some suggestions, that's all," Rathnait said quietly.

"But Rathnait, I don't . . . I don't want to be a burden," Felix replied.

"I wouldn't see you as a burden Felix," Rathnait said.

"That doesn't mean I wouldn't be one though," Felix said.

"But Felix, after what we've been through, I need to know you'd be safe . . ." Rathnait replied.

"You don't trust Adam?" Dracus asked his daughter.

"No, it's not that. It's . . . well I want to make sure he's safe myself," Rathnait replied, "I don't want help keeping my friend safe."

"Rathnait, I think your parents make a good argument. I think it might be best that go live with Adam, at least till I'm old enough to take care of myself," Felix told Rathnait.

"But... Felix..." Rathnait began as she looked down at Felix. Rathnait lowered her head right in front of Felix and stared at him with tear filled eyes. "Are you really going to live with Adam?"

"Well, it will be harder for me to live with dragons. I know you mind taking care of me, but I don't want to be dependent on someone for so many things. It makes me feel like a burden to you and I don't want to be a burden if I can help it," Felix explained.

"But... I... I wouldn't think of you as a burden. I want you to stay with me, please," Rathnait cried as she nudged him with her muzzle, "You're my truest friend. I don't want to lose you."

Rathnait began to cry and she laid herself down on her stomach and set her head next to Felix. Shanaye reacted quickly and she laid down beside her daughter. She positioned herself so that her left front leg was draped around her daughter. Shanaye pulled Rathnait closer, but Rathnait kept her head close to Felix and Felix tried to comfort Rathnait as best as he could as well.

"The bond seems stronger for Rathnait. It must be because she is younger in relative age. Maybe her torture from the evil lord and the fact Felix was the only one that helped her, enhanced that bond greater than Felix." Dracus realized. Dracus stayed where he was as Rathnait cried. He felt that Shanaye and Felix could calm Rathnait down better than him.

"Please, clam down, Rathnait," Shanaye told her daughter in a calm and assuring voice, "Things will be alright."

"But I want Felix to stay with us," Rathnait continued to cry.

"But you'll be far away in the village," Raithnait argued, "And I just... I can't..."

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- ---------------------------------------

Felix had been having a dreamless sleep until he found himself lying against a stone wall instead of Dracus's side. Felix moved his head around, because it almost seemed as though he had been teleported somewhere and was actually awake. He was able to move his body around and everything. (What had happened was that his conscious was teleported out of his mind and into another, but his conscious made it almost like a virtual reality for him.)

Felix found himself in a familiar place, the dungeon hallways of Lord William's castle. Felix still didn't know what was going on and he very confused and frightened. "Did I somehow get back here? What happened? How'd I get back here?" Felix questioned.

Felix heard a roar, followed by deep sobs. Felix knew that roar and the sobs. He knew whose they were and quickly ran down the hallway to the cell that Rathnait used to be in. Felix forced the door open to find Rathnait in the center of the dark and dank cell with chains around her once more. Rathnait was lying on her stomach and her head was lying against the ground with her eyes closed and swollen from all the tears that had fallen from them.

Felix had never seen the dragon like this before and he was in shock and awe and just stood at the open doorway without her noticing him at all. Felix remember when he had first met Rathnait, she was a proud dragon whose spirit seemed like it could never break. Now she seemed to be in a terribly broken state. Felix couldn't just stand and watch her cry like she was. Felix ran to her head, knelt beside her muzzle, and quickly leaned against it and hugged it will petting.

Rathnait opened her eyes to see Felix was with her again. "Felix," Rathnait said still crying, but her voice was filled with joy and relief. Rathnait though Felix was part of her dream and not the real Felix, but it didn't matter to her. To have Felix, dream or not, with her in her time of need was a great relief to her.

"Please, tell me what's wrong," Felix replied. He wanted so much to help her and comfort her, but he didn't know what was wrong. he still didn't even know if this was a dream or if it was real.

"You're leaving me," Rathnait sobbed, "You leaving me to live in the human village. You'll be so far away."

"I wouldn't be that far away," Felix tried to assure Rathnait, "You and I could visit each other at least one or two days a week and..."

"But that doesn't seem enough," Rathnait sobbed, "You've been alway there for me once I met you, once we developed a way to communicate with each other. You were the one that helped me keep my sanity in this place. Without you, I feel like I'm back in this prison cell."

"Rathnait," Felix said as he laid against her muzzle closer, "I will always be there for you, even in I'm a thousand miles away. I'd always be your friend, you'd always be my truest friend and nothing could change that. You helped me just as much and me."

"Then why is it easier for you that we part? Why are you as sad as me?" Rathnait questioned.

"I am sad and I don't wish to leave," Felix stated.

"Then why are you? Why can't you stay here with me. I could take care of you and..." Rathnait started to argue.

But Felix interrupted, "Because, I know that it would be best for me to live with humans, because I am human. And you need to live with dragons until you're old enough. I understand that sacrifices are a part of life. Sometimes we have to do things we don't want, because it would be better for us."

"I'm going to miss you very much," Rathnait replied while nuzzling Felix affectionately.

"I'll miss you too, but we'll still see each other regularly, just not every day," Felix replied.

Did Rathnait and Felix begin to realize they were actually sharing a dream, or did they continue to think the other were just a part of their own dreams?

"Thank you Felix for coming here," Rathnait whispered as the walls around them seemed to vanish, "If you hadn't come, this would have been my worst nightmare ever." Felix didn't notice the disappearing walls but did hear Rathnait's comment. He paused his stroking.

"But this is my dream, isn't it?" Felix asked, pulling away from Rathnait.

"I thought it was my dream. What's the last thing you remember?" Rathnait asked.

"I was lying against your father's tail and then nothing. And suddenly I was in this castle and I heard you crying," Felix explained, "You?"

"Well, I was crying for a long time before I fell asleep and woke here, crying because you were leaving," Rathnait replied.

"Could this be that telepathic bond your father spoke of?" Felix asked.

"It's possible," Rathnait said, "Then what is this place?" She looked around. The walls and castle were gone. Only the stone beneath them remained of the castle and it stretched only until where the walls once were.

"Maybe it's created by both of our dreams and thoughts?" Felix said, "Why don't we look around?" Rathnait nodded.

"I wonder what we'll find," Rathnait replied, rising to her full height. Felix started off, with Rathnait close behind him. "It's really beautiful," Rathnait said, looking out into the green field. Her gaze turned to Felix. She so wished Felix was an adult and she was too so they could be together. She closed her eyes, wanting that to be so real.

"Yeah, it is," Felix said, feeling off. He stopped walking and saw his hands looked larger. He looked down and saw he wasn't wearing what he had before, but something close to what Adam wore in town. "What the?" he said, "Rathnait, is something wrong with . . .WOW!" Felix jumped out of the way as a huge foot came down. Felix looked up and saw it was Rathnait who had nearly stepped on him, but she was closer to her mother in size now.

"Felix?" Rathnait said, hearing his yell but didn't see him before her. She looked to the side and saw a very tiny human below her. She heard it calling her name. "Felix!" she replied. The figure nodded. She lowered her large head and looked at Felix. "How did you shrink?" she asked.

"I didn't shrink. It looks like we both grew up," Felix said, though his body was older, his voice was the same, "Did you know what might have caused it?"

"Well, I was just thinking what it'd be like for us to be adults," Rathnait replied, realizing she might have changed their forms. She smiled a huge smile. "This is amazing." she said.

"This means we can probably use this to see each other everyday when we're gone," Felix replied.

"Felix, do you want to use this to look into your past to try and remember your parents?" Rathnait asked.

"I don't know," Felix said while looking up at the enormous adult-sized Rathnait head as it laid on the ground, "I don't even know if it would work."

"Don't you want to as least try?" Rathnait asked.

"But, what if we can't look into the past," Felix replied.

"We can look into the future," Rathnait informed him.

"But this might not be the future," Felix explained, "This is just a dreamworld. Us as adult is just a dream mine and your prediction of what we might look like. It doesn't mean we'll look exactly like this."

"What does that have to do with it?" Rathnait questioned.

"I fear that if we try to look in the past, it might just be a dream like this whole world is right now," Felix explained, "What if what I see isn't true and just what I want to believe?"

"I understand, now," Rathnait said, "So, if this is a dreamworld, we have to go somewhere else."

"What are you planning?" Felix questioned.

"This is a dreamworld. A place that's in neither of our minds but in between. We have telepathy, right? What if we can enter each other's minds?" Rathnait wondered.

"You think the two of us can go in one of our minds?" Felix questioned. he was nervous about this. He had never had someone enter his mind before. It was the only thing he had to himself. Having another enter his mind seemed like violation.

Rathnait sensed Felix's nervousness and could see it in his eyes, despite how large she was too him. "Felix, you're worried about me going in your mind. You don't want me there, do you?" Rathnait asked.

"It's not because it's you," Felix tried to assure her, "It's just that my mind has always been my own and having another person in it... well it's..."

"I understand," Rathnait replied, "But you can trust me. I wouldn't do anything to harm your brain. You trust me, right?" Rathnait slightly nudged him with her huge snout. Despite the massive jaw she had now, she was still gentle.

"I do, but there is another reason," Felix told her, "I... I don't know if I want to know what happened. I don't know if I want to know why my parents weren't there for me when I became a slave. Lord William always told me my parents sold me for money and that they didn't love me at all. What if he's right?"

Rathnait could see Felix's tears and she moved her massive head behind him and rubbed her muzzle against his back. "It will be alright," Rathnait tried to assure Felix, "It doesn't matter what happens in the memory. Even if your parents did sell you, you would have never found me if they didn't. We would have never met and I wouldn't have found a savior."

Rathnait was new at the comforting. It was usually Felix comforting her and the reverse roles was a little strange for Rathnait. However, she did a good enough job at comforting Felix, because he eventually felt better and said, "Alright, we'll try to enter my mind and see into my past."

"And I promise you can enter my mind too, if it makes you fell better," Rathnait informed Felix.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- --------------------------------------

Rathnait and Felix had no idea how to enter Felix's. So, they just concentrated on wanting to do so. Eventually, they opened their eyes and saw a large hallway of widows that seemed to stretch forever. Felix noticed he was himself again and Rathnait was young again too. However, there was something very different about Rathnait. She was the same size as Felix!

"Wow," was all the two of them could say as they looked at each other. Felix and Rathnait looked at each other for the longest time till Felix finally touched Rathnait's muzzle. Rathnait moved her muzzle and nuzzled Felix's neck and cheek.

"This is very strange," Rathnait commented, "I never imagined you being the same size as me."

"I kind of like it," Felix replied.

"You don't like me being my normal size?" Rathnait questioned.

"I do like you at you normal size sometimes. You can protect me and let me ride you. I do also like when we fly together and you carry me. However, your normal size is very intimidating at times," Felix explained, "Besides, we can be closer when we're the same size."

"Then I shall be the same size as you sometimes when we are in the dreamworld, if that's what you want," Rathnait replied.

"You'd do anything for me, wouldn't you," Felix stated.

"Of course, you're my best friend," Rathnait answered, "I'd do anything for you if you ask it of me."

"Then let's find out about my past," Felix replied and the walked down the hallway towards the back. The past the windows and each one had a memory with in them. Rathnait didn't look at many of them. She didn't want to feel like an intruder in Felix's mind. She was only there for support, not to intrude on his memories.

Once Felix made it to the first memory he remembered, he found the rest of the hall was blocked by a black shadow. Felix placed his hand on the shadow wall and tried to push through. The wall bent, but it didn't break. "I... I can't get through. It's blocked," Felix stated.

"Let me try," Rathnait said, determined to let her friend see his past. Rathnait pushed on the wall, but it still wouldn't budge.

"Be careful," Felix warned.

Rathnait then hit her body against the wall with all her might. The wall was strong, but it was beginning to give in to Rathnait's power. Eventually, Rathnait was able to push her head and half her neck through the wall, but the rest was being held back. She continued pushing, but it was no use.

A window caught Rathnait's eye and she turned her head to look at it. In the window appeared to be the aftermath of a battle scene. Many humans were dead on the ground and only a black dragon, the size of Dracus, was left standing. The black dragon was fearsome with red eyes, large horns, and looked demonic. (All shadow dragons looked terrible and evil, but very few were actually evil. Most shadow dragons were shy and reserved creatures and kind to others.)

Blood stained the black dragon's teeth and claws as he walked over to the cave he was defending. He came upon a baby human inside. The baby looked to be about two years old and very frightened. The black dragon approached the child and lowered his head in front of the child and gave a purr like growl. The growl reminded Rathnait of when her parents tried to assure her and comfort her. The human child hugged the massive muzzle and the dragon nuzzled the child.

There was sadness in the black dragon's eyes and the dragon said, "I'm sorry Felix, but I can't take care of you anymore. You aren't safe with me. They'll try to find me to get to you and I can't let you death me in my claws. This has to be done."

Suddenly, the wall forced Rathnait out and she was forced into Felix. Both rolled down the hall but neither were injured since it was just all in their head. "Rathnait, what happened? Did you see anything?" Felix questioned.

Rathnait looked around the cavern and only her mother and her were up at the moment. "Mom, how many kinds of dragons are there?" Rathnait questioned.

Shanaye, although awake, was still a little tired and was still lying in her sleeping position. However, when she heard her daughter approach and ask such a strange question, Shanaye lifted her head and looked down at her daughter. "Why do you ask such a question?" Shanaye questioned.

Rathnait thought about telling her mother about Felix's past, but then she realized it might be a bad idea. "Felix was worried to have me in his mind. He's closer to me than my parents. he probably wouldn't want me to reveal his secrets to them. Especially since he didn't know them himself. I have to let Felix tell them if he wants to."

"I was just curious, because I know there are many different dragons much different than us," Rathnait replied innocently.

"You're right. There are at least ten different species that I know of," Shanaye stated, "Each species is unique in their own way and live different lifestyles. All of them except two are actually bigger than us."

"There are dragons much larger than us?" Rathnait asked.

"Nearly all of them are. Three of them, the Earth, Silver, and Gold dragons, can easily grow four times bigger than us," Shanyae informed her daughter.

Rathnait was in utter shock. She had no idea something could be larger than her parents, let alone four times that. Rathnait remembered how small Felix look when she was adult sized in her dream. She could imagine being four times bigger than that, Felix would be a speck. "How can such large creatures live on this planet?" Rathnait asked.

"Well, the Earth dragons are usually underground. I don't know what they eat, but it's nothing on the surface. The Earth dragon have a whole society down there and they barely come up. No one has seen and Earth dragon for a thousand years. The silver and Gold dragons don't need to eat to survive. Gold dragons use the sun for energy and the silver dragons draws energy from the life forces around us, without killing things or course. Plus, there are only about ten gold and silver dragons. The gold dragons limit their numbers purposely and the silver dragons come from space. Their eggs are meteors that fall from the sky and another comes only a hundred years after one dies. They automatically bond with whatever creature sees them hatch," Shanaye explained.

Rathnait remembered that the black dragon was around her father's size, well, a little smaller than her father. "Which species are around our size?" Rathnait asked.

"Well, the forest dragons are the same size as us. They aren't as fast at flying, but they live in large clans like we do. They live in the forests. Like the gold dragon, they can use the energy of the sun. Forest dragons are very friendly to all creatures and they only kill if they have no other option. They see every intelligent creature as an equal with rights. They are a very strange dragons," Shanaye answered.

"What about the other dragon species around our size?" Rathnait asked.

"Well, there is only one species that are smaller than us, but not by much. They are shadow dragons," Shanaye began to answer.

"Do they have black scales and look demonic?" Rathnait asked, forgetting she should be less suspicious.

"Yes, they do," Shanaye replied while eying her daughter carefully. "How does she know what they look like? Has she seen the one in the village? Had it been in the cloud dragon territory?" Shanaye wondered.

"What are they like? Are they evil?" Rathnait asked.

"No, they are not evil. In fact, shadow dragons can be just as kind and generous as forest dragons, despite how evil and scare they look. They are very shy and reserved, however, and they usually like to be alone. That doesn't mean they don't enjoy company, though. They get very lonely at times and are usually kind to those who enter their territory, offering them shelter, food, and so on. Their are a few that like their privacy more than others, but those are rare," Shanaye explained, "You seem very interested in shadow dragons. Have you seen one before?"

"No mom, I was just wondering what other dragons are out there," Rathnait replied and to keep the act, Rathnait asked more about other dragon species and her mother told Rathnait everything she knew about the other species. Eventually, the other siblings woke up and when Dracus arrived, it was time for breakfast.

"I'll have to tell Felix about what I saw. I have to tell him he somehow knows a shadow dragon. However, I tell him at night." Rathnait decided.

Content with how things were going Dracus made his good-byes to Adam, Felix and Ashley. Ashley watched the large dragon take off a distance away from the mound.

"I can't believe you know the dragons so well," Ashley said, "Father rarely ever gets to ride one."

"Ashley, Dracus and his people don't like being viewed as pack animals and you know it," Adam said as they left the mound, "And besides Felix has earned their trust, so they let him be carried around." Ashley looked at Felix.

"How did you do that?" she asked, "How did you earn their trust?" Felix blinked, wondering how to say it without it insulting Rathnait.

"Well, Rathnait and I saved each other," Felix said. Ashley looked confused.

"How could you save something so big?" Ashley asked.

"I befriended Rathnait when we were both in trouble," Felix said, "Because of that, her parents liked me really quickly."

"And that's the reason we have Felix living with us, because he is their friend and Dracus is our family's friend as well," Adam said. Ashley nodded.

"Well, I guess that makes sense," Ashley said as they entered the town. Adam walked to two large horses. They were both brown and black and an attendant was standing near them.

"Sir Adam, Milady," the man said, then looking at Felix, "Master Felix." The man bowed his head to Felix. Felix blushed and looked away, not expecting such treatment or used to it.

"Felix, this is Abraham," Adam said, "He is Ashley's caretaker when her mother and I are unavailable. He will also be looking after you."

"It will be an honor and pleasure," Abraham said, smiling.

"Um . . you don't have to do this," Felix said, his face flushed with blush, "It's not really needed." Abraham blinked momentarily.

"Sire, why don't you take Lady Ashely back so Felix and I may talk some in private?" Abraham suggested. Adam nodded and put Ashley on a horse and left Abraham and Felix. Abraham pulled off the leather glove on his right hand. "Felix, I understand your hesitation and issues," Abraham said in a quiet solem voice.

"How?" Felix asked. Abraham knelt down and showed Felix his hand, scarred with a mark burned into it.

"Lord William isn't the only evil lord who abused his slaves," Abraham said, "I was just thankful Sir Adam was able to pay a price to free me and some other slaves. We came here and started over. It was hard at first, but there is such a wonderful feeling in being free Felix. And you have been blessed by befriending the dragons and that has given you a chance few others have."

"What do you mean?" Felix asked, still looking at the mark.

"I mean to live well and be tutored to receive a good education," Abraham said, "As well as to learn to fight and protect yourself. Now come, let's show you your new home." Felix was in slight shock as Abraham lifted the young boy onto the horse and mounted himself. They rode up the streets to the castle's entrance. “I don’t know what happened to my parents. I don’t know if they intentionally abandoned me or they died somehow,” Kaage continued with his face looking downwards, “All I know was that I was born alone and I had to fend for myself for the first eight years of my life. It’s understandable that I became extremely lonely, because I was still an infant without anyone else. Because of this, I became different from other shadow dragons. I don’t like the loneliness.”

“Is that why you live in a human village instead of a cave all alone?” Adam questioned.

“That’s one reason why,” Kaage answered, “Anyway, I actually went up to any sentient being I could find to hopefully find someone that cared. For eight years, I had no luck. That was until I met your father, Felix. I remember as if it was yesterday.”

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- -------------------------------------------

Kaage was crying in the cave. He was lonely and sad. He had no one that cared about him, no love, nothing but himself. He had met a human caravan that day and he tried to go up to them for help. He had been going up to every creature he could find in the woods for help. However, every creature he had gone up to was afraid of him. It was understandable, because Kaage was nearly twenty feet tall and even though he was an infant, Kaage still had some of the demonic-like features all shadow dragons had. Sure, his horns weren’t as long as an adult’s, but he still had red eyes, black scales, and a scary looking head.

So, the human caravan Kaage had run into that day only thought he was a monster. They drove him away no matter what Kaage said to try and calm them. Kaage had learned human long ago when he realized they were the only sentient beings around. He stayed and listened to people talk sometimes and learned the words that way.

Kaage was now in the cave and crying from the unsuccessful day. He felt it was hopeless and that he would be alone forever. It was raining out and a boy about ten years old named Frewen had been playing outside in the forest when it started to rain. Frewen ran into the nearest cave and leaned against the rock wall. “Mom’s going to hate it when I come home soaking wet,” Frewen thought to himself.

Frewen was about to sit down when her heard someone crying in the back of the cave. Frewen looked in the direction, but it was too dark to see what was back there. Frewen waited and could here deeply depressed sobs. “Is someone back there?” Frewen called out, “Are you hurt?”

Kaage lifted his head and saw a human boy in the distance. Kaage wanted to run up to the human and nuzzle him, but Kaage soon realized the human couldn’t see him. The human didn’t know Kaage was a dragon. “He’s going to run away from me when he sees me,” Kaage thought as he cried harder.

“I can hear you crying, whoever you are,” Frewen informed the crying being when he heard no reply, “I’m not going to harm you, if you’re afraid of me.”

“I’m not afraid,” Kaage replied, “But you’ll be afraid of me. All you humans are.”

Frewen was confused by the statement. “Is the being not human?” Frewen wondered. “What’s wrong? Are you hurt?” Frewen asked.

“I’m very hurt, but no one can help me,” Kaage called back, “If you come back here, I’ll only be hurt more.”

“What’s wrong?” Frewen questioned. He knew the creature wasn’t human, but he wanted to still help it anyway. The creature sounded so depressed and Frewen just couldn’t let it cry. Plus, the creature sounded like a child younger than himself.

“Everyone thinks I’m a monster,” Kaage cried, “Everyone hurts me or runs. I’m all alone. I have no parents. You’ll only run away from me too when you see me.”

“Why would I run away? Do you intend to hurt me?” Frewen asked.

“No, I’d never hurt a human. It’s just that I’m scary looking,” Kaage sobbed, “But I can’t do anything to change that.”

“Well, if you’re not planning on hurting me, then why would I run?” Frewen asked as he walked into the darkness. Eventually, he noticed something massive in the dark. The thing was moving and shivering at the sobs and deep breaths. “Why don’t you come into the light so that I can see you?” Frewen suggested.

“Just so that you can see me and run away?” Kaage snapped back. Frewen noticed two eyes open and move upwards. The eyes were a blood red color with slited pupils. Though the eyes looked terrifyingly evil, they were filled with a deep sadness that Frewen couldn’t look away from.

“I’m not going to run away from you,” Frewen tried to assure the creature, “You seem so sad and I want to help you.”

Suddenly, fire appeared below the eyes and engulfed some wood on the floor. The creature was lit up by the light and Frewen could now see it was a twenty foot tall dragon with black scales and a terrifying head that looked demonic, despite the sad expression in the face. “I can see fear in your eyes,” Kaage informed Frewen, “So, why don’t you just run away like everyone else and leave me in my sadness.”

Kaage turned his neck in the opposite way of the human and curled up and continued to cry. Frewen just stared at the dragon for the longest time. He had been taught that dragons were vicious and monstrous creatures. Yet, this one was different. This black dragon was only a child and it was very sad and lonely. That was understandable if it was truly alone without any parents. “I can’t imagine never having parents and having to fend for myself. No wonder this dragon is so lonely and gets depressed when no one helps it. The dragon must feel awful.” Frewen realized.

Frewen sighed. He just couldn’t leave the dragon in such a sad state. He had to help it. Frewen walked around the twenty foot tall dragon that could easily have been sixty feet long with the tail and long neck. Frewen walked up to the head as was slightly larger than his entire body and he knelt beside the crying head. Frewen took a deep breath and touched the dragon’s muzzle.

Kaage quickly reacted and pulled his head up and stared down at the human. Kaage was extremely confused and tears still ran down his face. “Wh-What are you doing?” Kaage questioned.

“I’m trying to help you,” Frewen replied.

“But, aren’t you afraid of me?” Kaage asked.

“You do look pretty scary, but I’m not going to run from you, because you’re not a monster. You’re just sad and lonely and it would be cruel of me to just leave you here,” Frewen explained.

Kaage lowered his head in front of the boy’s body; his muzzle was only inches away. Kaage was in utter disbelief and he had to make sure he was hearing the human right. “I’m not a monster and you not going to run away like everyone else?” Kaage questioned.

“I’m not going to run away,” Frewen stated.

Kaage was joy controlled his actions and Kaage automatically lowered his head to the human’s side and preceded to use the side of his muzzle to nuzzle the human’s side. Kaage continued to cry as he said, “Thank you. Thank you for not running away. You don’t know how happy I am right now.”

Frewen just took both hands and pet the large dragon’s muzzle until Kaage calmed down.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- --------------------------------

“Then what happened?” Felix asked.

“We became good friends and he promised he’d visit my every day. Your father, Frewen, was my first and truest friend. Those were the happiest days of my life,” Kaage continued.

“No one got suspicious that Frewen was going into the woods alone when others thought you were a monster?” Adam questioned.

“His mother did, and she followed him one day. She thought I was a monster at first, but when Frewen explained to her I was his friend and that I’d never hurt a human unless I was forced to, She accepted me. She would even come sometimes and she treated me like another son when she found out I never had parents,” Kaage informed the group, “When I figured out how to turn into my human form, she was kind enough to take me in and everything. Of course I had to stay as a human while I lived there.”

“I became used to humans then and because if that, I’m more comfortable with humans than other dragons,” Kaage continued, “One day, Frewen and I realized we could hear each others thought and he could perform some of my powers. Neither of us understood what was happening, but we learned it from a wandering wizard that was passing by. He told us we were forming a magical bond because of our brother-like relationship.”

“So technically, you’re my uncle,” Felix spoke up, “Not by blood, but you were adopted by my grandmother.”

“You’re right, Felix, and I would gladly call your father my brother. He was very kind to me and treated me like a brother. I wish you could have met you grandmother though, she was the sweetest human I ever met,” Kaage commented, “But she died over a hundred years before you were born.”

“What?” Felix gasped.

“Your father gained a dragon lifespan when he was bonded with me. He and I lived closed to two hundred years before we met your mother,” Kaage explained, “You will age slowly too once you reach eighteen years.”

“How did you meet my mother?” Felix asked.

“Your father and I were staying at cave in a forest for a few weeks. Frewen was saddened from being nearly immortal and knowing anyone he fell in love with would die long before him. I was trying my best to comfort him when we heard a scream for help. Your father and I rushed out to save the woman in need. We eventually found her at the edge of the woods tied to a pole,” Kaage told Felix.

“The funny thing was that many people had seen me and were afraid of me. They decided to give me a human sacrifice to please me. I would never accept such a thing though. The woman was completely hysterical when she saw me and I’m sure she thought she would die,” Kaage explained, “But eventually Frewen cut her down and she thought he was a knight come to save her from the vicious dragon. It took a long time to convince her I wasn’t going to harm her, but it was worth it. Frewen quickly fell in love with her. Believe it or not, your mother and I became good friends too, once she realized how kind and gentle I was.”

“What was her name?” Felix asked.

“Her name was Isabel, and she was very beautiful and kind. She loved you and your father more than anything else in the world,” Kaage told Felix.

Felix then asked…
