"Could you . . . Would you tell me more about my parents?" Felix asked. Kaage nodded.

"Your father was a brave man with a just heart," Kaage said, "He would often stand up for people who were treated poorly in our travels together. Your mother had an equally strong spirit. Once she opened up to me, we found we had much in common. Your mother was the child of a prostitute who was left to fend for herself for a long time. She finally found work in the town near the village, working as a baker. But when the call for a sacrifice was made, she was chosen quickly, from both her heritage and she was new to the town. Because of her pain, we understood each other deeply because of our shared pains and how Frewen was our savior." Kaage smiled a little.

"Did you love her?" Adam asked, noticing the peculiar expression on Kaage's face.

"I loved her as a close friend and because of the bond with Frewen. When they were together, and the barrier was down, I felt everything Frewen felt for her," Kaage asked.

"So what happened then?" Felix asked.

"We traveled together for a couple of years," Kaage said, "The three of us. And soon, three turned into four." Kaage chuckled. "The look on Frewen's face when Isabel told him she was with child was amazing. He had never looked like that before."

"Did . . . Did my mother ever come to terms with the fact my father would outlive her by decades?" Felix asked.

"She had a hard time accepting the man she loved would not grow old with her and she would one day look old enough to be his mother, while he was young. But Frewen promised her that she was his only love and would take no other," Kaage said, "We were even looking for a remedy to the problem."

"How?" Felix asked.

"We were searching for a being for her to bond with," Kaage said, "But looking for something like that stirred up some trouble for us." Kaage's voice turned dark for a few moments.

"You mean those people who you were protecting me from?" Felix asked. Kaage nodded.

"They were slayers who sought to kill anything inhuman. They targeted us for Frewen's bond with me and your mother was friendly with us. They attacked without warning . . ." Kaage said quietly as tears came to his eyes.

"Did my parents die?" Felix asked.

"Your mother was kidnapped to lure us into a fight. Your father rushed to save her, but fell into a trap. I felt your father die and I almost suicided to be with him. I couldn't stand to be alone once more. But his final words to me were to protect you from their reach," Kaage breathed.

"And my mother?" Felix asked.

"They had killed her before Frewen even reached her," Kaage answered, "That day is another day I will never forget. It is just as vivid as when I first met Frewen and he helped heal my loneliness."

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- --------------------------------

"Frewen, this is crazy!" Kaage argued, "You can't go alone. It's surely a trap. You'll need my strength."

"Felix can't be left in the cave alone," Frewen pointed to Felix who was still only a few months old lying in a makeshift bed, "You must stay and protect Felix, Kaage."

"But you are Felix's father. Let me go get Isabel. There's no need risking both of Felix's parents," Kaage continued to argue.

"I understand you're argument, but I feel as though I have to be the one to save her. I trust you in caring for my son if anything is to go wrong. You're his uncle and my brother," Frewen informed Kaage.

"I'm not a blood relative," Kaage sighed.

"But we are brothers in soul. I see you as my brother, even though you're a dragon and I'm a human," Frewen informed Kaage as he touched the side of Kaage's muzzle. Frewen stared into the red eyes of the dragon's lowered head and said, "I trust you with my child and I know you'd make the right decisions if something were to happen to me."

"I don't know if I'd be able to go on if I loose you," Kaage replied, "I don't want to go back to being alone again, not after all these years of happiness with you and Isabel."

"I know it will seem like those first years you were alone to fend for yourself, but I'd always be with you. You just have to keep me in your mind and heart. Besides, you'd have Felix to look after. You wouldn't be alone," Frewen stated.

"I still don't like this plan," Kaage replied.

"Everything will be fine, I promise," Frewen replied.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- -------------------------------------------

"Then what happened?" Felix asked.

"Things didn't go to plan," Kaage answered.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- -------------------------------------------

Frewen entered the deep cannon with his sword at the ready. He eventually came upon an alter in the center of the cannon and Frewen dropped his sword. Isabel was lying on the alter and Frewen rushed to her. Isabel's skin was pale and blood drenched the side of her dress. Frewen felt around her mouth and nose, but he didn't feel her breath. Isabel was dead and there wasn't anything Frewen could do. it was too late to borrow Kaage's shadow magic to heal her.

Frewen placed his hands around her and sat her up in a siting position. With one hand on her head and the other on her back. He brought her against his body and cried on her shoulder. The love of his life was gone and he was helpless to save her. "Frewen, I'm sorry," Kaage apologized. Kaage was using their bond to see through Frewen's eyes and talk to him.

"None of this is your fault," Frewen replied.

"But if you would have never met me and we wouldn't have bonded..." Kaage started to explain sadly.

"It's not your fault. You needed me, Kaage. I don't regret helping you about two hundred years ago. This isn't your fault. If I wouldn't have met you, I would have never lived long enough to met Isabel," Frewen informed Kaage.

"But those men are after you and Isabel because of me," Kaage argued.

"It takes two to bond," Frewen stated, "And it's neither of our faults. It's the monsters that fear us! The monsters who want to kill us just because we're different."

"So, you've come, but where's your beast of a friend?" a deep voice questioned.

Frewen turned his head and saw a large, bald man in his thirties. The man was muscular and looked even larger with the thick armor on him. Frewen new this was the leader of the hunters and he slowly lowered Isabel on the alter again and looked away from the man. "It's too bad the woman was too stubborn to see you and that demon are monsters," the leader commented, "We never like having to kill other humans, but we do when it's necessary."

"There was no reason to attack us," Frewen stated, still looking away from the man, "We've done nothing to you. We're not evil."

"You are being possessed by that demon dragon," the man growled, "We need to free you before you and the demon infected others."

"Kaage is not a demon. He has no demonic blood within him," Frewen growled back, finally looking back at the man, "If you stopped to get to know him, you'd realize that he's a kind and gentle dragon. He was raised by humans and sees himself as a human more than a dragon. Besides, we're bonded, I'm not possessed by him."

"That's just what that demon wants you to think," the man replied.

"Then you are blinded by ignorance," Frewen stated.

"You're the one whose blinded!" the man yelled, "Unfortunately, you're too far gone to save. We'll have to kill you and then the dragon. Don't worry. I'll raise your son and make sure he doesn't suffer the same fate as you."

"You will not touch my son!" Frewen yelled as he charged, picking up his sword. Frewen swung and two swords clung against each other. "I will not let you turn him into a monster like you!" Frewen growled.

Frewen lifted a hand off the sword and borrowed Kaage's shadow magic. Frewen was going to phase into the man's chest and rip out his heart. But when Frewen's shadow hand touched the man's armor, he was forced backwards and fell a few feet away from the man without a sword. The man smiled and hit his chest. "There is one metal shadow dragons can't phase through. It's the metal that makes this special armor," the man stated.

Frewen looked around the cannon and saw many archers on the surrounding walls. "The same metal is on the tips of their arrows," the man smiled.

"Kaage, take care of Felix. Keep him safe," Frewen requested.

"Frewen!" Kaage roared, but when Kaage felt as though many arrows had penetrated his body and couldn't see through Frewen's eyes any longer, Kaage knew that his best friend and brother was dead. Kaage's mind was all by itself once again without the hint that Frewen had ever shared a part of it.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- -----------------------------------------------

"I felt everything your father felt that day, and I felt his thoughts leave my mind. I could feel his very being leave my mind as if it was never there. I was alone again," Kaage informed Felix.

Rathnait was shocked at what she had heard. She never knew the bond could be so terrible if one were to die. She hadn't imagined what it would be like if Felix were to die, but now she knew what it would be like and she feared it.

"You must have felt terrible," Felix said.

"Terrible doesn't even come close to describing it. There is no word strong enough for it," Kaage stated.

"Those monsters," Adam growled, "How could people be so ignorant and blind?"

"Unfortunately, there are many that don't understand what a magical bond is. They thing the magical creature is possessing the human, especially when a non-sentient creature bonds with a human. They don't understand it's a beautiful and wondrous gift," Kaage informed them.

"Uncle Kaage," Felix said. Kaage slightly flinched at Felix calling him Uncle once more. "I think I'm ready for my memories now," Felix informed his Uncle.

"If you think you are ready, I'll unblock the wall, but it might overwhelm you and might make you pass out. It's five years of memories after all," Kaage warned.

"I don't care, I'm ready," Felix replied.

Kaage placed his hand on Felix's head and his hand became a shadow. When the wall was taken down...

Felix began to open his eyes. His vision was blurry at first and he closed his eyes again. When he didn't fell dizzy anymore, Felix opened them again. He was in his room again. He didn't know how much time had past and how long he was unconscious, but it was still light outside and the sunlight still shined in his room. Felix slowly sat up in his bed and quickly groaned and wished he had waited a little longer. He became dizzy again and had to close his eyes once more.

"Take it easy, Master Felix," Felix heard a command. Felix opened his eyes and saw Abraham sitting in a chair. "You've been unconscious for quite a while and you're sure to be dizzy," Abraham explained.

"My head is screaming," Felix groaned, "How long have I been out?"

"A few hours, you missed lunch," Abraham answered, "I you feeling alright other than your headache."

"I'm fine except for the headache," Felix replied.

"Kaage, Rhain, and Adam all recommend that you stay in your room for the rest of the day and try to get as much rest as possible," Abraham informed Felix, "Are you hungry?"

"I'm very hungry," Felix replied.

"Maybe some food will help with that headache. I'll be back shortly," Abraham said as he got up. Abraham glanced at the balcony doorway and then back at Felix. "I believe someone wants to talk to you badly," Abraham stated before he left.

Felix looked at the doorway and saw a large eye looking through, an eye that could be only Rathnait's. Felix smiled upon seeing Rathnait and she asked, "Are you alright, Felix?"

Felix got out of bed and had to wait a while before stepping towards Rathnait. "I'm fine other than the headache," Felix replied. Rathnait backed her head away to let Felix through the doorway, but once he was through, Rathnait immediately began to affectionately nuzzle him. Felix laughed and pet her muzzle in response. "Miss me?" Felix asked.

"I was so worried, Felix," Rathnait informed him as she continued to nuzzle, "I couldn't hear any of your thoughts and I couldn't reach you. I thought something was going to happen to you."

"I was just unconscious was all," Felix informed her.

"Well, I didn't like it. Don't do it again," Rathnait replied with snort causing some smoke to emerge out of her nostrils.

Rathnait backed her head away and Felix got a better look at her. She was lying on her underbelly and her body took up most of the balcony. "Good thing I have a large balcony out here," Felix replied, "Otherwise, you wouldn't have been able to watch over me."

"Maybe Adam gave you this room for that reason," Rathnait commented.

"Were you out here the entire time I was unconscious?" Felix questioned.

"I would have been if my father didn't force me to come back and eat lunch with the family. Other than that, I was here whole time. I found it hard to leave you alone," Rathnait told Felix.

"Now I think I understand how Kaage feels," Felix replied.

"What do you mean?" Rathnait asked.

"We're finding it hard to be apart from each other and we've only been bonded for a few days. Kaage and my father were bonded for over a hundred years. Now I understood why he cried some nights after my parents died," Felix said.

"So, you remember everything now?" Rathnait asked.

"I do. I remember everything as if it had all just happened. It seems strange to me how a few hours ago I couldn't remember a thing and now I remember everything," Felix stated, "My parents were just like Kaage described."

"What about Kaage?" Rathnait asked, "Can he be trusted?"

"Yes, he's my uncle. He might not be a blood relative, but an uncle none the less," Felix replied, "He and my father were bonded a long time and they share many of the same traits because of it. Almost as if they are the same people. Kaage shares the same feelings and loves me as much as my parents did. He would never intentionally harm me. We can trust him."

Felix suddenly heard a knock on the door and Felix hollered, "You may come in."

Who was it?

Rathnait growled slightly. She felt strongly about people ordering around her close friend and the growl scared Ashely, turning Ashely pale. "No one should be ordering around a friend of a dragon," Rathnait growled.

Ashely had never been growled at by a dragon and Felix could see the fear in her eyes. Though Felix barely knew Ashely he somehow felt a strong sibling bond to her. She was a part of his new family and important. Felix quickly stepped in front of Rathnait and tried defused the situation before it could get any worse. "Now Rathnait, it's aright," Felix tried assuring Rathnait, "We must respect the sibling laws like all your siblings do. Besides, Ashely's only concerned about my well being."

They all got to know each other better and they all began to trust each other as they continued their conversations. None of them spoke about Lord William again in the conversation, knowing Rathnait was uncomfortable about the revelation. Felix could feel Rathnait's uneasiness about such a conversation as if it were his own feeling in his head.

Around the time Felix finished his food, the door to his room opened up again. Ashely and Felix turned their heads to see that it was Abraham entering the room with both Adam and Kaage. "Good evening, Felix," Adam greeted while Kaage simply nodded. "Is your headache gone now?" Adam questioned.

"Yes, I think the food helped the headache move along," Felix answered.

Adam seemed relieved and Abraham approached Felix and took the tray away. As Abraham turned to the door, he ordered, "Come with me, Ashely."

"Can't I stay with Felix and Rathnait?" Ashely asked.

"Kaage and I wish to speak to Felix and Rathnait alone," Adam explained, "Now go with Abraham, Ashely."

Ashely sighed and followed Abraham out of the room. When Abraham and Ashely were long down the hallway, Adam and Kaage approached Felix and Rathnait. Adam sat in the chair Ashely had sat in and Kaage preferred to just stand near the doorway. "So, how are your memories coming along?" Adam asked.

"I remember everything," Felix replied, "It feels strange to me. I knew nothing about my past a few hours ago, but now I know more than I would normally would. I don't think most people remember when they were really young."

"You memories were preserved behind the wall," Kaage explained, "Normal people forget the memories of their younger years because they get blurry as they get older. You're memories were preserved and you just gained them back. It feels as though they had just happened to you, right?"

"That's exactly how it feels," Felix replied, "I even remember my birth quite clearly because of the preservation."

"I remember my birth quite clearly, but those are for different reasons," Kaage muttered out loud.

"I remember my parents just as clearly. I remember what they looked like, how they acted, who they were," Felix said, "And because I'm older now, I see more of their character and who they were. They were just as you described. They were good people."

"They were," Kaage agreed as he looked to the ground and sighed, "They didn't deserve to be killed like they were."

"I know you even more," Felix said.

Kaage looked up and asked, "What do you know about me?"

"For one, You seem to blame yourself for my parent's deaths as well as feel guilty for my memory loss," Felix started.

"Well, if your father would have never met me, he would have never died that day and you..." Kaage started.

"If you wouldn't have bonded with him, my father wouldn't have grown old enough to have met my mother and I would have never been born," Felix informed Kaage.

"But if I wouldn't have bonded with him, he wouldn't have been hunted by those monsters," Kaage growled.

"They will always be evil men like those monsters. Unfortunately, we can't change that," Felix replied, "It's those monsters that killed them, not you."

"What else did you learn?" Kaage questioned.

"You are very much like my father. You and him were bonded for so long, you two became like twins. You share many of the same feelings and characteristics of my father," Felix continued.

"When two are bonded for a long time, it is true they become one in the same. But the fact that your father and I were bonded at such a young age helps that effect even more. He gained some pf my personality and I gained some of his. We shared the same feeling. Because he was in love with your mother and you, I gained his feelings as well," Kaage explained, "That's why I'd do anything for you. You father cared about you more than anything else and that strong feeling went into me as well."

"So because of your bond with my father, you see me as if I were your son two?" Felix questioned.

"It's a little more complicated than that, but that is a simple way to put it," Kaage agreed.

"I understand you reasons for what you did to me. I understand it was only to protect me and I will not hold that against you," Felix told Kaage, "You are my Uncle after all."

Kaage sighed, "I am your Uncle. My be not by blood, but we are nephew and uncle through spirit. I wish I could take care of you like your father asked me to do, but it's still too dangerous to be with me."

"Haven't you been living in this town for five years? Surly those slayers have forgotten..." Felix started.

Kaage interrupted, "I don't think I can risk that. Besides, if they ever do find me, they won't find you if you stay with Adam. Looking in the castle of a lord and searching through the royal family is the last place they'd ever look. You're safer with Adam."

"But surely we can't stay apart the whole time," Felix argued, "I do miss you, Uncle Kaage."

"If I were to leave the town and go somewhere else and do something to get their attention. They'd be on the right trail again and might not even notice the town. I can lead them away," Kaage explained.

"But we'd be further apart again," Felix argued, "I just learned that I still have family and now you plan on leaving me again?"

"Felix, I..." Kaage started.

"You can't leave me. Because of my memories are back, I'd miss you more than ever," Felix explained. Felix rushed up to Kaage and embraced him, pleading, "Don't go. Please, don't go. I'd miss you too much."

Kaage tensed up at first when Felix started the hug, but Kaage relaxed and hugged Felix back who only came up to Kaage's chest. Kaage bowed his head, inwardly wishing he was his dragon form so he could nuzzle his nephew who felt like a son to him. "I was only suggesting it, Felix. If we deem that it's best for me to stay, then I will. I must do whatever is best to keep you safe. Plus, I'd miss you to and I wouldn't want to leave just as much as you don't want me to leave," Kaage replied.

"What happens if they still come despite you leading them away? The merchants that come in go probably always talk about how we befriended dragons. They might come just for that," Adam stated.

"Those monsters might be evil enough to kill all of you, and Felix would still be in danger without me gone," Kaage said.

"So, wouldn't it be better for you to stay here?" Adam asked, "If they were able to find this place and attack the castle, it's unknown how long it would take the cloud dragons to rally up and come to our aid. Plus, they can't really land in the town of stop them if they're in the castle. You're the only dragon living here and you are Felix's best defense because not only can you try to stop them as a dragon, but you can turn human if they make it inside the castle."

"This is all true," Kaage agreed, "Plus, with me here, I'll be able to pick them out in a crowd. I know how to spot them, how they act, what they wear even when their in disguise, and what their leader looks like. I know their techniques. I can warn you faster then anyone else."

"Then, you'll stay, right?" Felix asked pulling out of the hug,

"Yes, I'm staying here," Kaage answered.

"And what about us meeting each other on a regular basis?" Felix asked.

Kaage was a little more hesitant to answer, but he finally answered, "I suppose we can work something out. I still want you to live with Adam, because he can care for you better and he's human while I'm a dragon. But, I'm sure I'll be able to see you certain days of the week."

Felix was happy with Kaage's answer and hugged him once more. He had his Uncle back.

"So, what will you do?" Abraham asked.

"When Felix and Ashley get back, I will talk to Felix and send word to Kaage to come. When their both here, I'll tell them the situation and tell Felix to talk to Rathnait and ask for Dracus's permission for an audience in his cave. I know Kaage won't go till an invitation is confirmed. He is a dragon after all," Adam said.

"What if Dracus doesn't let you come to his cave, or he won't carry you and Felix there? I know he wouldn't carry Kaage, so Kaage would have to fly, but..." Abraham started.

"I'll deal with it when we come to that, but for now, I must tell Kaage and Felix of the situation. We have two weeks till the trail," Adam interrupted.

1151212211221221211111211112221221211122.content:
Felix was pushing his horse hard as he and Ashley were returning to the castle.

"Felix," Ashley called to her brother, "You need to calm down." The cold look of hatred in his eyes, the depth of the anger, these things were things Ashley never dreamed of seeing in her brother.

"I can't!" Felix snapped back, "You heard why the merchants were raising their prices. They're worried about rumors of Lord William returning to power."

"But that can't happen. You said that the dragons destroyed his old home," Ashley said.

"But they couldn't capture him. He escaped," Felix said, "I need to tell father on this and see if he has heard anything as well!" Ashely said no more, on their return to the castle.

-----------------------------------------------------

When they reached the castle doors, Felix didn't even take care of his horse, only jump off and run into the doors. Ashley followed him in a similar fashion, but did thank the castle stablemen.

By the time Ashley caught up with her brother, he was in the meeting room.

--------------------------------------------------------

Adam eyed his son as he entered. He had never seen Felix so angry before, it was a wonder he had contained it.

"Did something happen at the market with the merchants?" Adam asked.

"Father, have you heard any news on Lord William?" Felix asked suddenly. Adam bit his lip.

"What have you heard?" Adam asked.

"The reason the merchants are raising prices is because of many rumors that that bastard lord is returning to power!" Felix raged, "Tell me it isn't true! Tell me this is some whisper of stupidity that has no grounds!" Adam took a moment to think of how to proceed.

"The rumor does have fact to it," Adam said, "The man is spreading malicious lies about his fall from power, claiming I ordered the dragons to attack."

"But father that's absurd!" Ashley said, having entered and heard everything.

"I know but some people believe him and it has even reached the king's ears," Adam said darkly, "He is giving William an audiance."

"I won't allow it! I was a boy before, but not anymore. I will kill him before he can take another slave!" Felix growled. He turned to leave, only to find Abraham in his way.

Adam inwardly thanked Abraham for his forethought in blocking Felix's escape should he become to angry.

"Killing him would only prove him right about this land," Abraham said, "What is needed is evidence we did nothing to him, that it was his own arrogance and pride when he captured a dragon, nothing bad would befall him."

"So Felix, you can get your chance to 'kill' him by telling the king of your past with the man," Adam said.

"Will that be enough?" Felix asked, looking at Adam.

"I doubt it. That's why I need your help with another matter," Adam said.

"To be rid of him for good, anything," Felix said.

"I would like you to arrange for me to speak to both Dracus and Shanaye in their cave. I would like Rathnait to speak at the audiance as well," Adam said.

"I will get on it right away," Felix said, having calmed down, "I'll go contact Rathnait right away." He departed for his room.

-------------------------------------------

Once there, with his mind, he said, "Rathnait, where are you?"

Rathnait received her bond's question but also realized something was off when Felix spoke no pleasantries to her.

"I'm . . .

1151212211221221211111211112221221211122.content:
"I'm eating lunch with my family right now. Why do you ask? What's the matter?" Rathnait questioned. Felix could feel Rathnait's worry enter his mind. The worry was very strong, but Rathnait always worried about Felix. This was most likely because Felix was smaller than her despite him being much older than her relative to their species. Well, Rathnait was the stronger one of the bond and which made her the protector.

"Something has come up, Rathnait," Felix told her, "My father wishes to speak with you and your parents. So, I am to ask you to ask your parents if we have their permission to go to your cave. The matter is of grave importance."

"Felix, what's wrong? I can feel how upset you are and it makes me worried. Please tell me what is of grave importance," Rathnait pleaded. Felix hadn't seen Rathnait worried like this in a while. It was obvious that she could feel his emotions. The bond was strong enough that they could feel each others emotions as well as their thoughts. it was understandable why she would be worried about him if she could feel his anger.

"I don't know if I can speak of it without getting angrier," Felix informed Rathnait.

Rathnait's voice sounded scared now. It must have been terrible for her to hear her bond mate so upset and be too far away to calm him down like she usually did. "Felix, I never heard you so angry before. Please, tell me what's wrong. I just want to help you," Rathnait encouraged.

"And I'm sure your parents will demand to know that the problem is before they accept Adam and I to come over to their cave," Felix sighed. Felix took a few deep breaths to calm down and then continued, "You know how Lord William wasn't killed? Well, he's causing troubles again."

"What's that monster doing this time?" Rathnait growled angrily.

"He's spreading lies about this city and the cloud dragons. He's making it seem like his the victim and he was wrongly taken from his seat of power," Felix explained.

"What kind of lies is he spreading?" Rathnait questioned.

"They're too terrible for me to speak of," Felix replied, "But people are starting to believe him and he will have console with the king in about a week."

"How can he be stopped?" Rathnait asked.

"That's why my father wishes to talk to you and your parents," Felix told Rathnait.

"I will tell them after lunch what you told me and I'll relay their answer," Rathnait informed her bond mate.

"Thank you, Rathnait," Felix replied before ending the link.

Felix left his room and back to the throne room. Felix opened the doors and saw that Adam and Abraham were still there. However, Ashley was gone. "Father probably didn't want her to know about our business in any great detail. He still tries to protect her from the evils of the world," Felix thought. Felix agreed with Ashley in her conflicts with her father. Ashley didn't need to be babied and protected behind a shroud of goodness. She was older than Felix and had grown very mature over the years. Adam trusted her enough to train her how to rule the city, yet he still protected her from the series evils such as Lord William. Though it was only hurting Ashley for not knowing such things. This was why he and Rathnait had told Ashley all about Lord William and the evils he committed.

Felix also noticed that Kaage was there now and Adam was just finishing telling Kaage everything. Kaage definitely needed to be in the plan since it involved Felix. Kaage was after all the closest thing to a relative that Felix had since Kaage was Kaage was the adopted brother of Felix's father and Adam and his family never even knew Felix's parents. The doors shut behind Felix causing everyone in the room to turn their attention to him. "What did Dracus and Shanaye say?" Adam asked his adopted son.

"Rathnait told me they're all eating lunch right now," Felix informed him, "Rathnait will ask them permission when they're done eating and then relay the answer to me."

"When she replies back, tell her to ask Dracus if I am aloud to join you and Lord Adam," Kaage asked of his nephew, "It's one thing for humans to enter a cloud dragon's territory, but it is usually very different when a dragon, especially of a different species, were to enter."

"I'm sure you'd be welcome. You are my uncle after all," Felix assured him.

"But you need to still ask to be on the safe side, because I'll be the one flying you there. Not only will I have to be accepted by him but it has to be alright with the other cloud dragons since I'm a shadow dragon," Kaage explained.

"You sure you want to fly us there?" Adam questioned, "Most dragons feel that flying with a human on their back is degrading..."

"You forget, my lord, I was raised by humans and I don't have many of the dragon mentalities because of that. I'm more human in my mind than dragon," Kaage told him.

"But it must still feel strange since you're a sentient being. I don't want you to feel like you're some beast of burden or something," Adam argued.

"I don't see it like that," Kaage informed Lord Adam, "I see it as helping a friend and my nephew. Because I'm more human in my mind, you are my lord and my loyalties are to you and my nephew and his new family. Besides, I miss giving Frewen and Isabel rides."

Very well, when Felix gets word from Rathnait..." Lord Adam started, but one of the side doors opened up and Ashley fell into the room. She had been listening in on the conversation and accidentally twisted the doorknob, causing the door to open and her to fall into the room. "Ashley!" Lord Adam yelled, "What did I tell you?"

"Dad, it's not fair. I need to listen to this!" Ashley argued.

"This is for Felix and..." Lord Adam started.

"No, you're only keeping me out because you want to protect me from the evils like Lord William. That's why you never told my the details of Felix's life. But you shouldn't hide me from such things," Ashley argued, "If I happen to be in control of the city, I'd need to learn about such evils so that I will know hoe to properly handle them. All you're doing is making me blind from them so that they can sneak up behind me and destroy me."

Lord Adam listened to Ashley's words and was surprised by her mature words. "But you don't even know what happened to Felix. How could you help?" Lord Adam questioned.

"Rathnait and I told her, father," Felix informed Adam, "I realized long ago that she was only being hurt by not knowing what happens in other places."

"I want to come along, father," Ashley said.

Lord Adam hesitated for the longest time and eventually sighed, "Both of you are right. I should hide you from the real evils. You may come."

Soon, Rathnait linked back up with Felix. "Can you hear me Felix?" Rathnait asked.

"I have two more people coming other than just me and my father," Felix told Rathnait, "Ashley's coming along as well, and Kaage has decided to fly us there. Are they allowed to come?"

There was long silence as Rathnait asked her parents if Kaage and Ashley were aloud to come as well. Eventually, Rathnait replied...

1151212211221221211111211112221221211122.content:
The flight to Dracus and Shanye's cave was strange to everyone involved. For one, it was the first flight got Ashley and Adam. King Adam respected the dragons and knew that they wouldn't take kindly to a human riding on their back. It was one thing if a human was injured or could only get somewhere by flying and even than the dragon "carried" humans. Even with such exceptions, there were dragons that wouldn't ever let a human be carried, they felt it was demeaning to be considered no more than an beast of burden. Though it might not be the human's intention to make it seem that way, it is what goes through most dragons' heads. There were a few species of dragons that would see giving humans a ride as being helpful, though those were forest, silver, some gold, and some water dragon. Fire dragons, Snow dragons, and Cloud dragons were too proud of creatures and most saw letting humans ride them as demeaning. (by the way, there are nine known species of dragons all with their own personalities and beliefs.)

Not only because of the respect for dragons Adam had, Adam also knew all too well that dragons were intelligent being. He felt uncomfortable having to ride Kaage to get to Dracus's cave. If it wasn't for Kaage persistent assurance that he didn't mind letting them ride him and the fact that the only way to get to the cave was to fly, Adam would have never agreed to going through with it in this manor.

Ashley, like her father, was a little uncomfortable with riding a dragon. She shared his beliefs and knew all to well what could disrespect a dragon. She was taught how to deal with them and all the what to do and not to do's around dragon, because it was clear she'd have to eventually deal with them. Those these beliefs existed, there was another part that existed in her ever since she was a child: the desire to be able to fly. She had always wanted to fly, even more so when Rathnait described to her what it was like to fly. Ashley was sometimes tempted to ask Rathnait to give her a short ride. Rathnait and Ashley were good friends and it was quiet possible that Rathnait would give Ashley a ride if she asked it. However, Ashley didn't want to risk her friendship for a ride.

The flight was strange to Felix as well. Sure, Felix had flown many times with Rathnait and he was used to the flying experience. However, it seemed strange to be on the back of a large creature he called Uncle. He had flown with Kaage before, but those were times before he had his memory erased and had become a slave to Lord William. He now remembered those memories, but those memories were still strange to Felix, as if they never happened or happened to someone else. They felt foreign to him and flying on Kaage seemed new to Felix because of this fact.

Kaage hadn't been in his dragon form, his true form, for a very long time. He had stayed human ever since he had come upon the village in the mountains after leaving Felix with humans he thought he could trust. Because of this fact, the flight was also strange for Kaage. It wasn't that he was used to flying, because dragons were natural fliers, well the dragons with wings, because some water dragons and Earth dragons didn't have wings.This strange feeling came from all the things he missed about flying. Flying was a way Kaage used to relieve his stress and before he and Frewen were being hunted. Kaage may have enjoyed being in human form to be with humans since he was raised by humans, but he was still a dragon and most dragons loved to fly.

As Kaage flew to Dracus and Shanaye's cave, Kaage once again felt free and alive. He missed flying way too much and it would be near impossible to describe the happiness he felt at that moment and it made Kaage feel even better to have people that were close to him sharing the experience together. It was in no way demeaning to him to have them on his back, as long as they didn't see him as a beast of burden, which he knew they wouldn't do, he would be fine giving them a ride. It reminded him of the happy times he had when he flew Frewen and Isabel on his back.

Though Kaage enjoyed the flight, Adam and Ashley were scared of the flight and were a little uncomfortable. Ashley was a little less terrified than her father since she always wanted to fly, but no matter how much one wants to do an exciting activity, it's always scary the fist time. It also didn't help matters that Kaage was a terrifying beast that looked demonic with black scales, wicked looking horns, and blood red eyes. No matter how much Kaage warned them of his dragon form and no matter how many times he had assured them he was the same man they knew, there was still a hesitant moment where Ashley and Adam took a while to get on Kaage's back initially. People's fearful glances was something that Kaage did not miss about being a shadow dragon.

Kaage soon began to slow down and Felix questioned, "What's wrong?"

Kaage turned his head slightly to see his passengers with one of his large red eyes and answered, "I'm in Cloud Dragon territory now, and I think there might be a patrol guard up a head."

Felix and the others couldn't see anything in front of Kaage, but sure enough, a large cloud dragon suddenly swooped down and blocked Kaage's flight path. Kaage was glad he slowed down before hand. Any more sudden of a stop and some of his passengers might have fallen of his back. The patrol dragon was a male and one of the larger cloud dragons of the clan. Because of this, the male was far larger and more intimidating than Kaage. Kaage was about the average size of an adult male shadow dragon and that was slightly smaller than the average size of an average adult female cloud dragon. Kaage was small compared to the cloud dragon.

"What are you doing in these mountains, Shadow Dragon?" the patrol dragon growled, "This side of the mountains range is Cloud Dragon territory."

"I'm well aware of that fact and I have been invited to the cave of some dragons from your clan," Kaage informed the cloud dragon. Kaage tried to be as polite and careful with his words. Kaage hadn't spoken to many dragon in his lifetime and only knew the basics of certain thing he could and couldn't say. Kaage was far more comfortable talking with humans and because he was raised by humans, he talked like one.

"I wasn't told of a shadow dragon arriving, and what is on your back?" the dragon questioned.

The cloud dragon changed his position to see what was on Kaage's back. Kaage wanted to move with the dragon to keep the dragon's gaze off his nephew and friends. Though Kaage had to fight his protective urge for that moment and let the cloud dragon inspect his back. It was the patrol's job to see everything going in the clan's territory. Plus, Kaage didn't want to anger the already grumpy larger patrol dragon anymore. If he were to get in a fight with the Cloud Dragon, his passenger and himself might not make it through such a fight.

Once the cloud dragon saw that there were three humans on Kaage's back, the cloud dragon immediately glared at Kaage and growled, "You're letting humans ride you?!"

"I'm giving them a lift," Kaage started.

"You're their pack mole, is that it? You're their horse or their pet?" the dragon interrupted. The patrol dragon obviously saw Kaage's behavior as disgraceful. "How could you disgrace yourself by becoming a tool for humans?" the patrol dragon questioned.

"I see no disgrace in helping my friends. They have been invited as well, and they have to get to the cave somehow," Kaage commented. Kaage tried to stay as calm as possible, but the dragon seemed to have no regard for the humans on Kaage's back.

"Yet you don't seem to be disgraced by this fact. How can you be fine with this?" the cloud dragon questioned.

"I'm not disgraced because I am helping my family, and if you keep talking about them like that..." Kaage began.

"You're family?" the cloud dragon questioned.

"I was raised by humans," Kaage explained, "The young boy on my back is my nephew and the others are my nephew's new father and sister."

"Your family? You're a dragon! You're not a human. You're one of those freaks that think their humans. Many of you shadow dragon have those problems because you can turn into a human. You probably live with humans and take human form just so that they can accept you, is that right?" The dragon roared.

"I was abandoned by my true parents. I never even met them. Humans were the only ones that were kind enough to take me in and I can't stay here and listen to you talk about them like that and not do anything. So what if I live with humans. They are the only ones that have accepted me for who I am. I may be a dragon, but it was humans that took me in. I would..." Kaage started to yell

"What's going on here?" a voice called out. Both Kaage and the patrol dragon turned to see Dracus flying towards them.

"This shadow dragon and his human masters are trying to come into our territory and..." the patrol dragon tried to explain.

"Let them through, they are here to speak to me and my mate," Dracus ordered, "Lord Adam has something of importance to speak of."

The patrol dragon just snorted and flew back to his perch. "Follow me," Dracus commanded and Kaage followed closely.
1151212211221221211111211112221221211122.title: Uncomfortable Flight

1151212211221221211111211112221221211122.content:
If any of the other cloud dragons had issues with Kaage's presence, him following Dracus quelled their desires to speak about it. Felix smiled as he saw Dracus' cave approach and the large cloud dragon land and soon Kaage landed as well.

"Felix!" came a cry of happiness from inside the cave as Rathnait sensed her bond-mate approach. The forty foot tall dragon walked outside to greet her friends.

"Hi Rathnait," Felix said as he slid off his uncle's back. He helped his father and sister off as well. Ashley looked around at the dragon's home. But a snort from Dracus made them look up to him.

"Come in so we may talk," he said, leading the way. Rathnait walked near Ashley and Felix, used to doing so when she visited the town. Adam looked back to Kaage and saw an awkward expression on his face.

"What is it?" Adam asked quietly.

"I'm unsure if I should revert back to my human guise or not," Kaage replied, "I prefer being in human form because I'm used to it, but . . ."

" I think you should enjoy the time you have to be in your natural form," Adam said quickly, "It's not often you're in it and it might make this meeting go better if you don't change back." Kaage nodded his head.

"That makes sense," Kaage said, his worry dissipating and then followed the human lord into the cave.

As the last pair entered they heard Dracus informing his other children Felix's visit was not merely social when they wanted to ask him how life at the town was, Rathnait was the only child permitted to visit the town. Leading the group into the back area, Shanaye waited with a dark look on her face. Once the group had fully arrived, Shanaye spoke.

"So what are these lies that monster is spreading about us?" she asked in human tongue. Felix took a deep breath. He knew it would be best coming from him because of his closeness with the family.

"He is saying Lord Adam ordered a battalion of cloud dragons to destroy his keep and steal his land and property, that there was no just cause for such an attack," Felix said.

"One merchant told me one rumor he heard is that some of the slaves taken were used to feed the dragon force," Ashley spoke up. Shanaye immediately looked at Ashely with a deep look of disgust.

"Because of these rumors, the King my father and that man bow to has agreed to an audience so he may state his grievances and ask for retribution," Felix continued, drawing Shanaye's gaze back to him.

"What sort of ramifications could occur if he is believed?" Dracus asked in a cold voice.

"King Alfred could reinstate his title and lands and even strip me of my title and right to rule the city," Adam said, "And he could also agree to have men come and attack your people."

"Humans have a hard time attacking us," Shanaye replied curtly.

"True, but even the Imperial Army has means of fighting dragons. I'm sure you remember the powder they used to capture you Dracus," Adam replied. Dracus growled at the reminder of that incident.

"But we do have a plan to stopping him," Felix said.

"Kill him?" Shanaye asked.

"No, that would only solidify his claims," Adam said, "Felix is going to testify against these charges. But his word alone would only do so much against such rumors. He could be seen as just a former slave not wanting to return to his master."

"What else can you do?" Dracus asked.

"We were wondering if you'd agree to allow Rathnait to accompany us and testify as well, saying she was captured and it was that capture that led to your attack on his castle," Adam said, steadying himself for the anger.

"Of course not!" Shanaye replied loudly, her voice echoing off the walls, "We won't let her go and reveal that to an entire crowd of ignorant humans!"

"But mother!" Rathnait replied, "If it means his defeat . . ."

"No!" Shanaye replied.

"Shanaye, it will also be seen as what could happen to some ignorant human if they try and capture one of us," Dracus commented.

"You can't be serious Dracus?" Shanaye replied, looking at her mate.

"I am," Dracus replied, "But obviously you will not agree to her going alone. So, what if I accompany her?"

"You can't be serious! To let them know of that . . ." Shanaye started.

"The good of this community is more important than my own pride," Dracus answered, "Besides, Lord Adam has kept every promise with us. He has kept any slayer from using his city as a base. If he should be stripped of rank, we don't know who will come to power."

"It could even be William," Adam added, seeing Shanaye's eyes fill with even more anger.

"So mother, may I go?" Rathnait asked.
1151212211221221211111211112221221211122.title: Split on the Matter

choices: The next afternoon...
A few days later...
1151212211221221211111211112221221211122.content:
"When is your King going to let that evil little vermin audience with him?" Shanaye questioned.

"Sometime next week," Adam informed the large unsure dragon. "However, even if we fly to the King, it will take a while and we might have to leave tomorrow," Adam added knowing that Shanaye was wondering when Rathnait had to leave if she let her go.

"This is all a very short notice, Adam," Shanaye said, giving a small growl for her frustration, "You couldn't have told us all of this sooner."

"Unfortunately, rumors spreed faster than news, nowadays," Adam informed the dragoness, "I wasn't sure the rumors were even true till we got really news of the event. I'm sorry I left you two in the dark about this, but I didn't think it was possible for people to believe such a man as William."

Shanaye sighed and asked, "Who would be going on this journey?"

"Well, Felix would have to and I will go to show the King our treaty with your dragon clan. We did preserve the original contract thanks to Rhian," Adam stated. Felix was slightly shocked to hearing her name. She looked young yet she was apparently around when the contract between the cloud dragons and the people of the village was formed. Felix knew that she could wield magic, but he had no idea how old she truly was. She might be immortal for all he knew.

"And I will join them as well," Kaage spoke up for the first time in the cave, "I must make sure my nephew is safe. He has suffered enough torment when I was away from him, and I will not let that happen to him again. Plus, I can become human and travel with them and give them the protection of a dragon when no dragon can fit in the city." Adam nodded to show Kaage that he was welcome to come along.

"I wish to go too, father," Ashley told her father, "I know I can't help in the trails, but I wish to be with my friends in this dark time." Adam was reluctant, but he nodded his head again to show it was alright for Ashley to come along as well."

Shanaye looked at her mate and looked at him for advice or assurance. Shanaye still didn't want Rathnait to leave again and be so far away from the family. She was worried that Rathnait could be captured again and this time, Rathnait might be gone forever. "I understand your worry, for I'm worried too, Shanaye," Dracus informed her, "But Rathnait will be among friends on the journey. We have an alliance with them, and I'm sure they won't let any harm come to Rathnait. Rathnait will be far away, but she will be safe with them. Besides, if you allow it, I will go with them as well and keep her safe. She will not be captured again."

"It's not just that I'm worried about," Shanaye replied, "But she'll be going to a city where humans don't see dragons the way these humans do. You know that most humans don't believe dragons are sentient beings. There are humans that can't comprehend the fact that there are other creatures out there with intelligence. I'm worried some of those humans could be violent towards Rathnait because they'll thinks she's a monster or some demon because she can talk and they think dragons can't. There could be a whole range of dangers from going to a city with such ignorant humans."

"I will make sure our daughter is safe," Dracus assured his mate, "I will do whatever it takes to protect her."

There was a long hesitation as Shanaye thought about what she should do. She weighed out the possibilities of harm coming to her daughter by being so far a way with the pleasure destroying William's chances of ever coming back into power. It was a difficult decision and she didn't want to put her daughter in danger, but it was a risk that had to be taken to stop William for good and ensure the safety of the cloud dragons and the human village they supported. Shanaye sighed, "Rathnait, will go, but only if you go with her, Dracus. You need to promise me you'll keep her safe."

"You have my word, my love. I shall keep our daughter safe," Dracus replied as he nuzzled Shanaye affectionately.

"So, I can help stop William?" Rathnait questioned.

"Yes," Dracus answered. Dracus looked down at Lord Adam and questioned, "When do we leave?"

"It might be best to leave sometime tomorrow afternoon, unless that too soon for you," Lord Adam informed Dracus, "The capital is is far away and will take a few days to get there even if we fly."

"Then we will leave tomorrow," Dracus replied.

1151212211221221211111211112221221211122.content:
"Then we'll head back and prepare. I'll see you tomorrow," Lord Adam said, bowing deeply to both Dracus and Shanaye. They in turn nodded to him.

The preparations went well and the following day the six travelers set off. Kaage, after some persuasion from Lord Adam, chose to fly in his dragon form. During the travels, the human travelers would alternate between dragons, though only Lord Adam rode on Dracus and Felix was almost always riding Rathnait.

The group would travel well after dark, as it was easier because seeing the dragons at night was more difficult. With each time they rested, Dracus and Rathnait were educated on human politics and key things they were to know if things were to go well.

On the final night of their journey, they were finalizing their plans.

"So you will approach first and Felix will call Rathnait when we are to come?" Dracus asked, looking down at the humans.

"Yes, we will need to first get an audience with him and then we will inform him of our side of the story," Lord Adam said. Felix sighed and laughed in a low voice.

"What's so funny?" Rathnait asked, sensing something deeper.

"I was just thinking how if I still had my scars I would have more evidence to show what sort of monster William is," Felix replied. The others looked at him with a little shock.

"Don't say that Felix," Rathnait said, "I couldn't think of you bearing those wounds." She lowered her head and gently nuzzled her bond-mate.

"She's right," Ashley said, "We would have never guessed that this man would come to power once more. So there was no need for you to keep them." Felix looked at his sister and nodded.

"You're both right," Felix admitted. He gave another sigh. "I guess I'm just worried."

"Then we should rest so we are not worn out for tomorrow," Lord Adam said. Dracus agreed and Felix and Ashley put their mats near Rathnait to rest. Felix was near Rathnait because of their bond and Ashley because she felt safe near Felix. Kaage elected himself to stay up and keep watch. It had been many years since he was near another human civilization.

-------------------------------------------------------------

The next morning Lord Adam, Felix, Ashely, and Kaage walked the mile to the castle town as Dracus and Rathnait were soaring high in the clouds above them. As they reached the castle town gate, the guard recognized Lord Adam's coat of arms and sent a messenger ahead to alert the castle of the desire for an audiance with the King. He also called for a carriage to take them to the front gates.

"Father," Ashley said as she rode, "Do you think that man will have arrived by now?"

"I hope not," Lord Adam answered in a quiet voice, "It would be best to explain to King Alfred without William's presence. I doubt Rathnait could restrain herself from killing him for what he did to her." Adam looked to his son. "I expect you to keep yourself in control as well Felix," Adam said.

"I know how to behave myself Father," Felix said, not looking at his adoptive father. Under his skin he could feel his anger growl at the thought of seeing William again. Rathnait held a similar feeling. But he knew he could not lose his temper in front of the king. He could not become a wounded child raging against that man. He took a deep breath as the castle gates came into sight. He looked at the vast land between the inner wall and the castle. He smiled, knowing there would be plenty of room for both Rathnait and Dracus when they landed.

Meanwhile in the castle . . .

1151212211221221211111211112221221211122.content:
Before the carriage could arrive in the courtyard, they had to cross a large bridge with a not so wide, but very deep canyon that separated the castle from the capital. The metal gates rose up, revealing the opening where they could pass through the outer walls of the castle. Felix looked through the carriage's window to examine the courtyard. The courtyard was massive and Felix knew that Rathnait and Dracus would both fit in the courtyard together, despite Dracus's incredible size. "We haven't talked with the King yet about letting you join his audience, but it looks like the courtyard is big enough for you both to land in without much trouble when it is time to join us," Felix informed Rathnait with his bond, "Where are you and your father now?"

"We're on the same side of the canyon where the castle is," Rathnait answered, "That way, we won't have to fly above the town to get to the castle's courtyard, and it won't cause as big as a panic."

"You know townspeople will still probably see you guys land in the castle and get worried," Felix pointed out.

"We know, but at least we won't be swooping over the town before we land in the castle. Landing at the castle will be better since the castle is sturdier and won't fall apart from the wind from our wings," Rathnait stated.

When the carriage was parked, the door was opened by a servant of the King. When the four individuals got out of the carriage, the servant motioned them to follow him. They were lead to two large double. The double doors were the entrance to the castle and about fifty to sixty feet tall! Felix knew that Rathnait will be able to fit through the entrance, but Dracus would not. Though Rathnait was 15 years old in human years, she was still a child and in dragon years, she was about seven and a half years old. Rathnait was forty feet tall on all fours, and if a seven year old child was that large, adult dragons were over one hundred feet tall. Rathnait wouldn't get that large till she was thirty-two years in human years. No human doorway could ever fit Dracus.

When the doors were opened, they found themselves in a large waiting room like area. The only other doors leading out of the room lead farther into the castle which Felix believed lead to the main hall. That doorway was the same height as the other. "Rathnait, you'll be able to fit through the doors, but your father..." Felix started.

"I know," Rathnait interrupted, "I can see through your eyes now. Father feared he wouldn't be able to fit, but his head and neck can make it to the main hall, and that's good enough for him."

"I forgot we can now look through each other's eyes," Felix replied. it was a bond power they had both obtained on their way to the castle.

The servant turned to the group and stated, "The King is in a meeting right now, but if you tell me of your business with the King, I can tell him and if it is important enough, he will let you join."

"Tell him we are here to defend our case against Lord William's accusations," Lord Adam ordered.

The servant bowed and said, "I shall tell him why you are here, Lord Adam." The servant went through the large doors and they closed behind him and the four waited to be called in.

Kaage noticed Felix's nervousness and questioned, "Are you and Rathnait nervous?"

"Yes, both of us are worried that Lord William is in there," Felix answered.

"Take deep and calming breaths. Breathe in your mouth and out your nose and try to calm yourself. Tell Rathnait to do the same as well," Kaage ordered, "Your and her emotions leak into each other through the bond you have with her. This leakage can make you both feel the same way, and if you are both feeling the same way already, then it can lead to you both being controlled by your emotions. Nervousness can lead to frustration and anger which could make this situation dangerous."

Felix nodded and tried to calm himself down and he relayed Kaage's message to Rathnait. Eventually, the servant came back to tell them they could join the King's audience. The doors were pushed open fully and they entered the grand and enormous main hall where the throne was. They noticed King Albert was standing towards the center of the hall conversing with another man. That other man happened to be Lord William.

When the doors shut behind the four travelers, William and King Albert heard the sound and turned there attention to the new arrivals. Felix glared at William, though William wasn't staring at Felix. Felix could also feel his mind being contaminated by Rathnait's anger. "That monster must die. He must pay for what he's put us through," Rathnait growled in her mind.

"Rathnait, we must keep ourselves calm," Felix said, trying to defuse her anger.

"But what that man did to us..." Rathnait began to argue.

"We can't change the past, no matter what we do. Killing him now will only make us look like the bad guys. We have to prove to the King that William is the evil one and the King will make him pay," Felix explained.

"I'm sorry, Felix," Rathnait sighed, "But seeing that man through your eyes just makes me so angry. I can only imagine what it will be like when I see him with my own eyes."

"I understand. That man did many terrible things to us that we could never forget. I'm angry as well, but we can't let anger determine our actions for us. We must keep calm. We must be there for each other," Felix said.

"So, it's true. The traitors did decide to join," William said angrily as he noticed Lord Adam walk in.

"Lord Adam, there have been serious accusations against you and your father. Could you care to explain to me what is going on?" King Albert asked.

"I have already told you what those bastards did to me and..." Lord William started.

King Albert interrupted, "I must hear their side of the story as well."

"All you will hear from them will be lies. Though it is true that one must hear both sides to truly understand what is happening," William replied, obviously trying to stay on the King's good side.

"William says that you have actually tamed dragons and used them to attack his castle without reason! Is this true, Adam? Did your father actually tame dragons to do his bidding?" King Albert questioned.

"I see William left out the reason why he was attacked, but before I can successfully tell you the reason why he was attacked, I have to explain to you our relationship with the dragons. My father never tamed dragons. They can't be tamed. For one, their pride would never allow them to be tamed, and two, dragons are sentient beings," Lord Adam explained.

"Sentient beings?" King Albert asked.

"I know it is hard to believe, because dragons look like animals, but they do have intelligence," Lord Adam told the King.

"Please don't tell me you believe this rubbish," William spoke up, "Dragons are mindless and savage monsters. There is no way they could possibly have intelligence."

"I assume you have some sort of proof to back this claim?" King Albert questioned. King Albert didn't seem to believe that dragons were intelligent, and he couldn't be blamed for that. Humans were taught that dragons were monsters and weren't intelligent beings. Humans were taught at an early age that only things that looked human could be intelligent beings, (elves, dwarfs, fairies, and so forth.) Dragons had once tried to explain they weren't evil monsters, but since humans killed dragons out of fear, most dragons had given up on convincing humans and just let them be.

"I have brought three dragons that have agreed to come along with me," Lord Adam explained, "They can speak human and prove to you that dragons aren't mindless monsters."

"You brought dragons!" King Albert gasped.

"You see, he brought monsters to try and overtake the crown!" William hissed.

"My King, I did not bring dragons to attack you, but only to prove to you that dragons are not what you think. The dragons are safely away from the castle and will come if you welcome them so that they and defend themselves against William's claims," Lord Adam explained.

"To prove that they are reasonable creatures, I have brought a treaty that was formed between my city and the cloud dragons of the mountains," Lord Adam continued as he asked Ashley for the treaty she had been keeping safe.

"You formed a treaty with dragons?" King Albert questioned with much confusion and astonishment.

"For a long time, our city and its people feared the dragons of the mountains and we wouldn't go near them. The dragons just kept to themselves and thought that as long as we didn't bother them, they wouldn't bother us. As my father had once described to me, our people always feared a possible attack from the dragons, but the dragons never attacked, this was when they believed dragons were mindless animals," Lord Adam informed them, "When my grandfather was in charge of ruling the city, my father, a boy at the time, got lost in the mountains. A younger dragon found my father. Neither of them could speak each other's language and my father had told me how scared he was.

Lord Adam continued, "However, during that encounter, the dragon tried communicating with my father though gestures and got far enough to explain that my father was in no danger. My father soon trusted the dragon and the dragon brought my father back to the city unharmed. My father told his father everything and my grandfather eventually found where the dragons lived and found some knew English. A truce was eventually formed and they put it on paper. The dragons and humans decided to help each other out. We help by keeping dragon slayers from coming and they help us when ever we need it. Some friendships between dragons and humans had also been formed through this truce. The young dragon that saved my father is a family friend and is one of the dragons who had decided to come along."

Lord Adam handed King Albert the treaty and King Albert examined it. William looked over it as well and commented, "This treaty looks new. They could have wrote this down last night to try and complete the lie."

"It looks new only because it was preserved through magic. There is a woman, who is not entirely human, who knows much magic. Her name is Rhain and she's been in the city ever since it was formed long ago," Lord Adam explained.

"Besides, this is definitely your grandfather's signature," King Albert told Adam, "I've seen this signature before in the achieves. There is no doubting it."

"But if you have a treaty with them, you could have had them attack your enemies, and you could make them attack me," Lord William growled.

"I can't make the dragons do anything. They do what is in their best interest. If an army were to attack the city, they would help, but if the enemy isn't directly affecting us, we can't make the dragon's help us," Lord Adam explained.

"Then why did dragons attack William?" King Albert questioned.

"That is something you must ask the dragons that came here with me. They would better explain why William was attacked. If you let them land in the courtyard, the child dragon could fit in this room and her father could fit his head through the doorways," Lord Adam suggested.

"Bring dragons here!? I'm not sure if that is safe. I see this treaty you've made with the dragons, and I want to believe you, but..." King Albert started.

"If you may, your majesty, can I speak?" Kaage questioned.

"And who might you be?" King Albert asked.

"I am resident of Lord Adam's city and a friend. You have no need to worry about the dragons. They have given their word not to harm any humans on their travel unless it is to defend themselves. The dragons will not harm you," Kaage tried to assure the King.

"And how can you be so sure?" King Albert questioned.

"Because I am the third dragon Lord Adam mentioned," Kaage answered, "I know it sounds odd, but I'm a shadow dragon, a dragon that can take human form, among other useful abilities."

"We are to believe you're a dragon?" William laughed.

Kaage transformed into a dragon before their very eyes. However, he had the ability to change his size and didn't make himself his real height, only enough to reach the ceiling. King Albert and William looked up at the scary demonic looking dragon before them. "You see, my King, I am a dragon and if the dragons truly wanted to harm you, we would have done it by now. You can trust us. Please here what the dragons have to say about why they attacked William's castle," Kaage requested while bowing his enormous head to the King.
1151212211221221211111211112221221211122.title: Lord William is Present

1151212211221221211111211112221221211122.content:
King Albert gripped the side of his throne as the fearsome creature spoke. He watched it bow its large head in subserviance, like any of his subjects would. And his words held an apparent truth. If Lord Adam wished to take the kingdom, one dragon alone would be a force to recognized and feared. But this one was not harming him and was even bowing to him. Taking a deep breath,

"Are the other two dragons of your species?" King Albert asked in a firm voice.

"No, they are Cloud Dragons," Kaage said, "And it is wise to say I am different from most every other dragon as I was raised by humans since I was very young. So I consider myself human in heart and mind, but dragon of body."

"Lies," William was able to mutter.

"How so?" King Albert replied, looking at William.

"Being like that, it's impossible," William replied, "This is either a well trained dragon to mimic human mannerisms or it is a human using a mystical spell to appear to be a dragon." King Albert looked at William and then to one of Kaage's eyes.

"I do not believe that is the case. My cousin is one quarter elf and his grandmother, an elf, told me how she was a war orphan found by the family Rela and raised as their own. She described her self in similar words. Human in spirit and elven of body," King Albert said, he turned his gaze to Lord Adam. "You may bring the dragons into this chamber." Lord Adam smiled. "Alert the castle guards," King Albert said to his Captain of the Guards. The strong looking man, who had not flinched when he saw Kaage transform nodded and left in a hurry.

"Rathnait, you and Dracus may come down," Felix said.

"Excellent," Rathnait replied, "We are decending now." Felix gave a slight nod to his father.

"They are coming now," Lord Adam said. King Albert looked confused and looked to Kaage for a moment.

"How did you tell them this? Are you sending them the words of this meeting Shadow dragon?" King Albert asked.

"No your majesty," Felix said, stepping forward, "I am because of my bond with the child dragon."

"Your 'bond'? You speak of the exchange of powers and deep connection between two mystical beings, correct?" King Albert asked. Felix nodded.

"Yes, Rathnait, that is the child's name, and I have this bond. And we both have words to say about that, " Felix said, carefully omitting certain words from what he wanted to say, " . . . Man."

William looked on the boy who was speaking. His eyes seemed familiar. But a loud thud from the outside broke his concentration. King Albert looked to the second group of guests.

"Was that?" he asked.

"That was the parent dragon, Dracus," Lord Adam confirming the idea.

"His daughter is waiting for the front guards to move," Felix commented, "They are scared and confused about their sudden arrival."
