1151212211221221211111211112221221211122.content:
Captain Arik was a strong and well trained soldier. He was the King's most trusted General in times of war and the King's most trusted guard when there was no war. Since this was not a time of war, Arik was the Captain of the guards at that moment. King Albert would have liked Arik to be an adviser rather than a guard, but Arik insisted that war and killing was the only thing he would successfully be able to advise the King on. Therefore, Arik told the King that his advice was only good as a General during war or on the brink of war. King Albert was worried that giving such a noble and well qualified man the duty of Captain of the Guards would be demeaning, but Arik didn't feel it was demeaning at all.

Captain Arik walked quickly towards the doors. He hoped to get to the courtyard before the dragons landed so that he could keep the rest of the guards from attacking the dragons. It seemed strange to him that he would be telling his men to not attack the dragons. He, like, nearly all humans, was taught that dragons were just simple minded monsters that would attack a person on sight. He would have never believed it was possible that dragons could actually be as intelligent as humans, since dragons looked like fearsome monsters. Once he saw that human, or it appeared to be human, turn into a black dragon and speak before his very eyes and ears, Captain Arik began to believe it was possible.

"I've heard many tales that ended up being untrue. The stories of dragons being monsters could be true. When we humans see creatures that are large and scary looking, we tend to dub them as monsters and if they don't have humanoid form, we call them mindless beasts," Captain Arik thought to himself, "And when humans dub creatures as monsters, we kill them mercilessly. if all dragons are as intelligent as the black one, they must hate humans for what we've done. I'm glad I became a soldier instead of a dragon slayer. I would have been horrified if I killed an innocent creature without any reason other then it being a dragon."

Before Captain Arik could reach the doors, he heard a loud boom along with the ground shaking beneath him. "They must have landed," Captain Arik realized as he pushed open the doors leading to the courtyard. In the courtyard, Captain Arik found a sight he could have never imagined, a massive dragon easily over one hundred feet tall on all fours was in the courtyard. he had heard stories of dragons becoming very large, but he never would have dreamed they could get as large as the dragon in front of him.

Captain Arik couldn't turn his eyes away from the dragon until he saw movement in the corner of his eyes. Captain Arik looked on either side to see the guards meant to guard the main doors rising to their feet, looking at the massive dragon in shock. Arik looked to the walls and saw that the men on the walls were rising to their feet as well. "The wind from the dragons' wings must have knocked them all down. It was luckily that they were able to react in tome to grab onto something. Unless the dragons just landed extremely carefully," Captain Arik thought to himself.

Soon, he noticed the door guards raise their spears and the guards at the walls aim their arrows. Captain Arik inwardly feared the dragon would become savage and attack causing much trouble. Yet, the dragon just looked around, stood tall, and stayed calm. "Dragons are nothing like the stories," Captain Arik knew at that moment, "Well, they don't act like dragon from those stories, but they sure look like how they are described to be, massive beast-like creatures."

Before the guards could start attacking the dragon, which would have been a stupid thing to do however brave, Captain Arik commanded, "Hold your fire! Stay your weapons! The dragon is not to be harmed!" All the guards were confused by the Captain's order. The men on the wall lowered their bows slightly, but the men at the entrance kept their spears up with shaky hands.

"Sir! It's a massive dragon that just suddenly swooped down to attack us and..." one of the door guards started.

"This dragons did not come to attack us," Captain Arik explained, "The dragons came seeking audience with the King. The King has sent me out here to tell that the King has agreed to talk to the dragons." Captain Arik spoke up loud enough for all the guards to hear him.

"But it's a giant monster. It can't speak!" the guard argued.

The massive dragon opened its mouth and with a deep voice said, "You will find that I can speak your tongue quite well."

All the guard stared at the dragon in utter amazement once the dragon spoke. Captain Arik was the only one not fazed by the dragon's ability to speak. "The... the b-b-beast... s-s-spoke!" the guard gasped.

Captain Arik growled, "Dragon or not, this is the King's guest. Act respectively. You don't want to anger both a dragon and our king, do you?"

"N-no Sir," the guard quivered.

"Then begin opening the doors so the dragons can speak with King Albert," Captain Arik ordered. The guards turned to the doors and began opening them. The guards on the wall were still nervous, but returned to their duties. Many still kept an eye on the gigantic dragon. Captain Arik turned back to look up at the massive dragon before him and approached without fear or hesitation. Not only was it because Arik had listened to the previous conversation with the King and he had learned dragons were intelligent, but it was also due to the fact that Arik was a brave and hardened soldier and had little to no fear. Dracus admired the human's bravery.

Dracus lowered his head a little lower to be able to see and hear the human more clearly. "I apologize for the for your inconvenience. I tried to warn my men about your arrival before you got here."

"It is quite alright," Dracus replied, "I understand that most of your species fear us as monsters and I've come to expect such reactions. Though, you seem to be a much braver and more understanding human. it's always a pleasure seeing a human with a more open mind. I makes encounters much more peaceful. I am glad you arrived when you did."

"My King has allowed you to see him," Captain Arik informed Dracus. Captain Arik looked at the doors and them back up at Dracus and pointed out, "Though, I'm not sure you can fit through the doors."

"I believe my head can fit. Then I could stretch my neck into the main hall," Dracus informed Arik.

Captain Arik looked around, but didn't see the second dragon. "I was told that there would be two of you. Where is...?" Captain Arik began to ask.

"I am here," said a smaller dragon head as she peeked out from behind her father's wing. When the humans had got up to attack, Dracus had covered Rathnait with his wing to protect her Captain Arik gave a slight small seeing that the large dragon cared more about protecting his daughter than attacking humans.

"You I believe can fit through the doors," Captain Arik informed the younger dragon. She sounded as though she was about eight years old from her voice, though the voice was deeper due to the fact she was forty-five feet tall. "I will take you to my King and the rest of your companions," Captain Arik informed the dragons. Captain Arik walked to the doors and the dragons followed behind. Dracus had to wait for his daughter and the human to get through before he could lie down on his stomach and put his head through the doors and stretch it into the main hall.

Kaage transformed back into his human form and Captain Arik soon entered the main hall with Rathnait who walked very carefully behind him. King Albert was relieved to see that Rathnait wasn't as large as Kaage, but when Dracus put his head through and stretched it into the room till his large head was behind Lord Adam's group, King Albert looked at the massive head in shock.

"King Albert, these are the dragons we have been talking about," Lord Adam informed the King, "This is Dracus, the one who saved my father when he was a child, and his oldest daughter Rathnait."

"You really saved Micheal's life long ago," King Albert questioned, hardly believing such a massive creature could care about something as small as humans.

"I was younger, but yes. I couldn't just let him die in the mountains," Dracus answered, his deep voice filling the entire room.

"And you are the one magically bonded with this boy?" King Albert questioned Rathnait.

Rathnait kept her eyes focused on King Albert. She tried to keep her eyes from seeing William. She had herself calm and she wouldn't do anything stupid, but she feared that she would if she saw the man once again. "I am bonded with Felix, and I wouldn't have it any other way. Felix is a great friend," Rathnait answered.

King Albert noticed that Felix moved over so that he was beside on of Rathnait's front legs. Felix also was leaning on Rathnait's leg with one of his arms wrapped around as much of the leg as he could. Rathnait broke her eye contact with King Albert and gave Felix a small nuzzle before returning her gaze to King Albert. King Albert could tell Felix and Rathnait were close like most who were magically bonded.

"I understand that you dragons have a pact with Lord Adam and his city and that you're intelligent beings, but I still don't know the reason you attacked William and his castle," King Albert said.

"The reason begins with Felix and my daughter," Dracus told the King. All eyes turned to Rathnait and Felix.

"I ran away from home," Rathnait informed King Albert, "I wanted to live on my own, but I was too young and foolish. I was captured by humans and held prisoner. William was the own who kept me prisoner."

"Preposterous! Why would I want to capture a dragon?" William argued.

"I listened to your side of the story without interruptions," King Albert told William, "Now let me hear their whole story." King Albert turned back to Rathnait and told her, "Go on, child, continue your story."

Rathnait continued, "William threw me into a dungeon and chained me down. He thought I was a monster, and since I didn't know the human tongue at the time, I couldn't do much to convince him I wasn't a beast. William made his guards hurt me and he tried to tame me like I was some beast so that he could control me."

"Is that the reason your people attacked William?" King Albert questioned.

"My family didn't know where I was. That's not why they attacked the castle," Rathnait replied.

"I was one of William's slaves," Felix spoke up, "I was in charge of feeding and taking care of Rathnait. At first she thought I was the enemy as well, but when William beat me in front of her."

King Albert turned to William and asked, "Do you beat your slaves?"

Before William could say that it was a lie, Felix said, "He does whatever he can to make us obey him. He views us as only property. He rules by abuse and fear."

"I soon realized Felix was in the same situation as me, and tried to make friends with him.He taught me his language and we soon became good friends. He helped me escape the castle and we both flew back to my home," Rathnait said.

"But before they could reach us, I was getting worried and heard from Micheal of rumors of William capturing a young dragon. I flew there after Rathnait and Felix escaped. William captured me with sleeping gas. My clan attacked William's castle to save me and because of the inhuman things he did to my daughter," Dracus explained.
1151212211221221211111211112221221211122.title: Why the Dragons Attacked

choices: Felix chooses to ask for help finding the men who killed his parents
They are interupted by Arik and Kaage returning . . .
1151212211221221211111211112221221211122.content:
King Albert turned his head to ask William his response to these claims, but the man was no where to be found. The King's eyes widened in shock.

"Where is he?" Lord Albert spoke aloud.

"It seems everyone was focused on myself and my daughter and he took the chance to flee," Dracus said, his voice, deeper than when he last spoke. King Albert did not need to ask to know this dragon was angry about this. King Albert looked at Arik.

"Find him Arik. Bring him back alive," King Albert said. Arik nodded.

"Unharmed?" Arik asked. King Albert looked at him with a look the Captain knew all to well: No. Arik nodded and departed out one of the back servant entrances, likely one of the ones used by William. King Albert returned to his throne and sat down.

"This has been an enlightening day," King Albert said, before looking at Lord Adam. "The charges against you are dropped."

"And what about the lies he spread?" Lord Adam asked.

"I'll order a proclimation saying most of the truth of the events," King Albert said, looking to Dracus, "It will say the former-Lord William captured a young dragon and his lands were attacked for reasons stemming from that foolish action." Ashley and Felix smiled and Lord Adam bowed his head.

"Thank you your majesty," Lord Adam said. There was momentary silence when Felix noticed something.

"Kaage has disappeared as well," Felix said.

"He vanished the moment we realized that man escaped," Dracus said.

"What other powers does that Kaage have?" King Albert asked.

"He can become invisible to the human eye and move through solid objects," Dracus said, "Hence his species' name, Shadow Dragons."

"Then with it should be only a small matter of time before that traitor is found," King Albert said.

"He's a traitor?" Rathnait asked. She knew the man was evil and had done many things, but none seemed to prove he had committed treason.

"He lied to his King for selfish, manipulative reasons," King Albert replied, "Had I not learned the truth, I would have likely stripped Lord Adam of rank and given his lands to Lord William to govern. And he would then have once more tried to capture a dragon, leading to another attack from you and I would have ordered my army to kill you in retalliation. So his lie could have cost many lives, and all for his own gain. So he is a traitor." Dracus nodded as best he could, liking this king of the humans.

"I am glad it did not come to that," Lord Adam said, smiling.

"Agreed," Dracus said. King Albert looked to those before him.

"I am in your debt for revealing the truth of this matter to me," King Albert said, "If I can assist you in anyway, please don't hesitate to ask."

"Actually, I do have a request, your majesty," Felix spoke up.

"And what request request would that be my boy?" King Albert asked, encouraging Felix to ask the favor whatever it was.

"There are a group of people who want to kill Kaage and myself," Felix informed King Albert, "I would like you and all the lords under your command to keep an eye out for that group."

"And why would they be after you and the shadow dragon Kaage?" King Albert questioned, though he had a feeling he knew why the group wanted to kill Kaage.

"Kaage and I come from a kingdom far away from your home. It is there were this group of slayers live and work together to take down all the creatures they think are monsters," Felix informed the King.

"If this group is a group of monster slayers, then I understand why they would be after Kaage. Even though I know that Kaage isn't an evil monster that needs to be slain. I understand why others might think Kaage is, because he's a dragon. However, I don't know why that would possibly be after you," the King replied.

"Kaage is my uncle," Felix simply answered.

"Are... are you a shadow dragon too?" King Albert gasped.

"No, Kaage and I aren't related by blood. When my father and Kaage were younger, the met each other during a storm, because they had both taken shelter in a cave. Kaage didn't have parents to take care of him. He never knew what happened to them. Kaage was sad and lonely. My father was kind enough to erase his fear of Kaage and comfort Kaage in his time of need," Felix explained, "Eventually, my father's family adopted Kaage, despite Kaage being a dragon and raised them as their own. Kaage and my father became brothers and eventually become bonded with each other."

Felix continued the story, "After many decades of living, my father finally found a woman she loved and who was accept his brother being a dragon since Kaage and my father were nearly inseparable due to the long lasting bond. My parents had me, but soon the slayers discovered them. They viewed Kaage as a demonic beast and they don't believe in the magical bond. They thing the bond is the magical creature possessing the individual. They killed my mother and father. Kaage took me and cared for me as we escaped that kingdom, hoping the group didn't have more stronger branches in other kingdoms."

"If this is true, then how did you become a slave to William?" King Albert asked, astonished by the story Felix had told so far.

"Kaage feared they would follow us and he didn't think I was safe around him. The group knew what he looked like in both his dragon and human forms, but they had no idea what to look for for me. Kaage loved me as a nephew because of his brotherhood with my father and he also loved me as if I were is own child due to the bond he had with me father. He could never forgive himself is something happened to me because of him. So he gave me to a human family he thought would care for me," Felix finished his story, "But, he had no idea that family would decide to sell me into slavery for William."

Felix also added, "If the slayers find Kaage and I, we won't be the only ones endanger anymore. Rathnait and her family could be endanger from the slayers' wrath because their dragons and the bond I have with Rathnait. My new family would also be endanger too, just for taking care of me."

"I see," King Albert replied, "I will do what I can to keep these slayers out of my kingdom. I will tell the lords of the dragons' intelligence and hopefully we can make friends from other clans and species of dragons. Dragon slaying will be banned and only permissible if a dragon attacks first without cause or reason. They will have the same rights as humans in my kingdom and I will make it into a law so that dragons will be safe in my kingdom long after I pass. I will also to my lords of the group of slayers and to watch out for them. However, I don't know them too well and don't know what they look like, how they dress, or whether they have a symbol to represent their clan."

"Kaage knows more about the group than I do. When he comes back, he can tell you much more about them," Felix informed the King.

A few minutes earlier Kaage's eyes turned from Dracus onto the man who had hurt him. But the man was no longer there. His sharp eyes noticed a shadow fleeing down a servant's corridor and he held a deep growl, slowly becoming invisible and chasing after William.

-------------------------------------------------

The former-Lord was running scared. He knew he had to escape the castle to where lords sympathetic to him would aide him in hiding until they could take over the kingdom.

"I escaped before, I'll do it again," he thought as ran past servants into the stables. As he was about to escape, he heard a terrifying sound. The horses were screaming in fear and rearing up on their legs. William turned to see nothing behind him, but horses didn't usually react in such a way. But as he turned back to the exit, Kaage stood before him.

"Trying to flee worm?" Kaage asked, his voice cold and filled with a deep seeded hatred. William's eyes narrowed in fear.

"You think you can stop me?" William asked, reaching into his pocket. From a bag within, he threw a dust at Kaage, but Kaage moved back, avoiding it.

"You'll need to try harder if you want to hit me with that powder," Kaage replied, his face shifting into his draconic one, "And if you fail to strike me, I will kill you."

"I don't think so," William replied when he felt a cool blade cross his neck.

"That's my line," Arik commented, before looking at Kaage. "The king wants him alive," Arik informed the shadow dragon.

"I don't bow to your king," Kaage replied, becoming his full dragon form, taking up much of the entrance to the stable. The true form of Kaage caused the horses' fear to increase even more and they slammed against their stables. One broke free and slammed down behind Arik, causing him to release Willaim who ran forward, trying to get past Kaage in a small opening, but was quickly slammed down into the ground by Kaage's front claw.

"Kaage, don't kill him!" Arik ordered. Kaage snorted smoke from his nose

"It has been many years since I had human blood on my claws," Kaage commented.

"And you think that boy wants you to dirty them on him?" Arik replied, "He's scum, beneath even beggars for his crimes. Don't dirty your claws on him." Kaage's eyes went from Arik to Lord William.

"He's not to be killed?" Kaage asked.

"Correct," Arik said.

"Then I'll see you in the throne room," Kaage said, gripping William's cloak with his teeth and leaping into the air, with the former lord screaming for help. Arik sighed and walked out of the stables as the horses calmed down. He looked into the sky and saw Kaage high above with a figure of William in his teeth. Then the dragon started to come down at high speeds. Seeing he didn't have much time, Arik ran to the entrance.

"Lord Dracus, would you lift your neck up a small way?" Arik called out to the large dragon blocking the entrance. Slowly the head moved upward granting him a passage way.

----------------------------------------------------

"Arik is coming this way," Dracus informed the throne room as he moved slightly. There was silence as Arik entered with a slouched head.

"Captain Arik," King Albert called out, "Where is the traitor?"

"Coming your highness," Arik said as a a loud scream penetrated the room. Suddenly Kaage became visible and threw the frightened man to the ground. Arik moved in and called for his men to enter and take the former lord. Kaage growled before shifting back into his human form. He walked over to Felix.

"He's lucky to be alive," Kaage muttered, watching the men taking Willaim to the dungeon. The former lord dared not look at the other dragons in the room.

"Kaage, King Albert has agreed to help us look for the men who killed mother and father," Felix replied. Kaage looked at Felix, then the King.

"Are you serious?" Kaage asked.

"Yes, all it would take is your knowledge of what they look like," King Albert replied.

"Then I will tell you what I know," Kaage replied.

"Again, I apologize about not being able to invite Dracus and Rathnait to dinner, but there is simply not enough room at the table for them and it would take a lot of food to fill them," King Albert apologized.

King Albert, Lord Adam, Kaage, Felix, and Ashley were all seated at the table in the dinning room. Like most of the castle, the dinning room was very large, but the doorways weren't as big as the entrance doors. So, even if this room were to be big enough for Rathnait to fit, the doorway wasn't big enough to get her in the room. The table they seated at was very long and had many seats. Felix inwardly wondered if it was ever used to its full capacity and whether the people at the end would even be able to hear the people on the other end of the table. King Albert was at the head of the table. On the side of the table that was the King's right was Lord Adam and then his daughter Ashley. Across from Lord Adam was Kaage and Felix was across from Ashley. King Albert had no family. This has brought some tension in the past about who would become King after Albert is gone, but King Albert, although fairly old in age, is still fit and healthy.

"Don't worry, you majesty," Felix assured the King, "They understand completely. Besides, I think they prefer to hunt the food for themselves. They're very proud creatures."

"Not as prideful as fire dragons though," Kaage commented.

"So, there are other species of dragons other than Cloud Dragons and Shadow Dragons. What are these Fire Dragons like?" King Albert questioned.

"If you're lucky, you will never have to meet one. They aren't known for forgiving and gentle nature. They are war like and nearly all of them hate humans as well as other species of dragons. Especially the species that are kind to humans, like Shadow Dragons, Forest Dragons, Gold Dragons, and most Water Dragons and Silver Dragons. They believe they are the strongest of the dragons and are very stubborn about their beliefs. One could say they are infected by their high pride. The only thing that can compare to them are the Spartan humans. Who heard of them, I presume," Kaage explained.

"I have. These sound like dragons I don't wish to met," King Albert said.

"They don't make deals or contracts with humans. They see them as weak insects that need to be killed. They only way you'd find a good fire dragon is if it is outcasted because it's considered weak, and somehow survives on its own," Kaage replied.

"How many species of dragons are there?" King Albert wondered.

"I know of at least twelve species, but I'm sure there are more types in other lands that I have not ventured," Kaage answered, "I do not sound to be rude, my King, and I don't want to offend you, but I thought you wanted to know about the people that are after Felix and me."

"You're right, Kaage of the Shadow Dragons, business comes first," King Albert agreed, "It's just that I could have never dreamed to actually be talking to a dragon. I had been taught that dragons were just animals. Now I've learned that dragons are sentient. This is all so fascinating," King Albert informed the Shadow Dragon.

"It's alright," Kaage assured the King, "I have encountered similar curious humans."

"So, what can you tell us about your pursuers," Lord Adam asked Kaage to keep the subject going.

"I don't know as much about them as I want to know, but they are a organization of monster hunters. They discovered the potential of working together and realized that taking down creatures was easier with a group of hunters rather than a single one. They do the same thing as normal monster slayers and go around the lands hunting monsters," Kaage informed them, "I do not know how many lands they have spread, but I know the organization it numerous. Just as numerous as a religion."

"That many hunters working together?" King Albert gasped.

"They must have a base of operations somewhere to keep their more outward groups together, but I am unsure where that base is. They are constantly encouraging new monster slayers to join them to keep their numbers up," Kaage continued, "They are merciless and kill everything they believe is a monster. Once they see something as a monster, they deem it and its species as a monster. There is nothing the creature would be able to say or do. There is no changing this organization's mind. Once you are considered a monster, you will always be a monster in their eyes. They will also kill anyone who helps the 'monster'."

"What do this slayers look like?" King Albert asked.

"There is no specific race, because they obtain any one they can find. They don't have a uniform armor, for some prefer light and some prefer heavy armor. Each hunter has their own style. This keeps their attacks unique. Therefore, if a monster defeats one group, the next group will be very different. There is only one way to tell they are part of the group. They are required to have a tattoo of the organizations symbol to show their loyalty to it. There is not required place to have it, so it can be under their clothing," Kaage told them, "So, it is very difficult to spot them. They could easily have already infiltrated this land."

"I will just have to ban dragon slaying and have a any other sentient creatures that we might be able to make treaties with. This will keep the authorities keeping an eye on monster slayers," King Albert explained.

"There is one more thing," Kaage stated, "When a group is assigned to kill a monster, that group has to keep hunting it till they defeat it. It isn't until they are killed that a new group is assigned to the creature. I didn't kill the group that killed my brother and his wife... Felix's parents. Therefore, that same group is still after me. I saw through the eyes of my brother when he was killed. I know exactly what the leader of the group looks like."

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- --------------------------------------------------------

The former Lord William sat in the prison cell thinking about how King Albert would kill him. He had been so close to winning the favor of King Albert and quite possibly the ability to rule after his death, but now it was all foiled by the very dragon he had captured as well his own child slave. William clenched his fists, growling at the fact that a slave child had tampered and shattered his plans. Now he was locked in a cell and chained to the walls very much like the same treatment he gave the dragon when he had it captured. "How can it end this way?" William wondered.

William heard footsteps approaching the cell as they collided with the stone floor. William didn't even look up. He expected it to just be a guard. The footsteps stopped in front of William's cell and just stayed where they were. "Leave me alone," William growled when the guard didn't leave.

"I have come to ask you questions," a deep voice said.

William looked up and saw that this was no guard. The man wasn't dressed in any armor and had only two daggers. He was a big man with a bald head and looked to be in his forties. "You're not a guard, who are you?" William asked, "What are you doing here?"

"I've heard about how you were attacked by Cloud Dragons. I came to see you because I'm looking for a particular dragon. I have heard he has come to this land and is seeking refuge somewhere. I'm talking to everyone with information about dragons," the man stated, "When I arrived, I heard that you have been imprisoned. Why have you...?"

"The King has taken the dragons' side and claimed I'm a traitor to the kingdom," William informed the man.

The man growled, "If I was on this assignment, the King would perish for siding with monsters."

"What do you mean by assignment?" William asked.

"I work for an organization of monster slayers. I am on a different assignment and can't take another until it is finished. I am after a Demon Dragon that can take human form. It has been taking care of a human and might have possessed him by now like it did with its previous victims," the man answered, "The dragon calls itself Kaage. Have you heard about this dragon?"

"He's looking for the shadow dragon that caught me! He doesn't know he's here right now!" William thought, "I can use this to my advantage. If I tell him where this dragon is, he'd just leave me here. But if I tell him I know and agree to tell him once he frees me, I can use him to my advantage. I could..."

"Do you know this dragon?" the man asked once again.

"I do know about the dragon of which you speak, but in order for me to tell you, you must free me from this cell and out of this city where I'd be safe. Only then will I tell you where the dragon is," William said.

The man didn't care about the conditions William brought to the table. he had been searching for Kaage for nearly ten years and to finally have a trail once again brought him relief. The man released William and began bringing him out of the city.

When the guards find William missing from the cell...

A few minutes before, the three guards watched the sole entrance to the dungeons. Normally there would only be one, but considering who was being held, Captain Arik felt it wise to make sure no supporters made it by. But as the three stood, something seemed to move past them, but they dismissed it simply enough.

"I hate it when a draft comes down here and stirs the dust," one guard said. His comrades said nothing, their eyes forward looking when they heard the snapping of metal echoing from within the dungeons.

"What was that?" the second guard noted.

The lone guard walked down the path and saw the door to the former lord's cell open and he was walking out towards a strong looking man, strong enough to go evenly against his captain.

"Stop right there!" the guard called, looking at the pair. The former-lord's eyes narrowed when he saw the guard present. The man was unflinching and in a swift motion threw a dagger into the guard's chest, causing him to drop to the floor.

"This is unexpected," the man said, as the sound of other footsteps came rushing down. One of the guards had come rushing in while his partner went to call for help. The lone guard saw his comrade and looked to see who had done it, but it was too late as the monster hunter had used the moment of shock to close in and injury his foe, but not before the guard pulled out a dagger and scratched the man's arm in a vain attempt to fight the superior fighter. With two guards laying dead, William walked forward.

"I could have used a man like you earlier in my life," he mumbled.

"And why aren't we running?" William asked.

"Because right now, they won't be able to see us by means of a magic trinket I have," the man said, "But they can hear us, so stay quiet." William wanted to yell back he was not to be ordered around, but he knew to well you don't attack a person trying to save you. You wait until the threat has passed for that time.

1151212211221221211111211112221221211122.content:
Kaage was in his dragon form flying above the capital invisible to the human eye. If William and the one who helped him escape were truly using some kind of magic to make them invisible, Kaage was confident in his abilities in finding the wicked human. The capital was large though, so Kaage searched it in sections. In each section, he'd scan it with his normal vision which was the same kind of vision humans had. Then Kaage would change his vision, like nearly all dragons could do, to a different vision that all dragons had. That vision could see the heat of living creatures. Only the more advanced dragons could switch between these two visions. The more primitive dragon-like creatures such as wyverns, benhirs, etc. only had the vision that saw heat. Also, primitive doesn't mean that they're all savage. It just means it's rare to find a sentient being in the "primitive" species of dragons, but it is possible to have one that is sentient.

Kaage examined the sections and kept track of how many humans were in the section when he scanned with his normal vision. If William and the other person was truly invisible, then they wouldn't show up in his normal vision, but would appear in his heat vision. Therefore, if he found an extra human in the second vision, it would most likely be William or William's partner. It was much harder to do this for the busier streets, this was the capital of the kingdom after all, but Kaage was a quick and observant creature and managed well enough.

Unfortunately, Kaage found no traces of an invisible person, let alone two. "How is this possible? They couldn't have escaped the capital already, there wasn't enough time to do so. But if they haven't escaped, how could I have missed them?" Kaage wondered as he hovered over the last section of the capital he had searched.

Kaage soon fell into denial as he thought, "He has to be in the city still! I have to find that little bastard!" Anger swelled up in Kaage. He couldn't let William and his accomplice escape. Normally, Kaage wouldn't bring himself to harm a human being. Not only were they sentient being that needed to be respected and beings that had their own rights, but Kaage felt closer to the human race than his own species. He was raise by humans when his own kind didn't do anything for him. However, Kaage would make an exception for the former Lord William. The human had done terrible things and was the second most evil creature Kaage had encountered. Plus, William had done some of those terrible deed to his nephew who felt like a son to Kaage due to Kaage's brother's feelings still deep in Kaage's mind through the magical bond they had shared for an extremely long duration of time. William was one of the few humans that Kaage would gladly slash to shreds.

Kaage flew over the city in the desperation of trying to find William and the one who might have helped him escape the cell, but he found nothing. "There's no one using invisibility magic," Kaage muttered as he flew over the capital for the third time. "But how could this be. William is known to the humans. He would have to use invisibility magic to make it out of the city without being captured."

Suddenly, a familiar scent wafted up to his snout. Kaage snapped his head in the direction of the scent. It was a recent scent that Kaage had recorded in his memory, and after what the man had done to his nephew, Kaage would remember William's scent until the human was dead. Kaage tilted his body and turned towards the scent. "Why didn't I notice that scent before? Was I too distraught and missed it?" Kaage questioned as he landed. Kaage made his large dragonic body passable by every object except the ground itself. That way, he could stay in his dragon form without having to worry about where he stepped and blocking human progression. Kaage sniffed William's scent and focused on only that scent through the hundreds of scents that clouded the area. As Kaage followed the scent, he kept his head low to the ground and many humans past through him, not knowing that he was even there among them.

Eventually, Kaage found himself at the main entrance of the city. "How did he get past the guards?" Kaage questioned, "They had to have been invisible to slip right past them, but I combed the city vigorously. I couldn't have missed them."

Kaage continued to sniff the area and discovered something familiar. Kaage smelled another scent in the area that was familiar and not William's. "What is that?" Kaage wondered. Kaage focused on that scent trying to drive away all the others that contaminated the well used entrance to the capital. Through the hundreds of scents that blanketed the area, Kaage was able to focus on the single scent and smell it clearly. Kaage's eyes widened in shock and surprise. "It... It's him!" Kaage gasped in his mind.

Kaage took off and flew as fast as he could to the castle. Kaage had a feeling that he knew why he couldn't find William. If the man who helped William escape was the man Kaage thought he was, then he would have been able to hide them from his vision: the metal. It had to do with the metal that shadow dragon's couldn't past through. The man who was hunting him had armor of that metal and a way to make himself invisible. Not only could Kaage not pass through that metal, but it distorted his dragon vision as well. The man could be invisible to Kaage on both visions!

As the Captain looked behind himself, his men were preparing William with a horse of one of their fallen comrades. They were also giving William some spare light armor made from the specific metal that kept them invisible to shadow dragons. "We're bringing him with us," the Captain told is comrade.

"Sir, this man is sneaky and I don't think he should be trusted. We should have just killed him right then and there," Nicholas replied.

"I gave my word that if he gives me good information, I'd free him," the Captain informed Nicholas, "He may have told us where the demon dragon lives. If we kill him and find out that he wasn't lying, then I would have broken my word for nothing."

"And if we get there and it turns out he's lying?" Nicholas questioned.

"We'll demand that he tell us better information or we'll kill him. It's as simple is that," the Captain replied, "But I have a feeling he isn't lying. He's is wrongly a fugitive and desperately needs are help."

"Why do you think he was wrongly accused?" Nicholas asked.

The Captain explained, "He used to be a lord, but cloud dragons attacked him and another lord, a man who seems to have some sort of pact with these cloud dragons, took all his servants away and replaced the lord with another ruler. Now the King calls this man a traitor for trying to tame one of those beasts. I wouldn't think of trying to train a dragon, since I would never be able to trust such a monster. However, dragons are just animals and if that can be successfully tamed, than they should. It would be one less dragon to kill."

"So, he was trying to train a dragon, probably one of the cloud dragons which was why the cloud dragons attacked him. However, how can the other lord have a pact with the dragons?" Nicholas asked.

"Maybe the lord and a few others in the town are being possessed. This town we speak of is where the shadow dragon supposedly lives. Maybe they even got to the King," the captain answered.

"Are we going to have to cleanse this town as well?" Nicholas asked.

"Only if we have to in order to kill the shadow dragon. Remember, our mission is the shadow dragon and nothing else at this moment. We may have to send word to the elders and others will probably be given such a mission," the Captain informed.

"There are so many crazy things happening right now. A cloud dragon clan may or may not be possessing a whole town of humans which have attacked this man for taking one of their own and trying to tame it and now the King here is siding with the cloud dragons and the town. Now this former lord says that our shadow dragon just so happens to live in the town that had ruined his lordship," Nicholas stated.

"I know how it sounds, but I think he's telling the truth," the Captain replied.

"There is another side to those who are desperate," Nicholas pointed out, "You said this man was desperate. How desperate is he?"

"We will keep an eye on him, but he is not to be harmed unless there is reason to harm him. We are monster slayers, not murderers. We only kill humans if it is self defense or if there is reason to do so, such as possessions. Though he had lied to me and didn't tell me the whole truth until I got him out of that cell, he hasn't shown any signs of lying now," the Captain explained.

"I will keep an eye on him, though," Nicholas said.

Back at King Albert's Castle, Kaage and the others try thinking of a plan...

1151212211221221211111211112221221211122.content:
In the throne room, before the king,, was now a large map of his kingdom and some of the surrounding lands as well.

"Let us assume for the moment the slayers are not coming to this castle," King Albert said as he looked at the map.

"I am certain of it, your Majesty," Felix commented. "It would be for William's benefit to not lead them back here if they are no longer in the city."

"Do explain your idea," King Albert replied.

"My Uncle Kaage told me how these men were violent pursuers and would hate to lose any ground in their hunt," Felix replied, "By telling him Kaage was in the castle after they left would have made them get further away for William's personal gain. I doubt they would like that." King Albert nodded.

"Wise words," King Albert replied, "So then the question becomes of their destination. I feel it will be your lands, Lord Adam." Adam nodded.

"I had a feeling about that as well," Lord Adam replied, "But it will take them at least a week and a half to get there on horseback. Even if they push their horses to the limit. But with Rathnait and Dracus' aid, we will beat them there by several days." He began to rise.

"I have not dismissed you, Lord Adam, so take your seat once more" King Albert ordered. Lord Adam slowly sat back down. The King looked at his other guests. "Fanatics these slayers maybe, but stupid are they not. They obviously plan their strikes out carefully. Assuming William told them you were heading back to your land, they will need to take any information they could from William about your lands and town's defenses. So they will be on the ready."

"They will know we at the castle know of William's escape, but not the means," Arik commented, "They will not know if our messenger hawks could travel that far and fast in telling you of the escape."

"So they really are assuming a lot about their plan, aren't they?" Ashley asked.

"Especially considering William has never visited my castle or town," Lord Adam said.

"So we will use this precious time to formulate some plan of action," King Albert said. He looked at Lord Adam once more. "You know your land best for defense, but I would like to make a suggestion and request." His face turned to Dracus.

"You ask something of me?" Dracus asked.

"These men may fall prey to a trap by their own hatred, if they saw a dragon outside the town being accepted," King Albert began.

"I understand the suggestion, but that would require me discussing the issue with the other adult dragons where I live," Dracus responded quickly. King Albert nodded.

"Thank you," King Albert replied. His eyes stared at a southern part of the map. "In the southern part of my kingdom, . . ."

Choice 1: There is rumors of earth dragons in the canyons. King Albert would like to try and make peace with them, if they are there.

Choice 2: One of William's supporters, Lord Rileth, destests any non-human creature. King Albert plans on investigating him to see if he has connections to the slayers.

1151212211221221211111211112221221211122.content:
"I have heard rumors of Earth dragons in the canyons," King Albert informed the group.

"How will that help us?" Rathnait asked. She was lying on her stomach close behind Felix and Ashley's chairs.

"William is going to warn the slayers about whatever he can. They will expect to find cloud dragons and of course Kaage. They wouldn't except any other kind of dragon. Especially if they truly believe dragons are mindless beasts," King Albert stated.

"I see your plan," Lord Adam commented, "Earth dragons will catch them by surprise. They must have a strategy for each type of dragon. They wouldn't have a strategy plan involving Earth dragons."

"You don't know much about Earth dragon," Dracus informed the humans.

Everyone turned to the enormous dragon head that was in the room with them. "We know very little about dragons. Will there be a problem with making peace with Earth dragon?" King Albert asked.

"There are many different species of dragons and each have their own beliefs and personalities. Earth dragons are very different from us cloud dragons," Dracus began explaining, "Earth dragons live deep underground and many are born without wings. An even greater number are born blind, but they can all see be sensing the slightest vibrations in the Earth. They can not breath fire."

"The main problem will be finding them," Dracus continued, "They are live deep in the Earth and live together as a pack. However, they are reclusive of the rest of the world. Their reclusive nature is another problem."

"So, we might not convince them to fight?" Arik questioned.

"They are not as passive in nature as Forest dragons, but Earth dragons don't like to be involved with other people's problems. They like to keep to themselves and to their own community. This could make it troublesome to have them fight for you to stop the slayers," Dracus answered.

"Could be some way of convincing them?" Felix questioned.

Kaage, who had been silent for the longest time, spoke up. "Is there a human town near the canyons?" he asked the King.

"Yes, that's how rumors of Earth dragons started," King Albert answered.

"Maybe be can convince the Earth dragons to see that human town as a part of their community," Kaage suggested, "Despite their reclusive nature, they are almost as peaceful as forest dragons and don't harm humans unless needed."

"But how do we convince Earth dragons to view humans as part of their community?" Dracus questioned in disbelief.

"I'm not sure, but think about it. If we could do that, they'll realize that the human town is part of a bigger human community, and they'd become part of that on their own branch. They will feel the need to help any of those branching communities if they need help. They will want to help Lord Adam's home and city from these slayers," Kaage explained.

"He only problem is convincing them in the first place to see that town as part of their community," Dracus replied.

"It's still worth trying, isn't it?" Kaage said.
1151212211221221211111211112221221211122.title: Earth Dragons

choices: "Are you here to kill them like that group who went through yesterday?"

1151212211221221211111211112221221211122.content:
Dracus said nothing for a moment. Part of his reluctance on the matter was a dislike of asking for aide from other dragons he did not know, without even consulting his clan first. But from what Kaage had said of the slayers, King Albert had a point. They needed surprise to help them win.

"It is worth trying," Dracus concluded. King Albert nodded.

"But given this will put us farther from my lands and we'll still need to travel back there, we should not spend too much time if the dragons don't wish to be found," Lord Adam noted.

"Good point," King Albert said, before looking at Arik. The Captain moved forward with paper and a candle. King Albert took the paper and signed it before dribbling some wax on the paper and pressed one of his rings into it.

"What's he doing?" Rathnait asked Felix by their connection.

"His ring has his personal seal. What ever was written now holds his official backing," Felix answered as Arik took the paper, rolling it and sealed it with more wax and handed it to Lord Adam.

"My Liege?" Lord Adam asked when the letter was given.

"It reads the Cloud Dragons on your land are not to be harmed," King Albert replied.

"We are apt at defending ourselves," Dracus commented. King Albert did not look phased by this comment.

"I acknowledge that. My words here signify I accept the treaty you have with Lord Adam and endorse it. And when you are traveling to aide this country, you have my protection from any slayers like how Lord Adam does not allow any slayers to use his lands," King Albert answered. Dracus shifted his head slightly to nod in understanding.

"I suggest we head out now," Kaage said, "It would be the best use of what time we have."

"Are you able to fly a long ways tonight?" Lord Adam asked Dracus.

"I am more than able," Dracus responded. He looked at his daughter.

"I am as well father," Rathnait answered.

"Then I wish you best of luck in this trip," King Albert said standing, "I will look into the slayers from my end and find out what else I can about them."

"It was a pleasure meeting you, King Albert," Dracus said.

"And to you as well, Lord Dracus," King Albert replied. Dracus pulled his head out of the doorway so Rathnait could exit with Felix and Ashley. Lord Adam and Kaage were the last ones to leave.

"Which way are we headed?" Dracus asked as he watched Kaage shift into his dragon form and Lord Adam mounted him.

"I saw the map. I'll lead," Kaage said. Dracus nodded and soon the three dragons were off into the night sky.

It was not a long trip to the southern canyons where the earth dragons were said to live. The three dragons pressed on through the night and through the morning, finally seeing the canyons around midday. Close to a mile away was a human village.

"Let's land and find out what we can from the village first," Lord Adam suggested to Kaage. He nodded and landed several hundred feet from the village. Dracus and Rathnait followed soon after him.

The sight of three dragons flying and landing near the village was unseen by many of the villagers, causing many to raise the alarms and called for the local guards to defend the village. Though many felt a small ban of forty men against three powerful monsters would not likely survive. When they saw humans around the dragons, the captain of the men, Captain Peter, moved a head of his men.

"You there! What is your reason for coming here?" he called out. One man looked at him, and began closing the distance between them. The other two humans stayed near the dragons.

Lord Adam stopped about twenty feet from the captain. "I am Lord Adam from the northern ranges," Lord Adam said, "I come on a mission from the King." Captain Peter was visibly shocked. He had heard rumors of the Dragon Lord, as some called him. A man capable of taming the wild dragons in the north.

He has come for those ones in the canyons? Peter thought.

"I am Captain Peter. What is your mission Lord Adam?" Peter called back.

"I seek to find out about the rumors of Earth Dragons in those canyons. What can you tell me?" Lord Adam asked.

"No one has seen one alive, but we have seen trails and other signs," Captain Peter replied.

"What sort of signs?" Lord Adam asked.

"Well, about six months ago, we were under attack by a small band of kobolds," Peter replied. Adam nodded, knowing about the little creatures that stood close to three feet tall and were vicious scavengers and raiders. One had to be sure to kill them all or they would come back in time. "But one day, the raids stopped. A scout told me he found their nest, destroyed by rock that seemed to come straight from the ground up. He also found dragon foot prints in the region. My guess is the little devils attacked the dragons and they responded."

"But have you ever had any trouble from them?" Lord Adam asked. Captain Peter shook his head.

"No, they have never bothered us, or even the traders who come through the canyons," Captain Peter replied. He paused a moment before asking
1151212211221221211111211112221221211122.title: Rumors and Aide

choices: Captain Peter accepts the plan.

1151212211221221211111211112221221211122.content:
"What it is that you want with them, sir?" Captain Peter asked. Captain Peter was nervous now. He had heard rumors about Lord Adam being able to train dragons. If Lord Adam wanted to find the earth dragons and gain control of them like he did with the cloud dragons, who know why he wanted them. Captain Peter noticed the black dragon among the three dragons and assumed that Lord Adam had trained other species of dragons as well. He wondered why Lord Adam would need such power. If he was anything like the former Lord William, then what could all this mean.

Captain Peter's mind was swarming with thoughts and concerns of danger as he waited for Lord Adam's answer. Lord Adam must have seen the concern, because he replied, "What have you heard about me?"

"Only rumors about you being able to tame dragons," Captain Peter answered. He didn't tell Lord Adam of the more sinister rumors of what Lord Adam could want from training dragons or how he was able to tame them. "Is that what you want to do with the earth dragons?"

"We need their help," Lord Adam stated, "There are some highly skilled monster slayers heading to my town wanting to kill a friend and they are ruthless and would kill anyone who gets in their way. Having earth dragons on our side would catch them by surprise."

"Why do monster slayers want to kill a friend of yours?" Captain Peter interrogated. He wondered if the slayers had good reason to attack.

"My friend is a shadow dragon. They fear that shadow dragons are demon, based upon their looks. They thought that the shadow dragon possessed a human. They don't understand what a magical bond is and thinks it is evil," Lord Adam explained.

"Are you bonded with that shadow dragon?" Captain Peter questioned, wondering if that's how Lord Adam was able to tame dragons.

"No, but he was bonded with a human he viewed as his brother."

"So, you want to tame the earth dragons to protect the shadow dragon. You don't have some other intentions?"

"I understand you're worry, but I have no evil intentions in using the dragons for power. As for taming dragons, you would find that is quiet impossible to do."

"Because of their ferocity?" Captain Peter asked.

"No, because dragons are just as sentient as humans," Lord Adam informed the captain, "Some have the ability to speak human. All they have to do is learn the words."

Captain Peter was completely surprised by this revelation. "Dragons are sentient?" Captain Peter gasped.

"Yes, that's how my father long ago and my grandfather were able to make peace with the cloud dragons of the mountains," Lord Adam explained, "We were able to make a treaty with them. We agreed to never house monster hunters and they in turn would not attack us and help us whenever we were in dire need."

"But you don't think the cloud dragons are enough this time?"

These hunters are skilled from what I've been told. They will know about the cloud dragons and will be prepared for the shadow dragon as well as any cloud dragon that should choose to fight. They wouldn't be expecting earth dragons," Lord Adam said.

How do you plan on getting their help?"

"Earth dragons are communal creatures and live in packs deep underground. They are reclusive in a sense that they only keep to their own pack or other Earth dragon pacts."

"Is that why they haven't ever bothered us?" Captain Peter asked.

They don't bother those sentient being outside of their own pack. They believe the we'll leave you alone if you leave me alone theory. Since you're town and the merchants have never bothered them, they've pretty much ignored your town, but this makes it difficult to get them to help. They're not going to help us if they see us as outsiders," Lord Adam informed him.

"How do you plan to get their help then?"

"We're going to try and get the earth dragons to see your town as part of their community," Lord Adam explained, "If we can do that, we can make peace with your town and the earth dragons, even if nothing violent has ever happened between you two. If they see you town as part of their community they would have to veiw the rest of the human kingdom as such too because how our community works and will have to come to my town's aid."

Captain Peter was blown away by Lord Adam's words. It was shocking enough to hear that dragons were actually sentient, but now, Lord Adam planned to make peace with the earth dragons and their small town. As Captain Peter thought about everything that had just been revealed to him, Lord Adam asked, "Where is your lord? Since this plan is going to have an affect on your town, your leader should have some say in it."

"We don't have a lord in this small village," Captain Peter explained, "But if you're looking for the leader of this village, it would probably be me. I act as the mayor and Captain of the guard."

"Then do you accept this plan?" Lord Adam asked.

1151212211221221211111211112221221211122.content:
"If it is going to bring peace with the earth dragons and us, then I agree with it. Though they have never attacked us, there have been frightened citizens in our village. If we can make a treaty like you have done with the cloud dragons, then those people won't have to be so frightened all the time. It should bring relief to our village."

"That is good," Lord Adam replied.

Though I do have one condition," Captain Peter told Lord Adam, "I wish to come alone on your journey to find the earth dragons. I will have to explain to the village and calm them down first, though. Three large dragons landing so close to our village have scared many people."

"I understand," Lord Adam replied, "I will wait for you by the dragons." Lord Adam walked back to the three dragons while Captain Peter walked back into the village with his men and explained the situation to the village. Luckily, everyone in the village was pretty much gathered because of the shocking sight of three large dragons landing near their village. Lord Adam explained the situation to the five others who were waiting anxiously as Lord Adam had talked to the Captain.

"Who’s going to be expected to fly him?" Dracus questioned.

"If it is a concern for you, Dracus, because of him being a strange, he can ride on my back," Kaage informed the larger dragon. Though Dracus was a more accepting dragon when it comes to flying humans compared to other cloud dragons, Dracus was still a prideful creature and didn't want to fly humans he didn't know, fearing they would see him as just some mindless beast of burden.

Captain Peter eventually arrived. Captain was clearly nervous as he walked slower towards them when he got closer. Lord Adam was the one who introduced Captain Peter to everyone. "This is Dracus, a trusted friend of my father." Dracus nodded his head in a very small bow. "And this is his daughter Rathnait," Lord Adam continued, "My daughter Ashley and my adopted, but still loved son, Felix. Felix and Rathnait are bonded. Felix and Ashley waved as Rathnait gave a small bow. Captain Peter waved back. "And finally, this is Felix's "Uncle" Kaage," Lord Adam explained, "It's a long story, but Felix's father was the one who was bonded with Kaage."

1151212211221221211111211112221221211122.content:
Captain Peter nodded slowly as Kaage lowered himself close to the ground as Adam climbed onto Dracus' back and Felix and Ashely got on Rathnait.

"Please tell me if I press to hard," Peter said as he climbed on to Kaage. Kaage chuckled slightly.

"It takes more than the force you are using to hurt my skin," Kaage noted. Soon, the three dragons were off into the sky. It was a short flight to the edge of the canyon, so they didn't go very high into the sky, or very fast.

"We should announce ourselves before entering," Dracus noted to Kaage, who nodded his head. As they reached the threshold of the canyon, the three dragons landed softly.

"What do you mean, Dracus?" Peter asked, looking at the larger dragon. But before an answer was made, the three dragons released three distinct roars, echoing into the canyon.

"The canyon is the Earth Dragon's home," Felix answered, "It is not wise for dragons to enter another dragon's domain without a call first." Peter nodded, understanding.

"When we find them, Captain Peter, the onus of making them see the town as part of their land falls on you," Kaage noted, "You are the one who has lived closest to them and would know things we don't that can tip their views." Captain Peter gulped.

"I understand," he said before the three dragons walked into the canyon, "Umm there's a cave entrance we believe was made by them about a three miles into the canyon. If we go straight, you'll find it easily." Kaage thanked him for the directions and led the group into the canyon. Rathnait followed behind, with Dracus taking up the rear.

****

The calls echoed far and deep into the canyon. Sentries near the surface heard the announcement and called further down to the three elders. It had been many years since three dragons entered their domain, this they knew. Talk was spurred by this fact, as well as what one called a challenge of land. It was from the one who identified himself as a Shadow dragon. Heads turned to the youngest Elder, who in her earlier years had met one of the reclusive Shadow dragons. It was decided she would go forth with some sentries and meet those entering their domain.

****

The dragons moved cautiously in the canyon, not wanting to miss and sign of being watched. Rathnait thought back long ago when she first heard of Earth Dragons, and their immense size compared to even Cloud dragons. These thoughts were shared with Felix and it was clear these were beings who would be found only if they wanted to be found.

"Here we are," Captain Peter called out, as they reached a cave's entrance that was even larger than the cave Dracus and Rathnait called home. But before they could enter, rocks on the path ahead erupted upwards and as Dracus quickly turned, he saw the path they came by was also blocked. A soft voice came from the opening in the cave. None of the humans could fully understand it, but Felix was able to pick up a few words, namely "Enter."

"What was that?" Lord Adam asked.

"The Earth Dragons wish to enter and state our business," Dracus commented, "It was a different dialect from our language, but I can translate, if need be."

"So can I," Kaage noted before leading them in. The group soon stopped once more as three gigantic forms appeared. Each one was covered in dark brown and red scales, nearly making them invisible to the humans. Peter wondered if there was a chance he walked right next to one of these dragons and never realized it. The faces here stouter than a Cloud Dragon's, but still they took up much space in the cave. The middle one spoke in a dragon tongue.

She wants us to tell her why we, may father, Kaage and I are here, Rathnait told Felix by their bond.

Kaage responded, explaining why, looking up at the eyes, noting they were not the same color: the right was dark green, like the other two dragons', but her left was half-white. The Elder said nothing for a moment, before responding.

"All right Captain Peter, she wants you off me to give your argument," Kaage said.

"why?" Peter asked, looking up at the titans, and this was still being forty feet up.

"They can sense vibrations in the earth. They will probably use it to see if you are lying," Kaage noted, "So be honest." Peter nodded and slowly climbed off Kaage. He moved in front of the Shadow dragon and cleared his throat.

"I am Captain Peter from the human village outside the canyon," he started, "I am here to first thank you for protecting our lands." Kaage translated. The elder responded.

"They want to know why it's both their land and yours. The canyon is theirs, not yours," Kaage noted.

"Because we have helped each other in the past. We are both surviving from the same ground and seek to protect it from harm," Captain Peter said. The elder considered the words. Her response was short and the Captain guessed it without Kaage telling him. "How?"

"First the kobolds were a problem to both of our people and we aimed to remove the threat," Peter answered, "Also, while you let humans to pass through your lands, we have never sought you out directly. We protected you from being known to the world." A few moments passed and a reply came.

"What concern is other humans knowing of us yours?"

"You have never done us harm or evil," Peter responded, "In return, we didn't want people coming looking for you, because of your help to us. Not just the kobolds, though, ten years ago, I was part of a group that hunted down some trolls in south. We found an egg shell far to large to be from anything smaller than a dragon." When the elder heard this claim, she thought back to a young mother' eggs were destroyed by trolls, but they were dead by the time a sentry found their lair. "We also encourage merchants coming through the canyons to not venture in because of unstable caves, so they fear being trapped in a cave and die. We dismiss any sign they think might have come from you, saying they are mistaken, or send our parties that purposefully fail to find anything." The elder said nothing for a minute. She finally responded.

"You claim we are allies?" Kaage said before adding, "And she means not just friends, but war allies."

"Yes," Peter answered firmly, "What do you say?" The Elder dragon was silent once more.

choices: as they wait news from the elders...
the scout comes back with news quickly.
1151212211221221211111211112221221211122.content:
There was a long silence as the large female elder Earth dragon thought to herself about the human's claim. It was strange for her to consider a creature of a different species, especially a human, as an ally. However, she did not sense any lies from the human. The human was telling the truth or at least it thought it was telling the truth, unless the human is a perfect liar. However, the elder female doubted that. She was one of the best of the elders to be able to detect lies and many of the things the human had said made sense.

"Maybe we can consider these humans as allies. Their village has been on the edge of our territory for a long time now and we have lived near each other in peace ever since. Neither of our races bothered each other, and if this human's claims are true then... just maybe... we can consider them allies and wouldn't have to worry about them ever again," the female elder wondered.

The female elder continued her thoughts, "I know the humans have never tried to attack us, but others dragons in this community, especially the older ones, tend to fear the humans will. Some can get paranoid. Probably why our race tend to keep to our race of dragons and not many others. If we consider these humans as allies, maybe that paranoia of humans will cease. However, I'm not sure if the other elders will like that. I'm the youngest of the elders. The rest are much older and tend to be less open of the idea of accepting others into the community."

The female elder sighed and finally gave the three dragon and three human newcomers an answer. Kaage translated for Captain Peter which he had been doing for the whole conversation, "I cannot give you a certain answer, because I am not the only one who has to make that decision. I am an elder, but there are more elders than just me and they have an equal say in the matter. Considering weather you're an ally or not is a very important decision that all the elders in this community has to consider."

"Then, do we have to talk to the rest of the elders as well?" Captain Peter questioned.

"Yes, but I don't think we can just bring you and your group into our community to see them," the female elder explained as Kaage translated. The female elder turned to one of her allies and told him to go back to the elders and tell them everything that has occurred. She also told him to ask for their permission to bring the travelers to them and then come back. The male dragon nodded and left to seek the elders.

"Earth dragon Elder, I know that the other elders have make a decision before me and my village can be considered allies or not, but what is your decision, if I may ask?" Captain Peter asked. It was a bold question to ask and Captain Peter didn't realize it until he asked it. Captain Peter stood still and quivered a little more in fear as he stood in front of Kaage and stared up at the Earth dragon the put Kaage's size to shame and was even larger than the male cloud dragon Dracus. Captain Peter had been fearful of the Earth dragon ever since he saw them and had to stand his ground before them. He was lucky that he had been able to keep his calm among them. However, his fear increased in fear that he had offended the Earth dragon.

It was a bold question, but when the female elder could feel the human's fear from the vibrations in the earth, the elder knew that he realized the mistake he had made. However, the female dragon wasn't that all offended by the question, at least, definitely not as offended as another elder would have been. Though the human's question did sound like a demand, the elder knew that it was meant to be more of an inquiry. "Do not be frightened, human; I am not offended by the question. However, you definitely should be more careful with what you say if you are to meet the other elders," the female elder warned, "If you wish to know what I think, I think that you and your village could be considered an ally, but I have no idea how the other elders will see it."

Captain Peter smiled with relief and the female elder smiled. "I've never really introduced myself. My name is Elder Ujana," the female elder stated.
1151212211221221211111211112221221211122.title: Allies?

choices: Ujana lends her support for Peter's claim.

1151212211221221211111211112221221211122.content:
"Ujana," Kaage thought as he recalled a memory from many years ago, almost one hundred fifty years ago. He and Frewen were traveling soon after their mother passed on. They had come to this canyon on the other side and entered. They explored one of the caves, not knowing it was Earth Dragon territory. As they opened a path hidden by some loose rocks, a sentry appeared, confronting them. Once explanations were given and Kaage and Frewen said they would leave soon, the sentry did not pursue them. But she did give her name should they visit again. "Were you the sentry I met many years ago?" Kaage asked in dragon.

Ujana looked at the small shadow dragon. "You had a human with you, Frewen, correct?" Ujana asked. Kaage nodded.

"Congratulations on becoming an Elder," Kaage responded.

"Thank you," Ujana said, glancing at the tiny humans. "Where is your bond-mate?" Kaage said nothing for a moment.

"He was murdered by evil humans who did not understand our connection," Kaage answered, "I know of no curse in Dragon or tongues of Man to say the depths of my hatred for them." Ujana said nothing in response. The communal hatred to the trolls who attacked a nest, killing the young, was massive and shook the earth they stood on. That same type of hatred flickered in Kaaage's eyes when he spoke of those humans just now.

**

Captain Peter stiffened up when Kaage and Ujana began speaking. "What's going on?" he asked, looking around. Felix was quick to look at Rathnait and she translated by their bond.

"It seems they knew each other a long time ago," Felix answered. "She met my father as well. She asked what happened to him and Kaage spoke briefly of the men we are preparing to fight." Peter nodded, happy it was nothing against their current action.

A rumble echoed in the cave, making all dragons pay attention. Ujana nodded. She began speaking.

"You will be allowed to come further in to make the claim before the other Elders," she said as Kaage translated. She turned her massive body around and moved to one wall, opening it for them to travel through. Peter quickly got on Kaage and the group followed Ujana with the other sentry taking up the rear.

They traveled in darkness, with only the dragons seeing through the darkness. Felix felt Ashley tighten her grip around his waist in the darkness.

Finally, they came to a large chamber where two dragons, slightly larger than Ujana, were waiting. Above them was a large glowing crystal. This chamber was an ante-chamber to where the dragons generally lived, unless they were giving birth and used places outside the domain. Dracus saw quickly both of these Elders were very old, far older than even he or Kaage were. They glared down at the group. One finally spoke. He was the oldest of the three Elders, Elder Kathmor.

"You claim we are war allies? Despite us never making contact before?" Kaage translated.

"Yes," Peter responded, "We both fight and seek what is best for this canyon."

"How so?" Kathmor responded.

"As I told Elder Ujana, we do not seek your harm or removal from this canyon," Peter answered, "If we sought to use you for our gain, we would have called on slayers to kill you to use your remains as trade items or weapons. But we have not. We benefit from each other." Kathmor let out a low growl.

"I still find this hard to accept," Kathmor responded. He glared at Ujana then to the other Elder.

"Wondrous news!" King Albert bellowed, getting up out of his throne "Far too long has it been since out last contact. Bring them in as soon as they arrive. They need not too wait any longer than need be." The guard bowed his headed and departed through the massive doors which were the entrance to the throne room. King Albert seated himself once more.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------

Back out in the yard, Lord Adam, Felix, Ashley, and Kaage were out of the carriage and Dracus and Rathnait were preparing to land. The wind picked up as the two dragons started their decent, yet everything in the yard managed to maintain its place, however, all apart from Kaage had to brace themselves to prevent from being blown over. Once Rathnait and Dracus had landed and the wind had ceased, Felix made his way over to Rathnait closely followed by Ashley. Lord Adam and Kaage made their way over to Dracus. Presumably to further discuss what could happen in this audience with King Albert.

“We are going to have to contain ourselves, Rathnait. I hope you understand how important it is that we do.” Felix explained. Rathnait growled at the thought of knowing that William may possibly be in the same room as her and Felix and that she couldn’t tear him limb from limb, as she so wished she could for what that menace did. But she understood.

“I will control myself.” Rathnait replied, slowly trying to calm down. Both Felix and Rathnait still found it difficult to contain their anger and each could sense it in the other. Ashley could see this in their faces, it began to worry her.

“Please. Please remember that there is still the chance that he won’t be here.” Ashley tried to reassure. It seemed to work as Felix and Rathnait quietened down and then looked at her. Ashley began to fear that she had just said something she shouldn’t have. Like they wanted to believe William was in there. They wanted to believe that he could be struck down there and then, without any consequences. All those thoughts melted away when Ashley saw the smile across Rathnait’s and Felix’s face. She couldn’t help but smile too.

“I will address the king and raise our claim. We will explain to King Albert that dragons do have intelligence and that we have not ‘tamed’ the Cloud Dragons-” Dracus growled at the word ‘tamed’, “- it is that we have a contract.” Lord Adam revealed a scroll. Kaage remained quiet throughout the explanation.

“It is then my understanding that if all goes well; we are to be called around so that my daughter is able to explain about what this evil man had done to her.” Dracus recalled. Rathnait would not be happy that she would have to explain her time in capture, but she had made it obvious that preventing William from getting back into power was more important to her.

“That is correct.” Lord Adam replied. A guard walked out of the castle and addressed everyone.

“King Albert will see you now. You may come in when you are ready.” With that, he returned to the castle.

Lord Adam walked over to the castle, closely followed by Kaage. Felix turned to Rathnait, who gave him a quick nuzzle, and Felix then began to move towards the castle. Ashley turned to Rathnait, exchanged a smile and was off.

--------------------------------------------------------------

“Welcome! It is good to hear from your family again.” King Albert made his pleasantries known with a smile across his face.

“It is good to see you again too, my king.” Lord Adam returned the welcome.

“I and your father were good allies Adam. And he was a good friend to me, especially when I needed him most.” King Albert stated. Felix had a sudden flash of Rathnait through his mind. Felix understood what the king meant and how he would have felt. “But you are here on business now. So let’s get down to it, shall we?”

“Yes, if we could please.” Lord Adam stepped forward.
