1151212211221221211111211112221221211122.content:
“So, my king, like I have said, the Cloud Dragons outside our village do have a high level of intelligence. If it was not thanks to the Cloud Dragons, then you would never have met my father, as I’m sure he had explained.” Lord Adam explained.

“Yes, he did say. He was lost when he was young and the dragons guided him back home. Is that correct?” King Albert questioned.

“Yes my king. It is because of that kind deed, that the Cloud Dragons delivered, that we signed a contract.” Lord Adam pulled out the parchment on which the contract had been written. “This is the original contract on which has the Cloud Dragons and our signatures. It states that we do not allow any slayers, or people as such, to use our village as a base. Also, any crimes committed against the Cloud Dragons whilst inside our walls will have severe punishments. Or else be left to the mercy of the dragons. The Cloud Dragons have accepted that whatever punishment we give is it, and no further action will be taken on their half. So, although our punishments are severe, they are nothing compared to what the Cloud Dragons would do.

King Albert listened with great interest. He listened and understood what was being said.
“And in return, my king,” Lord Adam continued, “The Cloud Dragons agree to help our village in times of need. May that be when we need resources or protection. The Cloud Dragons understood the terms, and accepted them.”

“May I see that contract?” King Albert asked.

“Certainly my king. That is why we brought it with us.” Lord Adam replied as he handed the parchment over to the king, who then proceeded to read it. “The Cloud Dragons have not been tamed by us. Nor would they allow themselves to be tamed. They are too proud a race.”

Felix felt as if a great weight had been lifted of his shoulders. ”It is such a relief the William is not here. This meeting is going a lot easier than if he were here.” Felix could feel Rathnait calm down through his bond with her. There was no need to be worried about causing a spectacle in front of the king now, as what might have caused it is not here.

“Then, what of this attack on William’s castle? What was the cause behind that?” King Albert questioned.

“My king, that had nothing to do with the village. A family from the Cloud Dragons came to the village in need of help. Due to the contract, we were obliged to. An infant of the family had gone missing and we were asked to help discover what we could about the disappearance.” King Albert nodded in acceptance. “We caught word of, at the time; Lord William had captured a dragon infant. We passed on the message to the Cloud Dragons.” Lord Adam explained.

“I had heard of that myself. I understand that the dragons at that time would have gone to save their young. Therefore, would have gone through any lengths to do so.” King Albert interjected.

“That is correct. But at first, only one went to help. It is very unpleasant for a Cloud Dragon to be caught because of their pride. So I will not state which one.” King Albert accepted this once more. “So, when things went wrong, there was only one thing that was left to do in that situation.” Lord Adam commented.

“The Call of Duty.” King Albert seemed to fade out of himself. He even gave a small laugh to himself. Felix noticed that King Albert seemed to know quite a bit about Dragons and their ways.

“My king.” Felix stepped forward and got down on one knee to bow. Both the eyes of Lord Adam and King Albert turned to him. Ashley was in shock that he addressed the king. Felix got up and looked at the king. “If you don’t mind me saying King Albert, you know quite a lot about dragons and their ways, don’t you?” All King Albert could do is chuckle.

“You are indeed correct there. I know quite a bit. I have had my time with dragons. More than one species as well.” All looked quite shocked. “I even know so much to know that your friend over there,” King Albert pointed over to Kaage, who had remained silent and still the entire time, “I know enough to know, he is a Shadow Dragon. Am I not mistaken?”

Kaage looked up at the king. Lord Adam, Felix and Ashley couldn’t believe that King Albert had managed to see through Kaage’s human form. “You are correct, my king.” Kaage said in a calm voice.

“Why maintain human form?” King Albert asked.

“Because I think of myself as more of a human than I do a dragon.” Kaage replied.

“Well that’s a new one.” King Albert said out loud.

“That is another story for another time. Right now we still have business to attend to.” Kaage stated.

“That we do.” King Albert settled back in his chair.

“My king,” Felix had spoken up again. “Can I ask as to, why you have granted William an audience, when you already knew that his claims about the Cloud Dragons being tamed were false, and that as and when he caught an infant Cloud Dragon, that it would provoke an attack from the Clan?”

“Because, my dear boy, one knows more when one does not.” King Albert said. He could see the confused looks on everyone’s faces. “Let me explain, by granting him an audience with his claims of an unprovoked attack, if I seem to not know anything, William will believe he can say what he wants, as long as he makes it convincing. At which time, I can compare what he says to what I already know.”

“So you wanted to discover if his word was a trustworthy one, and that he was a reliable person.” Ashley claimed for the first time.

“That is correct, and your audience just reinforces my thoughts and knowledge. William will still be granted his audience, as up until know; all I have heard is rumours.” King Albert stated. “So, Lord Adam, we have discussed the Cloud Dragons and your contract. We have also discussed as to what provoked the attack on William’s castle. But I need to know what went on in the castle to get a fair idea.”

“I think that would be better heard from a former slave of his and the very Cloud Dragon that William captured and tortured.” Lord Adam claimed. King Albert was stunned when the word “tortured” was mentioned.

Felix stepped forward. “Shall I call Rathnait up now?”

“You have bonded with the dragon? Impressive.” King Albert smiled at this. “Yes, please do call Rathnait up.”

"Rathnait, you can come up now. There is a big enough balcony outside the throne room for you to land on. The king knows a lot about dragons, so he won’t discard your word because you are a dragon.” Felix called out.

“Your father and I, Felix, we were brothers,” Kaage stated.

“Bothers?” Felix questioned, “But you’re a shadow dragon.”

“Exactly,” Kaage said, “Which makes your father and shadow dragon as well.”

“If my father was a shadow dragon then…” Felix gasped.

“You and your mother are shadow dragons as well,” Kaage informed Felix.

“I… I’m a… dragon?” Felix asked with a loss of words.

“You are a shadow dragon,” Kaage stated, “And I’m your uncle.”

“But, how is this possible? I’m a human,” Felix argued.

“You’re in your human form. I made you forget your past life and you forgot that you are a dragon and believe you’re a human.”

Felix was in utter shock and couldn’t think of anything to say. Could he really be a shadow dragon? There was much silence as everyone except Rhian and Kaage were in the same type of shock as Felix was.

Suddenly, Felix thought of something to argue with. “But dragons age differently than humans and I’ve aged like a human,” Felix argued.

“You’ve been in you human form those five years of slavery. Your human form ages like a human till it reaches eighteen years old. You’re really an infant dragon, but your human form aged like a normal ten year old human,” Kaage explained.

Felix couldn’t think of anymore arguments, and he didn’t know if he wanted to. All his life he thought he was a human, but now he learned he was a dragon. He still didn’t know if that was a good or bad thing.

“I think I should start at the beginning,” Kaage said, “Your father and I was brothers from the same batch. We hatched out at the same time, so we were called the twins of the batch. We did everything together and we grew very close. When it was time to leave the cave, we stuck together, which was normal rare for shadow dragons.”

“It was like this for two hundred years,” Kaage continued, “We traveled the world together and stayed in caves for a few weeks, looking for the right one. Eventually, we found a perfect cave that had many deep passages. The only problem was it was very close to a human village. Initially, your father and I had different views about humans. I didn’t want to go near them, but your father did. Frewen, your father, was always curious about humans. He would often become his human form and go to the village.”

“I would always warn him not to, because we had heard many tales of humans killing dragons just because they were dragons, but Frewen still went and made friends with the humans. He even brought me along eventually and showed me they weren’t the evil creatures I thought they were. Of course I told them they were only being friendly to us because they thought we were humans,” Kaage explained, “After a few years and after most of the town trusted us, Frewen called a town meeting and revealed we were actually dragons. They thought it was a joke at first, but Frewen and I transformed into dragons before them.”

“How did they react?” Felix questioned.

“They were frightened at first, but we explained to them we were still the same people we befriended, it’s just that we were dragons,” Kaage answered, “It took a while, but the town realized we meant them no harm. Eventually, the whole town became our friends. We were invited to every party and celebration and we often helped them in our dragon forms when our human forms weren’t adequate enough.”

“Eventually, another dragon came to the scene, and her name was Isabel. She was your mother, Felix,” Kaage told Felix, “Since the town was already used to Frewen and me, she was accepted fairly quickly. She was also raised by humans when she was young. So, she treated humans with the same respect we did. Frewen and Isabel fell in love very quickly and eventually had you, Felix.”

“I remember the day you we born,” Kaage reminisced, “The whole town came to see the hatching. You were frightened of the humans at first, but then you mother assured you that they would never harm you. You were even able to transform into your human form on the first day, which is remarkably rare. The whole town adored you and our family.”

“But something terrible happened, didn’t it,” Felix replied.

“Somehow, monster hunters got word of us. This group of hunters were terrible and evil people. They killed creatures just because they looked like monsters, it didn’t matter to them if the creature was good or evil, just as long as it was different,” Kaage sighed, “They overtook the town and started killing everyone just because they were friends with us. Frewen and I tried to stop them, but we were outmatched and Frewen died while I was severely wounded. Isabel and I were forced to run away with you, but they kept catching up to us. Isabel was the next to die, and I was forced to take care of you myself.”

Kaage continued, “I eventually realized they weren’t going to stop and I needed to keep you away from me. They didn’t know your human form and since it would age till it reached eighteen years old, it would be harder for them to recognize you. I had to erase you memory though so that you wouldn’t remember you were a dragon and tried to find me. I’m sorry, Felix, could you ever forgive me?"

Felix would have felt sorry for the gryphon if it wasn't such a terrifying creature. (Contrary to belief, gryphons are usually friendly to humans and protect humans from any danger that should arise. Gryphons only attack humans that are evil or that attack them first. If only Lord William would have known that treating a gryphon nicely would gain its loyalty more than treating it poorly and with cruelty.)

"The beast is probably hungry from the long trip. Once it is chained up, you are to feed it," Lord William ordered.

"Me?" Felix asked.

"Yes, just go in the cell and toss the food to it. As long as you stay out of its range, it can't attack you. It will be your job to keep it alive by feeding it and cleaning after it. If it should die before I have a chance to control it, it will be your head," Lord William told the slave before walking off.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- -------------------------------------------

Felix came back once the creature was supposedly chained to the ground. Felix was carrying a large bowl of water and another slave was carrying the deer for Felix. The guard opened started unlocking the human door for them. There were two doors to the cell, the large doors used to get the creature in the cell and the regular sized doors for humans to enter without worry of the creature trying to get through the door.

Felix was nervous and frightened as the guard tried to find the right key for the door. It felt like hours were passing to Felix and he didn't know if he wanted the hours to last longer or shorter. Once the door opened, the other slave, Jack, told Felix, "Now, set the bowl near the ground and them I'll hand you the deer to toss in."

"You're not going to come in with me?" Felix asked.

"You're a nice kid and all, but I don't want to go near that creature. It's your job and I'm only required to help you carry the things you need," Jack stated. Felix became more scared now he would be alone in the cell with the creature. "Don't worry, as long as you stay out of its range, it won't be able to kill you.

"How long are the chains?" Felix asked.

"It can only reach to the edge of light," the guard informed Felix.

Felix took a deep breath and walked into the cell. The cell was fairly large, but it was impossible to see how big it really was, the only light available was the light that came from the barred circular window on the ceiling at least one hundred feet above the floor. The room was all made of stone and concrete and the only light was the circular light that came from the ceiling. Felix could hear strange sounds that were most likely coming from the gryphon, but he was too scared to look into the dark corner where it was coming from.

Felix set the bowl on the ground and Jack handed him the dead deer. Felix nearly had to drag it across the room as he came closer to the light. The gryphon's eyes opened and a pair of eyes the size of his head were the only things Felix could see in the darkness. Felix was afraid of the gryphon and it took a great amount of effort for him to keep moving closer to the creature. Felix noticed that the eyes stayed where they were meaning it wasn't getting any closer to him. Felix was too frightened to realize that the gryphon was just as frightened of Felix as Felix was frightened of it.

Felix placed the deer in the light and quickly backed away. The eyes looked down at the deer before a talon-like hand came into the light and dragged the deer into the shadows. Felix could hear the gryphon eating the deer as Felix carried the large bowl of water to the light. When Felix set the bowl down, the griffin stopped eating and looked at the bowl and then at Felix. Before the griffin could do anything else, Felix had already bolted out of the room.
12.title: In and Out

choices: Raven head (The gryphon is a female half-raven half-panther)
Falcon head (The gryphon is a male half-falcon half-lion)
something else
123.content:
Weeks past, and Felix had to continue taking care of the gryphon as well as all the other tasks Lord William assigned to Felix. Felix continued to stay as far away from the gryphon as possible and only entered the light to set the food down. Felix also noticed that the gryphon stayed in the corner the entire time every time Felix entered the cell to feed it. When it came time to clean up the feces, the gryphon was sedated so that Felix could go around the entire cell and clean up. However, Felix never wandered near enough for the gryphon to reach out and grab him. He was still very much frightened of the gryphon even when it was asleep. Because of this, Felix had never seen how big the gryphon was or what it looked like for that matter.

Felix was still too frightened of the gryphon to realize it, but the gryphon was afraid of Felix because Felix was a human. The guards and other humans that entered the cell would torture the gryphon and abuse it to try and make it do something the gryphon didn't want to do. The gryphon was only about six years old. As the gryphon stayed chained to the floor in its corner, it began to notice that one human was different from the others. It realized that Felix was the only human that entered that never harmed it.

Instead, the human would only feed the gryphon and fill its water. Each time the human came in, the gryphon began to grow more and more comfortable of the human. So much so, that it thought that if it approached the human, it might find comfort in the terrible nightmare it was in. So, one day, it decided not to just stay in the corner when the human visited with food.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- ----------------------------

Felix entered the cell as usual with the door shutting behind him once the deer was in and Felix had the water jug as well to fill the water bowl. As usual, Felix walked up to the bowl to fill it. The bowl was always in the light. Felix stared at the giant eyes that were always watching him carefully. Felix knelt beside the bowl and began to pour the water in the bowl. Felix looked down slightly to see when the bowl would be full

When Felix looked again, he no longer saw eyes. Felix looked upward and saw a large bird head right above him, looking downwards. In that moment where Felix wasn't looking, the gryphon had got up and walked up to him without Felix even noticing! Felix feel backwards and looked up in terror at the giant...
123.title: The Approach

choices: pet the gryphon's beak
get out of the room very quickly
Before he can do anything, the guard looks in wondering what's taking so long
1231.content:
A giant raven head stared at him. Felix felt both terrified and in awe of the creature towering over him. It's black feathers, though ruffled, transitioned magnificently into fine black hair on the torso. There was some sign of the change line, made more apparent because of how unclean the gryphon was from not bathing itself and the beatings. But he did not notice this feature fully as he was focused on where the head was, and slowly tried moving back to the door.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- ----------

The raven gryphon looked at the small human and saw it shaking. It took her a minute to realize this human was scared of her like she was of other humans. She felt saddened by this, hoping the reason for it not hurting her was more than fear. Carefully, she laid down before the human to try and make herself less intimidating. Slowly she edged her head forward, trying to show she meant no harm to the human.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- ------------------------

Felix saw the gryphon laid down before him and realized even lying down, the gryphon towered over Felix by a good foot, probably more. But as he stared into the large eyes, he saw a similarity to himself. The eyes of the gryphon were ones longing for hope of a better life, much like his eyes have when he day dreamed.

"How could a monster have eyes so similar to man's?" Felix wondered, before noticing the beak of the gryphon was right in front of him, stretching as far as it could due to the strong chains around its neck and back legs. The head dropped slightly, as though it was trying to show submission or it wasn't dangerous to him.

With his heart thundering in his chest, Felix decided to . . .
1231.title: Similar Eyes

choices: Felix continued to comfort and feed the gryphon.
A guard comes in to check on Felix.
12311.content:
Felix was still afraid and his head screamed at him to get the hell out of there, but Felix's heart said otherwise. He stared into those strange green black panther eyes. The eyes were as big as Felix's head. Hell, the gryphon's raven head was bigger than Felix's entire body. The gryphon's eyes were so sad. "Those eyes look so much like my own," Felix realized, "But how? It's an animal. It shouldn't have the intelligence of a... or does it?"

The gryphon continued to try and reach out for Felix. It's beak was already over Felix's legs, but the beak never came down to grab his legs and drag him into the darkness. The beak just kept stretching to Felix's chest which it couldn't reach. The gryphon made strange and very sad sounds that Felix couldn't describe. They made him feel very sad inside, however, and reminded him of his own sorrows and his own life.

Felix wasn't thinking straight and he did something that he would never have done in a right state of mind. Felix lifted his arm and started stretching his hand towards the gryphonn. The gryphon began stretching to Felix's hand and continued to make the strange noises. The gryphon was choking from the ring and the chains around its neck due to the stretching. So, Felix reached out his hand faster and touched the raven beak.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- -----------------------------------------

The gryphon wanted comfort form the human so desperately that it was choking itself to reach out to it. When the human began lifting its arm, the gryphon became excited and she continued to desperately fight against the chains for the human's hand. Eventually, the human placed his hand on her beak and she soon found comfort. The gryphon couldn't feel the hand on her beak, but she could see it on her beak and she began to know that there were some good humans out there.

The gryphon noticed that the human was still shaking slightly and it was still afraid. Yet, the human held its ground and stroked her beak. Hoping that the human would realize she meant it no harm soon, the gryphon placed her head on the ground in front of the human.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- ----------------------------------

When the gryphon's head was on the ground and the gryphon's eyes were nearly level with Felix, Felix snapped out of his daze. He saw his hand was still on the gryphon's beak and he was kneeling by it. Felix became frightened once more when he saw his hand so close to the giant beak, and it caused him to shoot straight up.

As soon as Felix took two steps backward, the gryphon made the sad sounds again. Felix stopped in his track and stared at the gryphon's eyes. To his surprise, the gryphon had tears watering from its eyes down its cheeks to the stone floor. Felix stood there in shock wondering what to do. "It doesn't want me to leave," Felix thought.

"Because it wants you as its lunch," another voice argued.

"But, it had the perfect time to eat me when I was in a daze," Felix reasoned, "It might want me just for company."

"Do you hear yourself?" the other voice asked, "It's a giant beast. It doesn't have the intelligence like humans do. It can't be reasoned with, and it only sees you as a possible meal."

"But if it's not like humans, then how can it cry, and why does it have the same kind of eyes as me?" Felix's heart questioned his brain. His brain couldn't think up a reason why the gryphon was crying and silence only followed the question. The only thing that broke the silence was the gryphon who was continuing to make the sad sounds that combined that of a cat and a bird.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- ------------------------

"Please don't leave," the gryphon pleaded, "You're the only human that seems to care about me. Please." The human obviously couldn't understand her words, but it was quiet possible the human understood the meaning due to her tone and emotion. Silence followed and the gryphon continued to let the tears fall from her face as the human looked to the doors and then back at the gryphon.

To the gryphon's utter amazement, the human started walking back to her head. It was the gryphon who was in shock this time as the human knelt beside her head and placed his hand in her cheek to stoke it. The gryphon began crying out of pure joy and closed its eyes while leaning her head slightly in the human's direction.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- -----------------------

Felix stroked the smooth black feathers on the gryphon's cheek and he began to feel more comfortable around it as the seconds went by. The gryphon leaned its head closer, but Felix understood what it wanted. Felix had seen the gryphon's eyes when he had approached it. The gryphon had still been crying, but its eyes were filled with a happiness that Felix couldn't have imagined existed. The gryphon's eyes were closed at the moment and Felix knew the creature was crying from happiness. Felix hugged what he could of the place where the beak met and he continued to stroke the feather while doing so.

"I understand," Felix told the gryphon while hugging it, "You just want someone to care about you. You want someone's comfort to escape the reality of what seems like a horrible nightmare. You want a friend."

Felix knew all to well what the gryphon was going through, because he had gone through it when he first arrived in the castle and he was still partially going through it.
12311.title: Comfort

choices: A week or two passes and the gryphon talks back
A week or two passes and Felix is starting to know what the gryphon is thinking
123112.content:
"What's taking the damn slave so long?" the guard wondered, "He's never taken this long before. Maybe he's dead. If he is, I doubt the lord will be displeased." With that, the guard picked up his keys and jingled them as he moved to the lock.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- ---------------------------------------------

Felix heard the keys jingle and it woke him from his daze. He quickly released the hug and backed away. The gryphon was woken from her daze when Felix suddenly released her. She looked at him and started coming closer to him once more, choking herself as a result.

"No! Stop! Stop!" Felix said quietly, "I can't stay, but I'll be here again tomorrow, all right?" The gryphon looked sad and cocked her head slightly, unable to understand his words.

"What's he saying?" the gryphon thought, "Is he scared of me again?" Then she saw the human point to himself and then at the door and then her at the corner she came from.

"He wants me to go to my corner?" the gryphon thought before hearing the guard moving the heavy door and saw why. She gave a slight nod and rose up and went to her corner, while Felix went to the door just as the guard looked in.

"You're alive. What took you?" the guard asked, glaring at the slave.

"The gryphon came into the light to get the water and it scared me and I tried not to make any sudden movements. Thankfully it didn't want to eat me, so I was safe," Felix said, looking at the powerful guard. He nodded indifferently, buying the story as Felix tried ran off.

"Hey, aren't you going to feed the damn thing?" the guard hollered.

Felix looked and saw that the deer's corpse was still out of the gryphon's reach because it was at the opposite wall. "Right, I was so scared that I forgot about the food," Felix told the guard.

"That's probably why it didn't eat you, you're not large enough for a meal. It needs the deer to be full," the guard explained.

Felix nodded and dragged the deer to the light. The gryphon didn't grab the deer till both the guard and Felix were out of the cell. Both he and the gryphon felt much better knowing they had a true friend in the other.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- -------------------------------------------------------------------------

Over the next few days, Felix spent as much of the feeding time holding the gryphon's head or stroking her body. Both of which she enjoyed.

"He's so nice now. He's so wonderful," the gryphon thought, looking at her human caretaker as he was talking to her about what his day was like, but she didn't understand him just yet.

Felix was also surprised when he looked between the gryphon's hind legs and saw no outer genitals, realizing the "he" he had been referring the gryphon as in his mind was actually a "she". Felix also noticed how difficult it was to leave the room as every day the gryphon would become sadder and sadder with each passing day. This was because of the comfort received from Felix, the gryphon was seeing Felix as its close friend and was very loyal to Felix by now.
123112.title: Needed Escape

choices: The gryphon picked Felix up and brought Felix to the back.
Felix found a rock and threw it at the gryphon. It retreated and cried
reader's choice
1232.content:
The giant head above Felix was of a kestrel, a type of falcon. The feathers on its head were a grayish white and is eyes were large and pure black. The feathers below and above its eyes were black as if it had a scar on each side, but that was just the shape the black feathers made. The beak was curved like more birds of prey and the hooked part of the upper beak was a beautiful silver color. The entire front half of the gryphon was a bird and its front legs were bird's legs with sharp talons. The feathers on its chest were a light brown, almost white, with black spots. It wings were folded to the side and where a darker brown but still light enougth to almost seem like a tan color and it had black spots on the wings there too.

However, the gryphon's head was the only thing in the light and Felix didn't really pay attention to the details. He didn't see a beautiful creature, only a giant monster that wished to eat him.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- ----------------------------------

The gryphon didn't really want to eat Felix. It only wanted comfort from the only human that didn't hurt it. However, the gryphon was starting to realize that the human feared him. "He's scared of me," the gryphon realized, "Is that why he doesn't come near me and doesn't hurt me? Because he's afraid? Why is he afraid of me?"

The human was right underneath the gryphon's head and the gryphon could have lowered his head fast and pluck the human up with its beak. The gryphon could stop the human from running away and bring it to the back with him, but what good would that do. It would just scare the human even more. However, the gryphon need comfort. He had been alone in the cell for weeks without his family and friends. The gryphon was sad, lonely, and hopeless. He needed just the littlest bit of hope to go on. He need someone to care about him.

The gryphon began lowering his head to pick the human up by its shirt.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- -------------------

Felix fell backwards when he saw the gryphon's mouth open. He watched in horror was the opened beak began lowering itself to him. Felix was too frightened to run or move. "I should have brought the deer first. Maybe it would have ate that instead of me," Felix thought.
1232.title: The Need

choices: eatting the meat. The human willingly comforts the gryphon.
trying to nuzzle the human. The human freaks out again.
12322.content:
It was a miracle! Felix's hand came across a loose stone on the floor. Felix didn't have too long to think of the consequences. Felix just picked up the large stone and tossed it at the gryphon's falcon head which was coming closer to Felix. Felix didn't aim his throw, but the gryphon's head was close enough that Felix didn't really have to aim. The stone hit the gryphon in the forehead with a loud thud.

The gryphon's head backed away quickly and Felix was too scared to move. Realization hit Felix as the gryphon looked back down at Felix. Felix had just hurt the gryphon and now it was going to kill Felix out of anger. Even though that may have been the obvious result if the gryphon had been grown up, the gryphon was still a toddler. It didn't become angry, it became sad. Tears formed in the gryphon's black eyes as some blood trickled down its gash.

Felix was confused by the gryphon's reaction and started to get up slowly. The gryphon suddenly began backing away from Felix as it whimpered and cried. Eventually, it was back in its corner and in the darkness, the gryphon began to cry. Felix began to hurry to the door till he heard the sobs of the gryphon. Felix turned and listened. The gryphon was actually crying! Those were real sobs that Felix knew all too well. "Why is it crying?" Felix wondered.

"Because you hit it in the head with a rock? Wouldn't you cry?" Felix began arguing with himself while wondering what he should do.

"No, I would have ripped a human apart if I was in the gryhpon's position," Felix replied.

"But that gryphon didn't do that. Instead, it cried, like a child who had just been injured," Felix pointed out.

"That things too big to be a child, isn't it?" Felix thought.

"How would you know? You don't know anything about creatures like gryphons. They could be very large creatures even as babies," Felix still continued to argue with himself, "Did you notice the feathers?"

Felix began recalling the feathers on the gryphon's head and realized there was something a miss. "It has the right coloring of a falcon, but its feathers are still fluffy as if it was a..." Felix began to realize.

"a toddler," his thoughts of reasoning finished, "This thing must still be an infant. It would explain why it didn't attack when you attacked it and it would explain why it would back away, afraid of you even though it was clearly bigger than you."

"But what do you propose I do? It tried to eat me," Felix questioned.

"Maybe this is your chance. You could make friends with the creature and..."

"Are you serious? It tried to eat me!"

"Think about it, if you go back there and help it, you might be able to befriend it. It has been treated terribly by the guards and soldiers. You might be the only one acting kindly to it and it might see you as something other than food or an enemy. Plus, it might become useful later to have a gryphon as a friend. Lord William did say they were very loyal creatures."

Felix continued to argue with his thoughts for a little while longer so that he could understand all the reasons and possible outcomes and benefits to both options. It became clear that befriending a gryphon was something very useful even if it meant risking his own life. "If I'm going to do this, though, I'm bringing the deer with me. It's still hungry, after all," Felix reasoned.

Felix took the deer and began dragging it into the darkness while carrying a lite torch he obtained from the wall were the only human exit was. As Felix got closer, he was able to see the gryphon's whole body for the first time. Its entire front was like a falcon's body, including falcon talons for front feet. It had the body of a four legged creature though and the front half was covered in feathers and two wings that folded to the side. The back half was a lion's body with the back paws and tail of a lion. The gryphon was curled up on the ground and Felix couldn't see the private area, but from the tip of the lion tail, he could tell it was a male because the dark furred tip was starting to grow.

Felix was surprised to see the gryphon actually cowering in the corner. It was afraid of him. Felix pushed the dead deer closer to the gryphon. The gryphon peeked out from its curled position and stared at Felix before looking at the dead deer.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- ------------------------------------------------------------------

"Why?" the gryphon questioned, "Why me? The first time I wonder alone, I'm taken by these horrible humans. And Daddy said humans were kind creatures. Why do they all hurt me? I did nothing wrong,"

The gryphon continued to remember how he had wondered alone by himself. He had seen a group of humans and gladly walked up to them. The gryphon's father had told him how humans were like them and intelligent creatures. The father of the gryphon had protected humans before, but never told his son of the evil humans, because not many humans came to the mountains.

Now, the gryphon was trapped in a cell with humans that tortured him for no apparent reason. "That human was the only one that seemed to care about me. My only hope for something more then this pain has hurt me like all the other humans. I don't understand. Daddy said that humans were good creatures." the gryphon cried.

Suddenly, the gryphon heard something and peeked out. The human was back with the deer in front of it. The gryphon looked at the human and then the deer before...
12322.title: Scared of a human?

choices: The gryphon understands human.
The gryphon doesn't understand human.
123221.content:
The gryphon didn't know what the human was planing. First, the human didn't seem to want to harm the gryphon, then the human threw the rock at him, and now the human didn't seem too hostile anymore. "What does he want?" the gryphon questioned, "Does he want to be mean to me like the other humans? Is this a trick?"

The gryphon was become scared of the one human that it used to think was it's only possible friend. But now, the human seemed to be like all the other humans. The gryphon kept as much distance from the human he could, yet he was already backed in the corner and if the human got any closer, the gryphon wouldn't be able to stop it or back away. Therefore, the gryphon stretched out is bird-like front paw and dragged the dead deer closer to it. The gryphon avoided anymore eye contact with the human and just ate the deer while still crying from both the pain and the loneliness.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- --------------------------------------------

Felix still had troubles believing the gryphon was actually crying even though he was seeing the gryphon cry right in front of him. Felix watched in disbelief as the gryphon ripped into the dead deer all while still sobbing uncontrollably. "Maybe this gryphon really is still a child," Felix thought as he watched, "And if it really is a child, it must be frightened and lonely. I know my first week was scary, but this gryphon must have had it worse. It's constantly being tortured while I was only harmed when I failed to do something right. The gryphon is also living in this dark and dank cell with chains around its neck and back legs. The gryphon must be in a nightmare."

A certain realization came to Felix as he thought about his first weeks in the castle and as he thought about when the gryphon had reached out to him. "What if the gryphon wasn't trying to eat me after all. It must be sad and lonely down here. I'm the only human that comes in here that doesn't hurt it. It might have come up to me because I wasn't hurting it and it wanted comfort from this dark nightmare," Felix thought.

Felix remembered the how lonely he was during his first months as a slave. He was five years old and he had no one to look after him or care about him. Everyone paid little attention to Felix unless he did something wrong in which case he would be punished. Felix had been lonely, he had no friends, no family, nothing except the clothes on his back. He was completely alone and he was still alone. Felix sighed, "The gryphon is just alone and I threw a damn rock at it."

Felix watched the gryphon as it continued to rip the deer apart. Normally, Felix would have been afraid of the massive beast that was ripping a dead animal larger than Felix to shreds. However, due to the gryphon's tears which still continued to stream down its face, Felix felt sorry for the gryphon's predicament. Felix just couldn't leave the gryphon in such a state. Felix took a step forward, but the gryphon noticed it and quickly covered its face with both wings. The gryphon shivered and cried hard, obviously deadly frightened of Felix. "The gryphon's not going to let me near it. I have to think of a different way," Felix thought.

Felix devised a plan and quickly ran back to the bowl of water.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- --------------------------

As the gryphon covered his face with his wings, he continued to say in his mind, "Please don't hurt me. Please don't hurt me I just want to go home. I just want Mommy and Daddy and even my sisters and brothers. Please don't hurt me."

To the gryphon's surprise, he heard rushed footfalls heading for the exit. The gryphon peaked from his wing and saw the human hurrying away. The gryphon sighed believing the human was leaving, but the human stopped at the water bowl, picked it up, and began walking to the gryphon once more. Not knowing what the human was planning, the gryphon backed up as close to the wall as possible and eyed the human carefully.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- ----------------------

Felix noticed the gryphon back up when he came back with the water and Felix couldn't blame the creature. "It's alright," Felix tried assuring the gryphon, "I'm only giving you the water." Felix had no idea if the gryphon could understand him, but he knew it was possible the gryphon could understand Felix's tone of voice, even dogs could do that. Felix just had to keep a calm and assuring voice and the gryphon would understand. "It's alright," Felix repeated.

Felix held the water bowl as far out in front of him as he could and the gryphon began to slowly edge forward. Felix approached slowly as well and set the bowl on the ground. The gryphon eventually placed its beak in the bowl and began drinking. Felix waited a long moment to try and let the gryphon get used to him, but eventually, he placed his hand on the gryphon's head.

The gryphon felt it and quickly backed away. Felix outstretched both arms and said calmly, "It's alright. I'm not going to hurt you. Please, let me closer."

Choice 1: The gryphon lets Felix come closer and Felix comforts the gryphon. The gryphon knows human language because his father had taught him enough to get buy. However, the gryphon can't speak human because the gryphon has a beak and not a mouth.

Choice 2: The gryphon doesn't understand human and it doesn't let Felix come closer just yet.
123221.title: Offerings

choices: The gryphon lets Felix approach and Felix sucessfully comforts and befriends him
The gryphon quickly covers is head with its wings and wouldn't let Felix in.
1232211.content:
The gryphon could understand the humans words. His father used to protect a human village and his father had taught the gryphon human speech. The gryphon didn't know every human word since it was only four years old. However, it knew enough to get buy. Unfortunately, the gryphon couldn't speak the human language, because it had a beak and no lips. The only way he'd be able to communicate was through telepathy, which was how his father talked to humans and how his father taught him. However, the gryphon was too young to be able to use the telepathy and didn't know how to use it.

"Please, let me come closer," the human said as he took another step forward with an outstretched hand.

The gryphon quickly shook its head. He knew it meant "no" and he hoped the human would back off once the gryphon shook his head.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- -----------------------

Felix was amazed when he saw the gryphon's head shake. "Did the gryphon just say no?" Felix wondered, "Well, there's only one way to find out."

"Can you understand me? You know what I'm saying?" Felix questioned.

The gryphon was still crying and shaking as it nodded its head quickly.

"If you know what I'm saying, why are you afraid of me? I told you I'm not going to hurt you. Don't you trust me?" Felix asked.

The gryphon shook its head and Felix understood why. He had thrown a rock at its head. The gryphon has intelligence like a human, it must have really just wanted help from Felix and he threw a rock at it. Of course the gryphon would distrust Felix after that.

"Look," Felix willed the gryphon while showing his open hands, "I have nothing that can hurt you. I want to help you. I'm sorry about throwing the rock at you."

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- ------------------------

The gryphon opened its eyes and looked at the hands of the human. The human didn't have a rock or any of the weapons that the guards used to hurt him. Yet, the gryphon was having troubles believing the human. The human had thrown a rock at him when he did nothing wrong. All the gryphon wanted was some comfort, because he was lonely, sad, and missed his family. He had no idea what he should do.

"I'm not going to hurt you, I promise," the human tried to assure the gryphon. The gryphon was surprised to hear the honesty in the human's voice as the human continued, "I only threw the rock at you, because I thought you were going to eat me, but you weren't going to eat me, were you?"

The gryphon shook his head. Of course he wasn't trying to eat a human. Human were people too and the gryphon would never eat a person, especially when his father had told him never to harm a human unless he had no other option.

"You're just scared and lonely here aren't you?" the human asked.

The gryphon cried harder and nodded his head once more.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- ----------------------

Felix felt guilty about throwing the rock and the fact that the gryphon was crying harder didn't help matters. Felix took a step forward again and reached out his hand farther. He wanted to help the gryphon any way he could and try to stop it from crying. The gryphon became scared again and Felix whispered, "Please, let me try to help you. I'm sorry about what I did. Please, trust me. I won't hurt you."

The gryphon waited for a long moment with tears still wetting its cheek feathers. Felix stepped closer with an outstretched arm and he continued to get closer and closer to the gryphon's head in order to pet the gryphon and try to comfort it. However, it was obvious the gryphon was still afraid of Felix. Felix just hoped that the gryphon would let Felix closer enough to it for Felix to show it that he didn't mean it harm.

12322111.content:
The gryphon had no idea if he could trust the humans words. "He sounds sorry," the gryphon argued with himself, "But he threw a rock at me. I just wanted to be friends." Tears started to fall harder again.

"Please don't cry," the human pleaded, "I want to help you."

The gryphon stared at the human's outstretched hand before he looked in the human's eyes. There was something strange about the human's eyes. The eyes were very different from the harmful humans. The gryphon felt more comfortable about trusting the human as he looked into his eyes. The griyphon decided to try and reach out to the human once again. The gryphon raised his head and inched it forward toward the human's hand. The human stayed where he was when the gryphon started reaching out.

The gryphon was still nervous about the human's intentions and when the gryphon was only about a foot away from the hand, the gryphon stopped and hesitated. "It's alright, just a little further," the human encouraged, "I promise, I'm not going to hurt you. Just give me another chance to prove to you that I mean no harm."

There was a long pause and the gryphon brought his head the rest of the way, and the human's hand touched his beak.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- ------------------------------------

When the gryphon began lifting its head towards Felix, Felix stood completely still, because he didn't want to scare the gryphon again. He didn't want to spend the whole day convincing the gryphon. So, Felix kept still and waited for the gryphon to come to him.

However, the gryphon's head suddenly stopped when it was only about a foot of the way there. Felix kept his hand outstretched and looked into the gryphon's eyes. The gryphon's eyes were pure black, but somehow, Felix could still tell from the gryphon's eyes what it was feeling. He could see fear still in the gryphon's eyes as well as a deep sadness and loneliness that Felix had only seen in one other person, himself. The gryphon's eyes were filled with the same emotions Felix saw in his own eyes when he looked in a mirror: depression, sorrow, loneliness , hopelessness, and many other dark emotions that made life harder.

"It's alright, just a little further," Felix encouraged the gryphon, "I promise, I'm not going to hurt you. Just give me another chance to prove to you that I mean no harm."

The gryphon took a long pause before it suddenly shot its head forward. Felix didn't really have any time to react, one moment the gryphon was a foot away, the next moment the gryphon's smooth hooked upper beak was against Felix's palm. Felix was very still for a long moment as if the gryphon was suddenly going to try and gobble him up, but he calmed down when he felt the gryphon shaking in fear! Felix looked at the gryphon's eyes again, but the gryphon had its eyes closed tightly.

Felix stroked the beak while saying, "Calm down, please. There's no need to cry right now. Everything alright at the moment."

Yet, the gryphon still shivered and cried. "Poor thing, it's still frightened of me. I'm going to have to use a different tactic in order to calm the gryphon down," Felix thought.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- ---------------------

The gryphon kept his eyes sealed shut. He didn't want the human to hurt him again. Yet, the gryphon was still willing to give the human a try, because he wanted a sort of release from the terrible nightmare he was in at the moment. The gryphon felt something touch his cheek and he quickly opened his eyes to look down. Standing right next to him with a hand on his cheek was the human.

The gryphon wanted to back away again, but the human's strokes stopped the gryphon from doing so and eventually began calming the gryphon down. The human's touch was the gentlest and kindest thing the griffin had felt since he had been captured and even though he had been capture about a month or so ago, it felt like an eternity to him. So, having the gentle human touch gave the gryphon great relief and comfort.

It was so much relief and comfort that the gryphon began to cry due to the happiness it was now feeling.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- ----------------------------

More tears fell down the gryphon's cheeks. Some of the tears soaked into the feathers, but others touched Felix's hand as he pet the cheek. Felix looked up to see the gryphon's eyes filled with a great happiness that Felix didn't realize could exit. Seeing the gryphon so happy caused Felix to smile kindly to it.

Suddenly, the gryphon leaned its head towards Felix and began rubbing his body with the feathery head. However, the gryphon's cuddle was gentle and Felix was surprised how gentle and affectionate the gryphon, who was the size of an elephant, was. Felix pet the head back as he said, "I had thrown the rock at you because I thought you were going to eat me, but I know now that you weren't going to. You're just lonely. I know what it's like to be alone in a dark place. I know how you're feeling and I want to help you, and the only thing I think can help you now is for me to be your friend, would you like that?"

The gryphon nodded its head and continued nuzzling. "Alright, we're friends now," Felix told the gryphon, "And you wouldn't have to be lonely anymore."

12322112.content:
The gryphon watched as the human approached him. The gryphon was still conflicted with its thoughts. On one side, the human had thrown a rock at him and he was afraid the human was going to harm him again, even though the human had no obvious weapons in his hands and the human sounded like he was being honest by what he was saying. It was fear that ruled this side of the gryphon's argument.

The other side of the conflict within the gryphon was longing. The gryphon was only a four year old child. He missed his parents and home and he was being tortured by evil humans that didn't seem to care if he was young or not. They just tortured him mercilessly and kept him in a dark and dank cell where he was chained down around his back legs, around his midsection, and around his neck. He was being treated terribly and being so young has traumatized him. The gryphon was going through something a normal person shouldn't go through, let alone a child, and it has cause much pain, loneliness, and depression in his brain. The gryphon was longing for some sort of escape from the nightmare, and he felt that only of those options would be to befriend a human and hopefully find comfort from such a human. He had felt the one feeding him would be his only hope.

So, two options were being played in the gryphon's head. The gryphon could either satisfy his longing for comfort by trusting the human or he could give in to his fear and distrust the human approaching. Fear won in the gryphon's mind. He didn't know if he could trust the human anymore after what the human did and he feared the human would start acting like all the other humans that tortured him. The gryphon quickly covered his head with his wings to keep the human away.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- --------------------------------

Before Felix could approach the gryphon, the gryphon stretched out its tan colored wings with black speckles and covered its head. Felix felt worse than he had before. "It seems as though the gryphon was only coming to me because it was sad and lonely," Felix thought, "But I went and threw a damn rock at it. Now, it won't even let me come close enough to it for me to show it how sorry I am. It dosen't trust me,"

Another thought came to him. The creature was obviously intelligent enough to understand the human language. Those nods and shakes couldn't have been a coincidence. If the gryphon was as intelligent as Felix thought, it was possible the gryphon was intelligent to lie and trick. "What if the gryphon is just pretending and it just wants me to get close enough to it so it can eat me?"

However, Felix soon dismissed that possibility. He had been within the gryphon's reach for a long time. The chains only let the gryphon go so far and Felix had been within that range for a very long time. Plus, the gryphon had eaten the deer and drank the water Felix had given to it without any signs of wanting to eat him. "The gryphon doesn't want to eat me. It would have done it by now," Felix thought to himself, "Besides, there is no way those cries are fake. Those have to be real."

Felix listened to the muffled sobs behind the gryphon's wings. It deeply saddened his heart upon knowing he was the cause of it. The gryphon was just a sad and lonely creature. The loneliness and sadness reminded Felix of himself. "The gryphon needs comfort and a friend," Felix realized, "I know it will help me to have a friend and if it could help me, it could most likely help the gryphon because we're a lot alike." For some reason, Felix didn't have troubles admitting he and the gryphon were alike.

Felix noticed a small gap where the two wings met. Felix didn't hesitate as he approached the gryphon's wings and got on his hands and knees. His mind was set. He was going to repent for what he did and he was going to make it up to the gryphon and become its source of comfort and friend. Felix crawled through the hole and found himself in the darkness where only sobs of the gryphon filled the air.

Felix didn't see anything, not even the gryphon's eyes. He knew that meant the gryphon's eyes were closed, because those eyes were even blacker than the darkness around him. Felix carefully stood up and followed the sobs with his hands outstretched in front of him. Felix was being as quiet as possible so he wouldn't startle the gryphon before touching it. However, his footsteps were nowhere near as loud as the sobs that filled the feathery prison.

Suddenly, Felix bumped into a wet, soft, and feathery surface. Felix started right away and began stroking the feathers to try and comfort the gryphon before it got startled.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- -------------------------------

"Why is everyone mean to me?" the four year old male gryphon questioned, "Why can't I find good humans like Daddy? Daddy said humans were good!"

The gryphon continued to sob, feeling everything was hopeless. He thought he would never see his family or his home again and that he would be trapped in the prison for the rest of his life. He would be harmed and tortured by humans the rest of his life and no human would ever show any compassion to him. He would be lonely and sad for the rest of his life. This was the future the gryphon foresaw.

Suddenly, he felt something bump against his cheek. The gryphon stopped breathing out of shock and fear. He opened his eyes slowly and looked down to see the human touching his cheek. (The gryphon can see just as well in the dark as he could in the day.)

What did the gryphon do?

Felix saw the gryphon close its eyes once more and more tears dripped down its feathery cheek and on his hand. Felix closed his eyes and sighed. "Will the gryphon ever trust me again?" Felix wondered, "It just wanted some comfort and I threw that rock at it. I guess I don't deserve its trust. I guess I won't gain a loyal friend like I thought I would."

However, Felix still continued to pet the gryphon's cheek in hopes it would calm down. Felix could only think about the lonely nights he experienced as his first days of slavery, an experience the gryphon must also be feeling. "But the gryphon's feeling must be worse. It's only an infant. Infants need to be with their parents, but this one is alone in this dreadful cell. The gryphon needs a friend who could help it and comfort it. It needs what I need," Felix thought.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- -----------------------------------

The gryphon braced itself for pain and it was too weak and young to know how to fight back. (It was still an infant and didn't want to fight back and hurt people. Especially since his father said that it was just as wrong hurting humans as it was hurting other gryphon and with the gryphon's size and strength, he could truly harm or kill a human.) The gryphon wasn't going to fight back no matter what happened.

Yet, pain never came. Instead, the gryphon felt something he had never felt from a human's touch. The human hand gently brushed against the gryphon's feathery cheek. The hand never turned painful. It just continued to give comfort to the gryphon.The gryphon was soon reminded of his parents when they would rub their heads against them. (Gryphons nuzzled with their heads instead of there hard beaks.)

The gryphon opened his eyes and saw the human seemed to mean him no harm. The human was just continuing to pet his cheek with a kindness and care the gryphon never dreamed was possible in the nightmarish cell. "The human... it's not going to hurt me... It's trying to comfort me," the gryphon realized.

Suddenly, the human looked as though he would give up and walk away. "It's going to leave me here again. No, I can't let it leave. It's the only human that seems to care about me."

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- ----------------

Felix felt as though it was no use trying to calm the gryphon down. It was just too scared of him now that he had thrown the rock. Felix couldn't blame the gryphon, because Felix knew he'd be uneasy if he were in the gryphon's position. Felix sighed and stood up more guilty than ever. Just as he walked to the only source of light, Felix heard a strange whine.

Felix turned and see the black eyes of the gryphon open once more. The gryphon edged its head closer and made a terribly sad sound. Felix began to wonder why the gryphon was making such a noise, but he soon figured it out. "Do you want me to stay here?" Felix asked the gryphon.

The gryphon nodded its head and Felix could only see the darker than black eyes move up and down.

"But I thought you didn't trust me. Why do you want me to approach now?" Felix questioned.

The gryphon edged its head and placed it beside Felix. The gryphon looked down and continued to make the whining noises. "Please," the gryphon was begging in gryphon tongue, "Please don't leave. I don't want to be alone anymore."

Felix knelt down once more and placed his hand on the gryphon's wet feathery cheek. Felix pet the gryphon, but it caused the gryphon to cry more. Felix soon realized that the tears were of pure joy. It had finally found a human that cared about it. The gryphon leaned its head against Felix's body (but not with all it's might because it would have knocked him over.)

"It's alright," Felix tried to assure the gryphon as he pet it.

The phoenix looked like any ordinary bird of prey, but it was covered in many vibrant and beautiful colored feathers that it would be near impossible not comment on such a magnificent and beautiful creature.

However, Felix was truly frightened that the giant bird of prey would devour him and he didn't pay attention to its beauty. The phoenix continued to stare at Felix as it walked up to him. Felix began to hyperventilate as the creature's beak descended towards his helpless body. The phoenix probed Felix's back gently. When the smooth beak touched Felix's back, Felix once again held his breath. The phoenix's beak moved the folds of his rough shirt and slid along the exposed skin of his back. Felix could feel his very skin crawl as the cold and smooth beak of the phoenix ran along his naked back. The only thing that kept his back semi-warm was the hot breath of the large creature standing above him.

"It's going to kill me," Felix thought. His lungs ached with unspent air. The point of the beak sifted through Felix's hair, and he could feel the creature's breath move softly over his skin. Felix watched the wooden cage being moved out while the phoenix's attention was on him. There were two entrances to the cell. One was normal sized, the doorway Felix was pushed through, and the other was large enough to fit the cage in. The large doors were closing now that the elephant cage was out of the cell. Felix was beginning to lose all hope of escaping the cell.

"How do you like my phoenix, slave?" Lord William questioned, his voice smashing the calm of the moment. The creature jerked its head up and cried out, fixing its black stare on the open doorway where Lord William was standing unfazed by the shriek the large bird had given.

131.content:
Seizing the moment, Felix scrambled to his feet. He threw himself toward the door, desperate to reach safety before the phoenix's beak could come down on his soft flesh. As soon as Felix's feet started to pound on the stone floor below, a piercing shriek filled the damp air of the terrible cell, followed by a flash of golden light. Felix heard the phoenix's sharp talons scraping against the the floor and it felt as thought the air began to boiled behind Felix. Felix could make a good assumption that the phoenix's breath was what was rushing past him which meant the phoenix was close behind with an open beak edging closer to him.

Felix didn't look back once, but he kept the image of a monstrous bird, beak open wide, chasing him to give him encouragement to run faster. Felix to the door with the beak inches behind him. He had no idea he was going to make it to the door in time until...

SLAM! Lord William had actually taken Felix's hand and pulled him in just before a guard slammed the iron door behind Felix. The phoenix collided with the door hard, but the strong iron didn't budge despite the bird's strength. It was obvious that the impact was going to either leave a bruise or a bump on the phoenix's head. Felix whirled around just in time to see the bird wreathed in golden light. The spectacular yet frightening golden light flickered across the feathers, breathing life into the colors of the plumes. Felix gaped at it for a moment before bending over and breathing frantically to try and catch his breath. He had never ran that fast in all his life!

Lord William only chuckled and dusted off his hands. "Pull yourself together, slave!" he snapped, "The thing's too young for real fire."

Felix nodded, trying hard to catch his breath before Lord William decided to slap him. Felix thought about Lord William's actions. "He had saved my life," Felix thought. He had thought that the wicked man had finally done something nice for a change, but then reality hit him. "He just used me as bait. He threw me in there to distract the phoenix long enough for them to get the cage out of the cell!"

"You used me as bait," Felix muttered.

"It's better loosing a slave than one of my guards or soldiers," Lord William informed Felix.

"He hasn't changed one bit," Felix thought.

"Now, you'll be feeding it twice a day. Get the meat from that fat woman up in the kitchen and bring it down here. All you have to do is throw it the scraps, got that? Right through the bars," Lord William told Felix, "The only thing you can't throw through the bars is the water. However, you could just fill up a bowl and put it in while it's distracted with the meat."

The human sized door was made of tough iron bars that Felix could easily slip his hands through. It would have been easy enough for Felix to throw things through the bars. (That's probably why Felix was chosen out of all the other slaves.) Felix nodded again. As long as he didn't have to completely enter the cell again he'd be fine with taking care of the phoenix.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- -----------------------------

Several days passed, and Felix dutifully brought the pail of meat scraps from the kitchen every morning and night. It was unnerving to toss the slimy strips into the dark, listening to that razor-sharp beak snap them up, but he was glad to keep a safe distance. The only time he actually had to open the door was to fill a bowl of water for the phoenix. He would first toss the meat so that the phoenix would be distracted while he opened the door and filled the water. Luckily, the phoenix kept the bowl near the door.

Lord William seemed pleased with the bird's progress, and Felix had so far avoided getting beaten for any imagined negligence. It was, of course, his main concern - that the creature thrive so no one would have anything to blame him for.

Things might have continued on in just this way, but one evening, just as he finished throwing the last scrap, he heard the telltale rustle of the phoenix moving. The guards paid no attention. They didn't even hear the rustle because they were at the dungeon entrance on the other side of the door. Felix stood still and watched the creature approach. It stared at him through the bars, then slowly leaned forward.

A feather was held in its beak.

"Is it offering this to me?" Felix wondered. The bird looked at him with shiny eyes and held the feather still, just within reach.

134.content:
Felix tried to open his mouth in response, but he was still frozen as Lord William entered and approached the beast, flanked by a pair of guards. Lord William was practically swaggering with pride. "Well, slave," he repeated harshly, "what do you think of it? Tell me."
"L-Lord William," Felix whimpered finally, feeling the close proximity of the great, bird-like creature. "Please...please don't let it eat me."
The lord laughed, and Felix felt another shudder at the mirthless, corrupted sound. "I ensure that you shall be perfectly safe," he said. "At least, just as long as you obey me." Felix watched as Lord William beckoned to him. "Come, slave, come."
Felix stared at his master, anxiously shifting his gaze between the noble fowl and the foul noble. Deciding the worse of the two beign the foul noble, he stood and scurried towards Lord William. "Be quicker about it next time," Lord William growled, and one of his signet rings cut into the boy's cheek when Felix received another warning slap. The boy winced from the pain, gasping and clutching his face as Lord William gestured for a few stronger slaves to bring in a great chest, large but plain and wooden. He could smell some sort of spice in the air as it was dropped next to him. "Slave." Felix, no matter how badly his instincts were telling him not to, stepped closer to the cruel man.
"Slave," Lord William began again, and Felix ventured to look up into the nobleman's face. He recognized the glittering malice of pure evil in his master's dark eyes. The boy had seen that look before, but only just after Lord William was done torturing his prisoners. "Slave, I should like you to care for my phoenix. You shall be now a sort of stable boy to my creature. All you need is in this chest, but the breaking..." Lord William's eyes shone with even greater delight in Felix's fear. "The breaking of the beast shall be done by me." Lord William stepped back and out of the cell, his guards falling back with him. "There isn't much else you need to know, slave."
Felix tried to follow Lord William, but his master motioned for him to remain where he was. "Where do you wish me to stay in the meantime, my lord?"
Lord William shook his head, and Felix felt a cool layer of ice coat his insides. His master was grinning sadistically. "Why, if you are to care for my creature, here is where you must stay." The smaller door shut tightly, and Felix let loose a sob as the clasp of the latch metallically clicked what was sure to be the slave's last sound before he was devoured by the winged beast behind him.
It was not much longer before Felix could feel that hot breath on his skin again. "I really am going to die," he thought as the sharp tip of the cool, smooth beak rested gently on the top of his head. The tears spilled forth eagerly like from the spout of a fountain. He was scared. What was it like to die? No one knew, because no one who had ever died lived to tell what happened.
