14322.content:
Arachne didn't understand what was happening. She had been sleeping in her cave, but when she woke up, she was no longer in her cave, but in a large open meadow. She also wasn't alone in the meadow. There were also strange doll sized creatures around here she had never seen before. Though the creatures were smaller compared to her, they were numerous and she didn't have a chance to fight back, especially since she was only five years old and in a very confused state of mind. The strange creatures forced her into a large wooden crate without much of a fight. Arachne didn't attack the doll sized creatures, she only pleaded for them to stop.

Days past as the small creatures that had the same sort of upper half as her, but only two legs and no spider body kept her in the crate and only opened it to threw food into it. Arachne cried nearly the entire time. She didn't understand why she was being kidnapped by such strange creatures and why they were treating her so poorly. Arachne even started believing that this whole experience was a dream, but it was no dream and she was really being taken away by strange little monsters that were treating her as if she was some kind of giant savage beast.

Because Arachne was a dridder and still young, she couldn't understand why the strange little creatures thought she was some monstrous creature. Plus, their claims that she would eat them seemed absurd to her. It was true that most Felaryan top predators defined a person by their size rather than their intelligence. This was the whole reason why Felaryan predators deemed it morally permissible to eat humans since they were little despite the fact they were a sentient being like themselves. Too them, if they were large enough to eat something, they felt it was right to do so. What they didn't realize was that just because one has the power to do something, it doesn't always mean they should.

Arachne, however, didn't have these views yet. Like many dridders, she was left on her own to survive. This meant that the Felaryan moral system wasn't taught to her. Like all dridders and nearly every other Felaryan top predator, Arachne had the fascination of eating smaller creatures. She enjoying swallowing squirrels and rabbits whole. Though, she had never met a human before and didn't even know what they were. She understood they were intelligent beings that could even speak her language and with an added bonus of her curiosity, Arachne had no wishes of eating a person. This was the case for most dridders who were forced to live on their own. However, it usually changed with growth and humans eventually became too small to befriend dridders who had a fascination to eat small creatures. Dridders realize upon their growth that they have to power to do whatever they want with small beings and they had the choice to eat them or not. Besides, who could believe such small beings that are clearly a different species should be given the same rights: the thought that many Felaryans learn to accept.

Eventually, Arachne was let out of the crate and she found herself in a large chamber. The chamber was dark and creepy. A place that reminded her of home. However, the creatures forced her into chains which she couldn't break free from. This was the part that she hated and was afraid of. "Why are you doing this to me?" Arachne asked the small creatures, "Why am I here and why are you chaining me up like an animal?"

The creatures never answered her and just walked away. Arachne cried for a long time trying to will herself that it was only a dream. However, she never woke up in her cave and she continued to be trapped in her chains. Arachne tried to make herself better by making a large web so that she could feel more at home. However, it wasn't working. Nothing was changing the fact that she had been kidnapped, was far away from her home, and that there were chains. She was a prisoner.

Suddenly, the door had opened and, fearing that more of those little creatures had come to hurt her again, Arachne quickly backed into the corner of the cell where she had placed her webbing to make a fort-like sleeping area for herself. This would be the spot where she would rest and stay hidden from creatures until they became trapped in her web. Arachne only hoped the doll-sized creatures wouldn't find her in the corner.

Arachne had expected to see more of the creatures that wore the shinny clothing (armor), but to her surprise a cart filled with two deer and a large bowl of water came into the room first followed by a smaller creature pushing the cart. It was clear that this new small creature was different from the other creatures that kidnapped and hurt her. They were the same species, but this small creature was smaller than the others and younger. This little creature didn't wear the shinny clothing, but instead wore old and dirty clothes that were so worn that they looked more useful as rags rather than clothing. Arachne stared at the new creature with great curiosity as it approached closer.

"This one is different from the others. Maybe it will act differently and not harm me. Maybe I can ask it what I'm doing here?" Arachne wondered. However, she saw the fear in the creature's face. "He thinks I'm a monster like the other creatures think I am. He might hurt me like the others and treat me like a beast," Arachne assumed. Arachne decided it was best not to risk provoking the creature to attack her.

Arachne noticed that the small creature pushed the cart just before he could reach the other side of the line where she could reach. The small creature then took the large bowl and set it in her reach. "This creature is feeding me," Arachne realized. She still wasn't used to the idea of being fed, but it would be the only way to survive in the lifeless cell. Arachne also didn't like the fact that her food was already dead now, but she didn't dare complain to the little monsters, her captors. Arachne was hungry, but she didn't dare approach the small creature till it was gone.

Suddenly, the small creature slipped and fell in her webbing. Pure instinct took over Arachne and she quickly approached the small creature. Arachne believed the small creature was a dangerous creature, but it was in her webbing now, and anything that got caught in her webbing was her prey.

The small creature struggled and screamed, but nothing happened and he was still stuck in her web. Soon, Arachne was in front of the small creature as it was lying on the ground with pure terror in its face. Arachne licked her lips, wondering what the new small creature would taste like. Arachne bent down and outstretched her arms to pick up the small creature who was slightly less than a fourth of her size. Before her hands could grasp the small creature, the creature pleaded, "Please, stop. Please don't eat me."

The small creature's plea was simple, but it was effective to Arachne. Arachne stopped her reach. She had eaten everything that had gotten caught in her web before, but there was something different about this creature. It was one thing eating a dumb and mindless beast, but it was another thing eating something that could speak and even speak the same language. Though her instincts told her to eat the small creature and be done with it, she was feeling uncomfortable about eating a living being that was pleading and was actually speaking. Arachne looked into the creature's eyes and saw that it was actually crying. Arachne sighed, gasped the small creature's torso with both of her hands on either side and pulled it off the webbing.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- ----------------------------------------

Felix tried to yell for help, but no one would come. No guard would risk his life to save some slave boy. Felix became even more hopeless with he saw the giant dridder heading for him. Felix was in pure shock and terror for a moment as he witnessed the giant dridder. The dridder had the body of a five year old human on top of a spider's body. The spider body was large and black. It was easily the largest part of the dridder. Where the head of a spider normally was, the hips of the human half of the girl emerged. The human part of the dridder had a purple tint to her skin and she had black hair. The dridder's ears were slightly pointed and her eyes were a strange yet beautiful ruby color. Since the dridder was still only five years of age, she was still flat chested, but Felaryans developed more rapidly than other creatures and would have decent sized breasts by the age of eight which only made them seem bigger due to the size difference.

Felix snapped out of his shock and tried to break free, but it was no use and the dridder was soon upon him. The dridder smiled and licked her lips as she bent down to grab him. Felix screamed out as he closed his eyes shut, crying, "Please, stop. Please don't eat me!"

There was a hesitation, but Felix didn't dare open his eyes. Eventually, her felt the large hands grasp him on each side and peel him off the web. "This is it. It's all over," Felix thought to himself. He began to imagine everything Lord William had told him about dridders' eating habits. Felix imagined the fangs biting into him and putting him in to a comatose state while he was wrapped up in webbing. Then, the dridder would ingest his insides in due time. However, none of that happened. Instead, Felix felt ground beneath him and the dridder's hands left from under his arms.

Felix slowly opened his eyes and saw that he was standing on the ground in front of the large dridder no longer on the web. Felix was too confused and too scared to move. All he could do was stare up at the giant dridder as it stared down at him. Felix moved to take a step back and the dridder, in a frightened movement, backed many steps away from Felix. Felix didn't know how to react to this, and he...

143221.content:
Felix was in total shock at what just happened. He thought that the dridder was going to end his miserable life right then and there, but instead it let him go. He knew that it was thinking of eating him when it was walking toward him from the way it looked at him licking its lips. So why?

Felix just stared up at the giant dridder, completely unaware of the passing time or even the fact that he was still on the other side of the line, as he pondered why the dridder that was supposed to be an evil blood thirsty killer without remorse would spare his life. Even if it did have the food he brought it, it could have still just wrapped him up to save for later.

Suddenly Felix's eyes opened wide with realization. "Did it, spare me because I begged for my life? But how? Even if it does have mercy in its heart, it's from another world, or at least that's what Lord William said, so how could it understand me? Wouldn't it have a different language? Well, I guess there is only one way to find out," Felix thought as he worked up the courage to speak.

"E-Excuse m-me but c-c-can you understand me?" Felix asked. The dridder only gave a slight nod as a response. "A-Are you sparring me?" Felix asked as the dridder leaned in a little toward him but stopped when Felix took a few steps back. Again he got a single nod as a response from the giant spider girl. "So you don't plan on eating me?" Felix asked with worry in his voice. At this the dridder just lowered and shook her head.

Felix felt a lot better with the dridder's answer to his last question but still felt fear of this giant dridder that could so easily end his life. "Can you talk?" Felix asked.

"Yes I can. I'm sorry, I just had a bad day. My name is Arachne, what's yours?" she asked with the same uneasiness that Felix had in his voice.

"I'm Felix," Felix replied as a little more tension lifted from the two.

Suddenly, there was a loud knock on the door that caused both Felix and Arachne to practically jump out of there skins. "Hey slave, you dead in there!?" shouted one of the guards that stood at the door.

"I-I'm fine, I just got caught in the webbing for a moment. I'm free now," Felix answered as he held his right hand over his pounding heart.

"Ha! you owe me 5 silver coins!" shouted the other guard.

The first guards grumbled and shouted, "Well hurry up, slave, you have other things to do."

As the sound of the coins clinging when they were handed over was heard in the cell, Felix just dropped his head. The guards had heard his cry for help and only made a bet as to whether or not he would live through it. Felix then jumped over the webbing and dragged the remaining deer into Arachne's reach. Just then...

1432211.content:
Once, Felix dragged the deer in Arachne's side of the cell, Felix turned to see what she was up to. Arachne seemed to be a nice girl and she was a child who spared his life, but she was still a giant dridder. Felix was still nervous around such a large creature and he wouldn't be able to get used to being around such a creature over night. When Felix turned around, he saw giant spider legs before him. Felix quickly looked up to see that Arachne was now in front of him, very close and bending down to reach for him. This nearly gave Felix a heart attack as he fell backwards on his butt turned his head away and covered his face with crossed arms, because he felt there was no time to run. It was too late for him to do anything. Arachne, despite her size, was too fast and to silent . He never knew she had approached him.

When Arachne noticed Felix's reaction, she stopped her advancing hands and looked at Felix with hurt feelings. She thought that the little creature trusted her now, because she told him that she wouldn't eat him and she was telling the truth. She just didn't have the will to eat something that could speak the same language as her, even if it did fall in her web. Because she thought the creature understood he was safe to be around her, she thought she could get closer. She wasn't even reaching down for him, but the deer that he gave her. Arachne didn't say a word to the little creature and instead just kept reaching for the deer.

Felix thought that the dridder had changed her mind and was going to wrap him up and eat him. However, Felix never felt her hands grasp his sides. Felix peeked from behind his arms and witnessed Arachne grabbing the deer instead of him. Felix lowered his arms and saw Arachne grasp the deer with two hands and lift it. Normally, the deer would still be heavy for something of Arachne's size, but not heavy enough to have too much trouble. Though, Arachne was a dridder and had insect strength which gave her the ability to lift things that were many times her body weight. Arachne placed the deer under her arachnid body and, with the help of her spider legs turning the deer around, was able wrap the deer up in a webby coffin. Arachne then picked up the deer and placed it on the web with the other deer that she had wrapped up quickly as Felix had started to drag the second deer.

When Arachne was finished, she looked down at the little creature that was frightened of her again. Felix noticed that her ruby eyes were wet and on the verge of tears as she lowered her arachnid body in a lying position to make her look smaller and less intimidating for Felix. However, Arachne's upper human body was still over ten feet tall and her arachnid body was still large as she lied on it. Therefore, Arachne was still a considerably large creature even in a lying position.

Felix was surprised to see the deeply saddened expression on Arachne's face when she asked, "Are you still afraid of me?"

Felix was stunned that the creature was actually saddened by his frightened reaction. This was a giant dridder. It could kill him with little effort. Why would such a large creature care what Felix thought about it? The more Felix thought about it, the more he began to understand. The dridder was a child with feelings and intelligence. It's quite possible the child dridder didn't quite understand why size makes a difference and sees Felix as a person since he could speak and had feelings like the dridder. Now, add in the fact that this child had been taken from its world and was now being held prisoner in this terribly depressing and lonely place. Felix knew what it was like to suddenly be held prisoner and become a slave without his consent. Being a slave was all that Felix knew and he had been a slave since he was five years old.

"I became a slave when I was no older than this dridder here," Felix realized, "I remember how lonely and miserable I felt. This dridder must be feeling the same way. Though my size is smaller than her, she seems to see me as a person and want me to accept her. It must really hurt her feelings to see me frightened of her. I know I'd be saddened if people thought I was a monster and fear me in my time of need." Though Felix realized this, it was still very hard to have no fear for the giant creature before him.

Felix stared up at the towering vertical upper half for the dridder as she looked down. Trying his best not to try and harm the dridder's feeling any more than they were, Felix tried to explain the reasons he was afraid of her, "I'm sorry, but you are quite scary."

Before Felix could continue his explanation, Arachne questioned with tears rolling down her face, "But why are you afraid of me? Why do you and the other creatures think I'm a monster?"

"Well, Arachne, that's your name, right?" Felix questioned. Arachne simply nodded and Felix continued, "How old are you?"

"I'm five, but what does that have to do with being a monster?" Arachne asked.

"Well, I'm ten years old," Felix explained, "So, I'm five years older than you, yet you're close to five times taller than me. Your species is much larger than mine. You could end up attacking me and I wouldn't have the power to stop you. Wouldn't you be scared of something that could do that to you?"

"Yes," Arachne answered, "But I can't help being larger than you. If I could be littler to make you not be scared of me, I would. It's not fair."

"I know, but something that is a different species and much larger is scary to people. It's natural for people to fear things that are potentially dangerous," Felix explained.

"But I'm not dangerous," Arachne argued, "I won't hurt you, I promise."

"I think you're telling me the truth, but I'm still going to be fearful of you," Felix told her.

"Do you think I'm a monster?" Arachne whimpered with watery eyes and a quivering lower lip.

"Judging from our first meeting, you don't seem to be," Felix informed her.

"Then why are you still afraid of me?" Arachne whimpered again.

"Because I still don't know you yet," Felix told her, "You are a creature that I have never seen before and because of my natural fear of much larger creatures, you have to give me time to get used to you."

"How long till you get used to me?" Arachne asked.

"I don't know," Felix stated truthfully, "But you seem like a nice girl and it might not take as long as you think."

Arachne sniffed and dried her tears before asking, "If you get to know me better, could we be friends, Felix?"

"I don't see why not," Felix replied while finally standing up. This cheered Arachne up and she was getting more comfortable around Felix. "Well, I wish I could stay, but I have other things to do," Felix informed her, "I'll be back to feed you dinner."

Arachne suddenly remembered the reason she had approached Felix in the first place, other than to grab the deer. She wanted to ask him why she was here and what he and the other little creatures wanted from her. However, Felix seemed to be in a hurry. Did Arachne ask him what was going on?

"Oh um Felix?" Arachne asked before Felix left.

"Yes Arachne?" Felix replied. As he was trying to pull the cart up, its wheel got stuck in the line that was carved into the ground.

"What do you and the other...um...whatever you are want with me?"

At this Felix froze for a moment, completely forgetting the stuck cart and turning to face Arachne. "Well...er...It's not me or the guards that want you. It's Lord William."

At this Arachne leaned her head to the side in confusion. "Who or what is a Lord William?" Arachne asked as she sat her spider half back down with her human half still upright.

"Well a Lord is what you call a master of the land who is not of royal blood. And his name is William." Felix explained as best he could in hopes that she understood.

"OK I think I get it. But what dose he, she, or it want with me?" Arachne again questioned.

"He wants your power...He always wants more power. He plans to make you his slave so he can use you to get even more land and power," Felix told her.

Arachne was even more confused now. "What is a slave?" She asked.

"I am a slave. A slave is someone who another person owns and does whatever the owner, or master as they are called tells them to do,"Felix informed Arachne

Now Arachne was getting upset. "Well he's not going to make me a slave! And you should stop being a slave to," Arachne argued.

"I can't just stop being a slave," Felix started before he was interrupted.

"Yes you can. Just say no and that will be that." Arachne argued.

"It's not that simple," Felix tried to explain.

"Why not?" Arachne asked.

"To make you his slave he will hurt you. He will cause you as much pain and fear as he can till you do as your told. All his slaves live in fear of what he will do to us if we disobey. And if he can't break your spirit...There is this spell. I saw him do it once. It hurts him a lot but if he wants you, he will do it. He even explained how it works. What it does is it makes you a puppet. You can see, hear, and feel everything but you can't control yourself. You can't do anything unless he tells you to," Felix stated

Arachne's eyes widened at this and only fear showed on her face. "B-But, I don't want to be a slave," Arachne said as tears flowed from her eyes.

"No one wants to be a slave. It's just the way things are," Felix said as he lifted the cart out of the carved line and started pushing the cart toward the door.

"F-F-Felix." Arachne said as tears flowed down from her eyes.

"Yes Arachne," Felix said as he turned to face her.

"C-Can I have a hug?" Felix was surprised by this but he remembered when he first came to this place and was going through what she was. He was so depressed, he would have killed for a hug, so how could he say no.

"OK but just for a HEY!" Felix was cut off as he was snatched up by Arachne while he was walking to her. Arachne clutched him close to her chest with a firm but harmless grip. And he felt his upper back get wet as her tears fell on his back.

"Um A-Arachne I must leave soon so I can't stay long...Arachne?" Felix told her.

143221112.content:
Arachne heard Felix's request and outstretched her arms away from her chest so that Felix was dangling in front of her with each of her two human hands were under Felix's arms. Arachne looked at the human in her hands and apologized for hugging him so long, "Sorry, Felix. It's just that this was my first hug. You're the first creature that let me hug you and I enjoyed it very much. I really needed that hug."

"I understand," Felix assured Arachne, "I remember how I felt when I first got here. This place can make you feel terrible things. This was my first hug and I enjoyed it too. Unfortunately, I have more duties to attend to before I can come back to feed you diner. So, could you put me down please?"

"Oh, right, sorry," Arachne apologized seeing that she still was holding Felix even though he needed to do his duties. Felix noticed that Arachne's purple skin around her cheeks turned bluish. Felix assumed that she was blushing and her blush was a different color since she had a different color skin. Arachne was still lying on her spider body so she just had to bend her back a little and lower her hands to set Felix on the ground. When Felix's feet touched the ground and Arachne took her hands away from his body, she asked, "So, you liked the hug too?"

"I did like your hug," Felix answered truthfully, "I've never had such contact before. I've been here for five years and never found anyone who cares about me. That hug, at least for that moment, gave me hope that there is good in this world and that I might just find a friend."

"Then, we are alike more than I realized," Arachne replied.

"Yes, but let's save our past for a different conversation, like for tonight when I have more time to speak with you. But, I have one more request before I leave," Felix informed Arachne.

"What do you want?" Arachne asked.

"Next time you decide to pick me up, could you warn me your doing so or ask for my permission? I know you won't hurt me and you only being friendly, but it's kind of scary when I'm suddenly being picked up by something as large and powerful as you are," Felix said.

"I... I understand. I won't pick you up so quickly and I will ask and warn you first from now on," Arachne promised, "As long as it helps you see me as a friend. I've never had a friend before and I think I would really like you to be my first friend."

"I think I will like you as my friend as well," Felix admitted to the twenty-five foot five year old dridder before him.

"You will be back for dinner, right?" Arachne questioned just as Felix turned to push the cart once again.

"Of course, I'm responsible of feeding you. So, I'll see you three times a day," Felix informed her. He turned to see that it was slightly saddening Arachne that he was leaving the cell, but his words seemed to have cheered her up and she gave a slight smile back to him.

"Then I will be waiting for you to come back and I will be glad to see you again," Arachne stated, still smiling.

"See you at dinner," Felix replied.

Before Felix could leave, Arachne questioned, "Wait, you never told me what sort of creature you are." Arachne had heard of many creature, though she hadn't seen all of them. She was hoping she would know Felix's species though she hadn't seen his kind yet.

"I'm a human," Felix informed Arachne just before he left.

When the doors shut, Arachne's face turned pale and she whispered, "F-Felix is... a... a h-human?" Arachne had never seen a human until now, but she had heard many stories about humans. The one thing that she heard most often was that humans were delicious and a delicacy. She had heard from other Felaryans that any creature that comes across a human and lets them go is a fool. She had heard that humans needed to be eaten and they were too good to pass up. Humans are just a snack and nothing more. Arachne backed up back into her corner to think about what she should do next. She had to think carefully on the matter.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- ---------------------------------------------------

Felix had eaten dinner with the rest of the slaves and was now doing his final duty before he had to feed Arachne. Dinner had been like any other dinner: the food was tasteless and bland and the whole dinner was impersonal. There was no talking, no conversation. There was only other slaves keeping to themselves and only caring about themselves and keeping themselves behaved so that they weren't punished or tortured. Felix hated meals, but it wasn't like it was any different from the rest of his day. It's not like there was some other slave he had befriended. "It's sad when the only friend I have is a giant spider-like creature that supposedly eats humans and other small creatures without remorse," Felix thought, "Though, Arachne seems like a nice girl and it doesn't seem like she would be able to bring herself to eat me."

Felix was scrubbing the floors as he thought about the Felaryan dridder. Lord William had told him that Felaryans were terrible monsters that ate anything that was smaller than them without remorse and it didn't matter to them whether the small creature had intelligence or not. Yet, Arachne was different. She couldn't bring herself to eat Felix when he pleaded and she was willing to become friends with him. "I wonder how this could be. Could it be because she's only a child and she's had to take care of herself? She said she's never had a hug before, maybe she didn't have parents that took care of her," Felix wondered, "She also might not have been taught to eat small creatures no matter what since she was alone. Then again, it could be due to the fact that's she's so lonely and desperate and would befriend any creature to be happy. Or it could be all those reasons."

Felix decided not to think about it anymore for the time being. "Maybe I could find the answer when I talk with her when I feed her dinner," Felix said to himself. Just as Felix stopped thinking about Arachne and why she was different from what Lord William had described her to be, Felix overheard Lord William speaking to another man in the distance.

"But my Lord, you may not have to use that spell," the man argued with Lord William trying his best to persuade Lord William from doing something, "You haven't even given us a chance to try."

"This creature is a dangerous beast," Lord William informed the man coldly, "It's not some simple horse that can be tamed. It's a Felaryan monster. I have a feeling that this creature will needed to be controlled by magical means."

"But you know how badly that spell weakens you and that's when you are forced to control strong willed humans. This beast is large. How much life will it drain from you," the man pointed out.

Lord William hesitated. The man had brought up a good enough point. "Perhaps I should reconsider a bit," Lord William muttered.

"You must think of your health, my lord," the man said.

"I want the ceremony to be prepared for tomorrow night, though," Lord William commanded, "You will start training that creature between its meals. If there is a slight improvement and you can show me that you can have it tamed in time, then I will not have to use the spell. However, if you can't show any progress what so ever, then I will just use the spell tomorrow night."

"Maybe you should give use a week for improvement," the man suggested, "Even wild horses could take a few days to show improvement in being tamed."

"I will think about it," Lord William.

When Lord William and the man dispersed, Felix knew that he had to warn Arachne about Lord William's plans.

1432211121.content:
Arachne was back in her corner thinking about everything that had happened. Like most dridders, Arachne had to grow up and live on her own. It wasn't the easiest thing to live alone in Felarya, especially since she was human sized when she was first born. This is why dridders have a large amount of children; so that one of the hundred could beat the odds of surviving in Felarya. Once Arachne grew big enough, it was easier to live in Felarya. However, Arachne still had a few more growth spurts needed before she could grow to her normal size as a giant dridder of five years old.

Because she was alone, she never had parents that cared for her. No one to look after her and no Felaryan to trust since all the Felaryans she had seen were giants. Normally, this lack of care and nurture probably should have messed her mind up and should have filled her personality with mistrust and empathy. However, Arachne was a different case. Instead, it just increased her longing for a friend, someone to care about her. However, in Felarya, the only intelligent lifeforms Arachne had come across were the giant Felaryans she couldn't trust and were afraid of. So, she was very lonely in Felarya.

Suddenly, she had ended up in another realm far away from her cozy cave and captured by terrible humans that treated her like she was a monster. Then they forced her in a dark and dank cell, which she wouldn't mind if it weren't for her being chained up. Then Arachne found met Felix and he seemed to actually care about her. He could end up being her friend, her first actually friend. The only problem was that he was a human.

"Those other Felaryans. I've overheard them so many times and they always talk about catching and eating humans. All some of them talk about is how scrumptious and irresistible humans are," Arachne thought to herself. by the way the Felaryans talked, Arachne had decided from then on that she would find a human and try eating it, but she had never come across one and never knew what it looked like, until now.

"But, they never said anything about humans being intelligent," Arachne continued to argue with herself, "I can't eat a person. That would just make me a monster. But, all that talk about how taste humans are. I so badly want to try one."

"But what about Felix?" Arachne wondered, "He's a human, and he's the only person I've come across that actually cares about me. He's the only friend I have. I can't eat him, and even if I eat another human instead, what would Felix think?"

"What should I do?" Arachne whispered. Before she could think of anything else, the door opened and Felix entered the room with the cart of food and water. "Felix!" Arachne gasped both happy and sad to see him enter the room.

"Arachne, I have to tell you something," Felix started. Felix was pushing the cart forward unaware of Arachne's conflict within herself. Arachne was trying to fight back the craving she had for Felix, but she feared she might not win, which would mean that Felix was in danger. Felix was assuming Arachne was safe to be around.

"Wait Felix! I have to tell you something," Arachne told him, hoping he would listen so that she could warn him in time.

"Arachne, what I have is very important, I have to tell you what Lord William is planing," Felix interrupted, much closer to the line now and with no sign of stopping.

"Felix, don't come near me!" Arachne cried out.

Felix was confused by the dridders command and stopped before he could reach the line. Arachne began to tear up. "Wh-What's wrong?"

"You're a human. You're not safe with me," Arachne cried.

"Why am I not safe with you anymore?" Felix questioned.

"There are other giant people in Felarya, and I overhear them talking once and a while," Arachne started.

"What do you mean by overhear them and what do you overhear?" Felix interrogated.

"When I was younger and more human sized, Felaryans tried to eat me, just because I was little. It didn't matter to them that I was only a child and a person. Even though I'm 25 feet tall now, I still stay away from them. I overhear them talk about humans. They never say what they look like. So, I didn't know what a human was. They only talked about how tasty humans were. They talked about how they liked to swallow them whole and let them squirm in their mouth and use their tongue to play with the creatures before swallowing. They talk about how they like it when they moved around in their stomach and how scrumptious they tasted. It made me want to try a human, though I had no idea humans were intelligent beings," Arachne answered.

"But, it sounds like you don't want to eat me. Why am I not safe?" Felix asked.

"Even though I don't want to hurt you because you both a person and my friend, I'm still curious and I still have the craving for eating a human. The way the taste was described makes the taste sound so... so..." Arachne explained.

"Irresistible?" Felix finished.

"Yes, and I fear that I might not be able to control myself. I don't want to eat you, Felix. You're the only friend I have. You're safer if you're not within my reach," Arachne said.

"Arachne, the fact that you're worried about my well-being and the fact that you don't want to hurt me is what's keeping me safe. Your worry will keep you from hurting me since you see me as a friend. I'm safe with you," Felix informed her.

"How can you be so sure?" Arachne questioned.

"Arachne, other giant Felaryans have tried to eat you just because you were smaller, right?" Felix asked..

"Yes, but I don't understand where this is going," Arachne replied.

"Think about it. Do you remember how it felt when those giants didn't view you as a person and only thought you were a taste little snack?" Felix continued.

"Yes, it was terrible," Arachne admitted, "Those giants are just monsters."

"Do you really want to become one of them and eat a human just because you heard they were tasty. Do you want to view people as little snacks and put them through the fear and sadness you went through?" Felix questioned.

"No, I would never want to put people through what I went through. I don't want to become a monster," Arachne informed Felix.

"As long as you keep that in mind, you will never become a monster and I will be safe with you and I will always be your friend," Felix replied.

"So, we can be friends?" Arachne asked.

Felix stepped over the line and was within Arachne's reach. Felix looked up at the large five year old as she towered over him with her long spider legs giving her much height. "As long as you don't eat me, I will be your friend," Felix told her.

Choice 1: Arachne holds back her craving and doesn't try to eat Felix. Instead, she brings him into another hug, after his permission of course.

Choice 2: Arachne is controlled by her craving for a bit, but is able to stop herself before she can wrap Felix up completely and before she can bite him. Arachne is very sorry and feels terrible for trying to eat Felix.
1432211121.title: Do You Want to be a Monster?

choices: Felix has no plan for escaping.
Felix has come up with a plan.
14322111211.content:
Arachne noticed that Felix had stepped over the line and was within her reach. She could snatch him up right then and there. She could finally find out what those Felaryans were talking about and how tasty a human really was. Well, not quite since she was still not large enough to swallow Felix whole and wouldn't get the same experience the Felaryans do. However, the craving and curiosity was still strong inside Arachne and it didn't help with Felix being within her reach.

Arachne bent her spider legs to lower her spider body on the ground, though she was still much taller than Felix. Arachne then moved her hands towards Felix. Her hands were reaching out to grab Felix's torso and carry him with her hands under his arms. Arachne's mouth created saliva at the very thought of finally eating a tasty human.

However, Arachne's hands stopped before they could grab Felix. She stared at the cringing Felix whose muscles were tensed up and whose eyes were shut tightly. Felix was afraid of her. Arachne remembered back to when Felix had pleaded to her, when he had got caught in her web and begged for his life. "Humans can speak and they have feelings," Arachne told herself, "Though their upper body is the only thing that similar to me physically, Humans are very much like me on the inside. They're people. How can other Felaryans eat people?"

"Those other Felaryans are monsters, that's what they are," Arachne continued, "Eating a person is killing a person and that makes one a monster for doing so. If I eat Felix, I'd become a monster, just like the other giants. I have put Felix through the very same fears I went through when I was small."

Arachne's mouth was no longer filling up with saliva, but her eyes were dispersing tears as she realized what was happening. "Humans are not food. They may be tasty and they may be small, but they are people and eating one makes a person a monster. I cannot eat Felix. I don't want to be a monster," Arachne decided, "And, Felix is my friend. He's the only person I've found that's kind enough to care for me. He's so nice and kind to me. He doesn't want to eat me and doesn't think I'm a monster. He may be the only friend I'd find. If I eat him, it would all be over. I would never become his friend and may never find another person willing to be my friend. I'd be alone forever. I can't eat Felix. He means too much for me."

Arachne became saddened as she realized that she scared Felix with her reaching. She reached with one hand and placed the palm of it on Felix's shoulder, though the large hand took up a lot more than just Felix's shoulder. "F-Felix," Arachne spoke. Felix opened his eyes and looked up at the giant five year old face with tear soaked cheeks. "I... I'm not going to eat you. I don't want to be a monster, and you're my friend. I... I don't want to lose you," Arachne informed Felix.

Felix visibly relaxed when he heard Arachne's words. He was safe with the giant Felaryan dridder who saw him as a friend. "Thank you for telling me why I can't eat you," Arachne continued, "If you wouldn't have said those words, I might have... I might of..."

Arachne began to cry again, and Felix placed a hand on the back of the large hand on his shoulder. He was amazed at how big the twenty-five foot spider's hand was compared to his own. "It's alright Arachne. I forgive you. You didn't know any better," Felix assured her, "Now that I know you're not going to eat me, I know that I am safe with you, Arachne, and I think we can easily be friends."

Arachne smiled and tears of joy began coming out instead of tears filled with apology. "F-Felix, c-can I... h-hug you, again?" Arachne asked. Felix nodded and told Arachne it was alright to pick him up and hug him. Arachne was gladdened by this and she placed her hands under his arms, picking him up and pressing him against her chest. Felix knew that his arms had no chance of wrapping around Arachne. So, he just laid his head down on Arachne's soft and smooth skin. Felix was very comfortable, even if he was being held by a giant spider child. Felix could hear Arachne's heart with thumped against the back of her chest.

The hug was far longer than the last hug, but neither of them cared. Both of them enjoyed the hug very much. Eventually, Arachne stopped the hug and set Felix back on the ground once more. "Thank you, Felix. You're a great friend. I don't know what I'd do without you," Arachne said, "Now that I know what it's like to have a friend, I don't ever want to go back to the life without a friend. I promise that I will keep you safe and you will never be in danger when I'm around you."

"Thank you, Arachne," Felix replied.

Felix walked over to the cart and pushed it over the line. That way, Arachne could just pick the deer up from the cart without Felix having to drag it to her. As Arachne stood up to wrap the new deer up in her web, Felix filled Arachne's water bowl. "Um, Felix?" Arachne questioned as she put the deer on her web, "Weren't you going to tell me something important before I interrupted you?"

Felix soon realized that he had been so busy helping Arachne see him as a person, he didn't tell her about Lord William's plans. "It's about Lord William, the one that's keeping you here as a prisoner," Felix informed the giant dridder.

Arachne paused what she was doing and turned to look at Felix. "Wh-what about him?" Arachne asked. She had heard from Felix how terrible her capture was and she didn't want to meet him.

"You know how I said he had some sort of ritual he could do to control people like puppets?" Felix asked. Arachne nodded her head and Felix continued, "Well, if the tamers don't show any improvement in 'taming' you, he's going to do the ritual."

"He's... he's going to force me to do what he wants, and I won't be able to stop it?" Arachne quivered. Felix had told her about the ritual and how Lord William would control her body, making her do whatever he wanted. "I... I don't want that to happen. What do we do?" Arachne asked.

"Either we find a way out of this place soon, or you have to pretend that those men are taming you," Felix informed Arachne.

"I'd like to get out of this place, but do you have a way of doing that?" Arachne questioned.
14322111211.title: Do on to Others What You Want Done on to You

choices: "Hold up slave, the tamers are inside with the it.  No food until their done."
The guard glared at Felix and asked why he was early with feeding Archane.
143221112111.content:
"I never had any plan," Felix answered, "I want to escape, but there was no way for me to escape. If I tried, I would be killed." Archane looked down.

"Then there's no hope for me?" she whispered.

"Archane, I couldn't do it alone, but with your help, I could think of a plan," Felix replied firmly. The dridder looked back at Felix.

"I'll help, in anyway I can," Archane answered. Felix smiled at Archane.

"I have to get going before the guards begin to suspect something. I'll be back in the morning," Felix assured her. Archane nodded and watched Felix exit through the door. Tears came to her eyes. She was used to being alone, back in her home cave. But then, she had no one to call friend. She had to fend for herself and could trust no one. But now she was friends with Felix. And she knew she would never harm Felix.

"I hope Felix can think of something" Archane thought before taking her meal and started sucking it.

******************

"What took ya?" the guard asked when Felix left the room. Felix didn't look at the guard as he pushed the cart.

"Slipped on some fluid," Felix said. The guard laughed at Felix's "misfortune."

"Wish you could be with the wenches washing clothes?" the guard taunted. Felix said nothing, thinking about the women slaves whose duty was to was clothes for the guards and Lord William. As he walked away, he slowed down.

"The wenches, they complain about using the underground river that passes under the castle The rapids down stream are filled with rocks that have killed those who tried to swim. Maybe we could escape upriver?" Felix realized. He had stopped fully. His mind drew out the sole memory of going to the river, taking a pair of pants a soldier wanted cleaned right away, but the cleaners didn't believe him. He was whipped badly for his failure. As he thought about the place, it was large enough for Archane to swim or climb the walls about. But as his mind came back to the now, he wanted to turn around and rush back to Archane, but he had no reason. He couldn't say he forgot something or he'd be beaten. Slowly, he began walking again, hating the fact he couldn't get to Archane. He remembered the first night he spent in this hell hole. He had no doubt Archane would have an equally bad night.

He left the cart in the kitchen before going back where the slaves sleep.

"I'll just have to rush there first thing with her food to tell her about this," Felix decided. He laid down and fell into a light sleep, hoping he would wake before the tamer and his men reached Archane.

*************************

It was early morning when Felix was woken by someone moving over him. It was a woman, probably just sent back from a soldier's room. He stayed still for a moment, wondering if he should try getting to Archane now. He could see small rays of sunlight coming from the window high above.

"I'll go," Felix whispered to himself. Slowly, he rose up and looked around. The one who woke him was laying down with her back to him. Felix smiled with a small hope he would be out of this place soon and ran for the kitchen.

He knocked and waited. A burly man appeared.

"What do you want slave?" the assistant cook demanded, rubbing some sleep from his eyes.

"I came for the carcass for the dridder," Felix said. The man glared at Felix.

"One moment," the cook ordered. A few minutes later, the man returned with the carcass of a buck and a bowl of water. Felix thanked the man and went on his way.

A few minutes passed as he walked the path to Archane's cell. A new guard was in front of it.
143221112111.title: Never Any Hope

choices: Arachne accidentally dropped Felix into the river.
The tunnel got smaller and Arachne would have to go underwater part of the way!
1432211121112.content:
At a distance, Felix noticed that the guard was leaning against the wall near the door with his arms crossed and his legs straight out in an angle. His head was also stooped downwards. However, when Felix got closer to the guard, the man's head looked up and turned towards the noisy cart coming down the dungeon hall. The man glared at Felix and growled, "What are you doing here so early, slave?"

"I couldn't sleep. So, I thought that I might as well feed the creature and get its breakfast over and done with," Felix made up a lie to convince the guard, "Plus, the dridder might still be asleep and I won't have to worry about it eating me."

It was clear that the guard wasn't a morning person and he hated being here on the most boring of duties early in the morning. The creature was heavy chained up after all and there was no way for it to escape. What could possibly happen for it to escape? No one would be dumb enough to free it. The guard groaned and turned himself towards the human sized door. Now he had to keep awake for the slave boy and open the door for him when he needed to enter and leave when all the guard wanted to do was sleep. "Why did I take Eric's shift? If I would have known that it was such an early shift before I told him I'd do it, I would have never agreed to it. He owes me big time," the guard thought.

The guard fumbled with the key chain full of many keys, trying to find the right key to open the door. Felix noticed that some of them were very large and different from the others. Eventually, the guard found the right one and unlocked the door for Felix. Once the door was open, the guard moved out of the way. The grumpy guard grumbled, "Get going!" Felix began to push the cart and the guard added, "Move your ass, slave. Feed the monster quickly!

Once Felix was through the doorway, the guard closed the door behind. Felix looked around the dark room, trying to have his eyes adjust to the darkness. Felix looked around for Arachne, but couldn't see her. Somehow, Arachne blended in with the dark quite well, despite her size being so large and her human half having purplish skin. Felix continued to push the cart in Arachne's half of the cell, avoiding the sticky strands of webbing. "Arachne," Felix called out as quietly as he could as he looked around at her web which was much larger than he had last seen it.

Suddenly, two large ruby colored eyes appeared in the darkness. Felix knew that they were Arachne's eyes and once he saw them, he could just barely see the outline of the rest of her body. Arachne had laid her spider body on the ground and laid the rest of her body down as well. She was in a strange web that resembled a tent. Her giant body laid in that "tent" without the worry of sticking to the web since none of her body could. The ruby eyes looked tired as if just waking up, but when they feel upon Felix, the eyes widened and lit up with excitement and joy. "Felix!" The giant Felaryan dridder called out.

Before Felix could blink, Arachne was no longer in the web tent, but in front of him towering over him as she stood at her full height. It was clear that Arachne was happy to see him again She was so excited to see her only friend again, that she forgot to ask for his consent as she bent her human body and picked Felix up. Arachne brought him against her chest again and firmly hugged his doll-sized body, well doll-sized to her. "Oh Felix, I missed you. Last night was horrible. It was so scary without you. I'm so glad you're back. I really am," Arachne informed him as she continued her embrace.

"I can tell, because you sort of forgot to ask me before picking me up again," Felix replied.

Arachne brought Felix out of her hug and put her arms straight out with a hand under each of Felix's arms again. "I'm so sorry," Arachne apologized, "I forgot. Please don't be mad at me."

"It's alright, I understand," Felix assured her, "I remember my first night in this castle, and I was about your same age when it happened. I understand how scary it is. I'm not mad at you."

"Thank you, Felix. Um, Felix, can I continue the hug?" Arachne asked.

"Sure," Felix answered and as soon as that single word departed from his mouth, Arachne brought him into a firm hug once again. The hug was long, but it was eventually ended and Arachne set Felix on the ground and laid her spider body down on the ground. "Hey, did you get any bigger?" Felix questioned as he noticed that Arachne seemed a little bit bigger than yesterday.

Arachne looked at herself and then compared her size with Felix. "I think you're right," Arachne agreed, "I did get bigger, but by how much?"

"I'd say you grew about ten more feet," Felix said as he stared up at Arachne in awe.

"I've been having a lot of growth spurts lately," Arachne informed Felix, "I think I'm growing to my natural height with each spurt."

"How big are you supposed to get?" Felix asked.

"I'm not sure, but something in my mind is telling me that the normal height for a giant dridder like me is about 75 feet," Arachne said. Arachne looked down and saw that Felix was nervous around her again. Arachne recognized that this was because he was worried about her being so big. "Please don't be scared, Felix. I promise that no matter how big I get, you'll always be my friend and I will never hurt you," Arachne tried to assure him.

Felix seemed to be calmed by that statement and Arachne grabbed the cart. She took the deer out and began her wrapping. "Arachne, I think I may have found a way out," Felix informed her.

Arachne stopped wrapping the deer right away and bent down closer to Felix till her large face was almost level with Felix. "R-Really? A way out of here? Can we leave now?" Arachne asked excitedly.

"There's a problem with that. I'm not sure how to get those chains off you," Felix pointed out.

Arachne's hopes seemed to dash away as she replied sadly, "Oh."

"Arachne, can I get a closer look at one of them?" Felix asked.

Arachne lowered one of her hands to Felix and he looked at the cuff around her wrist. He found the keyhole to it and saw how large it was. "It would need a huge key to unlock this. Wait, the guard had some unusually large keys on that chain. Could one of those keys unlock these chains?" Felix wondered. "I might know a way to get these chains off you," Felix told her, "There is a guard outside that has some large keys. They could be the keys needed to unlock the cuffs around your wrists and waist."

"If we get these chains off, can we leave this morning?" Arachne asked.

"Yes, it's highly possible," Felix stated

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- ------------------------------

Outside of the cell, the guard tried his hardest to stay awake. He rubbed his eyes once more, hoping to keep his eye lids from drifting downwards. "What is taking that boy so long?" the guard muttered, "Does it really take that long to feed a monster? You'd think he'd want to spend the least amount of time possible in there."

The guard yawned and sleepiness was much stronger in his mind now, ready to place a blanket of dreams on his brain. "If I fall asleep now, the slave will be trapped in the cell with that monster, and if he needs help, I won't be able to save him," the guard realized.

"Screw it," the guard decided quickly, "If the slave is trapped in the cell or he dies from that beast, it's his own damn fault for taking so long and coming so early. Besides, what's another dead slave." The guard let his eye lids cover his eyes as he leaned against the wall once more.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- -----------------------------

Felix walked to the door quietly and peeked through the iron bars the door was made of. The guard was asleep, just as Felix had hoped. Felix's eyes locked onto his target, the key chain on the guard's belt. Felix put his hand through the bars and realized that his whole arm could fit through as well. Felix pushed his arm through the bars and reached for the keys slowly.

Felix's fingertips touched the cold metal of the keys causing them to clang against each other. Felix froze and the guard stirred, but never opened his eyes. Felix stood frozen at the door with one arm still sticking thought the bars of the door stretched to the keys around the guard’s belt. Felix's heart hammered beneath his chest and he perspired from the event, but he didn't wipe his forehead. He didn't dare move an inch, fearing it would wake up the guard and his plans would be foiled.

Long moments passed and the guard was still fast asleep. "He's still asleep, Felix. Get a grip," Felix thought, trying to encourage himself, "You can do this. All you have to do is reach out and take the keys." Felix reached out again, but much slower and gentler. Felix grabbed the keys themselves and gently pressed them together so they wouldn’t jangle as he brought them to the door. Felix pulled the keys off the guard's belt and pulled them through the bars without alerting the guard of anything unusual.

Felix turned around to see Arachne waiting as close as she could with the restricting chains around her. She was clearly waiting in hopes that Felix obtained the keying. Upon seeing Felix approaching her with the keys in hand, Arachne nearly yelped with joy, but luckily she stopped herself in time.

Felix eventually reached the giant five year old dridder that was gitty with excitement. "I hope this works," Felix said, "Could you lower a wrist for me?" Arachne complied with Felix's request, and Felix found the keyhole for the cuff. Felix studied it and then the keys. He picked a key that seemed to be the right size. The key fit and turned. The cuff on Arachne's right wrist split and fell away onto the ground which luckily wasn't too high up and didn't make too loud of a sound. Arachne lifted her right hand and stared at her free wrist in amazement.

"Arachne, I need to see your other wrist," Felix informed her. Arachne snapped out of her trance and lowered her left wrist. Felix unlocked that cuff as well. "It looks like the only one left is around your waist," Felix pointed out, "I'm going to need a lift to unlock it." Arachne agreed and picked up Felix so that he could unlock the cuff around her waist.

When this was done, there were no longer any chains restricting Arachne. Arachne was so happy that she pulled Felix into a hug again and whispered, "Thank you, Felix. I'm free."

"We're not out of this yet," Felix replied.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- -------------------------------

Felix soon found himself at the door once again. He had already told Arachne his plan. She was a little hesitant about the idea, but Felix assured her that it was what they needed to do. Felix unlocked the door by putting his arm through the bars. The guard didn't even budge from his position leaning against the wall by the door. "He's tired and a heavy sleeper. For once, luck is on my side today," Felix thought.

Felix opened the door and walked to the larger door that Arachne could fit through. Felix found the right key and unlocked it. Arachne could hear the unlocking from the other side and waited a bit before trying to push the door open. Arachne did it as slow as she could. When it was opened enough for her to get through, she squeezed through. She looked down at Felix below her who pointed at the guard. This was the part of the plan Arachne didn't want to do, but Felix had convinced her earlier it was for the best. Arachne shot out a stream of webbing which covered the guard as he tried to wake up. His mouth was covered and the rest of his body was encased in a cocoon. His nose on up were free from the cocoon so that he would live.

Arachne picked up the guard and placed him in the cell before closing the big doors. "I should probably carry you so that we get there faster," Arachne suggested.

"You're right," Felix agreed before she picked him up.

"Show me the way," Arachne commanded.

Felix pointed Arachne the way to the underground river and they were able to use the underground dungeons to get there. Luckily, they didn't run into anymore people. Arachne walked through a large, cavernous archway and they were on the rocky platform in front of the underground river. Felix smiled, thinking they had finally made it. Felix looked up at Arachne and saw a very worried and frightened face staring at the water. "Arachne, what's wrong?" Felix questioned.

"You didn't say anything about water," Arachne whispered, "I... I can't swim."

"You can't swim?" Felix asked in shock.

"I... I'm afraid. I can't do this," Arachne panicked.

"Arachne, listen to me," Felix demanded, trying to calm her down, "You not going to have to get in the water. You can climb the walls easily, right?"

"But what if I..." Arachne worried.

"Arachne, every thing's going to be alright. You're not going to fall in the water. Trust me," Felix interrupted.

Arachne took many deep breaths and replied, "Alright."

"Now, I think you should crawl on the walls and go upstream. If they realize we used the underground river, they might think we went downstream. They wouldn't think we'd go up river," Felix suggested.

"Alright," Arachne agreed and started climbing the walls while pressing Felix's body close to hers. They continued up river for a long time and they were far from the platform, but something bad happened.

What happened?
1432211121112.title: Finally, an Escape Plan

choices: It was a large open cavern with a dry path she could take.
They came upon a waterfall inside the mountain. It was lit by some glowing rocks
14322111211121.content:
Felix blinked a few times as he felt Arachane's body undulate behind him. Darkness was all around him. He could not see his hand three feet from his face. Only his senses of hearing and touch helped him. The air was heavy with water and dankness he had known from his years as a slave. He felt Arachane's grip tighten every once in a while. He had no idea how long they had been going, but given the feel of wind on his face, he knew it was a good pace.

His hearing told him things as well. First, Arachane was taking deep breaths frequently and whimpering every once in a while.

"Probably worried about falling in," Felix thought as he turned to the river. While he could not see the black water racing below, his ears told him the river was running quickly. He finally chanced speaking.

"Arachane," Felix called out. He felt a sudden stop.

"Felix? Is everything all right?" she asked, breathing deeply as she did.

"I'm all right. I was just going to ask you how you were doing," Felix replied. What Felix did not see was his worry made Arachane smile for the first time since they began moving into the tunnel. She was happy she had him with her.

"If it wasn't for Felix, I know I wouldn't be here .. . trying to escape over . . . a river," Arachane thought as her breathing quickened even more from remembering the fast moving waters beneath her. Her vision allowed her to see very clearly in the darkness and her legs were sticking well against the stone. She just had to keep looking forward.

"Thanks Felix, but I don't want to talk to much, not with the . . ." she replied. Felix felt the chest rise once more and injected.

"I understand. Let's get moving," Felix said. He felt Arachane's breathing slow down and soon she was moving again. But in her haste, Arachane did not see the small crevice in the lower part of the wall as she approached. She did not see the water coming from it. She just kept moving and soon found her back foot landing in the hole.

"AHH!" Arachane screamed as she lurched forward. She felt her hands fly open and watched in slow motion as Felix fell into the river. Her eyes narrowed with fear. Felix wasn't coming up.

************

Felix felt the lurch and before he could scream from being airborne, he hit the cold mountain water. A new darkness surrounded him and he panicked and tried to swim to the surface. Finally, he broke the surface in time to hit a rock. It was wet and so slippery. The water was draining all warmth from his body.

"ARACHANE!" Felix screamed as he was pressed against the rock, trying to climb on.

*****************

Arachane turned about and looked down the river when she heard the scream. "FELIX!" she cried out. He was a hundred feet behind her, in the middle of the river clinging to a rock for dear life. She moved quickly towards him.

*********************

With the roaring of the water at his ears, Felix just barely heard his friend's call. "Ara*cough*Chane!" he responded, looking blindly around, until he saw them, two large red eyes looking down at him. Relief filled his mind.

******************

Arachane reached to her friend from her place on the side, but could not reach him. She was short by ten feet. Tears came to her eyes as she wanted so badly to save her friend. She saw his grip loosening. Biting her lips, she knew what she had to do. Swim or not, Felix was going to die if she kept doing nothing. So, she jumped and quickly grabbed Felix with her hand. But she fell short of the other bank and pushed Felix above her head as she hit the water.

*************************

Felix saw the eyes approach him quickly and a familiar hand grab him, then quickly push him upward when Arachane began to fall. He heard the large splash Arachane made, but nothing else. Arachane was where she landed.

The young dridder quickly got to her feet and realized the water did not even come to her knees. She began to laugh and moved to the bank, clutching Felix to her chest.

"Felix, are you all right?" Arachane asked looking down at her friend. Something seemed off, but his safety was all that mattered at the moment.

"I'll be all right," Felix said as he felt the cold air chill his wet skin, "Thank you for jumping in for me."

"I couldn't let you die," Arachane replied, bringing Felix into her breast for another warming hug. As she did, she lifted her hind legs and pulled out some webbing. With a free hand, she grabbed it. "Felix," she said after a moment.

"Yes?" he responded.

"May I wrap you in some webbing? That way I won't worry about dropping you again," Arachane inquired. Felix smiled.

"That sounds wise," he answered before finding his lower regions wrapped in his friend's webbing. It did wonders to warm his cold body. It went as far as his neck and felt himself pulled up to Arachane's neck. He recalled seeing a lady visitor dressed up with some jewel around her neck. He imagined he looked similar on Arachane. "Ready?" he asked.

"Yes," his friend responded before starting once more. But what they did not realize, from Felix being too cold and Arachane being too worried, was Felix's rags he called clothes, if you could consider them clothes at all, were all but destroyed by the river, leaving him very nearly naked.

Some time passed, with warmth fighting out the cold that filled his bones, and Arachane soon came upon a new place

143221112111211.content:
Arachne came upon a fork in the path. One path continued upstream against the underground river. The other path started as a rocky shore for the river and continued into a large tunnel big enough for Arachne. Also, Arachne and Felix could see a light coming from around the corner as the dry tunnel turned. Given that Arachne was frightened of water and that the dry path seemed to lead to a way out, it was an easy choice for Arachne as she took the dry tunnel. She was glad she was on the right side of the wall to go to the tunnel, otherwise, she would have had to go on the ceiling and go upside down to get there.

Once she was on the dry tunnel, Arachne got off the wall and placed all eight legs on the floor. Arache let out and exasperated sigh of relief. Felix looked up at what he could of Arachne as he dangled from her neck. "You did it, Arachne," Felix congratulated the forty-five foot tall five year old dridder that was is only friend.

Arachne looked down at her little human friend so that he was about to see her pretty and youthful face."I did, and it's thanks to you, Felix. I couldn't have done it without you," Arachne told him.

Felix was glad to hear this. Despite Arachne being a giant that made Felix look like he was a little more than seven inches tall to her, she still saw him as a person. Arachne still saw him as an equal and a friend that had helped her find the courage to overcome one of her greatest fears. He was truly safe with the giant dridder, and Felix no longer feared her. He trusted her with his life!

Suddenly, Arachne smiled and giggled as she stared at Felix. Confused by this reaction, Felix questioned, "What's so funny?"

"You look so funny and cute as my necklace," Arachne laughed. She poked Felix's side to make in swing for an added effect.

"Hey," Felix hollered. He wasn't mad at Arachne. In fact, he thought it was quite funny as well, he was just playing with Arachne.

"Sorry, Felix," Arachne replied, still giggling, "I couldn't help myself. Do you want down and out of those webs?"

"Actually, your webbing is very warm. I'm fine with staying in this till we find a place to stay," Felix informed her.

"You sure?" Arachne replied, "Well, if you like being my necklace, then I guess I'll let you be that."

With that said, Arachne began walking again. When she came to the turn, she turned and had to cover her eyes with her arm for a moment. Felix had to close his eyes till he was a little more used to it. When their eyes adjusted, they found themselves in a huge cavern. It was perfect for a giant dridder that was still growing, such as Arachne. Arachne was amazed by the cave. It reminded her so much of her home in Felarya. The light was coming from the entrance of the cave, but it didn't engulf the entire cave. There were still dark places that pleased Arachne. Arachne looked down at Felix and with excited eyes she pleaded, "Can this be our home?"

Felix had no problems with the cave. He could also see a dense woods outside the entrance. So, they might not have troubles getting food. "Sure, we can stay here," Felix agreed, "This should be a safe place to stay. Even if Lord William figures out we went up stream and find where the river reaches the surface. This cave is on a different path from the river. We can stay here," Felix informed her.

Arachne smiled and replied, "Good, this looks just like my old home."

Suddenly, Felix heard a deep growl beneath him from the dark abysses of Arachne's stomach. "Looks like you're hungry," Felix laughed nervously.

"I didn't eat the breakfast you gave me, and it's lunchtime. Are you hungry too?" Arachne asked.

"Yeah," Felix answered.

"Would you like to wait here, and I'll catch the food?" Arachne suggested.

"Sure," Felix agreed.

Arachne made a very quick and small web and placed Felix in it. "I'll be right back," Arachne told him.

"I don't have to worry about being par of your meal, right?" Felix asked as he was suspended in her web.

"You may be in my web right now, but I will never eat you, Felix," Arachne assured Felix, "You're my only friend. I need you too much to just eat you."

With that assurance, Arachne left the cave to catch some food. After lunch, she would make her web in the cave and make a few trap webs for the animals of the woods. They animals won't know what hit them.

Archane moved quietly through the woods. The forest was old and the trees were still larger than her current height. But despite being larger, they were still no where near as large as the ones in her old home. This made her guess hunting would be similar to there.. Of course, she realized as she moved through the trees, she was now the largest predator and could take out any thing she wanted.

"No," she thought, stopping for a moment, "Not everything. Humans are not prey. I can't eat humans." She nodded as this fact. If she ate a human, she would risk becoming a monster and Felix would never be safe around her ever again. "I can't lose Felix! I won't lose him!" She paused her thinking when she heard a noise in the area. She moved into the shadows and saw a large buck in a clearing. She wondered how she would entrap the creature when she heard another noise and looked around. Out of no where, an arrow flew and struck the buck in the legs, causing it to fall to the ground. A human appeared from the trees and walked over to the buck. It looked different from the other humans Archane had seen in the castle. The hunter removed its hat revealing long red hair.

"Good size," Archane heard the hunter say. She turned to the edge. "Emily, bring the rope so we can take this home."

"Coming mother," came a young voice. A young girl, no older than Felix came running out with rope and handed the rope to her mother. Her mother, a hunter named Beth, smiled and took the rope before instructing her daughter on how to tie up the buck.

"I hope they leave soon," Archane thought as they tied up the buck. She was hungry and really wanted to find some food.

Finally, they pair moved away and dragged the deer off in one direction. Archane made a note of it, not wanting to run into that woman. She moved back and headed off in a different direction.

It took Archane a while to find some more deer. She saw two sitting at the edge of a river. Carefully, she produced some webbing and laid it between some trees. Then, she moved to the other side and made a loud noise. She watched the deer come to attention and rush off into the brush, but they did not make it far. She smiled a little as she went over and encased her two prey.

"This should be enough for now," Archane said to herself. She didn't want to leave Felix alone for too long a time. While she felt he was safe, she didn't want to chance that hunter coming to the cave and finding Felix.

A few minutes later Archane returned to her new home. She would wait until night to set up her traps.

Upon entering, she saw Felix dosing off in his web cocoon. Archane smiled and moved close to the web. She placed the two deer on before picking Felix off. He still did not wake. She smiled down at her little friend.
