145322.content:
Felix's eyes adjusted to the low light and looked around the dungeon. The room was tall, well over 100 feet tall. There were some skeletons still hanging from chains on the walls. He gulped and remembered why he was there. He expected to attacked quickly, but there was no attack. He looked closer to the ground and tried finding the naga, but in the dark corners, he saw nothing.

But then he heard it. A quiet rushed breath, like the being was scared. Felix noticed then a thick chain coming from the ceiling dipped down to one corner. He pushed the cart towards the corner and when the contents stumbled, he saw it. Or at least its eye. A large dark blue eye stared before hiding again.

Felix felt his heart race in fear and realized he shouldn't be standing there looking at this creature. It could realize Felix was nothing and eat him, so Felix quickly put the food and water bowl on the ground and left as quickly as he could. As he pushed the cart out, he heard the sadistic guard call to him.

"See you at dinner slave," the guard called, "Or possibly for dinner." Felix shook in fear and continued on his way.

---------------------------------------

Back in the dungeon, slowly the young naga unraveled itself. It was a unique naga as its tail scales were solid obsidian, which let him hide in the shadows perfectly. His human body was covered in scars from whips and swords General Ethan and his men used to capture him. His black hair was the same color as his tail and he pushed it out of his way to look at the things the human left.

He had never seen humans before. One moment, he was hunting some small nekos, then the next thing he knew he was no longer in his home woods, when suddenly humans started attacking him. The young, scared, confused naga never stood a chance.

The little human that entered, this naga knew he'd be hurt by him like the others if he got close. But the human left.

Slowly, the naga slithered to the food and drink and sniffed. It didn't smell poisonous and there were few poisons that could harm one of his kind. So, it took the large cut of meat and put it in his mouth and drank the water. But it was still hungry.

"You will be very hungry now my son, as you are about to grow to a large proud naga," he could remember his mother's words and a promise he'd taste his first human after wards.

"Once I grow, these humans will pay," the young naga thought without much confidence. His declaration was more to comfort himself than any serious promise. He could only wonder how much longer until his first growth spurt.

Little did he know it would be in a two days . . .
145322.title: Two Scared Boys

choices: Felix entered to give the naga lunch and heard the naga crying.
During the next growth spurt...
1453222.content:
Two days past and the naga soon began to realize the routine of the humans who had captured him. Human soldiers came twice each being between meal times, and they tortured the naga brutally. The naga didn't know what the humans wanted as they beat him with strange and strong weapons, and the naga didn't know what he could have possibly done to them to deserve such a treatment. The torturers used many different and bizarre looking weapons and the naga was too busy trying to protect himself from the blows. The naga never fought back for many reasons. For one, he thought that if he stopped blocking to attack a human, he would be open for attack for another humans, because about ten humans came each time. Also, he feared that the attack on a human would provoke the humans to fight harder and hurt him more.

Besides, he was still five years old. He wasn't a proficient fighter and he still only knew the basics of hunting, let alone fighting. He was too young to do anything against the humans, especially when he was too scared to do so. However, he did know that when he becomes his real height of about seventy feet, he would have a better chance against the humans. One doesn't need too much strategy when one is large enough for humans to look like they're a few inches tall. Still, it would be a risk if the humans should swarm and fight with more powerful weapons. For now, the naga just had to wait and take the terrible hits from the humans

Because of the brutal torture secessions, the naga started becoming desperate within a day! The torture and the dark and gloomy cell the naga was forced to suffer was just too much for a five year old mind to handle. It was already starting to traumatizing him and put him in a state of hopelessness. It had been two and a half days he had been in the terrible darkness and it was becoming too much for the child naga.

It was morning and the naga was coiled up in his corner with his human half lying on his coils. The naga was coiled in a spiral, but not an upward spiral. The spiral was on the ground and his whole tail was flat on the ground. His human half was lying on top of the coils with his chest and stomach on his tail. The naga had his arms crossed with his chin resting on his arms and he was staring at the human sized barred door. He knew that food would arrive soon.

"The human will feed me, but it won't be enough. I'm always starving after wards," the naga muttered. It was true that he was still hungry after every meal now, but it was also true that the meals were filling his stomach. For some reason, Felaryan nagas can eat more food than they need to. They can survive off of filling their stomach, but there always seems to be room for more and they often eat more just to comfort themselves. Now that the naga was becoming a giant, he was starting to have those effects on his stomach. It's still unknown why Felaryan nagas have such a strange appetite. One belief is that eating is an enjoyment to them. They eat to make themselves happy and they hunt for fun. So, when a naga is feeling a little down or bored, they hunt and eat to make themselves feel better. They don't realize what's going on, but their stomach makes them feel as though their hungry to get them to eat and hunt for enjoyment. So, since the naga is trapped in a dark cell, being tortured by humans, it's no surprise to why he feels like he's starving.

As the naga waited for his food, he began to think about his home. He missed the thick forests, the sunlight when it warmed his skin, the food from his world, and most of all his parents. "I need to get out of here," the naga whispered, "But how? I have to wait till I'm bigger to try and escape, but that could take month. Those monsters might kill me by then."

The naga began to cry, "I wish I knew what they wanted of me. Maybe if I give them what they want, they'll let me go." The naga thought about talking to one of the humans, but he soon became frightened to do so. He began to worry that the humans might hurt him for asking. It seemed hopeless to the naga and he thought the only way out would be to escape, until he remembered that there was a human who didn't harm him, the young boy who fed him. The boy had never hurt the naga, he just ran in, gave him the food, and then ran out as quickly as he could. "It's as if he's afraid of me for some reason," the naga thought to himself, "Maybe he won't hurt me if I talk to him and maybe he'll be willing to tell me what they want from me."

The boy feeding him was only a few years older and seemed much more approachable to the naga. Plus, the human was still a person to the naga and not food. To a Felaryan naga, some one as a person if the person couldn't fit in their mouth, but if the person can fit in a naga's mouth, the naga categorizes that person as food and prey. Since a naga can swallow anything that fits in its mouth, because of its flexible throat, its safe to say that anything swallowable to the naga is prey and everything else is a person. The human boy couldn't fit in the naga's mouth yet, so the human was still a person. It sounds terrible to us that a naga could see something as a person one day and change its mind the next just because of the size change, but it was normal to the nagas. There have been cases when a five year old naga made friends with five year old human. They'd become best friends until the naga grew to seventy feed and ate the human best friend like it was no big deal. As cruel and heartless as that may seem, Felaryans don't see it that way and don't understand the cruelty of it because their too used to using size to judge whether something is a person or not.

The young boy was still a person in the naga's mind, for now, and the naga thought it might be best to try and speak to the human and ask the human why he was here. So, it was decided, the naga would approach the human this time and try to speak to the human. He needed help and the human that fed him seemed to be the only possible help he was going to get. The naga waited in his coils for the young boy to arrive.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- -----------------------------

Felix was heading for the naga's cell while pushing the cart of food and water. Felix began to think about the naga as he walked. He had been in the naga's cell eight times and it hadn't once tried to kill or attack him. This seemed odd to Felix because Lord William claimed the naga to be a monster. "Why doesn't it try to attack me when I go in there?" Felix wondered.

"Maybe it's because I go in and out too fast for it," He suggested in his mind, but he soon threw that suggestion out of his mind. The naga was part snake and Felix knew how fast snakes could be. There had to be another reason.

Felix thought back to how Lord William told Felix the naga was only five years old. The naga was still a toddler. Felix knew the naga was being tortured, he had come early one time and saw the aftermath of the torture. "If that naga is only a child, what effects might be from that torture?" Felix wondered.

Felix remembered the first day he was enslaved, the earliest memory he could remember. He remembered how terrible he felt in those first days. "It's a sentient being, so it must feel the same way I did when I came to Lord William's castle. It's scared, sad, and alone," Felix realized. Felix remembered the feelings and the depression he suffered from the first few months. It was something no man could describe. "That must be the reason why it doesn't attack, its scared," Felix realized.

As Felix walked down the corridor getting closer to the cell door, Felix thought about what he should do. "I know that Lord William said that Felaryan nagas see humans as food, but maybe I can reason with it. The naga is sentient after all. Maybe if I treat it better than the guards..." Felix wondered.

"But Lord William said they can't be reasoned with," Felix's brain argued.

"But I would never eat a fairy," Felix argued with himself, "How can a sentient being be so cruel they'd eat another sentient being whose helping it just because it's larger than the second?"

Felix made it to the cell and ten guards were stationed outside. They were ready for the naga in case it grew out of its chains. Felix was let in the cell and he pushed the cart in the center as fast as he could. Luckily, he spotted that something was off and he stopped the cart. Felix stood in awe as he saw the naga was free!

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- -------------------

As the naga waited for the young human to come, the naga continued to feel an increasing pressure around where the chains were. Eventually, it became painful the naga examined himself. The naga's eyes widened in surprise as he noticed he was growing. The naga uncoiled himself and stood up straight. Excitement overwhelmed him as he was finally having a growth spurt. Soon, the old chains around him broke and he was free. He loincloth also ripped off as well, showing off his privates. (Yes, Felaryan nagas have a snake tail starting at the hips, but where the human skin and the snake skin start, it forms a fancy U. So, the front privates are on the human half and they have human reproductive organs. They don't have a human butt though because its all snake tail back there.)

The naga eventually stopped growing and was now close to twenty feet tall from ground up and he tail was at least fifty feet long! "Wow," the naga whispered as he looked at his hands. The naga slithered into what light it had in the cell and examined his new body. The familiar sound of the door slamming and the wheeling of the cart brought the naga back into reality. The naga looked and saw the human hurrying up to give the food so he could get out quickly, but the human soon stopped when he saw the naga and the human looked up in fear.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- ------

The naga was just like Lord William had said, a fully human upper half on top of a snake tail. The naga even had a penis. The naga had a black snake tail with some red coloring like symbols, but it was just the coloring. The naga had long black hair and his human half looked just like a five year old human, except the naga was twenty feet tall now. The naga stared down at Felix and Felix was frightened beyond belief since he was a little less than one fourth of the naga's height.

----------------------------------------------------------------------------

The naga was becoming desperate and the first thing he thought about doing was escaping. he didn't realize he still wasn't big enough to properly escape. He just wanted to get out. The naga ignored the human, who was still a person to him, and slithered around the human, he hadn't done anything wrong to the naga. Then the naga reached the large doors and tried to break them apart.

Unfortunately, he wasn't big enough or strong enough. The guards entered quickly and began stabbing him with spear. The naga cried out in pain and just tried to protect himself. Suddenly, a guard blow a dart and the dart connected with the naga's neck. The naga pulled out the tiny dart and looked at it. The naga started seeing double and he became very dizzy. Soon, he collapsed and passed out.

Eventually, the naga woke up, in his corner with new chains on him. The naga didn't recover quickly and had to wait a while before he could get up. Once the naga could, he looked at the chains and saw they were much stronger than the others. The naga didn't know it, but the chains were also enchanted so that they could grow with his body. The naga pulled and tugged at the chains, but he was no use.

The naga tried for many minutes, but he began to realize it was hopeless and he collapsed in a coil and cried upon his tail. "I'm going to be here the rest of my life. I can't escape!" the naga thought.
1453222.title: Desperation

choices: Just collapsed and started crying about needing more food.
Saw Felix and demanded more food.
14532222.content:
As the naga cried, Felix was on his way to the kitchen to collect the food for the naga. But when he arrived, he ran into some trouble.

"No. He's not to get any lunch," the cook said, when Felix noticed the lack of food ready.

"Did . . .Did Master say this?" Felix asked quietly, questioning orders was an easy way to get whipped. But thankfully the cook wasn't the type to tell on him.

"It's for him trying to escape, so he's forced to miss a meal," the cook said, "Come back at lunch." Felix nodded and walked out.

"They really hurt him this morning. And he didn't even eat his breakfast. I hope he's all right after missing lunch as well," Felix thought as he moved on to his other chores.

----------------------------------------

In the cell, the naga stopped crying from fear of never escaping. But something had come to replace that crying, cry for food.

"I'm soooo HUNGRY!" the young naga cried as he held his tail, "Why isn't the food here yet?" His breathing was heavy and his need for some food was increasing by the second. His huge hands gripped the blades of grass to eat but there weren't enough coming between the dungeon's floors. His eyes looked up at the skeletons and other bodies hanging and grabbed for them, chains and body. He pushed the meek bones in and the metal and swallowed but it wasn't enough. And because they were just bones or rotten flesh, he really didn't taste what a human tasted like, similar to how tasting sour milk is far different from normal milk.

"I NEED FOOOOD!" the young naga thought as he grabbed his tail once more and cried heavily.

------------------------------

Later, his usual beating came and departed and the young naga didn't even try to fight back because of his huge hunger. He was just sitting there, holding his tail, crying about food.

-----------------------------------------

Dinner came and Felix was inwardly happy as he pushed the cart to the cell. First, it seemed there was more food for the naga. Second, with the usage of those new chains he saw them put on the naga after it was put out, the guards had been reduced to two. But the blow dart remained. He walked past the guards as they opened the door and quickly closed it behind Felix.

"Now where is the naga," Felix said, his eyes instinctively looking to a corner, but instead saw him lying on his tail near the middle. The eyes were closed tightly and the naga seemed to be crying. Then the eyes suddenly opened and looked at Felix. Felix, worried, started moving back, bringing the cart with him.
--------------------------------------

"Soooo Hunngrryyy," the naga bemoaned in thought. He was so out of it, he didn't hear the door open and close. But then something came to his nose. Blood. Fresh blood not his own. The eyes darted at the cart and the naga smiled.

"FOOD! the naga thought but saw the human leaving. Quickly he released his tail and shot it behind Felix so he couldn't escape and grabbed the meat on the cart.

----------------------------------------

Felix was terrified when he looked back and saw a shiny black tail that wasn't there a moment ago. As he looked forward he saw the the huge hand grabbing the meat and shoving it to the mouth. Bits of meat dropped from the over stuffed mouth. Felix quickly put the water down and moved away to get around the tail to the door. But as he did, he saw the tail moving along with him. But when Felix looked, the naga seemed too caught up in grabbing the bits of meat that he missed to notice him. But then he saw the naga seem to rise up in the air and the chain that held him grew thicker.

"He's . . . He's growing again!?" Felix thought, watching the the naga gain about seven feet in body height and the tail another ten feet. The tail now touched the wall and made it impossible for Felix to escape without possibly calling the guards. But they would just beat the naga and Felix couldn't see that happening. Not to someone so young and alone as this naga must be. "Well I wanted to talk with the naga," Felix thought meekly.

Soon the naga, not even noticing his growth, only his hunger remained unsated took a breath and
14532222.title: Hungry

choices: The naga was overwhelmed and picked up and hugged Felix.
The naga, not wnating to scare Felix away, held in his joy and asked his name.
145322221.content:
In the naga's despair, he completely forgot about the boy who fed him. The naga pretty much assumed that the boy left already since the boy usually left as soon as he fed the naga. The naga was too hungry and too depressed to realize the boy was trapped by the tail. The naga's upper body collapsed on the ground causing the naga's body to be in a C-shape. The naga crossed his arms and laid his face on his arms while he sobbed harder than he ever had before. The naga was tired, hungry, and depressed. "I'm never going to see my home and family again," the naga despaired, "I'm going to be trapped in this place the rest of my life, or until I starve to death." The naga feared there was no hope.

Felix could only stare at the naga as he cried uncontrollably. In that moment, Felix forgot the naga was some terrible and dangerous creature that had no remorse in eating humans. Instead, Felix saw himself when he was forced into slavery. He saw a young child that didn't deserve the unspeakable treatment it was getting. The naga, though about twenty-seven tall with an extremely long tail, was still only a very sad and lonely child.

Felix looked to the door. He could still get around the crying naga by going around the upper body of the naga, but in Felix's mind, he couldn't. Felix just couldn't let the naga suffer anymore. "Hey," Felix called out, still a little meek. However, the naga was sobbing too hard and oblivious to the world around him. Felix tried again and was louder. The naga flinched, able to hear Felix this time. The naga slowly lifted his head till only one large, blue, sad eye was staring at Felix.

The naga had thought he was the only one in the cell, and it was startled by the sudden voice. When he peeked from his wet arms, he saw the older boy who fed him was still there. The naga was in a confused state and didn't notice he had grown just yet. He was too busy wondering why the boy was still in the cell. "he usually runs off as soon as I eat. Why is he...?" the naga questioned, but soon saw his tail was in his way.

"I'm blocking his way. He just wants out," the naga thought. Because the human still was too big to swallow, the naga still viewed the boy as a person. The naga, no matter how badly he wanted help, couldn't bring himself to hold a person captive. The naga curled his tail away and then brought it into himself. The naga didn't coil the tail underneath him, but he still laid his upper body on his tail nevertheless. the naga then continued to cry on his tail.

Felix was a little confused by the naga's reaction. "Maybe he thought I wanted to leave," Felix wondered, "I never stay that long and by the way the guards treat him, he probably thinks humans aren't capable of good deeds"

"If I show him it is possible for humans to be good and I'm kind to him, I might be able to befriend him," Felix reasoned, "He is a sentient being after all. And if he and I become friends, surely he won't eat me. I know Lord William warned me Felaryans can't be reasoned with, but no sentient being could be heartless enough to eat someone whose a kind friend, can they?"

"Excuse me, naga," Felix called out. The naga peeked again and Felix slowly approached as he continued, "I just wanted to..." Before Felix could continue, the naga quickly lifted his arms and put them on top of his head as he laid his head on the ground as if trying to protect himself. The naga even hid his head behind his tail for the safe measure.

After seeing the naga's reaction, Felix's fear quickly began to evaporate, and sympathy was replacing his fear. Felix couldn't believe something as large as the naga was afraid of him. "Those guards must have really traumatized him," Felix realized, "Damn those heartless monsters."

It may seem odd that the twenty-seven foot tall and estimated sixty foot long tail creature could be afraid of a ten year old boy. But the naga still viewed Felix as a person and since humans were still people to the naga, the naga couldn't bring himself to fight back if they attacked. If the naga was his normal five year old size of seventy feet tall, then the naga wouldn't be afraid of humans, because they would be prey. And if the humans were prey, the naga would just eat them like it was no big deal. As strange as that may seem, that was just how Felaryan nagas thought.

"There's no reason to fear me," Felix tried to assure the naga in a comforting and inviting voice, "I just want to talk." But as Felix got closer, the naga backed up. Felix stopped approaching the naga and began to worry the naga couldn't understand him. "Can you understand me? Do you know what I'm saying?" Felix asked.

English was the primary language for Felarya and the naga could understand and speak English. The naga just nodded his head. "You just don't trust me, right?" Felix asked. The naga nodded once more. Felix paused and wondered what he could say that would get the naga to trust him. Felix noticed the naga's back and got an idea. "What if I told you I'm not like the rest of the humans you met?" Felix asked.

The naga peeked over his thick tail and stared at the human in confusion. "I think it's better if I show you first," Felix explained as he turned around.

The naga was even more confused when the human turned his back to the naga and started lifting his shirt. However, when the naga was able to see the human's back, the naga began to realize what the human meant. The naga's eyes widened in shock and surprise and he lifted his head over his tail to get a better and closer look, though lifting his head over his tail was as close as he got to the human. The human was still two or three yards away. The human's back was full of scars both old and new. The naga couldn't believe it. The human had been hit by many whips as well. With his confusion, the naga found a voice and spoke for the first time since he had been captured. "They whip you too?" the naga asked.

"Yeah," Felix replied, not entirely surprised the naga could speak, "They whip me too."

"But, you're a human, like them," the naga argued, "Why would they whip you?"

"They whip me when I do something that displeases them," Felix told the naga, "Though I am a human, they don't see me as a human."

"Why?" the naga asked. The naga found it confusing that humans didn't see the boy as a human when he was clearly a human.

"They see me as a slave," Felix answered, "I'm in a class that is lower than the insects they crush under their boots. I'm nothing to them, not even an insect."

The naga couldn't believe what he was hearing. It was so sad and unbelievable. "How can humans be so cruel?" the naga wondered, "They don't even see him as a human, just something less than a person. Has he done anything to deserve that treatment?"

Felix lowered his shirt and turned back around. "So you see, I'm not like those other humans. I'm more like you than those monsters," Felix stated, "That's why I'm not hear to hurt you, I don't think I ever could try to hurt you. I just want to talk."

"Talk? Why?" the naga asked.

"Well, I see what they do to you and I know how bad you must feel," Felix explained, "I felt the same why when I was forced to come here."

"They captured you to?" the naga gasped.

"I'm not sure. I was five when I got here, but I can't remember anything before I got here. It's as if my memory was wiped of something," Felix replied, "But I remember my first day here very well. I felt alone and sad. I felt hopeless, worthless, and powerless to do anything. I know that's how you must feel, right." The naga nodded and Felix continued, "Because I know what it's like to be in your position, I can't just let you suffer. I thought that maybe there was someway I could help you so that you aren't sad and lonely anymore."

"You... you want to be my friend?" the naga questioned, wondering if that was what the human was implying.

"Yes," Felix answered.

1453222211.content:
"He wants to be my friend . . .A friend! the young naga thought. He smiled a broad smile and reached out quicker than Felix could realize and he grabbed the small human, bringing him to his chest.

"What the?!" Felix thought as he was suddenly pressed against a wall of muscle and little baby fat. He heard the large heart booming and the hands of the young naga pressing him against the chest. "He's hugging me?" Felix thought realizing very quickly this was the first hug he could ever remember receiving. He didn't know what to say or how to respond until a few seconds passed.

"Umm . . . this is getting . . . a bit . .. tight," Felix said as he felt the pressure increase. He heard a gasp and was pulled away from the chest but not let go.

"Umm, I'm sorry," the naga said, "I'm still getting used to my new strength."

"Well, that's understandable, considering you just grew again," Felix said. The naga looked at him with confused eyes once more.

"I . .grew again?" the naga said, looking around. And he noticed his tail was definently longer than it used to be. He smiled. "I didn't even realize I grew!" he said in an amazed voice, "I was just really . . "

"Hungry?" Felix guessed, watching the five year old naga nod his head. Felix smiled at the young boy's happiness, depsite the young boy being over five times Felix's height, over ten if you included the tail.

But as he felt the hands of the naga around him, he recalled Lord William's harsh words about this creature, about how it would see him as prey and eat him.

"But we're friends," Felix thought, "How could he eat his friend?"

"Umm, Naga," Felix called.

"Yes?" the naga asked.

"You see me as a friend, right?" Felix asked.

"Yes," the naga said, nodding.

"Then you won't see me as prey?" Felix asked. Felix waited in hope the naga would nod, but no nod came. A shake from the naga's head emerged instead.

"Once something is small enough for me to swallow whole, it is prey," the naga said matter-o-factly. He watched his friend's expression change to one of shock.

"But . . How could you?" Felix asked, shocked at hearing the truth.

"It is the way things are," the naga said simply.

"But . . But . . . But that's like what the guards do to me!" Felix said, "I was a person forced to be a slave! They see me with no value and once you're large enough, you won't either!" The words came out faster than Felix could realize he was speaking to a child, and a child who could harm him very very easily.

But in the naga's mind, Felix's words bounced around.

"He's my friend now . . . And will be prey one day soon . . . He is human . . . But other humans treat him worse than crap . . . " the naga thought.

the five year old naga heard the words but didn't fully understand them. As he tried to understand what the human meant, the naga could only think about the day he would have to eat his human friend. 145322221122.content:
"Umm, Nahash," Felix said, looking at the young naga.

"Yes friend?" Nahash asked, smiling.

"I need to head out now," Felix said, looking at the door. When he looked back at Nahash, he saw a face of dread and worry.

"No! You can't!" Nahash said in a loud voice, causing Felix to panic. He didn't want the guards coming in and finding them being friendly.

"Nahash, not so loud!" Felix said in a loud whisper. He heard the naga's tail move behind him, likely blocking the door.

"But . I don't want you to go," Nahash said, quieting his voice. He brought his head close to Felix. "Can't you stay the night?" Felix bit his lip. Felix was worried of what might happen if he did. If he stayed and Nahash grew to a large enough size, he might eat Felix, considering he never said he wouldn't. There was also the chance Nahash might squish him or the guards could discover them.

"It might be a bad idea if I stayed," Felix said.

"But I don't want to be alone! It's so lonely!" Nahash replied, tears in his eyes.

"Nahash, if I stay, they could check on us and find us being friendly. If they know I'm your friend, they wouldn't let me see you," Felix replied. Tears came to Nahash's eyes quicker at the thought of losing his only friend.

"But I don't want you to go!" Nahash said in a tone many five year olds would use when they are desperate to stop something they don't like.

"Nahash, it's for the best. Please let me go," Felix pleaded.
145322221122.title: I can't stay

choices: Choice 1: The next day...
Choice 2: A week later...
1453222211221.content:
Nahash really didn't want Felix to leave, and being a twenty-seven foot tall child with a sixty foot long tail, Nahash could easily force Felix to stay. Most five year olds would do that, but Nahash was different. He saw Felix as a person and an older person he needed to obey. Nahash was taught to respect his elders and Felix, though much smaller than Nahash was older, around the age of an older brother. Because of this, Nahash still had to respect Felix since he was still a person and friend. Nahash sighed and moved his tail away from the door so that it was blocking Felix no more. Nahash looked at the ground in sadness.

Felix was surprised that the naga listened to him. Felix knew that Nahash had the power to do whatever he wanted with Felix and Felix wouldn't be able to stop Nahash. Felix was relieved to see that Nahash was going to listen to him and obey. "He must really want to keep my friendship," Felix thought to himself, "He's large enough to force me to stay or do something terrible if he's mad, but it seems like he wouldn't do such things to me, not yet anyway."

Felix was about to leave, but then he saw Nahash tilt his head to the ground. Felix approached the head and Nahash looked up, with his chin on the ground. Felix knelt down to try and be eye level with Nahash, because Felix was still taller than Nahash's head. Felix looked into Nahash's sad blue eyes and he touched Nahash's cheek. Felix rubbed the cheek and assured Nahash, "It's alright, I'm not going to be gone forever. I'll still come here everyday three times a day."

"But the next time won't be till tomorrow," Nahash argued, "I have to wait till night ends. I don't like sleeping alone in here. It's scary."

"I know it must be, but it will be alright," Felix continued to assure the giant naga, "I'm going to be here in the morning and nothing will harm you at night."

"You promise?" Nahash asked, "You promise to be my friend and met me everyday?"

"I promise, and I"ll try to stay here a little longer so we can talk and stuff," Felix replied.

This cheered Nahash up and he picked up Felix up again with a hand under each of Felix's arms and then brought him into a hug. Again, Felix was a little panicked from the sudden grab, but he was comforted by the hug. After another minute of hugging, Felix said, "Nahash, what did we discus about you picking me up without permission or a warning?"

Nahash realized what Felix was talking about right away and set Felix back down on the ground. "Sorry," Nahash answered, "I forgot. It's just that I get so happy and..."

"You just automatically pick me up and hug me without thinking," Felix finished for Nahash.

"Yes, I'm sorry. I'll try to remember to ask before I pick you up again," Nahash told Felix.

"Thank you, Nahash," Felix replied, "All be back tomorrow morning with your breakfast."

"I can't wait, see you then," Nahash replied. When Felix left the cell, Nahash coiled up and laid his upper body stomach first against the coils. For the first time since he had been captured, Nahash felt happy. He felt like the situation was no longer hopeless and that he still might find happiness now that he had a friend. Nahash also noticed he wasn't as hungry as he had before. Nahash smiled and fell asleep for the night.

Choice 1: The next day, Felix visited Nahash for breakfast and he learned more about Nahash and where Nahash came from.

Choice 2: A week passed and Nahash was now fifty feet tall with a tail nearly one hundred feet long. Felix was still not swallowable and Nahash still treated Felix as an equal. Nahash started seeing Felix as an older brother who looked after him, despite him being much larger than Felix. Felix might have found a possible way out.
1453222211221.title: Less Sadness

choices: Felix follows the Alchemist
Felix goes to Nahash and tells him what he learned.
14532222112212.content:
Felix was kneeeling at the floor, scrubbing it with all his strength. He knew soon he'd have to visit Nahash and feed him his lunch.

"This whole week has been strange," Felix thought about how his relationship with Nahash evolved from friends to the young naga seeing Felix closer and closer to family. Felix only hoped that being so close would protect him from being seen as prey once Nahash grew large enough. After his second to last growth spurt, Nahash said once he was large enough he'd help Felix escape by eating Lord William and the guards.

But his desire to eat the evil guards wasn't all Felix knew of his Felaryan friend. Nahash also had an elder brother, about Felix's age but according to Nahash, over 100 feet tall. His mother and father had ruby and sapphire colored scales respectively. They were both loving and caring towards their sons.

"I hope they are equally nice to his son's good friends," Felix thought, knowing now that he did see Nahash as a younger brother who he had to protect. It gave the young slave a little light in his life. Nahash was someone who needed him and he could help. It gave him a sense of accomplishment, of purpose and duty. He couldn't stand to see Nahash beaten everyday, not as he was getting larger and larger, his beatings were actually getting worse and worse.

Felix shook his head, knowing it wouldn't be good to get caught day dreaming as his cleaning brought him close to Lord William's private chambers.

"What did you just say?" came Lord William's cold voice. Felix froze, wondering if he was speaking aloud? He looked and saw the door was ajar and Felix wasn't the intended target.

"I was saying that the chain's magic is growing weaker. It would be wise to apply another potion to it so the chain will stay strong enough to hold the beast," came a reply.

"You said that it would last the two weeks, why the change?" Lord William growled.

"My lord, I said it would last at most two weeks, depending on the strain the beast puts on it. And the enchantment will probably last until the end of this week, however by the time we apply the potion, it could be too late," the alchemist replied.

"You did well to bring this to my attention," Lord William said, "Prepare the remainder of the potion to apply to the chain when the monster's breaking session ends this afternoon."

"Forgive me but the amount I have will not be enough for the current size of the chains. I have a new batch brewing as I speak but it will not be ready until midday tomorrow," the alchemist said.

"Then apply what you have!" Lord William bellowed.

"But sire, doing so would be dangerous and might cause the chains to weaken rather than strengthen, as mixing the old batch in with the new is very unwise," the alchemist said.

"Fine, inform the guards when you are ready to apply the next batch," Lord William said in his dismissing tone.

Hearing the the alchemist coming towards the door, Felix turned around and pretended to continue working as he thought about what he learned.

Nahash's chains were weakening, but that didn't mean he would be able to break them. If he got the old potion and applied it without them knowing it, it could also help his friend escape when they applied the new batch. Of course it could strengthen the chains just as well, leaving Nahash stuck here even longer.

The alchemist left the room, walking past Felix and Felix wondered what he should do next.
14532222112212.title: Weakening

choices: The chains broke.
The chains were still too strong. Felix has to use the potion.
145322221122121.content:
Felix noticed he was done with his cleaning and it was almost time to feed Nahash, because the tormentors should be almost done trying to tame him. Felix also knew that the alchemist's quarters were on the way to the dungeons. "I can follow him and get the old potion that enchants the chains, because if Nahash can't break it now, we'd have to pure the old potion on so that it would weaken more when they put the new stuff on," Felix thought, "And if I don't follow the alchemist, don't get the old potion, and Nahash can't beak the chains again, we'd have to wait till the new enchantments weakened which could could mean Nahash will be trapped in the cell another two weeks. Nahash will be his seventy foot height by then, he's about fifty already."

Felix grew worried when he thought about Nahash growing large enough to eat him. Nahash still hadn't told Felix he wouldn't eat Felix. So, it was still a possibility that he could eat Felix. "How could someone eat a friend?" Felix tried to assure himself that Nahash wouldn't eat him, "I've been so good to him and he's been extremely gentle and kind to me. He knows I'm older than him and Nahash admitted that I was like another older brother to him. I'm even starting to see him as a younger brother I need to protect, even if he's fifty feet tall and nearly one hundred feet long and could easily be protecting me, but I can still be emotional support for him."

The alchemist was about to turn down into another hallway, and Felix quickly got up and followed the alchemist at a distance. Eventually, Felix saw the alchemist turn into his quarters. Felix walked slower to the room and peeked his head in the doorway. The entire room was filled with bottles, potions, and chemistry sets, Felix had never seen anything like it and found it a strange site. Felix soon saw a large cauldron with a green substance brewing in it. He saw a smaller cauldron just sitting on a desk and the the alchemist was there and turned around. The alchemist noticed Felix and Felix thought he was in trouble.

However, the alchemist didn't notice Felix had followed him and saw Felix as a good thing. "Slave, take this!" the alchemist ordered while holding out the small cauldron, "I need you to dump it out somewhere. It is useless now." Felix carefully took the small cauldron. The alchemist saw Felix's nervousness and just assured, "It's not a dangerous substance idiot, or I wouldn't trust a slave to handle it. Just dump it out." In actuality, Felix was excited in a nervous looking way. Felix took the small cauldron and walked away with it.

Eventually, Felix made it down to the dungeons with the cart with the meat and bowl of water on it. The small cauldron was on the cart as well. Felix noticed that there was only one guard by the door at the moment and it wasn't the man with the blow dart. Felix mad it to the guard and the guard didn't notice the small cauldron on the cart. "Where's the other guard?" Felix questioned.

"None of your business, slave," the guard simply replied.

Felix knew where the other guards probably was. The blow dart guard was one of the guards that loved to rape the slave women by ordering them to have sex with them. The blow dart guard was probably doing that at the moment. "If Nahash can break the chains today, it will be the perfect time to escape with only one guard out there," Felix thought.

Felix entered the cell and saw Nahash coiled up and lying on his coils, crying. Felix slowly approached the giant naga and said, "They really hurt you today, didn't they?"

Nahash looked up from his arms and looked down at Felix with tearful eyes. "It's getting worse every session," Nahash informed Felix, "I don't know how much I can take."

"You can't give up, Nahash. You know what will happen if you become their slave," Felix encouraged.

"I know, and I don't want to become their weapon. Felix, could I...?" Nahash started to ask.

Felix knew what Nahash was about to ask. Nahash was depressed with every torture and the was a sure way to calm him down. "Sure," Felix answered. Nahash moved his hands and carefully picked up Felix with two hands. It was possible for him to pick Felix up with one hand, because Felix was about seven inches tall compared to Nahash, but Nahash wanted to be sure he was careful and gentle with his only friend. Nahash slowly picked Felix up and them pressed him firmly against his chest for a hug. Nahash bowed his head and cried while he hugged his friend. Felix just rubbed Nahash's chest to try and calm Nahash down. The hugs usually calmed Nahash down quickly. "I don't think I'd be able to stay this strong without you, Felix," Nahash informed his friend.

"I'll always be here for support, Nahash," Felix told his large friend. Soon, Nahash calmed down and set Felix back down on the ground. Once on the ground, Felix stated, "I brought food and water."

"Thank you, Felix," Nahash replied before picking up pieces of meat and eating. While Nahash's fingers picked off the meat. Felix crouched down next to the cart to take out the bowl of water from the bottom level of the cart. When Nahash finished eating, Felix handed out the bowl to Nahash. Nahash took the water and drank it and handed it down to Felix. Felix took the bowl and put it back in the cart. "So, what should we talk about now?" Nahash questioned and he laid his body down on his coils once more.

"Actually, I was thinking of talking about escaping," Felix replied.

"Please don't joke about that," Nahash replied, ready to cry again.

"No really," Felix quickly tried to assure Nahash, "I heard Lord William and an alchemist talking. You know that enchantments on your chains? Well, they're weakening. You might be able to break them."

"Really?" Nahash gasped in disbelieve.

"But if you're unable to, we can dump the old potions on the chains and..." Felix started.

"How would that help?" Nahash demanded.

"If the old potion reacts comes into contact with the new one they'll pour on, it might weaken the chains even more," Felix explained, "But if you can break those chains today, we can escape today."

"How?" Nahash asked.

"I think your tail is strong enough to bust through the large doors and the blow dart guard isn't outside, just one guard. The dungeons are made out of a cave system, and we might be able to find a way out of them," Felix informed Nahash.

"But what about the other guard? I don't know if I can bring myself to kill a person, and if I don't break the door down in one hit, he'll run and get others," Nahash argued.

Felix took a bone and asked Nahash to break it. It wasn't too hard for Nahash to break the bone since he was so large. He handed the pieces to Felix and Felix said, "I can stab him with the broken bone. If the chains can break, you should wait for me to go out of the cell, then you start hitting the door with your tail and I'll stab the guard before he get's help. He won't be expecting it. But first, we got to see if you can break the chains."

Nahash looked at the chains for a long time and looked worried. He was worried that the chains would still be strong. Nahash sighed and pulled on the chains.
145322221122121.title: Plans of Escape

choices: They escape easily
They get into trouble but something attacks the castle to let them escape
1453222211221211.content:
Nahash pulled tight on the metal links but gave up quickly.

"I can't do it," Nahash said in defeat.

"Come on Nahash, you can't give up just like that! Do you want to risk being a slave here for another two weeks? Or longer?" Felix said, looking up at the naga.

"But I tried," Nahash said weakly.

"If we wait for the next time, they could have found out about us and killed me for being nice to you Nahash," Felix said firmly. He watched the fear and horror etch onto Nahash's face at the thought of those events coming to pass. Taking a deep breath, he grabbed the dangling chain and pulled as hard as he possibly could and then some. Felix was worried it would be for naught but then he saw some metal in links near where Nahash was pulling were starting to bend.

"Keep going!" Felix called until suddenly Nahash flew backwards onto the ground. Where Nahash just stood hung a chain loosely in the air and on Nahash's neck was the clamp and some ten feet of chain, but still the young naga had broken the enchanted chains. Nahash looked at the dangling chain that he had broken and was about to yell for joy when Felix waved for him to stop.

"Sorry," Nahash said, happy he was free. Felix nodded and proceeded to the next part of the plan. He walked over to the door and knocked. The guard opened and Felix went through. The broken bone was hidden close to his body between his arm and torso.

"Done already slave?" the guard asked, as Felix passed by.

--------------------

Nahash watched as Felix left and the door was closing after a second hesitation, just as the door was to be closed, Nahash shoved his large tail through the door, nearly breaking it off its hinges. He pulled the tail back and put his head towards the door.

-----------------------------------------------------------------

Felix smiled as the guard laid on the ground dead. When the door opened suddenly, the man was pushed back with it into the wall and his neck was snapped from the force of the impact. Felix looked now at Nahash as the naga pushed out through the doorway.

"There's lots of room," Nahash said, looking down the corridor.

"Yeah, now let's get out of here before anyone comes," Felix said, dropping the bone in favor of the small sword the guard had.

"Felix, I think you should ride on my neck," Nahash said, "That way I can move quicker and protect you." Felix nodded and moved towards the large neck, and got on, holding tight as Nahash started into the hallway.
1453222211221211.title: Breaking

choices: Nahash finds the natural opening quickly before dinner.
Nahash is unable to find the natural opening before dinner.
14532222112212111.content:
Nahash slithered through the hallway quickly, but not too quickly. He knew that if he went his fastest speed, he might accidentally knock Felix off his shoulder. Felix was already hanging onto the metal collar and the chain around Nahash's neck. "Are you okay, Felix?" Nahash asked, "Do you need me to slow down for you?"

Felix was holding on tight, but knew he could manage his grip with the speed the giant naga was going at the moment. However, Felix was quite glad that Nahash was truly concerned about Felix's well-being. "He couldn't possibly eat me, could he?" Felix wondered. Felix answered up to Nahash's ear which was covered by his long black messy hair, "I'm fine, Nahash, but thanks for the concern."

"Well, I have to make sure my friend is alright. That's what friends are for, right?" Nahash replied, "I have to make sure you're safe."

"Looks like you're going to be the protector in this friendship," Felix stated, "Even though I'm the oldest and it should be me protecting you."

"Well, you can't help being smaller than me. It's just your species," Nahash informed Felix, not really understanding what he had actually said. "So, these dungeons were made out of a cave system?" Nahash asked.

"Yeah, Lord William's men were digging the ground to make dungeons for the castle and they suddenly hit rock. They somehow broke through and found a large cave system underneath," Felix explained.

"So, the entrance to the dungeons isn't the natural opening to the cave?" Nahash asked.

"No, it's not the natural opening," Felix informed Nahash.

"Then there is an opening somewhere. Don't worry, I think I can find it," Nahash replied.

"How can you be so confident?" Felix questioned.

"My family lives in an underground cave system. My parents taught me about how to travel through them, how they work. They call me their little guide, because I good at finding the way in and out of caves," Nahash informed Felix.

"So, you think you can find a way out?" Felix asked.

"I believe so," Nahash answered.

Eventually, they came upon the point with the hallway ended and the cave continued on. There was no light in the cave and it was completely black. "Are you sure you can travel through darkness?" Felix questioned.

"You mean, humans can't see in the dark?" Nahash questioned.

"A can't see anything through that darkness," Felix informed Nahash.

"Don't worry I can see perfectly. I know what I'm doing," Nahash replied confidently. Nahash slithered into the darkness with Felix holding onto the metal collar more than ever.

Choice 1: Nahash finds the natural opening quickly before dinner. The natural opening leads to a dense forest very far away from the castle.

Choice 2: Nahash is unable to find the natural opening before dinner. Nahash finds a large room in the cave systems and have to take a break, because Nahash is very hungry and has to hunt for the creature living in the caves.
14532222112212111.title: Cave Travelers

choices: Nahash finds his fill quickly and returns soon.
A hunter in the woods comes along and spots Felix in the tree
145322221122121111.content:
Felix could not see his hand in front of his face, but he could tell Nahash was able to see easily in this dark labyrinth. Every once in a while, he'd feel Nahash stop moving for a second and become very still. Finally Felix spoke about this.

"What are you doing Nahash?" Felix asked.

"I'm smelling the air and listening for noises outside the cave, like birds or other creatures," Nahash said, before he started moving, "I can't wait to get outside. And once I grow again, I'll be rid of this collar." Felix nodded.

The pair continued traveling far into the darkness, Felix beginning to lose hope they'd be lost in it. But Nahash gave his reassurances they wouldn't.

"The path we're on will take us to freedom Felix. I can smell fresh air coming stronger now," Nahash said, taking a deep breath, "Yes, this scent is coming from outside." Felix gave in and let Nahash continue on.

What neither of them knew exactly was Lord William's castle was built at the foot of a range of mountains whose insides had made into catacomes once the volcano that once was there thousands of years ago died. The system of caves connected one edge of the range to the other. And so, as they neared the opening, they had put a great distance between themselves and Lord William's castle, well over a week's travel on the outside.

When Nahash gave a cry of joy, Felix saw the opening his naga friend found. He felt Nahash pick up speed and race to the exit.

The pair entered into a range of green and brown. Felix looked in awe of the old forest they had entered. He had never seen a forest, let alone a tree this close before. It shocked him to see just how big the forest was. But he was also shocked by Nahash's next words.

"This place has small trees compared to home," he said, seeing the small trees, compared to the giant ones in his homeland, "I doubt once I grow any bigger, I could hide in them like mommy and daddy do."

"Well, hopefully we can find a way to get you home then," Felix said, though a little sad as well. He liked Nahash and didn't want to say good-bye to him but he knew the odds of him living safely in that place where he would be a bug to everything would be too dangerous.

But then something troublesome occured as Nahash's stomach growled.

"I guess it's nearly dinner time," Nahash said, licking his lips as scents of animals came to his nose.

"So you'll hunt then?" Felix asked.

"Yeah, but I don't think I can with you on me," Nahash said, looking over to a "low" branch, "Why don't I put you there and go hunt? This way you'll be safe." Felix looked at the tree and the branch Nahash was talking about was the lowest one and was over thirty feet to the ground.

"All right," Felix said as Nahash moved over to the tree and put Felix on the branch. "Will you be eating your fill then?"

"Yeah, I haven't been properly full since before I was captured," Nahash said before departing, moving in a way that not even the chain bounced. Felix watched his friend go, wondering how long until Nahash might see him as prey.
145322221122121111.title: The Old Forest

choices: Choice 1: Felix tried to escape.
Choice 2: Felix didn't try to escape.
1453222211221211111.content:
As soon as Nahash was no longer around, Felix began thinking to himself as he sat on the "low" branch of the tree. His mind was swarming with thoughts and emotions he couldn't recognize. The forest was nothing like the terrible castle as he looked around at its beauty. The forest was bright and colorful while the castle had been dark and bleak. The forest was full of browns, greens, and blues from the occasional blue bird that flew by. Felix had never seen so much of these colors, because he was much used to the grays and blacks Lord William's castle offered. Felix was glad to see a larger variety in colors. It made him feel better and more comfortable.

The forest he was in was a very old forest with tall and old trees and many of those trees. Though many trees looked like they were too old to stand, they were actually stronger than the new trees. Most people would have been scared of the strange formations the old trees made as they twisted through the forest, but Felix, having never seen trees up close before, thought they were large, majestic, and beautiful. (Wonder if he'd still think that at night.) The trees were very close together and it was a little crowded, Felix could even reach the longer branches of other trees. It was a surprise to Felix that Nahash was able to slither through such a crowded forest. However, it didn't seem as close and claustrophobic as the castle corridors. So, Felix wasn't bothered by the closeness of the trees.

Felix thought he would never get outside the exterior walls of the castle. He was relieved that he was far away from the castle walls now. He "responsibilities" and "chores" he had to do for Lord William seemed to evaporate away from him. Felix was no longer worried about Lord William or his guards. He was no longer afraid of what might happen to him and the was finally excited about the world around him he wanted to explore. He also felt other strange feeling inside him he couldn't explain efficiently enough, but they were all great feelings. "Is this what it feels like to to be free?" Felix wondered, "I feel alive for the first time. I feel great."

Felix felt peaceful and he scooted closer to the trunk of the tree where the branch he was sitting on came from. He had to duck under some branches even though he was scooting to the trunk in a sitting position the entire time. Once he was at the trunk, he leaned his back on the trunk and sat so there was a leg dangling over the side of each of the branch's side. Felix reclined as far as he could and sighed with relief. he had never had a brake before at the castle. His only resting periods there was when he had to eat and when he had to sleep. Other than those times, Felix had to be working constantly. In the forest, Felix could finally relax and it felt better than he could have ever imagined. Felix would have been more relaxed if he had put his legs on the branch as well, but he wasn't comfortable enough to do so. Heights and climbing trees was a new experience for him. He may have been a little more carefree being free now, but he wasn't reckless. The low branch was about half as high as Nahash which meant the height was close to twenty to thirty feet since Nahash was fifty feet tall. Felix knew falling from the height could seriously hurt him, or worse. He would just have to wait for Nahash to come back and pick him up.

That small thought about Nahash suddenly brought Felix's entire mind focused on Nahash. Nahash still hadn't said that he wouldn't eat Felix. So, there was still a possibility that Nahash would... "No, Nahash is my dearest friend and he cares about me as I care about him. We're like brothers. He couldn't really eat me, could he?" Felix wondered.

"I know that I would never eat a person just because their smaller than me, but Felaryans morality is much different from a humans. A person to them is something that isn't smaller than them, and Felaryan nagas start seeing things that are swallowable prey," Felix argued with himself.

"But he should still understand that we're friends. he wouldn't change his mind just because he's bigger," Felix thought, "I mean, he's much larger than me now, but he treats me like an older brother. Most five year olds would look at me and think I'm a plaything and wouldn't understand I'm a person. Nahash may be an exception to the naga views."

"But he was taught that things swallowable are prey, no matter what. He's still only five years old and might not understand the complications of morals. He'd obviously be sorry and sad about eating me, but he'd still eat me because that's what he was taught to do," Felix thought.

"But I might be able to convince him not to eat me. I could explain things in simpler terms for him and make him understand why eating me would be wrong," Felix tried to assure himself.

"But do I really want to take that risk?" Felix wondered, "If he decided to eat me, I won't be able to stop him. He's far too big, strong, and fast for me to stop him. My words would be my only weapon. That's not a good scenario."

Felix looked down from the branch and looked around. He noticed he could try to grab some branches from a near by tree and try to climb down, but it was a risk since he had never climbed a tree before. "Should I try to escape?" Felix asked himself, "I might be able to get away, but it will break Nahash's heart if I run away. He also might suddenly think I'm prey and hunt me down. He may not have a snake's tongue, but his nose it just as strong as a snake's tongue and he might easily track me down. Plus Nahash is so silent as he slithers around. It seems impossible for something so large to be quiet, but he doesn't make a sound and could easily sneak up on me. What should I do?"

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- ------------------------

Nahash had found many small animals and filled his stomach up. Some of the creatures he came across he had never seen before and their taste was very strange, but just as good as the meat from his home. "I wonder if Felix is hungry now?" Nahash wondered, "I better bring back one of these creatures for him, just in case."

Nahash caught a deer and snapped its neck so that he could carry it around without it squirming around. Nahash than began slithering to where he had left Felix. When Nahash got there...

Choice 1: Felix was hanging from a branch, in danger of falling. Felix had tried to climb down to escape, but he messed up and was going to fall if Nahash didn't catch him.

Choice 2: Felix was still on the branch waiting for Nahash. Felix decided it was too risky to try and escape from Nahash.
1453222211221211111.title: Free?

choices: Felix finds some stones and gets the fire going and cooks.
Felix can't find the proper stones.
14532222112212111112.content:
Nahash saw Felix sitting patiently on the branch.

"Hi Felix," Nahash said, coming close.

"Hey Nahash," Felix said, noticing the dead animal, "Why do you have that?"

"I brought it for you," Nahash said, "You must be hungry as well." Felix smiled.

"That was really nice of you Nahash," Felix said. He watched the young boy beam at the praise. "But I can't eat it like that." Nahash looked hurt and looked at the deer in his hands.

"Is it bad?" Nahash asked.

"No, it's that I need to cook the food to eat it," Felix said.

"But why?" Nahash asked, realizing he never once asked Felix about his eating habits.

"Because that's how my body is. I can't usually eat meat unless it has been cooked by a fire," Felix said. He saw tears form in the boy's eyes.

"Then you don't want it?" Nahash asked.

"No, I just need to make a fire to cook it," Felix said quickly, not wanting to upset Nahash, for fear of what a temper tantrum from a large naga might do. Nahash nodded.

"So, how do we make a fire?" Nahash asked, looking at the deer.

"I think I know how," Felix said, "I once worked in the kitchen. Would you set me down on the ground?" Nahash nodded, picking Felix up and setting him on the ground, the deer still in his other hand.

Felix worked quickly, finding some fallen limbs and enough kindling. But he was still lacking two stones to make sparks.
14532222112212111112.title: Felix's Dinner

choices: the sun was falling and night was approaching.
the sun was still out and would be out for a few more hours.
145322221122121111121.content:
Felix looked around for the rocks he needed as quick as possible. He could tell that Nahash was still a little upset by the situation. Felix didn't want to see Nahash upset. Not only was Nahash only a five year old child, but seeing such a large creature cry miserably is something hard to witness. Plus, Felix didn't want to see what Nahash would be capable of when he was upset. Nahash has been nothing but kind to Felix, but Felix didn't want to chance hurting the giant naga's feelings. There was still a chance that Nahash could eat him.

Felix looked behind a tree and found something that startled him. Felix was so surprised by what he found, that he fell backwards away from the tree. "What's wrong, Felix?" Nahash quickly questioned. Nahash was still upset that Felix couldn't eat what he gave him, but Nahash still saw Felix as a friend he needed to protect for now. Nahash quickly slithered to Felix. Nahash snaked behind Felix till his body towered beside Felix and his tail formed a wall behind Felix.

Felix stared up at the giant five year old naga as the naga bent down to take a look around the tree. Nahash formed a nearly perfect J as he edged closer to the tree and Felix stood up, using Nahash's black tall as support. Eventually, Nahash saw what had startled Felix and gasped. Felix slowly walked beside Nahash's side till he was around the tree with Nahash's head. Lying against the tree was a dead body. The body was just a skeleton now and was dressed in clothing that was tattered and indistinguishable. The skeleton had a pack at its side and a few weapons with it. There was a knife on the skeleton's belt, a sword in its hand and a bow and quiver of arrows next to the pack.

"How long has it been dead?" Nahash questioned.

"I long time if he or she is only bones now," Felix stated, "I'm surprised none of us noticed it before."

"I can smell those who are alive or dead, but not when they're just bones," Nahash informed Felix. Felix walked closer to the dead skeleton. "What are you doing?" Nahash asked worriedly. It was quite clear that Nahash was afraid of the dead body. he was still a child and hadn't seen that much death. The dead was a scary thing for most children.

"It's alright, he's dead," Felix assured Nahash, "I'm just going to see what he has I can use."

"Careful," Nahash warned.

Felix was different from Nahash and Felix had seen much death in his life time. He was only five years older than Nahash, but Felix had seem many thing and did many things that made his mentality grow much quicker. He was much more mature than most humans his age. Felix approached the skeleton and knelt down beside it. The skeleton looked human, but Felix couldn't help but feel that the skeleton was different in some way. There was something about it that didn't seem right. Little did Felix know, this skeleton was actually an elf.

Felix looked in the pack and found all the supplies, except the food, was still in perfect condition. There were even supplies meant to start fires. Felix took those first and rushed to the fire. Nahash slowly followed behind Felix and saw Felix make a fire. "Wow," Nahash said in amazement. As Felix made the fire bigger, Nahash asked, "Now, do you just put the deer in the fire?"

"No, I'm going to have to skin the deer first and then tie it to a large branch and rotate it above the fire," Felix explained as he stuck two of the larger branches in the ground which were fairly Y shaped.

"I didn't realize you had to do so much before eating," Nahash replied, "Is my gift that bad?"

"No, you're gift isn't bad at all," Felix quickly tried to assure the giant naga, "It's great that you thought of me and I appreciate the food, because I'm really hungry. it's just that my body is different from yours. I need to cook meat first or I could git very sick. Please don't be offended by my actions, I truly am thankful of your gift."

Nahash laid his body on the ground stomach first and edged his face closer to Felix. The giant child face was smiling and cheering up. Felix soon found one of Nahash's hands forming a wall behind him. Eventually, Felix was pressed against one of Nahash's cheeks with a giant hand firmly pressing him against the soft, smooth, and slightly wet from tears surface.When Nahash released Felix, Nahash apologized, "I just wish I knew you had to do so much before you could eat."

"It's not your fault that you didn't know," Felix assured his giant friend.

Felix walked back to the skeleton and looked at the weapons. The weapons too were in perfect condition and were the more elegant things he had ever seen. "Surely these aren't from fighting," Felix thought to himself. Yet when he lifted the sword, it was sharp and strong. However, the sword seemed lighter than it should have been and adult could probably use it with one hand though it was a two handed blade. Felix would still have to use two hands though. There were strange symbols on the sword that Felix had never seen before. (Elf language). Felix took the knife which was just as impressive and brought the knife to the deer with rope he found in the pack.

Felix skinned the deer and then tied it to a large branch. Nahash was happy to lift the deer and place it above the fire with the two Y branches supporting the deer. Felix cooked the deer and was eventually able to eat it. Felix was so hungry he was able to eat nearly all of the deer. Nahash gladly finished the rest and swallowed it whole, bones and all. Nahash liked the taste of the cooked meat.

When they were finished, Felix and Nahash looked at the sky to see...
145322221122121111121.title: Surprising Supplies

choices: The pair travels until sunset where they make camp
The pair meet a person or group of people in the woods.
1453222211221211111212.content:
The sun was not near the horizon just yet.

"The sun is nice to see," Nahash said, smiling. Felix nodded.

"I don't recall ever seeing a sunset before," Felix mused.

"Really?" Nahash asked, looking back at his friend.

"Yeah, because the castle faces only to the east with part of it in the mountains we escaped through," Felix replied, before looking back to the elf's body.

"So what should we do now Felix?" the young naga asked. He averted his eyes from the body, looking only at Felix.

"I don't know," Felix replied, "It might be wise to put some distance between us and the cave if any of the soldiers should find the way through." Nahash nodded.

"Felix, is something wrong?" Nahash asked in a worried tone.

"I'm just wondering about that skeleton and why it died here of all places," Felix replied.

"Could he have been a slave?" Nahash asked. Felix shook his head.

"If he was a slave, he wouldn't have had the weapons or supplies on him," Felix answered, "And if he was attacked by bandits, he wouldn't have had the possessions on him either."

"So what happened?" Nahash asked.

"I don't know," Felix said, before seeing the fire die down. "Nahash, would you help me put out the fire?" Nahash smiled and moved his tail over the small fire and put it out without issue.

"So we'll be going?" Nahash asked. Felix nodded and made sure the weapons and supplies were on his body.

"Yeah, let's follow the sun until it sets," Felix said, as he saw Nahash reach out for him. Felix jumped on the large hand and was placed on Nahash's shoulder when the boy was upright.
1453222211221211111212.title: Planning Ahead

choices: Nahash came just before the sun set.
Nahash wasn't back before nightfall and Felix was attacked by a wild animal!
14532222112212111112121.content:
Nahash continued through the forest with Felix on his shoulder holding onto the metal collar around Nahash's neck. Felix was surprised at how quickly Nahash was traversing through the forest. Nahash was an impressively large creature for a five year old, having the upper body of a fifty foot giant child and a tail that was easily one hundred feet long or more. Felix stopped measuring Nahash from the ground up, because that size varied depending on how much of his tail he used as vertical support. Felix realized that he had to go with Nahash's upper body height which was close to twenty-five to thirty feet tall which meant he had the upper body of a fifty foot giant child.

Being so large, it seemed like it should be difficult for something like Nahash to move so easily through a dense forest. Grant it, Nahash knocked down some of the smaller trees to make some room and he had to slither sideways to get through some parts of the forest, but Nahash was still able to get through the dense forest with relative ease. Nahash even climbed on the trees and slithered through limbs. No matter how dense the forest was, he seemed to instinctively know a path through it. Nahash's upper body seemed to be made of the same bones and have the same structure of a human being, but he was extremely flexible, agile, and precise as a snake.

His size should have hindered his speed and movement, because he weighed so much. However, what Felix didn't realize was that Nahash's weight and muscle ratio was the same as a human sized naga. This meant it would take the same amount of strength, or it would seem like it to them, for a giant naga to move his arm and a human naga to move his. Everything else about the naga was the same ratio which meant that a giant naga and a human sized naga were about the same average speed, relative to size, making Nahash's a dangerously fast creature. Something as small as a human wouldn't stand a chance against a giant naga's speed.

Felix began realizing that Nahash was extremely fast and agile. This worried Felix. (it would have worried him more if Nahash were to tell him he was making sure to not go as fast as he could, because Nahash was going slower so that Felix wouldn't fall off and get hurt.) "Nahash is fast, way too fast," Felix thought as he sat upon his giant friend's shoulder, clutching the metal collar around his giant friend's neck for security, "If he gets his mind set on eating me, I wouldn't stand a chance. If he truly has no remorse in eating me, he could snatch me up and swallow me before I have a chance to blink! Maybe I should have tried to run."

"No, I can't," Felix argued with himself, "He may want to eat me when he grows, but he's still my friend and he still needs me. He'd be heartbroken if I run away. Even if running away means staying alive, I just can't bring myself to leave a friend. The only hope I have now is that Nahash continues to see me as a friend and not prey or that he at least hesitated when it's time for him to eat me due to the size difference. That will give me enough time to talk to him and maybe convince him that eating people is wrong."

Wanting to stop thinking about such a subject, Felix asked Nahash, "What do you think happened to that person we got the supplies from? How do you think he or she died?"

"You're still thinking about that? Can we talk about something different?" Nahash requested.

"Why?" Felix questioned.

"Death is scary," Nahash told Felix.

Felix remembered how uncomfortable Nahash seemed around the dead body. "But you weren't uncomfortable with killing the deer," Felix pointed out.

"Deer aren't people," Nahash informed Felix, "They're prey."

"Because they're swallow able to you?" Felix questioned.

"They weren't swallow able yet, but they can't talk," Nahash explained.

Felix realized that Nahash was first judging that people were considered people when they weren't swallow able and then out of the creatures that weren't swallow able, the ones with intelligence were people. Felaryan nagas judged with size first and intelligence second. Felix just had to convince Nahash that intelligence had to be the first judge. Felix placed that information in the back of his head and said, "Well, I thought of two possible ways he could have died since we ruled out escaped slave and bandits. The person could have froze to death since he didn't have a blanket or anything to keep him warm, or he could have been poisoned, but I'd think a traveler would have know what he could and couldn't eat."

"But a traveler would know to bring a blanket too, right?" Nahash replied.

"You're right," Felix agreed, "This just makes the cause of death more confusing."

Soon, Nahash and Felix came upon a large clearing. They looked at the sky and it was getting close to sun set. "Do you think we should stop here?" Nahash asked.

Felix was glad Nahash was being fair to him and he was asking for Felix's opinions. Felix was happy to know his voice still mattered to the giant five year old Felaryan naga, because Nahash could just as easily force things upon Felix or see Felix as a pet of a toy rather than like an older brother. "I think this is as good a place as any to stop. So, let's sleep here," Felix gave his opinion.

Nahash agreed and put his hand up to his shoulder. Felix walked onto the giant hand and sat down. Nahash bent down and lowered his hand to the ground. Felix stepped off the hand and turned to look up at Nahash as Nahash laid his body down on his stomach with his arms crossed and his chin resting upon his crossed arms. Felix noticed that Nahash looked different. "Nahash, I think you grew a few feet while we traveled to this clearing," Felix told Nahash. Nahash got up and looked at himself compared to his surroundings. Felix was very intimidated by the fact that he was so close to something gigantic standing at near full height.

"I think you're right, Felix," Nahash replied. Nahash felt the metal collar around him which still grew with him. Nahash became worried and asked, "What if this collar stops growing with me and ends up choking me when I grow?"

"The growing of the collar will wear off. I just hope it makes it weak enough to break before you start choking," Felix stated.

"I hope so too," Nahash hoped. Nahash's stomach growled and he automatically looked down at Felix. Felix grew worried as he knew that Nahash was judging if Felix was small enough now to swallow. Nahash growth wasn't that large of a growth and had the upper body of a fifty-five giant child as opposed to a fifty foot giant child. Felix's height still looked about five or six inches to Nahash, not small enough to swallow yet. "Are you hungry Felix? I can get something for you as well," Nahash said.

"I am hungry, and thanks for the offer, Nahash," Felix replied.

"Well, that's what friends do. They help each other," Nahash informed Felix before slithering off quickly. Felix started the fire.
14532222112212111112121.title: Worries of Growth

choices: The two are awoken in the middle of the night by Nahash choking on the collar.
The collar's magic remains through out the night.  The next morning . . .
145322221122121111121212.content:
Felix watched the fire for a long time. His mind wandered for the first time in his life and he didn't have to worry about being hurt for it. His mind moved from the body and what could have killed that person to if some of Lord William's men had made it though the cave searching for them. But mostly his thoughts drifted back to how Nahash was starting to see 'people' differently.

"Oh the fire," Felix mumbled, seeing it die low. He rose and put some more wood on it, and blew for it to regain strength. As it started to come back, an urge came over Felix. He looked around to some bushes a little ways away and walked over to them. He pulled open his pants and relieved himself, noticing as well the sky above the trees was very dark by now. Many stars appeared above him. It was a beautiful sight but once he was finished, his stomach growled, alerting him to another immediate problem.

"I hope Nahash comes back soon," Felix mumbled, before walking back to the fire. He was about to sit down when he heard heavy footsteps from behind him. Turning slightly he saw a tusker, though he didn't know what they were called. Felix did see this pig-beast stood well over him, his nose was level to Felix's head and from ground to the hump on the pig's back was well over the height of any man. Tusks were on both sides of the beast's mouth as it sniffed the area Felix went on. Now normally a tusker wouldn't have bothered with Felix, he wasn't anywhere the pig cared about.
