But after smelling the urine, the tusker squealed and looked at Felix.

"Oh no, what does it want?" Felix wondered in fear. When he heard another squeal the tusker charged at the human, with Felix just jumping out of the way. Felix landed near the fire and picked up a burning branch and brandished it at the tusker.

Unfortunately this along with what the tusker thought was a challenge to his territory led the beast to charge once more, not caring if he was injured by the flames of the branch.

But the tusker never made it that far because a long thick snake tail shot between Felix and his foe. Felix looked around and saw Nahash circling the pig-beast, smiling at it.

"Felix, are you all right?" Nahash asked, turning a head to his friend.

"Yes, I'm fine." Felix said. Nahash smiled.

"I'm glad. I was worried when I heard the squeal of this pig," Nahash said turning about while keeping the terrified tusker contained. Nahash placed another deer by Felix.

"So you ate your fill?" Felix asked.

"Yes, but I won't forgive that pig for attacking you," Nahash said, "So while it's not prey, I will eat it. Plus if I don't eat everything, I'll have food for breakfast right away in the morning." Felix nodded and watched Nahash turn back to the hidden pig. He saw the naga's hands reach down and one final squeal from the pig. With the threat gone, Nahash moved his tail so Felix could get to the fire. Felix cut the deer and started cooking the meat as Nahash took small bites from the beast. It was so large Nahash had to use two hands to hold it.

After Felix finished his meal and Nahash about half the tusker, Nahash gave a large yawn.

"I'm so sleepy now," the boy naga murmured, "Felix, will you sleep with me so I can keep you safe?" Felix was worried for a second, fearing what might happen if Nahash wanted a midnight snack while he slept. But quickly he realized if he was away from Nahash he'd probably be very cold and unprotected from anything else in the woods.

"Sure Nahash," Felix replied in an equally sleepy voice. Nahash put out the fire and reached down for Felix. Felix stepped on and was brought to Nahash's chest and the naga wrapped his tail around them for warmth and safety.

Unknown to either, over this night, Nahash would experience one of his largest growth spurts during his growth period. Felix would shrink to just over an inch tall compared to the young naga.

And so, the two boys rested, unaware of what was to come.
145322221122121111121212.title: A Big Meal

choices: Nahash sets Felix down and tells Felix that he's not safe around him.
Nahash began crying and embraced Felix, sorry for trying to eat his only friend.
1453222211221211111212122.content:
It was unfortunate for the two friends that Nahash would experience the growth spurt that would grow him to the size a five year old Felaryan giant naga should be. It would end the growth spurts and cause Nahash to grow with age from then on, but this growth spurt would make him large enough to be able to swallow Felix and unfortunately that would make Felix prey, despite their close friendship at the moment.

It may also be considered unfortunate that the collar grew with Nahash that night, as cold as that may sound. If the collar wouldn't have grown, Nahash would have woken up in the middle of the night choking, which would have also woken up Felix. If this would have happened there would have been two possibilities. Either Nahash would have choked to death by the collar, or Felix might have figured out a way to get the collar off. Either way would have been greater chance for Felix's survival. If Nahash would have choked to death, Felix wouldn't have to worry about being eaten by Nahash and Nahash wouldn't have to live with the guilt of eating a friend. Sure Felix would have been sad if Nahash had died, but it would have probably been the safest route. If Felix would have managed to save Nahash instead, Nahash might have become so grateful that probably would have forgotten about eating Felix and no longer see him as prey.

However, the collar grew with Nahash and none of those possible situations ever happened. Felix never noticed Nahash's growth while he slept and Nahash was never choked on the collar. In fact, the last growth that the collar was forced to do caused a crack which caused it to break in the middle of the night. Nahash and Felix didn't hear the crack. This would be the hardest scenario for both of them to overcome. Their friendship would be put to the test, but for now, they had a peaceful sleep.

The next morning, Nahash woke up on his back with his tail lying on him in an S-like shape and finally ending with the end of his tail under his head like a pillow. Nahash had never slept like this before, and it felt strange to him. Nahash was about to just slide his tail off himself, but he felt something lying on his stomach under his hand. The thing under his hand was moving slightly and felt alive. Nahash soon remembered why he was lying on the way he was, it was to keep his little friend warm and close.

Nahash could feel Felix under his hand, breathing steadily. "He's still asleep," Nahash thought as he slowly and carefully dragged his tail off himself. Nahash made sure his tail didn't run over his friend since the thicker parts of his tail could easily crush Felix if he wasn't careful.

Once Nahash moved his tail away, Nahash lifted himself where his stomach was slightly inclined and his chest on up was more vertical. Nahash has to support this position with his elbows while keeping his hands covering Felix. When Nahash got in this position, he felt his metal collar fall away from his neck and fall on the ground. Nahash was just able to turn his head around enough to see the collar cracked and destroyed. Nahash was extremely happy and excited to see the horrid collar off of him.

Felix was about to wake Felix up in his excitement, but then Nahash made a horrifying discovery. He realized that he had grown and when he lifted his hand off Felix, he saw how little Felix was now. Nahash let out a quiet gasp. Felix was now swallowable. "F-Felix is prey, now," Nahash realized.

Nahash looked down at Felix with eyes and mouth wide open in shock for the longest time. "What am I waiting for?" Nahash wondered, "He's prey now, and I'm hungry. I have to eat him. I can't back away from it. I'm supposed to eat prey when I'm hungry. I'm not a loud to let them go. Felix is prey now."

"But he's my friend," Nahash argued with himself, "I can't harm him."

"He may be my friend, but he's prey now, I have to eat him. It's my responsibility as a naga to eat prey when I'm hungry," Nahash reasoned.

"I know," Nahash sighed, "I have to eat Felix now, even if he is my friend. He will be helping me by giving my body nutrients. He'd become a part of me. He'd be happy helping me. Since he is my friend, I must make his death quick and painless by swallowing him while he's still asleep."

Nahash stared down at Felix with tears in his eyes. No matter how many things he said to himself that would try to assure him, there was a part of him that didn't want to go through with it and didn't want to eat his only friend. But in his mind he felt as though he had to do it. The stomach underneath Felix, the final resting place for Felix, gurgled and Nahash saw Felix stir a little. "I have to make this quick," Nahash thought, "For both our sakes."

Nahash placed a hand back down on Felix and carefully wrapped it around his little friend. Nahash gently lifted Felix up and brought him to his awaiting mouth.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- ------------

Felix had slept peacefully between Nahash's stomach and hand. The giant Felaryan naga's skin was soft, warm, and more comfortable that any bed Felix had ever been in, and Felix didn't want to wake up and have to leave the comfort. Nahash was still young, so his skin was still soft and smooth and the feeling of it only multiplied due to the size difference between Felix and Nahash. Nahash's body heat was also extremely warm because instead of being cold blooded, Nahash was much different. All of the giant Felaryan top predators either had the body structure of a human of the upper body structure of a human on top of another creature, because of this, the human bodies don't have fur. They need warmth for colder weather, but there is barely any clothes out there that would fit such large creatures. So, to survive colder climates, they have an inner heat that keeps them warm. It's unknown how they sustain the warmth with enough energy, but they can survive cold climates without clothes. In fact, they aren't in danger of freezing to death till the temperature is below freezing. Felix was kept extra warm snug between Nahash's hand and stomach.

Though the thing he was sleeping on was the most comfortable bed he had been on, it was a little disturbing that he was lying on a giant five year old he called his friend and calling him a bed. However, if it wouldn't have been for him sleeping on Nahash, Felix would have been cold at night. Felix didn't want to leave the comfort despite the fact he was sleeping on his friend. Felix suddenly heard the stomach growl beneath him. Felix shivered as he remembered that it was still possible that Nahash would eat him. Felix was lying above the organ that could end up being his prison. He could be sent into the large organ, digested in terrible acids, and then be absorbed into his friend only so that the giant naga would gain nutrients from what he called his friend. It seemed like a terrible fate to end up being nothing at all and be eaten alive.

Felix suddenly felt Nahash's hand wrap around him where only his shoulders and head weren't encompassed in the large hand. Felix then felt his body being lifted in the air. "Is he just waking me up?" Felix wondered. Felix opened his eyes to find a cavernous mouth wide open. Felix was extremely close to the mouth and could see all the disgusting and terrible little details. He could see some raw meat stuck between Nahash's teeth, strands of saliva , and the terrible black abyss that was Nahash's throat. Felix could fell Nahash's warm and humid breath swoop onto his face. Felix was utterly terrified at the sight and was too shocked to do anything. He couldn't believe that Nahash was already turning on him. Felix's body was getting closer to the mouth and soon it was all that filled his vision. The naga's tongue stretched out and before Felix was placed upon the large, moist organ, Felix yelled, "Nahash stop! Please, don't eat me!"

Nahash stopped his hand when he heard his friend cry out. Nahash closed his eyes, as if not seeing Felix would change the creature in his hand to something else. "Go to sleep, Felix," Nahash muttered.

"So, that you can eat me?" Felix screamed.

"Please, you talking is making everything harder to do," Nahash informed Felix.

"If it's hard for you to eat me, then why are you killing me?" Felix questioned.

"Because I have to, Felix. You're prey now. I'm hungry and I have to eat everything that's small enough. It's how we nagas survive," Nahash explained, "I'm sorry, Felix."

"Don't call be by my name," Felix demanded, "You're not my friend if your going to eat me."

"But Felix, I have to," Nahash cried, "I don't want to, but I have to. Why can't we be friends? You'd be helping me survive."

"By killing me? Is that how you treat friends? By eating them for nutrition?" Felix questioned.

"But I..." Nahash started.

Felix interrupted, "Friends don't kill other friends. It's wrong!"

"But you're prey now," Nahash argued.

"But I wasn't prey yesterday! Now I'm prey just because you grew over the night. Does that seem in any way fair to you? Would you like it if I was the giant and I grew big enough to swallow you and just decided that you were prey and eat you without hesitation?" Felix asked.

"No, I wouldn't like it," Nahash cried.

"If you believe that small things are prey, why don't your parents eat you?" Felix asked.

"I'm their son. They wouldn't eat a son," Nahash answered.

"And then what about the deer and the tusker? They were bigger than prey but you ate them, why?" Felix asked.

"They aren't people. They can't talk and can't think like people. They were alright to eat," Nahash said.

"So, you judge people by their size and then their intelligence? But what about the people that are small and intelligent. You think you can eat them just because their small? But they have feelings and intelligence like you. Are you willing to destroy people just to gain food?" Felix questioned.

"Felix, I..." Nahash tried to say.

"Nahash, I saved you from that prison. I helped you when you were sad and kept you company when you were lonely. I was there for you and helped you escape that dreadful place. We've become close friends and you said I was like a brother to you. Are you just going to throw that all away and kill me?" Felix questioned.

"But how can we be friend when I'm, so much larger than you?" Nahash asked.

"I've always been smaller than you and that never stopped you before from being friends with me," Felix replied.

"But I can eat you now," Nahash stated.

"Just because you have the power to do something, it doesn't mean its the right thing to do it," Felix informed his large friend, "No one is making you do this. You don't have to if you don't want to."

"I don't know what to do," Nahash replied with tears streaming down his face.

"Do what you think is right," Felix replied, closing his eyes tight hoping that Nahash would make the right decision.
1453222211221211111212122.title: Friend or Prey

choices: Felix tries running after the naga.
Felix heeds Nahash's desires and goes another way through the woods.
14532222112212111112121221.content:
Nahash looked at the tiny human in his hands. His face slowly contorted with conflict.

"This is how mother and father raised me!" one side replied, "It's alright to eat him!"

"But Felix is my friend! He cared for me when no one else would in that castle!" the other part replied.

"If he cares about you, he should let you eat him!" the first answered back.

"He may owe me things, but I owe him as well! I would never had escaped from that place without him! I can't pay him back for saving me by killing him!" the second said. Silence came in his mind as he realized what was the right thing.

"Felix," Nahash said softly. His eyes still shut, tight, Felix tensed a little at Nahash's soft tone.

"Yes Nahash," Felix replied, worried about his fate. But then he felt Nahash's hand moving downward.

"You must leave Felix," Nahash said, dropping Felix to the ground. "I cannot be around you." Felix's eyes opened up as he looked at the giant naga, seeing his full height for the first time this morning. He truly was huge.

"What do you mean?" Felix asked, "You aren't going to eat me?"

"I cannot eat you Felix," Nahash said softly, "But that doesn't mean I might not on accident. I want to see you safe, but I'm no longer safe!"

"But you can control yourself, like this morning!" Felix replied. He looked hopefully up at his friend. While he did not want to become food, he certainly didn't want to be left alone in the woods without him.

"Felix, you have no idea how hungry I may become," Nahash said, "I could just pick you up and devour you without any thought because I'd be so hungry!" Felix didn't know what else to say. "Goodbye Felix." Nahash said after a moment of silence. He quickly turned and fled into the woods.

"Nahash wait!" Felix called when he saw the boy naga turning around, but it did no good. Nahash was out of there far to quick to hear the little human. Felix looked down the path Nahash went.

"Should I try following him?" Felix muttered to himself.
14532222112212111112121221.title: For Felix's Sake

choices: Felix catches up.
Felix doesn't catch up
145322221122121111121212211.content:
Felix stood there in the clearing staring in the direction Nahash had taken off in. Felix slowly recalled everything that had happened that morning. Felix had honestly thought that Nahash would actually eat him. Nahash was still young after all and it was quite possible that he didn't understand morality or be able to understand why eating people was wrong, even with Felix trying to explain it as simple as possible. Things such as morality and right and wrong were very abstract things for a child to understand. Felix only understood because he was mature for his age since he had to learn to grow up fast in the hostile environment of Lord William's castle. Nahash only know of what right and wrong was through his parents and they had taught Nahash that eating creatures that were small enough to swallow were okay to eat, despite the fact they could be intelligent of not. Nahash was taught the twisted version of morality through a Felaryan's eyes where if big things had the power to do something to a little being, it was alright to do it.

So, it came of great surprise to Felix when Nahash didn't eat him and actually set him down on the ground. It seemed as though Nahash understood Felix, or at least understood Felix vaguely enough to realize he shouldn't eat Felix. Felix had been so surprised that when he feet touched the ground, Felix wasn't ready and feel down onto his butt without Nahash's large hand for support.

It was clear that Nahash didn't want to hurt Felix, but from what Nahash told Felix, it was also clear that Nahash wasn't sure of himself. Nahash wasn't confident that Felix was safe with him. Nahash didn't trust himself with Felix because even though he saw Felix as his friend, he still had the instinct as well as his parents' teachings in his head which both told him he should eat Felix and it was alright to eat Felix since he was small enough. Nahash made his decision and made sure to be as far away from Felix as possible, and there was nothing Felix could say to stop the giant five year old naga.

Felix looked down the path Nahash slithered off to. Nahash wasn't being careful or trying to cover his tracks, he was just going as fast as he could. Therefore, Nahash had left an easy enough trail to follow. "I can easily follow him," Felix thought to himself, but he started to contemplate whether or not he really should follow Nahash. "Nahash is my friend. I should follow him," Felix told himself.

"But he tried to eat me. If I wouldn't have woken up in time, he would have swallowed me whole and wouldn't have even cared. I would have woken up in his stomach slowly dying and he would have just went about his day not caring that his "friend" was being digested alive in his stomach. How could a monster like that possibly be a friend?" Felix began to question.

"He didn't know any better. He's still just a kid and he was taught to eat smaller things," Felix began arguing with himself.

"That's no child. That's a damn monster!" Felix thoughts pointed out, "Even young humans children know hurting their friends is wrong. If this naga can even think of hurting me, let alone killing you, it must not think I'm a friend at all."

"But I don't think he wanted to hurt me," Felix realized, "I think he truly believed that if he would have swallowed me alive while I was asleep, I wouldn't feel pain. The only reason he was willing to kill me was because there were things conflicting his thinking. One part of him saw me as a friend, but he was also taught to eat things that were swallowable and I was not swallowable to him. Those conflict thoughts were giving him a hard time. He's not a human. He's a giant naga that was born and raised in that messed up world where it is considered okay to eat humans as long as they're small. Now he's been introduced to two different worlds and of course he's extremely confused."

"I need to be there for him," Felix continued his thoughts, "He's got to be feeling horrible and lonely right now. He needs me and as long as I show him I'm there for him, he'll see me more as a friend than prey. If he continues to see me as a friend more than prey, he might eventually forget about me being prey and only as a friend."

"But he's dangerous," Felix thought of one more final argument, "He still has the urge to eat me and at his size, he could do anything he wants with me and I'd be powerless to stop him."

"Honestly, I'm not much safer alone. It's better to be with something that still has the possibility of not hurting me rather than be in the forest by my self with creatures that only rely on their instincts and basic needs to make their decisions," Felix thought, "Besides, the longer I'm with him, the more he'll realize I'm a friend and he will eventually not want to eat me at all."

With that final thought, Felix ran into the direction Nahash had left.

Choice 1: Nahash didn't go that far and Felix was able to catch up with Nahash by noon. Nahash had stayed in a clearing and is crying when Felix arrives. Nahash hadn't eaten yet and is hungry.

Choice 2: Nahash just kept going and there was no way that Felix could catch up with such a large creature going so far. Night approaches and Felix has to sleep alone. Luckily he was able to get some food along the way like berries and possibly a small animal.
145322221122121111121212211.title: Nahash Needs Him

choices: Someone comes across the lone Felix in the middle of the night.
A group of hunters come across the young Nahash at dawn.
1453222211221211111212122112.content:
Meanwhile, Nahash was far ahead of Felix, pushing through the woods, not caring about the welts some of the larger branches were giving him. Part of him even saw them as punishment for what he had almost done.

"I almost ate my friend," Nahash thought once more, "I can't be with him anymore. I'm too dangerous to protect Felix. I have to keep going! The further I am, the safer Felix will be." before he ran into a large tree. Nahash barely registered the fact he knocked the tree over the river he was about to cross. He looked at the water and felt his stomach rumble.

"There are no people in the water," Nahash muttered before dropping down and chugging down the river water. He took in many fish that happened to be spawning up stream and felt his hunger sated, for now. But he knew he couldn't wait there as Felix might be following him. So Nahash tore across the large stream and continued into the woods.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------

Felix, despite the scars and bruises from being a slave, was not out of shape, ironically, because he was a slave. So he had the endurance to keep a good pace following the broken trail of Nahash.

"He really isn't paying attention to anything," Felix breathed, watching the number of fallen branches on the trail and the silence of all other creatures in the woods. No predator would come to Nahash's trail for a while, so Felix was safe from them, but not his stomach. He heard it grumble for a third time since his run started and while he had worked under the pain of hunger before, it was never a pleasant experience.

"Black berries!" Felix said, smiling as he came to a patch Nahash had literally slithered through. Thankfully he didn't destroy every bush and Felix was able to eat a large amount to sate his hunger as well and pocket more before charging on.

----------------------------------------------------------------------

Dusk came to the woods about the same time Felix arrived at the stream Nahash has been at hours before. Parched from the day's run, Felix drank from the river as well and saw on the other side, Nahash's continuing trail.

"I can't follow him . . ." Felix breathed out, laying down. He had spent so much energy, Felix knew he couldn't continue on without resting. Looking around, Felix decides to climb to sleep near the fallen tree.

I'll continue pursuing him in the morning," Felix thought, feeling the cold of night come upon him. He started a small fire with his tools and dozed off.

--------------------------------------------------------------------

Elsewhere, far away Nahash was asleep in a clearing, having found a deer to satisfy his hunger. He looked back, down his trail and cried once more.

"Felix, I hope you're safe without me," Nahash thought as he curled up and cried himself to sleep.
1453222211221211111212122112.title: So far gone, so little gained

choices: He has troubles and tries to eat the elf, but ends up stoping himself.
Nahash keeps under control and searches for Felix, the elf wants to come with.
14532222112212111112121221122.content:
Nahash didn't sleep well that night. He felt alone again and was having the same amount of nightmares as he did when he had been alone in the prison cell. He was once again sad, lonely, and hungry exactly like when he was in the cell. It felt as though he had never escaped.

Nahash slowly opened his eyes and looked over the coils of his tail he was lying on. It was a beautiful dawn in the forest, but Nahash didn't notice its beauty. Nahash was too depressed and felt the lowest he had ever felt. "I may be far away from that monster and his wicked men, but I still feel the same way I did when I was all alone there," Nahash thought to himself, "I was feeling good before, but I don't feel that good anymore. I shouldn't feel this way. I should be happy that I'm far away from my captures and that I'm free, but I don't feel happy. I feel sad."

Nahash pondered about his situation carefully and wondered why he felt so terrible. "Felix!" Nahash realized, "I was happy when I was around Felix. He was my friend. He was there for me when I felt terrible in that cell. He took care of me, talked to me when I was lonely, and helped me escape. Now that I'm away from him, I feel sad and alone like I was still in the cell. Just being near my friend make my happy and keeps me from feeling sad. He was the best friend I've ever had and he's helped me so much. he's important to me."

As Nahash realized that seeing Felix would make him happy again, he remembered what happened the other morning, what he had almost done to Felix. "I can't see him ever again," Nahash told himself as he shook his head, "I'm too dangerous for him to be around me. Although seeing him will make me happy, causing him harm will make me feel even worse. If I did something to Felix, if I ate Felix, I would never be able to live with myself. I need him now, but I like him too much and I have to stay away to keep him safe from me."

Nahash hated the dilemma he was in. He could see Felix and cure his sadness, but that could endanger Felix if he gave into his hunger, or Nahash could stay away from Felix and keep Felix safe, but by doing so, Nahash would be left alone to suffer the terrible sadness and loneliness of not being able to see his best friend. Nahash decided that he could not see his friend anymore. He had to keep Felix safe, especially from himself. Weakened a little by his sadness, Nahash decided to lie on his coils a little longer. Nahash gave a deep sigh of sadness as he staying lying on his coils.

Suddenly, a large net fell on Nahash. Nahash panicked and tried to get up, but the net tightened and didn't budge. Nahash looked around, barely able to move his head, and saw that large spikes were attached to the ends of the net. These spikes had penetrated the ground and penetrated them deep. The rope and the spikes were too strong for Nahash, especially in his depressed state. Nahash heard a cold and cruel laugh. Nahash looked in that direction. A laughing man came out into the clearing with nine other men. The men looked like monster hunters of some sort. "Looks like we caught ourselves a big one, boys," the man who looked like the leader stated upon seeing the giant naga he had captured.

"What is that thing? It looks like a naga, but its upper half is completely human. I thought nagas are supposed to have snake skin and snake heads," one man questioned.

"A naga?" another man spoke up, "Haven't there been rumors of a giant naga escaping from Lord William's castle?"

"There have been rumors, but is this monstrosity really a naga?" the leader asked.

"Someone told me the naga that came from Lord William's castle is a Felaryan naga. Whatever that means," one man stated, "That must mean the naga that escaped is different from any ordinary naga and this is a different type of naga."

"Though rumors said that the monster that escaped Lord William's castle is a very dangerous beast. This creature looks like a child and he seems to be scared and shivering," the leader pointed out, "Could this really be the dangerous creature of the rumors? Besides, he's supposed to be traveling with a slave child."

"Maybe the naga ate the slave and only brought him along for a snack," one man suggested.

"If this is the real naga that escaped from Lord William, Lord William would pay greatly for his return," the leader said, already imagining the gold coins.

"But we don't have the means of moving him," a man argued.

"Then we'll bring Lord William's soldiers to it and they can bring it to Lord William," the leader suggested. The leader turned to two men and ordered, "Jeff, Harold, run to Lord William's castle and tell him what we captured. Bring the army back here. The rest of us will stay with the naga and keep it alive for Lord William."

The two men that were ordered to leave started running in the direction of Lord William's castle. However, they didn't get far, because they soon collapsed on the ground with an arrow in their back. The eight men were startled and looked around for the source. Four of the eight men had crossbows at the ready. An arrow came from the tree tops and connected with one of the bowmen's head. The thee remaining men with crossbows shot their arrows in the direction of wince the arrow came from. However, no corpse fell from the tree tops.

One of the bowmen became scared and started backing away without the knowledge of the other group. The man backed out of the clear hoping to escape. A mysterious man in with a green hooded cloak silently jumped down from the trees landing behind the scared man. In one fluid motion, the mysterious man covered the scared man's mouth and slit his throat with a knife. The scared man shook and convulsed as his vital fluids left his neck. Then the scared man was dead, the mysterious man set the dead man down gently as to not alert the others. Nahash stared at the man as he put two arrows in his bow and aimed them and the remaining two men with crossbows. "Show yourself, you coward!" the leader demanded.

"I'm right here," the mysterious man called out. When the two bowmen turned around, the mysterious released his arrows into their chest. Three men charged at the archer. The archer quickly pulled out a long, slender, and elegant blade and quickly disposed of the men was grace and ease. Nahash had never seen such a talented swordsman. The leader pulled out his claymore and yelled, "How dare you..." Before the leader could even finish his sentence, the mysterious man had charged at him and already had a his blade in the leader's gut. The man pushed the leader off his sword and muttered something. The blood on his blade fell freely off his blade and the blade was once again clean. When the blade was clean, the man sheathed his sword and turned to look at Nahash.

Nahash stared at the mysterious man with both fear and curiosity. The man pulled his hood back, revealing a handsome face, more handsome than any human Nahash had witnessed. The man had long brown hair that reached the back of his neck and green eyes. Nahash soon realized why the man had such handsome features when he noticed the man's ears. "Y-you're an elf," Nahash gasped. The man was indeed an elf and not a man at all. (Well, he was a male, but not a man in the sense that he is human.)

Nahash became very weary of his empty stomach. It was craving substance and elves were supposed to be tasted even better than human and nekos combined! The elf had just saved Nahash, but Nahash knew that if he couldn't control his stomach, he would eat the elf as soon as he was freed. Even though he didn't want to hurt the elf because he had saved his life, the elf was still swallowable which made the elf was prey and not a person. Nahash could eat the elf without consequences.

The elf stared at the naga child for a long time before he asked, "You are the Felaryan naga that has entered our realm, aren't you?" Nahash nodded as best as the net would allow him. "Why have you come to our realm, monster?" the elf interrogated.

"I... I didn't mean to come here. I was just suddenly here and William's soldiers soon captured me," Nahash explained with tears starting up. He didn't like the fact that the elf was calling him a monster, but after recalling what had almost happened the other morning with Felix, Nahash realized that monster was the best word to describe him.

"So the rumors from the elven winds are true," the elf muttered. (Some elves relayed messages using a magical wind that only elves and half-elves could hear.) "They said that Lord William has captured a Felaryan naga and it escaped. So, when I stumbled upon you, I had to save you from ending up back in Lord William's grasp. It's dangerous enough having a Felaryan naga eating everyone it meets just because it's bigger and can do so, but it's worse if a Felaryan naga is being used as Lord William's personal weapon," the elf stated.

"Is that the reason you saved me? Just to keep me away from William?" Nahash questioned.

"It's the only reason I'd save a terrible monster like you," the elf replied.

"You're right, I am a monster too dangerous for this realm," Nahash admitted with tears seeping out of his eyes as he admitted it.

"Don't say you're not a monster because... Wait. You admit being a monster?" the elf questioned with surprise. All the Felaryans just viewed eating people as a natural thing and didn't think it was wrong to eat a person. They believed humans, elves, and nagas that weren't their size too small to be considered people and only could be there for their amusement and to fill their stomachs. Some Felaryans even thought it was their duty to eat such small creatures. So, it was a surprise to the elf to hear a Felaryan believe it was a monster for thinking this way.

"I judge people by their size like all other nagas. If they are swallowable, I'm aloud to eat them without reason other then I'm bigger and hungry at the time," Nahash explained, "This is what I was taught and I have troubles thinking any differently. I had no problems with that thinking until I met a human friend. He wasn't swallowable when I first met him, so he was a person and we could be friends. But yesterday, he became swallowable and now he's prey."

The elf remembered hearing that the naga had ran away with a slave boy. "What did you do to him?" the elf growled.

"I... I tried to eat him, but I couldn't. He's my friend, he was once a person. How could a person turn into prey? Why should one turn into prey just because I grow?" Nahash questioned, "Part of me doesn't want to harm Felix and knows that my way of thinking is wrong, but the other part of me is used to that thinking and believes its what I should do. Want kind of person doesn't think its wrong to eat their only friend? I am a monster."

The elf stood and watched at the Felaryan naga child cried under the heavy net. He never dreamed that a Felaryan could actually grow a conscious. Sure, there have been Felaryans befriending humans, but they saw humans as an amusement, not a person. Sure they treated them like friends, but in the back of a Felaryan's mind, the human is only an amusement allowing them the spare it. Even those Felaryans with human friends have no problems eating human strangers. They just thought human sized creatures were too small to be considered people and could only be food or objects of their amusement. However, this one seemed different. It actually seemed to be truly conflicted. "Maybe it's because this naga has met a human friend as such an early age or that it's in a different realm where the definition of a person is determined by intelligence instead of size. Maybe there is hope for this naga, the elf thought to himself

"Are you going to kill me?" Nahash asked.

"Do you want to die?" the elf questioned back.

"No, but if it keeps my friend and everyone else in this realm safe from me, then I'd rather die than become a monster," Nahash sobbed.

The elf thought carefully before saying, "I'm not going to kill you. In fact, I'm going to free you and we'll find your friend."

"No! You can't!" Nahash yelled, "I'm hungry. You're not safe if I'm free."

"Do you want to eat me?" the elf asked.

"No. You saved me, even if it was just to keep me from William. I don't want to eat you, but me hunger..." Nahash tried to explain.

"The fact that you're worried about eating me and that you don't want to eat me should be enough to keep me safe around you?" the elf pointed out.

"But I could lose control of myself," Nahash replied, "You may not stay safe around me. You're still prey, and you're supposed to taste better than humans. I might become too curious of your taste or eat you without thinking because I'm so hungry. You mustn't free me."

"It will be alright," the elf assured the giant naga child, "I used to live in Felarya. That is where I was born. I know how to handle myself if you lose control, but I don't think you will lose control. You are very different from the other nagas I used to encounter."

"Y-you're from my world? Can you take me back home? This place would be much safer if I were to go away," Nahash told the elf.

"I don't know how to get back, and I would never want to go back to that terrible place," the elf answered, "I was a slave to the giant elves. That's not a life I would go back to. Besides, wouldn't you miss your friend?"

"I miss him already, but he's safer away from me. If I have to stay away from him to keep him safe, I will never see him again," Nahash informed the elf.

The elf began to cut the ropes of the net as he said, "That compassion you have for protecting him is what keeps him safe around you. If you really feel that strongly for your friend, then you will never be able to bring yourself to harm him. He will always be safe with you."

"But I'm still worried that I'll try to eat him again and fail at stopping myself," Nahash replied.

"Aren't there other dangerous creatures in this forest?" the elf questioned.

"Yes, but what does that have to do with anything?" Nahash asked.

"Those other dangerous creatures are all around this forest, and your friend could stumble on to him. Do you think they'll show your friend mercy?" the elf asked.

"No, they're animals, they don't have intelligence, just instincts," Nahash answered.

"Don't you think he will be safer with someone he knew and someone who could protect him rather than be alone with dangerous creatures surrounding him?" the elf questioned, "I think he'd be safer with something that has a chance of not eating him rather than something that will not hesitate in eating him."

Nahash had never thought of that way. Though Nahash wanted to keep Felix safe, he had overlooked the fact that other creatures could eat him, and without Nahash to protect him, Felix would be vulnerable. Even though there was a possibility that Nahash could loose control, he had a better possibility of staying in control of his instincts more than an animal. Felix would be safer with Nahash. By the time Nahash decided to go back to Felix, he realized he was free from the ropes. Nahash slowly brought himself up to full height and looked down at the elf. Nahash's empty stomach called out to Nahash as it growled for food.

Is Nahash able to keep himself from eating the elf?
14532222112212111112121221122.title: Found

choices: Nahash and Felix reunite on the trail.
Felix runs into hunters . . . .
145322221122121111121212211221.content:
Nahash moistened his lips with his tongue as he looked at the prey before him. He saw his hand reaching down for the elf and the elf watched the hand approach him. The elf watched the approaching hand, his own on the hilt of his blade, ready to strike back. But when the hand was only a few feet from him, just outside the reach of his blade, the elf saw the hand stop moving.

"No! I can't eat him!" Nahash thought, finally controlling his hand. "He isn't prey! He helped me. I cannot eat him!."

"But we need food! we're hungry! Make the pain stop! Eat the delicious elf!" cried part of his mind as his stomach growled in agreement.

"No!" Nahash yelled as his hand slowly receded towards his body. His chest rising and falling from deep breaths. The elf kept his hand at the ready as he watched Nahash.

"I see you will not try to eat me," the elf said, his tone gave no accusation towards what might have happened.

"You are prey . . . But I won't eat you because you are sentient," Nahash said between breaths. The elf nodded.

"A step in the right direction to say the least," the elf thought.

"What will you do now?" the elf asked.

"I want to find Felix. I need to make sure he's safe," Nahash said.

"Would you mind if I joined you in your journey?" the elf asked, again his voice held no alterior tone, just a simple request.

"But I might try to . . . No, I can control it," Nahash thought, "Besides if I try to eat Felix again, I might need someone to stop me."

"No, you may come with me," Nahash said, turning to the path he carved through the woods and started at his full speed.

"Thankfully he's a child or I would have never been able to catch up," the elf thought as he ran after Nahash.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- -

Meanwhile, Felix woke to the sun's warm rays and he drank some more water, refreshing himself, before walking across the giant tree to the other side.

"Time to find Nahash," Felix thought, running down the trail.
145322221122121111121212211221.title: Right Step

choices: Nahash and the elf arrive...
Reader's Choice...
1453222211221211111212122112212.content:
Felix walked down the path of destruction that Nahash had left. Nahash was too busy trying to get as far away from Felix as he could and didn't notice knocking down the weaker trees. Felix looked down at one of the trees. "In this world, Nahash is a very large and powerful being, and he's only five years old. I can only imagine how much stronger and bigger he'd be if he were older." Felix thought.

Another worry came into his head, "Will I even be able to catch up with him? He's very fast as well as large and could have traveled a great distance the other day. If he goes the same pace he did the other day, I will never catch up with him. And if he slows down to his normal pace, he'd be able to hide his trail. I saw how he traveled through the forest when I was on his shoulder, for a big guy, he can be very sneaky and quiet if he wants to be. I may not ever find him again."

"No," Felix thought as he shook his head, "I mustn't give up. Nahash needs me more than ever and I need him as well. We're friends, I can't just leave him to his fate."

Suddenly, a man walked out from behind a tree and into the path Nahash had made with his tail. The man faced Felix and was in his way. Felix stopped and looked behind him to see another man behind him as well. Felix turned to face the man in front once again who just stood there and watched. It looked like neither of the men were going to start the conversation. So, Felix asked, "Wh-Who are you? Are you bandits?"

The men laughed and the man in front replied, "Bandits? Do we look like bandits to you, kid? We're hunters. I think we should be asking you what you're doing in these woods all alone."

"I wasn't alone. My friend is missing and I have to find him," Felix informed them. Felix knew it was not best to tell the hunters that his friend was a Felaryan naga. For one, if the hunters were caring people, they might take Felix away from Nahash, believing Nahash was dangerous. But if those hunters were evil, they might force Felix to tell them where Nahash was, wanting to claim a lot of money for capturing a Felaryan Naga.

"A boy your age shouldn't be wandering alone in a forest like this, too dangerous," the man in front informed Felix, "Maybe you should come with us."

"No, you don't understand. I have to find my friend. He needs me," Felix replied.

"Duncan, do you see what this boy is wearing?" the man in the back called to the man in front, "He's wearing rags like one of those slaves."

"You're right," the man in the front, Duncan, agreed, "He is wearing slave clothing."

"Didn't Lord William lose a slave not to long ago as well as a giant Felaryan naga?" the second mean asked.

Felix's face turned pale. The hunters had found out that he was a slave of Lord William. Duncan asked Felix, "Are you Lord William's escaped slave? You match the description." Felix's hand reached for the sword. He knew he wouldn't know how to use it properly, but maybe it would scare the hunters away. The sword was large, but much lighter than it should be. If they saw Felix being able to pick up, what they thought was a heavy sword, it might scare them. "Hold up, kid. We're not here to hurt you. We're not the kind of people that turn in slaves. There have been slaves who have escaped Lord William's castle before and many have come to these woods. If any of the rumors about what goes on in that castle are true, we can never bring ourselves to bring a slave back there," Duncan said.

Felix studied the man's face. Felix had learned how to tell when a person was lying or telling the truth, and this man looked sincere in what he said. Felix took his hand away from the hilt. "Then if you're not going to turn me in, then please let me pass so I can find my friend," Felix pleaded.

"By the word friend, do you mean the giant Felaryan naga?" Duncan questioned.

"I... yes," Felix answered.

"I don't know what Felaryan means, but I know the words giant and naga. You shouldn't be looking for that beast. I think it will be best to come with us and let hunters find and kill the beast," Duncan suggested.

"No, you don't understand. Nahash is not a monster. He is a good person. Felaryan nagas are different from our nagas, because they're from a different world called Felarya. Their upper bodies are completely human and they are intelligent creatures," Felix tried to explain.

"You're telling me that the giant naga is sentient?" Duncan questioned in surprise.

"Yes, and he's my friend. But he ran off and I have to find him. He needs me," Felix informed them.

"Wait, why did this naga run off?" the second man asked.

"He... he..." Felix tried to come up with something, but he couldn't.

"He's hiding something Duncan. We should bring this boy to the village and find the naga and kill it," the second man suggested.

"Patience, Jacob, let the boy explain himself," Duncan ordered.

"He... he left to protect me from himself. Felaryans view people differently. They believe that if something could be swallowed, it is not a person at all and only prey. Yesterday, he grew large enough that he'd be able to swallow me," Felix explained.

"Sentient or not, this thing sounds like a monster," Jacob added.

"He's not a monster. He's very kind and gentle. He's only five years old. He doesn't know any better," Felix explained, "He only knows what his parents taught him and they taught him that things that are swallowable are just prey and nothing more. However, when we were imprisoned, he wasn't as big as he is now. At that time, he viewed me as a person and we became friends. We helped each other escape. When he tried to eat me, he remembered that we were friends. He couldn't bring himself to harm me and had to run off to keep me safe. I need to be there for him. If I can help him understand that humans are people and not prey, then maybe he will never think about eating a person ever again. He can be reasoned with. I'm sure of it."

"Duncan, you can't be thinking of letting that naga live. It's a monster and will be a danger to our village. It..." Jacob began to argue.

"Enough, brother. If this boy speaks the truth, than it is possible to explain to the naga that humans aren't prey. If we can change this naga's mind about people, think of all the help he can be for our village," Duncan said.

"I still think we should kill the naga and be over with it," Jacob added.

"I am the leader of the village brother," Duncan said, "And this course of action seems likely to succeed." Jacob did not look at his elder brother and disliked that tone he used, but he did realize he should not press the matter, for now anyway.

"So your orders?" Jacob asked, turning back to his brother.

"Take the deer we hunted back to the village and I'll go with the boy to find this naga and try to talk with him," Duncan said.

"As you command," Jacob said, nodding his head and departing. Duncan turned his head towards Felix.

"By the way boy, what is your name and your friend's name?" Duncan asked.

"My name is Felix. My friend is Nahash," Felix said. Duncan nodded.

"Then let's get walking on this trail," Duncan said, looking down the way Felix was headed before. "Pretty easy to follow."

"Only if he was moving fast," Felix said, "If he wanted, he would leave no trail at all. He was just in a hurry to leave me and keep me safe." Duncan said nothing in response as they began walking down the path.

***************************************

Elsewhere in the woods, five men were on horseback riding through the woods.

"Do you see anything?" the leader asked.

"No Captain Marcus," one man said.

"Then let's keep moving," Capt Marcus commanded, "Our Lord wants that naga back."

He knew battle strategies to outwit even the smartest forces. His only weakness, though no one knew this, was he could not read an animal's trail if his life depended on it. And right now it did, for if he went the wrong way and they missed a chance to finding the naga..... He did not consider the consequences.

"This way!" Captain Marcus yelled, pointing in a specific direction, not knowing it would lead him and his men to
14532222112212111112121221122122.title: On the Trail

145322221122121111121212211221221.content:
One didn't have to be a great tracker to realize which way the giant naga had gone. In the giant five year old Felaryan naga's rush, he had broken and bent branches, flattened the grass and made an impression in the ground from the weight and force of his large tail, and even tipped over a few trees. It doesn't take too much logic to figure out that if the naga bent the branches or knocked over those trees by running into them, then the branches would be bent and the trees and most of the trees would have fallen in the direction the naga was going. The injured and dead trees were practically pointing to the one responsible for their pain.

However, Captain Marcus didn't think about that. He might have been considered a genius in war, battle strategy, and fighting, but those were the only categories his intelligence was found. In any other category in his brain, he was either of average intelligence or a complete nincompoop. This was why he was one of the most revered captains in the army. Lord William knew that he could be controlled easily and still serve a great purpose in his army. Lord William had run into subjects too smart for their own good, but he didn't have to worry about that from Captain Marcus.

Captain Marcus didn't take much time in making a decision. He didn't want his soldiers to realize he wasn't good at tracking. So, Captain Marcus made a rash decision and pointed in a direction. He ordered him and his men in the wrong direction. His men didn't question his orders. Most had seen how excellent of a strategist and how good of a fighter Captain Marcus was. They assumed he had a well rounded intelligent in all other categories. Besides, it was never a good thing to question a superiors orders, especially in Lord William's army. Little did they now, they weren't heading in the direction of Nahash, but would end up encountering Felix.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- ---------------------------------------------------

"So, you actually were able to befriend a giant naga?" Duncan questioned as they walked down the easy trail.

"He was big, but nowhere as large as he is now," Felix explained, "Since he was sentient and still saw me as a person, it was actually pretty easy to befriend him. Once I got past the fact that he's a giant naga, I realized that he was just a very scared child. He's only five years old and he's been brought to a strange world and had been captured by strange people who chained him in a dark cell. He reminded me of myself."

"How so?" Duncan asked.

"I was five years old when I was made Lord William's slave. I know what it was like to suddenly be in an unknown place being forced to do things you don't want to do," Felix answered, "Hell, being a slave is all I can even remember. I understood what kind of things Nahash was going through and I guess that's what helped use become friends."

"It makes sense. Let's just hope his friendship for you is stronger than the rules of his world," Duncan replied, "You really don't remember your past life before Lord William's castle."

"I don't remember anything. I was told my parents sold me into slavery, but I'm not sure what to believe," Felix told Duncan.

Duncan thought about what Felix must have gone through. He had never known what it was like to be cared for or to have a family. All Felix knew was being a slave and living in the darkness of Lord William's world. "Sarah and I have been unable to make a child. We have tried, but nothing has happened yet. We've tried recommended herbs, medicines, and healers of God, science, and magic, but nothing has worked." Duncan thought, "Maybe, this former slave child could be willing to be adopted by us. Then we could finally have a child."

However, there were more pressing matters at hand, like finding the giant naga. Duncan placed the thought in the back of his mind and pressed onward. Eventually, Duncan heard the distant sound of galloping hooves coming closer. Duncan stopped and put out his arm to stop Felix as well. Felix didn't hear the sound, but Duncan heard five horses getting closer.

"What is it?" Felix asked in a worried tone.

"Five horses, coming this way," Duncan answered. Before Duncan and Felix could hide, five horses appeared in the horizon. Nahash's trail was going straight forward at that moment so a far distance could be seen.

"They're from Lord William's army," Felix recognized the armor and symbols on the chest plates. He could also tell one of them had a captain's armor suit on. "What do we do?" Felix questioned.

"Don't panic and act natural. Follow my led and don't say anything unless you have to," Duncan ordered. Duncan began to walk again and Felix followed. Duncan knew that the soldiers had probably seen them already and stopping to wait for the soldiers to reach them would probably seem too suspicious to the soldiers.

Eventually, their paths met. The soldier slowed their horses and Duncan and Felix had to stop since the soldiers were in the way. Captain Marcus stopped in front of Felix and Duncan with two soldiers beside him and the other two on either side of Felix and Duncan. "Good afternoon, hunter," Captain Marcus greeted, "How long have you been out in this forest today?"

"I have been out here with my son ever since the sun rose this morning," Duncan lied.

Captain Marcus glanced briefly at Felix and them back at Duncan, "We are looking for two things that has escaped from Lord William. Surely you've heard that a giant naga that Lord William has been holding captive has escaped with one of his slaves."

"I have heard of such news," Duncan replied.

"We are looking for the naga in these woods. The slaves isn't as important to Lord William and he was probably eaten by the naga by now. Have you seen the naga?" Captain Marcus.

"I have not seen the naga with my eyes, but I do believe this is a naga trail we are standing in," Duncan replied, knowing he couldn't just say no and not talk about the naga trail they were on at that moment.

"You best keep moving away from the naga's trail," Captain Marcus suggested, "This is not a giant naga from our world, but from a more savage and vicious world. This naga wouldn't think twice about eating a human and usually enjoy swallowing them whole."

"We will be careful," Duncan nodded.

Captain Marcus took another glance at Duncan and then back at Felix. "This you're son?" Captain Marcus asked.

"Yes," Duncan answered.

"He doesn't look very much like you," Captain Marcus commented.

"He takes most of his looks from his mother," Duncan lied.

"His clothing is also in shambles," Captain Marcus pointed out.

"We are just poor and simple hunters," Duncan argued.

"Yet you seem to be able to afford enough to get yourself decent huntsmen clothing and leather armor. Can't you give your son more than these rags?" Captain Marcus questioned, "His clothes are in just as bad a shape as Lord William's slaves. if I were to base my guess just on looks, I would believe he was the escaped slave."

"I assure you he is my son and not an escaped slave," Duncan tried convincing the soldier, "He only wears this clothing for hunting. Once he's proven himself to be a worthy enough hunter to spend money on, I'll get him the hunting armor he needs."

Captain Marcus eyed Felix carefully and remembered that Lord William branded all his slaves on the bag. Captain thought about asking the boy to lift his shirt so that he could see if there was a brand on his back. If there was, than this was the escaped slave and the hunter might know where the naga was. But, the man could be telling the truth and Captain Marcus would then only have wasted more time in finding the naga.

What did Captain Marcus decide to do?

Choice 1: Captain Marcus ordered Felix to lift his shirt. They found the brand on Felix's back. However, Nahash and the elf arrive at that moment and see Felix and Duncan in trouble.

Choice 2: Captain Marcus decided their telling the truth and there was no time to waste in finding the naga. Captain Marcus even tossed a few coins for Duncan so that he could buy Felix some clothes. The soldiers then kept going in the wrong direction

1453222211221211111212122112212211.content:
"I best be safe than sorry, Captain Marcus thought, knowing full well Lord William had no trouble promoting lower rank soldiers should the officers fail and need to be removed.

"Boy, remove your cloth," Captain Marcus ordered firmly.

"What did you order?" Duncan asked, moving in front of Felix. Marcus eyed Duncan before looking back at Felix.

"Crossbows," Captain Marcus ordered. Two soldiers quickly pulled out their cross bows and aimed then at the pair. "We can do this the easy way or the hard way." The remaining two placed their hands on the hilts of their swords.

"The men are apart from each other, so I cannot take both of them down at once. The others would join in right away. And each is probably a decent fighter. I wish I hadn't sent Jacob off. He could have at least gotten Felix out of here," Duncan thought as he eyed the situation.

"Remove your shirt boy," Captain Marcus repeated.

"Don't David," Duncan ordered, looking back at the Captain. Captain Marcus looked at Duncan again, their eyes drilling into the other, trying to make the other yield. Had this been any other place, a bar, on a town street, or even if it was on this path but Marcus was not a soldier, things might have turned out differently. But once these two strong willed men locked eyes, two dams were built and the resivoir between was filling quick. And with the weaponry and numbers favoring Captain Marcus, even if he cracked slightly, he would still likely have Duncan shot and Felix knew he would remove his shirt in the end or be killed as well.

"He's lied to them and is willing to die for me," Felix thought as he saw the others grabbing their weapons. Things were esscalating without orders. One slip of the finger would mean an arrow would be let lose.

"Put your weapons down, I'll remove my shirt," Felix called out. He watched Duncan flinch visibally and turn to him.

"David!" he said, eyes in shock. He looked at the small sad eyes in Felix's face.

"I couldn't let them kill you," Felix whispered as he moved from behind Duncan's protection. Slowly he lifted his shirt. The mark stared Captain Marcus in the face.

"Where's the naga slave?" Captain Marcus growled. He had felt sympathy for this boy and with the truth know, hated himself for that sympathy. He also feared what would happen if one of his men spoke of it.

"I don't know," Felix replied, turning back around to face the soldiers he once feared.

"Tell me or the hunter dies," Captain Marcus said firmly.

"Kill me if you want," Duncan said, "Run Felix!"

"I don't know where he is," Felix said, "He was going to eat me, since he is that large now, but chose to spare my life."

"What?" Captian Marcus asked, "You expect me to believe that?!"

"I saved his life. He spared mine. We became even," Felix answered.

"And why are you on his trail?" Captain Marcus asked.

"Because it was easy moving on it," Felix said.

"And I was taking him back to my village," Duncan said, "I used the trail so he could move quicker." Captain Marcus looked between the two. Captain Marcus snapped a finger and an archer fired a shot at Felix's leg. It grazed the leg, causing Felix collapse in pain.

"Tell me the truth," Captain Marcus repeated, "Where is the naga?!"

"All right, I'll tell you," Duncan said, moving in front of Felix once more. His eyes moving past the soldiers.

"Where?" Captian Marcus yelled.

"Here," Duncan said as a large shadow came over the men.

**************************************************

A few minutes prior, the unlikely pair pushed through the woods. As they pushed on, the elf noticed on the path some thing had come onto the trail, something on horses. He made no word of it, as Nahash had a single focus to getting back to Felix.

Finally, the young naga stopped, looking down the path. Five soldiers were talking with someone.

"What's going on?" Nahash asked, not wanting to be seen by anyone and be attacked again.

"Those soldiers have Lord Willaim's crest on the back," the elf said, "And they're talking to a boy and a man. Can't you hear it?"

"A little," Nahash said, but he pulled back when he heard someone say Felix. "Felix!" whispered Nahash. The elf shot an arrow past the young naga's face, making him look at the elf. "Felix needs me!" Nahash said.

"Then use your mind when it comes to attacking," the elf said, "Don't come right at them from behind. They could kill Felix." Nahash bit his lip, but his eyes looked around. Carefully, he climbed into the canopy. The elf moved closer and stayed hidden.

"One more test given by the spirits, the elf thought.

Nahash moved quietly closer until he was over the man talking. He saw Felix fall to the ground and felt an anger rise inside. Quietly, he lowered his upper body and reached out for two of the men. He heard nothing as he was focused soley on the hunt. He saw the men tense up and looked around. The men with crossbows saw Nahash first and those were the ones Nahash attacked, grabbing the men and threw him into the woods, where they wouldn't rise again.

The horses bucked in fear of the predator they sensed near them, allowing Duncan to move Felix out of the way. The ones with no riders ran off.

With a swing of his powerful tail, Nahash slammed into each of the remaining soldier and their horses. The horses fell on their riders, baddly hurt, injuring the riders as well.

With the enemies defeated, Nahash looked around for Felix.

"Felix?!" he called out, looking where the remaining human had taken Felix.

***************************

"He took out those soldiers with no effort," Duncan murmured, as he held Felix on his back. When the naga called for Felix. Felix smiled.

"He does care about me," Felix said, as Duncan went back onto the trail Nahash's large face looked down on the hunter and his friend.

"Did you hurt Felix?!" Nahash asked, his eyes growing cold.

"No, those soldiers did," Duncan said, "It's a minor wound. He'll survive if given treatment for it." Nahash smiled relief.

"Nahash," Felix called up, "Are you all right?" Tears came to Nahash's eyes as he looked at his friend.

"I'm sorry Felix," Nahash said, "I'm sorry I tried to eat you."

"I fogive you Nahash," Felix called out.

14532222112212111112121221122122112.content:
Duncan wanted to start questioning the giant naga child right then and there. He wanted to see if this giant naga child could really be reasoned with and trusted. He had never seen a naga like the one before him before. The naga was fully human from the waist up with a snake tail replacing its legs. The human part looked like a child of about five years of age, but much larger. The naga was a giant after all and could swallow a human whole!

Duncan just started at the giant naga as it bent its body down and stared directly down at Felix in Duncan's arms. Questions swarmed through the confines of his skull, but none of those questions entered his throat so that he could speak them. Instead, it was the giant naga boy who asked the first question.

"Who is this man, Felix?" Nahash asked. Nahash looked over the man with suspicion in his large eyes as he brought his enormous head closer to ground level. Of course Nahash was suspicious. The only kind human Nahash had come across was Felix, and there were men trying to capture him and Felix to bring back to Lord William. Nahash knew that he had to be suspicious to survive. Plus, this man had Felix, his best and closest friend who was like a big brother to the giant naga, in his arms. Though Nahash was the younger of Felix and himself, Nahash was bigger and he felt it was his duty to protect Felix. So when there was a stranger holding his best friend and a lot of people trying to capture him, it was right to be suspicious.

"This is Duncan," Felix informed Nahash, "He was helping me find you."

"And why was he doing that?" Nahash questioned, more suspicion growing within Nahash.

Duncan began lowering Felix to his feet and Duncan supported Felix as he stood on his good leg. Duncan saw the uneasiness in the naga's expression. The naga didn't like Duncan carrying Felix, as if the naga was very protective of Felix. "I understand you not trusting me right away. There are many hunters and soldiers searching for you, but I'm not one of them. I am in charge of a small village as well as one of their hunters," Duncan began to explain.

"He was trying to keep those soldiers from taking me. He made up a story that they almost believed. He's not one of them," Felix added.

"You... You were trying to keep them from taking Felix, why?" Nahash asked. This time, Nahash had a look of shock and confusion in his expression.

"I've heard the stories about what kinds of things happen to slaves in Lord William's castle. I wouldn't wish that sort of treatment on any creature," Duncan explained, "I couldn't let this boy end up Lord William's slave again. We shelter slaves who escape Lord William's castle. However, very few ever escape and soldiers don't usually even chase after them. You and Felix are the first they've actually chased after."

"I thought you said you were going to run away from me forever. What made you change your mind," Felix asked, limping a few steps away from Duncan and getting closer to Nahash.

Nahash moved one of his large hands and positioned it sideways. Nahash moved his hand next to Felix and Felix held onto the large hand for support. Nahash giant child-like face was nearly level with Felix, yet Felix was no longer afraid of the giant naga. "Someone helped me see that you are safer with me," Nahash informed Felix.

"Aren't you still afraid of eating me?" Felix asked.

"Yes, but he said that worry is what will keep me from eating you," Nahash replied. Nahash's fingers wrapped around Felix and he lifted Felix up as he stood up himself. Nahash pressed Felix against his chest and held him there with both hands in a strange hug only giants could do. "I don't ever want to be away from you again," Nahash cried a little, "You're my best friend. I want to protect you and keep you safe."

"You're my friend too, Nahash," Felix informed the naga and hugged whatever he could.

Duncan looked up in amazement. This giant naga and former human slave were actually friends and cared about each other. The naga actually wanted to protect Felix and didn't see him as just a snack to be saved for later. "This naga is just like Felix had described. It is sentient and can be reasoned with. If it can be befriended by a boy, then it can be reasoned with," Duncan thought.

Suddenly, a green cloaked figure stepped into the destructive path Nahash had made the other day. "Who are you?" Duncan yelled out, causing Nahash and Felix to look down and see what the matter was.

"Relax, I'm not an enemy," the cloaked man said as he removed his hood, revealing he was an elf.

"An Elf?" Duncan gasped.

"It's alright," Nahash called down to Duncan, "He was the one who talked me into coming back. He also saved me from hunters wanting to turn me in to the soldiers."

"Despite my better judgments, I save this Felaryan naga," the elf stated.

"What do you mean by that?" Felix questioned who was now sitting in Nahash's palm.

"I am originally from Felarya. I know what Felaryans are like and know they should not be trusted and killed because they're monsters," the elf informed.

"Then why did you save this one?" Duncan asked.

"He's different from all the Felaryans I've ever met. He seems to understand that eating people is wrong and seems to be struggling against his Felaryan morality. I don't know if it is because he is still young, or because he befriended a human before he was big enough to eat humans, or something more. Whatever the case is, this naga has the potential of becoming a person and no longer a monster. He has the potential of understanding that people are people no matter their size," the elf explained.

"An elf hasn't been in these parts for hundreds of years, why are you here?" Duncan questioned.

"I'm looking for something, and it's not the naga," the elf answered.

"What are you looking for?" Duncan asked.

"It is elf business. I'm not aloud to speak about this mission to anyone except elves and friends of the elven kingdom," the elf replied.

"If you told us, we could help you find whatever you're looking for," Felix offered.

"I'm sorry, little human, but I..." the elf's words stopped when he looked up at Felix in the naga's hand. "Wh-Where did you get that sword?" the elf questioned.

Felix looked at the sword and answered, "Nahash and I found it on a dead body, why?"

Choice 1: The elf needs to know where the body is. Nahash has to take the elf to the body while Duncan brings Felix to the village to help heal his leg.

Choice 2: The elf demands Felix give him everything he had taken from the body and point the elf in the direction of the body. Nahash, Felix, and Duncan head back to the village.

145322221122121111121212211221221122.content:
"You desecrated a body? Stealing from the dead?" the elf said darkly. Nahash pulled Felix towards himself instinctively.

"We needed the tools to survive," Felix replied, "When I was a slave and another slave died, those who were close might have taken his footwear if it was good or maybe a shirt to help survive the cold." The elf took a breath and understood. Sometimes the place you lived in changed what you felt was right and wrong. And most elves would have given Felix some aide in surviving, though surely not what he ended up taking.

"Then return them to me," the elf said, "As you will probably be accepted into Duncan's village, you will not need those items for much longer. Return them to me." Felix nodded and pulled himself out of Nahash's grip. He walked over to the elf and handed him the pack with the rope and lighting stones, the dagger, and most importantly the sword.

"Um, as you're probably wondering, the body is across the river, towards the mountains. If you follow Nahash's trail, you'll come to a spot where he left me. From there, head towards the mountains. It's behind a tree near an entrance to a cave," Felix explained. The elf picked up the gear.

"Thank you, young Felix," the elf said, "May fortune smile upon you." "For your own sake and Nahash's as well. I pray he finds more friends soon, otherwise I may need to kill him in the end." "I may see you later," the elf said, before walking away.

Duncan waited a few minutes until the elf was a distance away before speaking, "You handled that very diplomatically, Felix," Duncan said. Nahash was smiling as well.

"Felix, should we be going?" Nahash asked. Felix looked at Duncan.

"Do you still mean what you said before?" Felix asked. Nahash blinked in confussion. Duncan nodded.

"Yes, Nahash is safe for you to be around," Duncan said, before looking at the giant naga. "But are others safe around you, Nahash?"

"Felix is safe with me," Nahash said, still confused.

"Yes, but what about me? Or better to say another human the same size as Felix. Is such a person prey or not?" Duncan asked. Nahash went silent for a moment.

In his mind, part of him was saying yes, they were prey. But another part asked what the difference between that one and Felix was. The predator inside him countered that Felix was his friend, the others weren't. But Felix's words came back to him, silencing the predator. If they had met that person before his growth, he would not have been prey. But now he was. And Felix would have asked "There's nothing different between us Nahash. If one of us is prey, then the other must be prey as well! Am I prey to you Nahash?"

"Felix is not prey," Nahash answered, "As Felix is not prey and you are intelligent, not like a deer, then . . .then you should not be prey either."

"It's a start. If he does believe that, then the village will be safe around him," Duncan thought.

"Nahash, before we met up with you, I offered Felix a chance for you two to stay in my village. But first I needed to see what you thought of me," Duncan said. Nahash looked confused once more.

"So Felix and I won't be leaving here for my home?" Nahash asked, his face filled with hurt at the thought of never seeing his mother or father again, not even his big brother.

"Nahash, how would your family see Felix? How would they see anything smaller than them?" Duncan asked.

"They'd be prey," Nahash answered.

"And do you think that's right?" Duncan asked, "You said it yourself: 'Felix is not prey'. And you also said anyone intelligent is not prey either. From what little I know of your people, these two views go against everything they believe. Who do you believe is right?" Nahash closed his eyes once more. Tears came to his eyes.

"They're . . . wrong " Nahash said as he cried. Felix moved close to his friend and Nahash picked up the small Felix, holding him close as he cried over this revelation. "You're all I have Felix," Nahash mumbled. Duncan shook his head.

"He really is young. I hope he can forgive me one day for doing this," Duncan thought, "He'll also be much more protective of Felix. Will that be a blessing or a curse?"

"I'm here for you Nahash," Felix said, pressing himself against the strong chest. Duncan waited quietly until Nahash had finished crying.

"Nahash, as I was saying, I am offering you a new home to live in," Duncan said, "A home for you and Felix where you can live together." Nahash's eyes widened a little.

"May I sleep with Felix near me?" Nahash asked.

"If Felix doesn't mind," Duncan said, figuring if he said otherwise there would be trouble. Nahash smiled.

"Would you like to go to it?" Duncan asked, "It's this way." Nahash looked at Duncan for a moment. His tone, his demeanor, his kindness, these traits reminded Nahash much of his own father. Nahash bit his lip as he realized he might never see his family again, but he knew they were wrong. Anyone who said it was right to eat Felix was wrong. Felix was his family now.

"Only Felix, but maybe . . . ." Nahash thought in some yearning for a father figure as he looked at Duncan.

"Duncan," Nahash said softly, causing the hunter to stop and turn around. "Would you like me to carry you?"
