1453222211221211111212122112212211221.content:
Duncan quickly thought about the situation. His consciousness was a little hesitant and cautious of letting the giant naga child carry him. Not only was Nahash a giant naga, but he was also still only five years old, a very young child. Who would normally trust their lives, literally, in the hand of someone so young. The possible dangers were endless. However, Felix trusted his life in Nahash's hands and didn't seem to be worried about what could happen. Felix looked as though he felt safe in the five year old boy's hand. Plus, Nahash seemed to handle Felix with great care. It was clear that Nahash paid close attention to his actions so that Felix wouldn't get harmed. Duncan already learned that Felix was very important to the giant naga.

"If Nahash feels just a pinch of what he feels for Felix, and if he truly sees me as a person, then I should be safe. He will be just as careful with me as he is with Felix," Duncan thought to himself, "I will be safe with Nahash. Plus, there are some other advantages to letting him carry me. For one, we'd get to the village much faster due to his size. Also, if I show him that I trust him, he might see me as a friend, and it might even evolve into a father son-like relationship if I'm the one that has to take care of him. Nahash already seems to see Felix as a brother. Finally, if I come to the village with him carrying me, the village will see that he's friendly, or at least he'd seem more friendly to the village."

With those final quick thoughts, Duncan made his final decision. "Yes, Nahash, you may carry me, as long as you are careful."

"I will be very careful," Nahash promised. Nahash bent his human half over and lowered a hand with the palm facing up. Duncan walked onto the giant hand and sat down on the soft skin. Duncan didn't have nearly as much room as Felix had on Nahash's other hand since Nahash was still young. However, there was still enough room to sit down. Plus, Duncan was about six inches tall relative to Nahash. Nahash slowly and gently lifted the hand with Duncan in it to chest level, glad that the human trusted him. "Would you two like to be on my shoulders?" Nahash asked.

Felix and Duncan agreed and Nahash lifted each one to a shoulder. Felix and Duncan climbed onto the opposite shoulders and Nahash stood perfectly still as they did this. Duncan was surprised that the five year old would have enough control to stay still. Despite being a giant naga, the boy seemed to be well behaved. "This actually might be able to work. We might be able to keep Nahash and Felix in the village and everyone will be safe. He also might actually be behaved enough for two humans to be his parents," Duncan thought since he had been worried about being able to take care of a giant naga.

"Which way is your village?" Nahash asked while carefully turning his head towards Duncan. Duncan gave Nahash directions and they were heading for the village Duncan lived in and ran. Duncan was impressed by how fast and silent the giant Nahash was. Despite his size, he truly was quiet and didn't leave a huge trail to follow. Duncan was very impressed. Nahash was clearly built to be a great predator.

Suddenly, Duncan remembered something and looked down from over Nahash's shoulder as he sat upon it. Sure enough, what he had thought he had seen was there. Noticing that they were getting close to the village, Duncan spoke up, "Nahash, could you stop for a moment, please?"

Nahash stopped as soon as Duncan asked him to like a very obedient child. "What's wrong?" Nahash asked.

"Well, you don't have any clothing to cover up your... private," Duncan informed Nahash.

Nahash looked down and saw that Duncan was right. "I've barely noticed. My cloth ripped off when I had my first growth spurt. Is this a problem?" Nahash questioned.

"Well, I don't think a five year old she be going around naked. Especially if he's going to be presented to an entire village," Duncan replied.

"Well, my mother did say that she would make a cloth for me until I was old enough. She said when I'm an adult it's alright, because my parents are naked all the time. She said it helps capture prey, whatever that means," Nahash added.

"Well, in our village, we were clothing in public. Since you'll pretty much be in the public a lot. We're going to have to get you something to cover that up," Duncan informed Nahash.

"How?" Felix asked, "There's no clothing that would fit a giant like Nahash, especially since he's a naga as well as a giant."

"All we need to do is make a loincloth. My wife, Sarah, makes clothes for the village. She should have enough cloth to make one and I should have enough rope to wrap it around you," Duncan said.

"So, what do we do?" Felix asked.

"We're close to the village right now. I can go there and get Sarah while you and Nahash wait here for us," Duncan said. Felix and Nahash agreed, and Nahash lifted his hand to his shoulder where Duncan was. Duncan got on and Nahash lowered Duncan to the ground so that he could get off and head for the village. "I will be back shortly," Duncan told the two boys before running off to the village.

Nahash slithered over to a tree and leaned against it. Nahash then picked Felix up from his shoulder and leveled with two hands chest level as Felix sat on the palms. The two boys waited for Duncan and his wife's arrival.

Duncan made it to the village where Jacob was waiting near the edge of town. "You took a long time, where is it?" Jacob questioned.

"Safe with the boy not far from the village," Duncan informed his brother.

"Is it like the boy described? Is it safe?" Jacob continued to ask.

"Yes, Nahash can be reasoned with and he is safe to be around," Duncan answered.

"Are you positive this... Nahash... is really safe?" Jacob asked.

"Yes, Nahash is safe. He truly cares about Felix like a brother and sees him as a person. Nahash reasoned that if Felix is a person, then all humans are people. We can befriend him," Duncan tried to assure his brother, "Now, did you tell the village anything?"

"I did not tell them about your plans or about what we found," Jacob told Duncan, "However, people found it odd that I came back alone without food, since we usually come back with a good amount. They questioned me, but I just told them that they will know more when you arrive." Duncan was relieved that Jacob kept his mouth shut. He was a great brother and even when they might not see eye to eye with certain things. Jacob knew when it was best to keep things secret. Otherwise, there would have been a large panic. "What's the plan?"

"Well first, I need Sarah's help to make Nahash a little more presentable. When that is finished, we will call a town meeting and then bring them to the edge of the village where I will explain everything and introduce them to Nahash and Felix. I just hope I can explain everything in a way to keep them from panicking," Duncan said.

"Once you do whatever you and Sarah have to do, get me and I'll go to the town hall and ring the bell. Once everyone is there, I'll bring them here and you can do what you need to. But whose going to take care for Nahash and Felix? Whose going to want to take care of a giant naga?" Jacob asked.

"Sarah and I will take care of them," Duncan informed his brother, "I just hope the village accepts Nahash and Sarah is fine with it. Do you still have doubts about Nahash?"

"I do," Jacob replied, "But I have not met him yet and I respect your decision. You usually have a good judge of character."

"Trust me, when you see Nahash, most of that doubt will disappear. He is just a child and very gentle," Duncan informed Jacob, "Now, I will get Sarah and speak to her."

Duncan ran off to his house, which was on the edge of the village, the same edge they were on now. Normally a leader of a town or village would live in the center of town. So, it seemed odd that Duncan would be on the edge of his village. Now, they did have a town hall in the center of town, but Duncan preferred to live on the edge since he was also one of the village's best hunters. Now this seemed to help if he was truly going to care for a giant naga. if he would have lived in the center of town, the giant naga wouldn't have been able to live with them.

Duncan entered his home where his wife was waiting. "Where have you been and what's going on?" Sarah questioned as soon as his foot entered the house. Sarah was a beautiful women with long red curly hair.

"What do you mean?" Duncan asked.

"I heard that Jacob had come to town before you and that something was going on, but no one knew what, because Jacob didn't say what it is," Sarah replied.

"Rumors spread like wildfire in this village, but what do you expect when there is only about forty families in the village," Duncan commented.

"What is going on, Duncan?" Sarah questioned her husband.

"Jacob and I came across another runaway slave from Lord William's castle. The boy was only ten years old," Duncan started.

"Only ten years old?" Sarah interrupted, "The poor child."

"He escaped with a friend, but his friend is a giant naga," Duncan continued.

"A giant naga!" Sarah gasped.

"But the naga is sentient and has a human upper body. The naga's about 75 feet tall, but its only a five year old boy," Duncan said. Duncan saw the fear in Sarah's eyes and face upon hearing how large the naga was. "There's no need to worry about the naga," Duncan explained, "The naga is gentle and sees humans as people. Felix, the slave boy, has befriended the naga and they act like brothers. The naga is safe."

"So, what are you planning to do?" Sarah questioned.

"I want the Felix and Nahash, the naga, to live here," Duncan answered.

"You want a giant naga to live in our village!? Sarah screamed.

"Nahash isn't evil. He would kill anyone. Plus he's only five years old, he can be raised to be good. Trust me, Sarah, everytings going to be okay," Duncan tried to assure Sarah, "Also think of what Nahash could do for the village once he's older and bigger? He can protect the village from almost anything."

"Where is this Nahash now?" Sarah asked.

"In the forest not far from the village," Duncan answered, "Before he can come to the village, I need your help."

"What kind of help?" Sarah wondered.

"I need you to make a loincloth for him. He doesn't have clothes and his... well... you know is showing," Duncan informed his wife.

"How much cloth do we need?" Sarah asked, blushing a bit.

"He's a 75 foot tall naga. He needs quite a bit," Duncan replied.

Once Duncan and Sarah felt they had enough rope and cloth for Nahash, they began bringing it to where he was. How would Sarah's reaction to seeing Nahash be?

14532222112212111112121221122122112211.content:
Once Duncan had departed, Nahash laid down on the ground. Despite his size and strength, it had been a long day for the young boy. Felix sat on Nahash's hand in front of the boy's face. The pair was silent for a time until worry began to fill the young naga's mind.

"Felix, will you stay with me even if this village won't accept me?" Nahash asked, looking pleadingly at his only friend in the world. Felix turned to Nahash's large eyes. The question held a lot of weight.

"Would I stay with him if Duncan's village won't accept you?" Felix thought, "He must really be worried about being alone. Of course he is. He has realized a truth that goes against his parent's way of life. He chose me over that life, over his own blood. I owe him too much to leave if they won't accept him."

"Nahash, let's not doubt things before they happen," Felix said, "After all, you see Duncan as a person and you saved him and me from those soldiers. Those are good reasons for them to accept us." He felt the plural would show Nahash they were in this together, win or lose.

"I didn't kill them to save Duncan," Nahash replied, "I did it to save you." Felix smiled.

"Yes, but you still saved him in the end," Felix said, "That is something they will take into consideration." Nahash nodded. He turned his head quickly at the sound of approaching people. He rose upward and brought Felix to his chest. Duncan and Sarah appeared on the trail and Nahash relaxed a little. He notied them slow down a little as they approached.

*************************

"My God, he's huge! And he's only going to get bigger?!" Sarah thought, freezing for a moment when Nahash came into sight. Duncan was pushing a cart with the clothes for the young boy and noticed his wife's fear.

"Sarah, I promise you, he will not hurt us," Duncan affirmed. Slowly she nodded and began walking slowly towards a creature her every instinct was telling her to flee from.

"Hello Duncan," Felix called from Nahash's hand. Duncan waved back at Felix.

"Come on down so we can dress Nahash," Duncan said. Felix looked at his brother and Nahash slowly put Felix on the ground. Nahash looked carefully at the human woman with Duncan. Despite his time in Lord William's castle, he had never seen a human woman before. So he took in her features and noticed the differences between her and Duncan were like the ones different between his own parents. But the thought of his parents, once again realizing he would never see them again, though it was their own beliefs of Felix not being a person that made it so, did not make the pain any easier to bear. Tears started to form in his eyes.

"What do you need me to do?" Felix asked as he limped off the hand, unaware of Nahash's pain.

"We need Nahash to tie this around his waste to cover his . . . you know," Duncan said, looking up at the tear filled eyes. Sarah and Felix looked up.

"Nahash, what's wrong?" Felix asked.

"I was just thinking about my family," Nahash whispered, before sniffing and rubbing away the tears from his eyes.

"Why is he crying though? Are they dead?" Sarah asked quietly. Felix shook his head.

"No, they view humans as prey, so they aren't a person," Felix answered, "Nahash doesn't think that way and knows he can't anymore. So he can never return home again." Sarah didn't realize her mouth was open from shock for a few moment.

"Umm, Nahash, when you're ready, would you take these ends of rope and tie them around your waist, covering you . . ." Duncan coughed and blushed a little, "Area." Nahash nodded and took the rope in his hands. It was no thicker than one inch thread to the naga and he reached behind him. His face contorted with discontent.

"I can't tie it," he said.

"Give me a lift on your tail and I'll do it for you," Duncan said, moving towards Nahash. The boy nodded and grabbed both ends in one hand and with his free hand brought it forward for Duncan to stand on. Duncan got on and was taken to Nahash's tail. Nahash leaned forward, so Duncan would have an easier time standing and his gaze went back to the woman.

"Hello," Nahash said, looking down at the woman.

"Hello, I am Sarah, Duncan's wife," Sarah replied, happy this naga's friend was near her for protection. But as she looked into the large eyes, she saw his youth and innocence. If he would always be like this, maybe he would do well at the village.

As Duncan tied the ropes, so the cloth made of a few sheets covered his naga-hood, Nahash took in Sarah's features interesting features more.

"Her hair is like mother's. And her face looks like mother's as well," the boy thought. She could be a double for his mother, minus the ruby colored tail. He bit his lip at this realization. But this did not go unnoticed by those in front of Nahash.

"Nahash, is something wrong?" Felix asked.

"Sarah looks like my mom," Nahash said quietly. Nahash had tried to say it quietly enough for only Felix to hear. However, it's hard to speak quietly to one person when one's a giant naga who’s bending down close to two humans. As Nahash shifted his eyes back to Sarah, it was clear that she had heard his statement.

Sarah looked away from the giant head near her. "He thinks I look like his mother?" Sarah gasped in her mind. It was a very surprising statement to make to a person one didn't know. Especially if it was a giant naga saying it to a human it had just met! Sarah began to wonder if Nahash really meant what he said and she looked like his mother, or if Nahash's mind was playing tricks on him and made Sarah look like his mother because he missed his mother a lot.

Because Sarah looked away, Nahash believed he had offended her in some way. "I'm sorry," Nahash apologized, "I didn't mean to upset you." Nahash was still young and didn't understand the full impact and complications of his statement, but he was a very bright young naga and understood a good amount. He knew how his comment could have been misinterpreted and makes it sound like he wanted Sarah to be his mother. He knew it must be odd for a giant naga to ask a human he had just met to be his parent. If she still believed he was a monster, it could have offended her.

"I just miss my mother so much, and you look like her a lot," Nahash tried to explain, "If you were a naga I would have thought you were her twin or something." Nahash continued to explain, but it seemed like he was digging himself in a deeper hole, "I wasn't asking you to be my new mom. You don't have to if you don't want to. I am a giant naga after all. But if you do want to be my mom, you can. I just..."

Sarah cut Nahash off and said, "It's alright, I understand what you meant." Nahash sighed and remained quiet. "He does want me to be his mother, though," Sarah realized, "But how can I raise a giant naga. How could something so large ever listen to me? So far as I can tell though, this giant naga seems to act a lot like a normal child. He also seems to be well behaved and considerate of others. Maybe it is possible to raise a giant naga. Maybe this really can work out. He seems gentle enough."

"I'm finished, Nahash," Duncan broke the silence. Nahash reached his hand back and Duncan hoped on.

When Duncan was set on the ground, Nahash stood to his full height and looked down. After being naked ever since his first growth spurt in Lord William's castle, it felt odd to have a loincloth again. It felt strange, yet comfortable. Nahash looked down at Duncan and Sarah and smiled. "Thank you Sarah and Duncan. It fits nicely," Nahash informed the two humans.

"Well, when you continue to grow, we're going to eventually have to add more rope and possibly more sheets," Duncan replied. Duncan turned to Felix and said, "Unfortunately we don't have the time at the moment to make you knew clothes, but we should take a look at that wound before we reach the town."

Felix nodded in agreement and was told to sit down. Duncan and Sarah had brought some things to deal with cuts from there home. Duncan brought over what he needed to disinfect and cover up Felix's wound. Nahash lowered himself down on his stomach to get a closer look. Sarah noticed the pure concern in Nahash's eyes. "How much do you really care about Felix?" Sarah questioned the giant naga.

"He is like a brother to me. I would do anything for Felix. I will protect him from anything," Nahash answered.

Sarah was surprised that a giant naga would care that much about a human. Due to Nahash's personality as well as her inability to have a child of her own, Sarah was becoming more certain that she could raise Nahash and Felix.

"This is going to sting," Duncan warned Felix as well as Nahash so that Nahash wouldn't do anything drastic when seeing Felix in pain. Duncan poured some disinfectant on Felix's wound and Felix hiss a little in pain. It took all of Nahash's effort to resist doing something about it. Duncan then wrapped up the wound with a clean cloth before putting Felix pants leg back down.

"So, what happens now?" Felix questioned.

"Now it's time for the hard part," Duncan replied, "We're going to go to the edge of the forest, but you and Nahash will have to stay in the forest a bit longer. Sarah and I will get my brother and he will gather everyone close to the edge. I will explain everything that happened and try to calm them before showing them you and Felix. When it's time we will introduce the two of you to the village."

"Do you think the village will accept me?" Nahash asked.

"It's uncertain, but I hope so," Duncan answered truthfully.

"And if Nahash is accepted, what will happen to us?" Felix asked.

"You will be raised and cared for by new parents," Duncan answered.

"Who?" Nahash asked.

Duncan looked to his wife. It was clear that she wanted to raise the two boys, even the giant naga. Sarah had seen to good in Nahash and she knew she could never have a child of her own. Sarah nodded, almost begging Duncan to agree with her in taking care of Nahash and Felix. "If all goes well, we will be your new parents," Duncan told them.

"You'd really be my new parents, even if I'm a naga?" Nahash questioned in disbelief.

"Yes," Sarah answered.

Nahash was overjoyed by that answer as he asked, "Can I pick the both of you up? I want to hug you both." Duncan and Sarah agreed to the request and Nahash carefully picked Duncan and Sarah up in each hand. He then brought them to his chest after standing up again. Nahash gave them a firm, but gentle hug. When he was finished, he placed Duncan and Sarah back down on the ground.

"I think we should start," Duncan said, "We're not that far, and we can walk there."

"Can I still carry you, Felix?" Nahash requested. Felix agreed and Nahash picked up the human he saw as his brother. They began heading for the village.

How do things go?

"All right, wait here until I call for you two," Duncan said as they reached the edge of the woods.

"Yes . . . Father," Nahash said, looking down at the small man. Duncan stopped for a moment as shock came over him.

"I'll need to get used to that," Duncan thought. Sarah gave a nod, knowing just what he was thinking. Long had they wanted to hear someone call them those words. And now someone was.

Duncan and Sarah moved to the edge of the village where Jacob was waiting.

"Is everything all right?" Jacob asked.

"Yes, our adopted children seem well behaved," Sarah affirmed. Jacob blinked but said nothing in response to that, just yet.

"So, I'll go ring the bell," Jacob said, before departing.

Duncan and Sarah waited, glancing between the inner of the town as they heard the bell's ringing and the forest, where Nahash was hiding. Soon Jacob was seen walking towards them with many people behind him.

"Some won't like this even if Nahash is gentle," Sarah muttered.

"Then we'll just have to convince enough so there won't be too much trouble," Duncan said as he got on a cart. He waited for everyone to arrive and quiet down before beginning.

"Everyone, in the woods today while hunting, I found two escaped slaves from Lord William's castle," Duncan began. His eyes scanned over the group. No one liked the man they sent tithes to for so called "protection". "They are both young boys, not brothers in blood, but brothers in experience. So, Sarah and I have chosen to adopt them as our own." He paused and heard murmurs amongst some of the people.

"Why are you doing this?" called out Ben, one of the more cynical villagers, "Why the big call and making us walk here? There's something wrong with them, isn't there?" There were voices in agreement.

"One of them is a boy of ten years named Felix," Duncan answered, "He is as human as you or me. His brother, however, is not. That's why I called this meeting here. So you can all meet him. He is a kind, gentle spirit who has no one else he can look towards. He will not harm us, despite what you may first think."

"Yes, but what is the thing?" Ben cried in response.

"It's now or never," Duncan thought.

"Nahash, would you come out here please?" Duncan called out.

In the woods, Felix was sitting on Nahash's hand and patted his large chest when they heard Duncan's request. He nodded in affirmation and Nahash took a breath before slithering out into the open.

There were many gasps and cries of shock upon seeing the giant naga. Ben stared in silence. He had heard of nagas before, but never had he thought he'd meet one. Nahash visibly flinched from the shock.

"A naga?! You want to adopt a naga that can devour one of us with as much ease as we breath?!" Ben cried out over the shocked people.

"Nahash is no threat to us," Duncan replied.

"Horseshit!" Ben answered.

"I swear I won't!" Nahash said, silencing everyone for a moment. "Felix is my brother, not prey. He is human like you. So you must not be prey either. I won't eat something that isn't prey." Many blinked in confusion at the young boy's logic. Ben stared with scrutinizing eyes.

"Nahash is just a young boy far from home," Sarah called out, getting up on the cart next to her husband, "I care for him because of his kindness and innocence. I will not let you harm him."

"Yes, but will you protect him from his own hunger, wench?" Ben shot back. Nahash's eyes narrowed.

"Don't you call my mother names!" he screamed, shocking everyone again. 'My Mother'. The words echoed across the group and between the ears of many present. The adults realized he said those words instantly, without thought put into them. His emotion behind them was rage for Ben insulting Sarah, like any child would defend his mother.

"Thank you Nahash," Sarah said softly, blushing from the amount of emotion Nahash just spoke with.

"As you see, Nahash cares for us like his own family. He will not harm this village," Duncan said, bringing attention onto himself once more. "What say you? Do you believe me?" There was silence. It seemed to drag on further than the length of Nahash's tail. Finally, one person screamed "Aye!" And many more followed, until well more than half agreed to allowing Nahash to stay.

The young naga, however, only looked confused by their response, but as he saw his new mother and father smiled, he smiled as well, realizing this was a good response.

"Thank you. As you would guess, given his size, he will not sleep in the town. But the woods will be a place for him to sleep and hide when merchants come to town," Duncan said.

"What about Lord William?" Ben called out, "I doubt he will like losing such a slave. There could be bad consequences to allowing him to stay."

1453222211221211111212122112212211221111.content:
"I will stop Lord William and his soldiers," Nahash spoke up as she looked down at the crowd of villagers before him, "I was afraid that I would be alone because of the way I view humans. I know other nagas won't accept me because I don't see humans as prey, and I was worried humans wouldn't accept me because I'm a naga. If this village is able to accept me as a part of it, and this becomes my home, I will do everything I can to protect it and everyone in it, because I'm grateful that I won't have to live on my own."

"How will you protect this village from Lord William's men?" Ben questioned with skepticism, "You may be a giant naga, but you're still just a child. How can you protect this village?"

"I've killed some of his soldiers to save Felix and my dad," Nahash informed Ben, proud of his accomplishments and saving Felix and Duncan. Nahash also came from a world where it was kill or be killed, a world where one had to fight to survive. Defeating adult humans, no matter how small they were compared to him, seemed to be one of Nahash's greatest accomplishments.

"You've killed humans!?" Ben yelled, jumping at the opportunity to show the village that Nahash was a monster, "You've heard it from this beast's own mouth! It killed humans, and it seems proud of that fact. This naga is a child and it has already killed humans without being affected by the fact it had killed someone. If it can kill that easily as a child, it could become a devastating and blood-thirsty monster."

"No, I..." Nahash tried to argue, but he didn't know what he could say to counter the mean human's argument. Instead, Nahash blurted out, "But those men were evil, and I didn't know them."

"And you think it is okay to kill someone just because you don't know them?" Ben yelled out.

"That's enough, Ben!" Duncan ordered.

However, Ben didn't listen and continued, "They may have worked for an evil man, but did that make them evil. They were just following orders. They could have had families and friends that will never see them again."

"But I," Nahash began to tear up, finally realizing the gravity of what he had done.

"I bet you ate those men to," Ben accused.

"I didn't," Nahash cried.

"You don't stop to think or regret killing a person on a battlefield," Duncan argued from a top the cart, "There are things that have to be done for the good of others."

"This is not a battlefield, this is a village. If he thinks it's alright to kill people he doesn't know, what's stopping him from killing again if someone makes him mad or doesn't give him what he wants. He's a giant; he'll have the power to do whatever he wants and..." Ben continued to try and rally others in the crowd.

"Stop it!" yelled out a voice. Everyone turned their attention to the small boy in Nahash's hand. The voice had come from Felix as he stood on Nahash's hand while it was level with the giant naga's chest. The large head of the naga above him was crying from Ben's words. "Nahash did it to save Duncan and I," Felix explained, "Those men were going to kill us, but Nahash stopped them because of his love for his brother within him. Despite what you think, Nahash is a kind and caring kid who would do anything for the ones he loves. If you are kind to him, he would never harm you. He knows humans are people and he will treat everyone as equals despite his size and power. I'm sure Duncan and Sarah will raise Nahash to be good and he will listen to them because he sees them as his parents since he can no longer be with his own. This village and everyone in it are safe with Nahash."

The whole village went silent and Felix turned back around to look up at Nahash's giant face. Nahash sniffed and wiped away a few tears with his other hand. "Thank you, Felix," Nahash said.

"That's what brothers are for, right?" Felix replied. Nahash smiled and hugged Felix against his chest which helped Nahash's cause by showing how gentle the giant naga really was.

"Now unless there is any more objections, This will be Nahash's new home and Sarah and I will be the Nahash and Felix's new parents. They will both be citizens and will have equal rights. Is that understood?" Duncan informed the crowd. No one spoke up. If there was still any shred of doubt in people, none of them spoke up. "This meeting is dismissed," Duncan finished.

The crowd began to disperse and Sarah approached Nahash. She placed her hand on the underside of the vertical base of Nahash's tail. Nahash looked down while still hugging Felix. "Are you alright, Nahash?" Sarah asked in a caring and sincere voice.

"That man's word hurt me," Nahash sniffed.

"I promise that I will do my best to make sure that man never hurts you again," Sarah told her giant son.

Nahash began to cheer up. He bent down and picked up Sarah with a different hand and pressed her against his cheek as he rubbed it against her. Sarah was relieved and happy at how affectionate Nahash was. She kissed his cheek as he showed her his affection.

"Nahash!" Duncan called up. Nahash looked down and saw another man standing beside his new father. "Nahash, this is my brother, Jacob. Whether he likes it or not, his is yours and Felix's uncle now," Duncan introduced.

"Hi," Nahash replied sheepishly.

"Could you please put Felix and your mom down, Nahash? I'm sure Felix is eager to have some real clothes that Sarah can provide," Duncan said.

"I should have some clothes at home that should fit you. I own a clothing shop after all," Sarah informed Felix. Felix thanked his new mother and Nahash obeyed his human father and set the rest of his family down gently. Sarah led Felix to their home and Nahash followed behind. He wanted to take a look at the house as well, even if he could only look through windows. He also wanted to stay close to his "big" brother Felix.

As all this happened, Duncan and Jacob spoke.

1453222211221211111212122112212211221111.content:
"What do you think of your new nephew?" Duncan asked quietly. Jacob looked at the departing form of Nahash and sighed.

"I agree he can be useful and he does care for you and Sarah," Jacob conceded.

"I sense a 'but' coming on," Duncan injected. Jacob nodded.

"I need more time to trust him. I doubt with all the able men in this village, we could take him down. Until I know he cares for those in this village like family, I won't fully drop my guard," Jacob answered. Duncan nodded. Their father, now passed, had taught them to see this village as a family. They cared for everyone and made sure there was enough food to go around, especially in the harsh winters that they had here.

"All right. Just keep an eye on Ben as well. I don't want him causing trouble when there is none," Duncan answered. Jacob nodded as they started moving to Duncan's house.

"So, do you want to go back out to hunt for the storage unit?" Jacob asked, "There was deer sign before we ran into Nahash's trail. Duncan nodded.

"Yes, but I want to see something first," Duncan replied.

******

"Are you comfortable in those new clothes?" Sarah asked, smiling at her new son. Felix touched the clothes he was wearing in a reverent manner. His old idea of "new" clothes was either clothes another slave out grew or a guard had damaged beyond repair and tossed them to him by chance. To wear something no one had used before, something that was so warm and fitting, it was almost as wonderful as his new family.

"They're wonderful mother," Felix answered softly as tears came to his eyes. Sarah was quick to hug Felix.

"Felix, what's wrong?!" Nahash asked, seeing his brother cry through the window.

"I don't know," Felix replied, "I just can't stop crying."

"Felix," Sarah said softly, "You're probably just happy, that's all. After such a hard life, it is over. And you are safe." Felix nodded and hugged his mother.

Duncan and Jacob saw Nahash looking into the building when they arrived.

"Nahash, how do you like the home?" Duncan asked.

"Felix is crying," Nahash replied. Duncan and Jacob froze for a moment before Sarah and Felix came outside.

"He's just overjoyed, that's all," Sarah answered Duncan's unsaid question. Duncan nodded, before looking at his younger son.

"Nahash, I would like to ask you a question," Duncan said. Nahash turned from Felix, looking down at his father.

"Yes," Nahash asked.

"When you hunt, do you eat everything of your prey?" Duncan asked. Nahash nodded. "I thought so," Duncan commented.

"Is that wrong?" Nahash asked, wondering if eating everything was as bad as eating a person.

"No, well, not for where you grew up probably," Duncan answered quickly. He took a breath. "You see those new shoes Felix is wearing? Those came from the skin of an animal we hunted. We use more than just the meat to survive, we use their skin and sometimes the bones in cooking." Nahash nodded.

"So, you don't want me to eat the whole animal?" Nahash asked.

"The pelts are either used to make clothes or trade for other goods," Duncan said, "And we don't always eat all the meat. We store some for later if food is scarce." Nahash nodded again.

"So what should I do father?" Nahash asked, before feeling a familiar grumble in his large stomach. He blinked, realizing with all the commotion today, from being attacked by hunters, to meeting the elf, to finding Felix and his new family, he hadn't eaten once. The adult humans stared in silence when they heard the loud rumble.

"Well," Duncan said before coughing a little, "I was going to say you could hunt with either your uncle Jacob or me and we would skin the animal, saving the pelt and you get the meat."

"I could do that," Nahash said, as he felt the hunger in his stomach again. "Can Felix come with us?" Duncan looked at the pleading eyes of his son.

"Nahash, Felix's leg was injured and needs to heal," Sarah said, drawing her large son's attention, "It would be best if he just rested for the rest of the day." Nahash nodded. He didn't want Felix hurt anymore and he trusted his new mother.

"All right," Nahash said, looking back at his uncle and father. "May we go now?" Duncan smiled.

"That was my hope," Duncan said, inwardly laughing. He had never though his first father-son hunt would be with something like Nahash, but he was happy none the less. Jacob smiled a little and nodded as well.

The elf followed Felix's directions and eventually came upon the body. The skeleton was sitting down, leaning against the base of the tree. The elf stopped upon seeing the skeleton and at first, all he could do was stand and stare in disbelief. There was a long moment of silence where not even the forest made a sound. "This can't be happening," the elf whispered.

The elf slowly took a step, and then another. He repeated this at a slow and hesitant pace, but he eventually made it to the body and knelt in front of it. The elf step the pack down as well as the weapons that Felix had taken from the dead body. The body had no belt or sheath. "The sword Felix found definitely came from this body," the elf said aloud, "And this is an elf's body." To the human eye, the skeletal frame of a human and an elf's looked similar, but to an elf, a difference could be seen. This elf knew that this was the remains of an elf.

The elf turned and saw a cave entrance. "If that's the cave system Felix and the naga used to escape Lord William's castle, it could eventually lead to the dungeons if one takes the right paths," the elf realized. He turned back to the dead elf and said, "You're the one who was sent to spy on Lord William. If that's true, you're the one I've been searching for."

The elf bowed his head and collected himself. He placed his hand on the body's chest and felt something under the coat. The elf opened it up and found a book underneath. No, not a book, it was a journal. The elf took the journal and opened it up. He glanced at the later entries and noticed that the elf that was once alive had written down all of Lord William's suspicious actions. The elf speed though the last entry which was cut off at the end. The sentence wasn't even finished. There was also no indication in the entry that he was in danger of being discovered. "What killed you?" the elf asked the dead body, "Judging by this entry, you died recently. You've even talked about him capturing a Felaryan naga. How can you be this far in decay?"

Of course, the skeleton couldn't open its mouth and tell the elf what he wanted to know, but the skeleton didn't have to. "Tell, me what happened to you," the elf said before placing his hand on the skull. The Felaryan elf had a gifted power that very few had. He was about to see the past of an object or a living thing by taping into his magic and touching the object of being. Well, it didn't work all the time, but he had to try. This situation depended on it. The elf tapped into his magic and focused on the date of the last entry, hoping he would see how the elf was killed.

Suddenly, night covered the sky and stars dotted the heavens. The elf saw a fire and saw an elf sitting by the fire writing in his journal. He knew this was the elf that was now dead, and elf named Melldor. The Felaryan elf walked over to Melldor and sat beside him. He stared at Melldor, hoping he would be seen, but The Felaryan knew that the magic didn't work that way. He touched Melldor's shoulder, but his hand phased through. The Felaryan elf sighed and listened to Melldor as he spoke a loud. "Lord William is becoming more dangerous. He's captured a Felaryan naga. I haven't seen the naga, it came in this afternoon, but I heard that it is a child. Still, Felaryan nagas could be considered the most dangerous creature around, even when it is a child. I don't know how Lord William plans to train that man eater, but whatever he wants with it, it can't be a good thing," Melldor said as he wrote the words quickly.

"I know the elves tend to stay within themselves and stay out of human affairs, but I'm sure that the elders will agree that Lord William is a dangerous individual and is gaining too much power. He's an evil and ruthless man. This could be trouble for the future of elves and humans. The elders have ordered assassinations of humans who they believed could become a danger of the balance of the world. Hell, they've done it to any sentient being who could gain the power to shape the world to their evil purposes. I'm afraid Lord William would someday become such a power and needs to be stopped before he can," Melldor said.

Melldor continued, "If that's bad enough, I fear that something worse is happening. I believe that Lord William is practicing black magic. I have very little proof, but there is something very wrong about this place. I can feel the presence of dark magic and-"

Suddenly, Melldor dropped his writing utensil and grabbed his heart. Melldor wheezed and screamed in pain. The Felaryan elf didn't understand what was happening. He tried to grab Melldor and help him, but again, his hands pasted through. he wanted to help, but he had no way of doing so. This was the past he was seeing and there was no way of changing it. Melldor stood up, but backed into a tree and slid down the trunk. His body began to deteriorate and his muscle and fat shrunk away leaving skin and bones. Melldor let out a final breath before a black mist escaped from him and left only bones.

The Felaryan elf knew this was dark magic a foot. It was a spell that drained beings of their life and magic to sustain someone else’s body, but Lord William wasn't even around. "He could have just taken the life and magic of anyone at random. The spell must have sensed Melldor and used him," the elf concluded.

Soon, he was back in the present. The Felaryan elf spent a lot of time digging a hole and burying Melldor with his bow and arrows. The Felaryan elf kept the sword and sheath and examined his sword and the sword of Melldor's. He read the words on both swords. The elven language on these swords doesn’t translate well in English, but the closest translation was this. On Melldor's sword it said "Blood Brothers" and on the Felaryan's sword, it finished, "always stand together".

Melldor was the Felaryan's brother. They had been through a lot together in Felarya and had somehow survived it. They had survived its giant predators and their lives as slaves to the giant race of elves in Felarya. They had made it to a world that was safer, but now he was alone and Melldor was dead. The Felaryan elf's name was Belgnir, and he vowed that he would find a way to avenge his brother's death.

Duncan, Jacob and Nahash left soon after and Felix was inside watching his mother work.

"Tell me Felix, do you think these colors work well together?" Sarah asked, putting a dark rose red against a brown. Felix stared for a moment.

"I don't know, it looks good to me, but I really have never considered fashion much in my life," Felix answered. Sarah put down the cloths.

"Felix, I know you were a slave before this, but I would like to know what sort of life you lived, if you don't mind talking about it," Sarah said softly. Felix said nothing for a moment.

"I don't mind," Felix said, closing his eyes and taking a deep breath. "I was a slave since I was five years old. I don't remember any of my life before then, but I do remember waking up in the castle, being told I was a slave." He paused for a moment. He was alone when he changed into the new clothes, so she didn't see it. Slowly he pulled up his shirt. A long thin mark was across his gut.

"Is that a scar from then?" Sarah asked. Felix nodded.

"It was the first one I remember receiving. I spilled some food I was ordered to carry. Even the kitchen staff were hard on us slaves," Felix said, "I was alone for many years, having to survive on my own."

"How did you and Nahash meet?" Sarah asked, moving close to her son.

"He was brought in and I was ordered to feed him. But I didn't try talking with him until my third day with this task," Felix answered, "I was too scared to try and approach him."

"What changed your mind?" Sarah asked gently.

"He kind of trapped me in with him," Felix answered, looking at the shock on Sarah's face. "He had just started his growth spurts. When I met him he was only like fifteen feet tall. Then he started to grow when I was feeding him and his tail blocked the door. I had to approach him to get him to move and I realized he wasn't a monster, just a scared boy."

"And you two became friends?" Sarah asked. Felix nodded.

"Yes. So for the next week, I would spend a few more minutes talking with him, comforting him and he came to see me as his big brother," Felix replied, "Then I caught a break, overhearing Lord William and his alchemist talking about Nahash' chains that grew with him. They were weakening and could weaken even more if I added an old batch of the potion to it." Felix took a breath and recanted the tale of following the alchemist and the subsequent escape into the mountains and finding their way out.

"It sounds like you two were very lucky and ran into little trouble," Sarah said. Felix shook his head.

"No, it wasn't," Felix replied, "The night after we escaped, I slept on Nahash. We had no idea he would grow to the height you saw him today. When I woke, I was a few feet from his mouth, feeling it was a good thing to eat me, to keep me safe." Sarah gasped in shock.

"What? How could he?" Sarah spoke quietly.

"Because of what his birth family taught him. I was able to break the view and he realized what he almost did. He dropped me on the ground and ran off. I froze for a moment before chasing after him, but he was going too fast. Come nightfall, I hadn't reached him. I fell asleep and this morning I ran into father," Felix finished. Sarah said nothing. She wrapped her arms around Felix and hugged him tightly.

Felix felt the hug come on. And he had been hugged by Nahash. But this hug was different from any time he was hugged by Nahash. Sarah's warmth was easing to him, his inner worries and fears seemed to go away. This motherly hug was the most wonderful thing he had ever experienced.

******

Meanwhile, in the woods, Nahash was following his father and uncle. He felt excited. He was never allowed to hunt with his family. He was too small and weak in Felarya. But here, he was stronger and could protect his family while they hunted and helped them hunt as well. And now his abilities helped find the deer they were hunting earlier.

Jacob was both in awe and unnerved at how quiet his "nephew" could move behind him. Something that large shouldn't have that ability, but yet Nahash did. He stopped when he saw Duncan stop and looked around. A young fawn was standing in the woods a distance away. Next to it was a large powerful buck. Jacob could count more then 10 points on its horns. He watched his brother draw an arrow and string it up. He loosed it and struck the buck in the neck. It fell soon and the fawn ran off.

Nahash watched his father kill the buck, and as the breeze was moving towards them from the deer, the buck's blood now filled the air. He looked where the fawn went to.

"May I hunt the young one?" Nahash asked.

"No," Jacob said sternly, "We do not hunt the young." He and Duncan moved to the deer carcass.

"Nahash, would this deer help sate your hunger until later?" Duncan asked, looking up at his son. Nahash nodded.

"Do you need remove its skin first?" Nahash asked, his eyes hopeful they would say no.

"Yes," Duncan said, "It won't take us long." Nahash held in his dislike and watched them work quickly. A few minutes passed and Nahash felt good with the deer in his gut. In his arms was the skin of the buck.

"Feeling better?" Duncan asked.

"Yes, I could do with another deer, though," Nahash replied. Jacob said nothing. The same buck could have fed a family of four for one whole day. To Nahash, it was a snack. And he was only going to get bigger.

"We'll see what we find," Duncan replied, "If you eat too much, the forest will suffer and we will have hard times for the village." Nahash nodded. He couldn't eat just for himself, but had to be weary of others now as well.

"I understand," Nahash said. The men nodded and moved further into the woods.

******

Choice 1: They come across a large creature Duncan would have never tried to kill if he was just with Jacob, will they try now?

Choice 2: They meet up with the Elf, Belgnir, once more.

1453222211221211111212122112212211221111.content:
As Duncan walked ahead, Jacob walked farther away from the back where Nahash was till he was beside his brother. "Brother, you saw how much Nahash ate, right? That was a very large deer that could feed a family for many meals. Yet, he ate it as if it were a snack," Jacob whispered.

Duncan didn't bother to turn his head and glace at Jacob's head which was very close to his ear. "Nahash didn't have breakfast. He just needs a bit more food. In the future, one deer may be able to sustain him a meal."

"You do realize how much deer he'll need even if that's true. I know that deer a numerous in this forest, but adding a large predator like a giant naga could easily and drastically change the situation. Besides, he's only five years old. What will happen when he grows bigger? Soon, he may need two or tree deer a meal!"

"I understand this situation seems very grim, but I can't bring myself to turn Nahash and Felix away. I know that it would be two if we were to throw Nahash out, because they wouldn't stand to be separated from each other. But throwing two children out and away from possible safety and making them leave to another forest to fend for themselves, doesn't seem right."

"I know it doesn't sound right. Believe me when I say I wouldn't want to do that either. Despite being a giant naga, Nahash seems to be a nice and gentle kid," Jacob informed.

Duncan was surprised by the fact that Jacob found it bad to throw out Nahash and that he had said that Nahash seemed to be a nice kid. Duncan couldn't believe these words came from his skeptical brother who had found it hard to trust strangers and from the same man that had began judging Nahash as a monster before even meeting him. Nahash's meeting with the town must have affected Jacob's view of the giant naga more than Duncan had realized.

Jacob was equally surprised by his own comment. He knew that there was good in Nahash and he knew that he was starting to like the giant naga. He also knew it would still take time to fully trust him, but he was really starting to like Nahash quicker than he would normally trust a potentially very dangerous stranger. Maybe there truly was a chance that he would eventually mean the word "nephew" when talking about Nahash.

"What are we going to do about his hunger?" Jacob asked.

"Maybe we'll be able to find larger prey. There are much larger animals in this forest that could be enough to supply Nahash with a healthy food source. There are creatures out there we are unable to bring down, even with most of the townspeople helping," Duncan suggested, "With Nahash's size, he could take down most creatures he'd come across in the forest, and when he gets bigger, he'd be able to handle absolutely anything lurking in the forest."

"He's large enough now that he could take down a giant boar. Plus one of the largest boars could last him more than a single meal," Jacob stated.

Nahash didn't like the fact that his new family was whispering, and the fact that Uncle Jacob walked farther ahead for speak with father meant that they were most likely talking about him. "They're talking about me, I know it." Nahash told himself, "But what are they talking about? Are they still unsure about me and still think I'm a monster? No, my new family wouldn't do that. They're human and I'm a naga, but they should know that if they love me, I'll love them. I won't harm my new family and never will. Maybe, they're upset that I eat too much.

Nahash's fear and concern for what his new family thought of him drove him to slither closer to quite maybe hear the conversation between his new dad and uncle. Nahash just wanted to be accepted by people again, even if the only people he had a chance of befriending were humans that were very small compared to him. Nahash didn't hear all of the words, but he could understand that it was an argument about how much he was eating. His naga body demanded a lot of food and the humans were worried he could tamper with the food supply of the forest. Tears formed in Nahash's eyes, because it was something he didn't think he could change about himself. "I'm sorry that I eat too much, but I can't help it," Nahash said.

Duncan and Jacob stopped and turned around to see Nahash had yet again approached them silently. Despite his size, he could really sneak up behind people efficiently. Duncan saw how sad Nahash and he knew that he'd have to be the one to comfort his new son. "Could you bend down closer, Nahash?" Duncan asked of his son. Nahash did as he was told. He backed up a bit and laid down flat with his arms crossed and his chin rested upon those arms. Duncan climbed up the arms and Nahash stayed as still as he could while he cried silently. Duncan placed his small hand, well, small to Nahash, on Nahash's cheek and rubbed it. Nahash could feel the hand and was comforted by such a simple touch. There was a lot of caring intentions in that small hand. "We don't blame you for being big. That is not your fault. I will do what I can to figure out a food source for you so that you can stay with us, because I don't want you to go. You and Felix are the first children that I've been blessed to take care of, and I don't want to fail as a father."

Nahash thanked Duncan and began to cheer up. Still standing on the crossed arms of his giant son, Duncan asked, "Now, are you able to eat fruits and not just meat?"

"Yes, but I haven't had any in a very long time, and many of the fruits I see here look different from the ones in my world," Nahash answered.

"We're going to look for larger creatures, but knowing that you can eat fruits will help in the future," Duncan replied.

"What will we hunt for now?" Nahash asked.

Duncan carefully climbed down to the ground before answering, "Giant boar."

"Really? I liked that meat!"

"You've killed one before?" Duncan asked.

"Yes. When Felix had set up camp after we escaped Lord William's castle and the caves, a giant boar attacked Felix, but I saved him and killed it before it could even harm him," Nahash answered with a sense of pride in his voice due to his accomplishments in protecting Felix.

"Good, killing one will be much easier now. I know where we might find one." Duncan led the way to a place he knew.

1453222211221211111212122112212211221111.content:
Nahash was happy as he followed his father and uncle. He was hopeful these boars would feed him even after he became a full adult naga. He grinned at the thought of helping his entire family through the woods as they sat on his shoulders. He shook his head and focused on the hunt a head.

Jacob and Duncan lead Nahash towards the river, upstream from where Nahash crossed before.

"The water is shallower and slower up here and the boars use it to bathe in and drink from," Duncan explained, "They also eat the shallow grasses." He didn't mention that it was also a natural crossing place for anything trying to cross the river, assuming the boars let the people across.

"But you need to be very careful. They have a powerful sense of smell and if we come from the wrong direction, they will either scatter or attack," Jacob added. "We lost a few foolish men who made that mistake."

"I don't think such a small animal could hurt me Uncle Jacob," Nahash answered.

"Yes, but if there are others with you, you should remember them as well," Jacob replied. Nahash bit his lip and agreed.

"So, are there parts of these boars you want as well?" Nahash asked

"Yes, the skin can be used to make leather and the bones make good weapons when ore is low," Duncan answered. He stopped suddenly. The area was almost completely quiet. He expected Nahash to be the cause, but then he heard loud grunts and squealling coming towards them. Nahash heard these noises as well and was unsure what to make of it. He saw his father and uncle looked confused before moving ahead very carefully.

The wind was blowing gently towards the hunting party. Scents from what lay ahead came to Nahash's nose. His eyes widened and his arms shot out quickly picking up both his uncle and father at the same moment as two large male tuskers came out of the bushes, fleeing past Nahash as quickly as they came.

The two hunters were shocked when they felt the large hands encompass them and lifted them from the hard earth. Their heads spun quickly but did hear the crashing of the boars as they came through the bushes. Both knew if it wasn't for Nahash's quick action, they would be dead.

Now they sat in Nahash's hands recovering from the experience.

"What would make boars flee like that and not even notice Nahash?" Jacob asked his brother.

"Something we should avoid," Duncan replied, "Maybe it's come out of the mountains for hunting." Jacob nodded in agreement.

"What came down?" Nahash asked. Duncan looked at his son.

"A powerful beast that thankfully has never attacked our village," Duncan responded, "It's called a hydra and it ..." But he realized Nahash was no longer looking at him, rather he was looking up and away. Duncan turned to see three serpent heads looking around and soon another pair was added to them. They stood tall and moved slowly. Before Duncan could tell Nahash to flee, the heads spotted the group. The hydra paused for only a second before charging at them. Nahash, fearful for his family turned and fled quickly.

"Great, how do we lose this thing?" Jacob asked as the hydra gave pursuit.

"I don't know," Duncan answered, looking up at Nahash's worried face. He watched as Nahash glanced over his shoulder to see the hydra. But what none saw was a branch from a tree was in Nahash' way, causing the boy to slam into the branch and the humans flew from his hands, landing on some bushing that cushioned their impact. But the delay was enough the hydra to catch up with them.

The hydra saw the large beast on the ground and moved quickly to stomp on it. Nahash cried out as the large, flat feet stamped into his chest. He tried striking it, but the skin was too tough and the punches were ineffective. Duncan and Jacob rolled off the bushes and looked at the scene before them. The hydra was covering all of Nahash's torso and part of his tail as it stood over the boy. The two hunters glanced at each other before grabbing their bows and got ready.

The hydra started snapping its minor heads at Nahash when arrows flew at its face. It paused to see the Jacob and Duncan firing arrows at him.

With the distraction at hand, Nahash swung his tail around the hydra, coiling around it only twice, but it would be enough. He started squeezing the hydra, making the hydra remember the other thing attacking it. It once more started biting into Nahash's flesh, as other heads bit the tail. But Nahash would not let go. The hydra screamed in pain as arrows landed in some of its eyes. Nahash glanced at his family helping him.

"Nahash, bash the middle head!" Duncan yelled to his son, "You kill that and it will die!" Nahash nodded and looked to the one head not attacking him. He pushed his hand through the defending head and grabbed the middle neck while squeezing tighter with his tail. He felt something give in the chest cavity and grinned as the beast roared in pain once more, focusing its heads on the tail. Nahash took this moment to pull the main head closer and slammed his skull into the hydra's, causing it to cry in pain as the minor heads froze in their actions. With the hydra stunned, Nahash looked to see a large rock and grabbed it, slamming that into the hydra's skull.

A crack like a clap of thunder ripped forth and the hydra collapsed. Blood spilled from the rock wound as Nahash uncoiled himself from the hydra and moved away. He clutched his chest as he moved.

"Are you all right Nahash?" Duncan asked, moving to his son. Nahash shook his head.

"My . . chest . . hurts, father," Nahash said, wincing with every breath.

"Lay down slowly," Duncan ordered. Nahash nodded and laid on his back. Duncan moved onto Nahash's body and looked were his bloodied hands lay. As he approached, he saw his son wince more with pain.

"What is it?" Jacob asked, staying on the ground.

"I think it hurt his ribs, but I don't know if they're broken or not," Duncan answered.

"Can you make the pain stop father?" Nahash asked. Duncan shook his head.

"No, I'm sorry son," Duncan answered, glancing at the dead hydra. Not even with the entire village would he have tried killing that monster. But Nahash had been able to kill it so quickly. He knew Nahash would be a good force protecting the village.

"Should I run back to the village and get the herbalist?" Jacob asked. Duncan nodded.

"Yes, and bring her back here quickly," Duncan agreed, "But don't say what Nahash has done to everyone. I think this should be a prize he brings in himself." He knew Ben might argue to try and kill Nahash in his weakened state or maybe sell him back to Lord William.

"I'll be back as soon as I can," Jacob said, running off to the town. Duncan looked at his son's face as he held back tears of pain.

"You did really well this hunt Nahash," Duncan commended, "You did what no one else in our village could."

"Thank you . .. father," Nahash said, smiling and wincing at the same time.

1453222211221211111212122112212211221111.content:
Belgnir was in the process of leaving the forest to find an open field of meadow. He had to give the Elders the message. He had tell them what Lord William has been planning, that Lord William has be toying with dark magic, and he had to tell them of his brother's death. However, Belgnir didn't trust putting all of it in a letter. There were no elves or "friends" of the elves in the area. Belgnir couldn't trust them with such a letter to bring to the Elders. He also didn't want to spend more time traveling the Elven Domain and then travel all the way back here. Belgnir had already decided that he needed to send his message through the wind. It was a magical gift the elves possessed. They could use magical winds to send out a message only elves could hear, but that ability worked best in open planes otherwise the message might not come out clear. This was why he was heading out of the forest.

Suddenly, a terrifying shriek pierced his sensitive like a needle digging at it from the inside. Belgnir stopped and winced at the sound that tormented hi. Luckily for him, the creature seemed to be a good distance away, but not far enough if it harmed his ears to that extent. When the sound seized, Belgnir turned in the direction of wince it came. Belgnir knew that sound. It was a hydra. Back in Felarya, he had heard creatures called negative hydras. These creatures were extremely rare and lived in deep and forgotten negative planes. Those creatures sent in avatars to different points of the universe to get its food, because it never leaves the negative plane.

However, the hydras of this world were much different from negative hydras. The hydras of this world weren't avatars, but a different species of hydra. They were large creatures, but not as big of creatures as the Felaryan top predators. So for Belgnir, killing a hydra by himself wasn't an outlandishly impossible thing, since he had killed adult nagas and such. The only hard part about hydras of this world was that one had to kill the main head to truly kill it and the shriek the hydras emitted could do serious damage to elves and other creatures with heightened hearing. Belgnir had even heard stories of elves' heads exploding from shrieks of a hydra. For other beings with normal hearing, the shriek had the potential of putting them into shock if they didn't have a strong enough will.

Belgnir contemplated on what to do. A hydra living in this forest was a dangerous. If he had to stay in the forest until the Elders replied back, a hydra would make this difficult and would have to be dealt with as soon as possible. Belgnir had enough strength still to deal with the hydra now, and he deemed it best to take care of it at that moment while he knew where it was. Belgnir hurried in the direction of the shriek but his footfalls were light and silent as an elf's steps should be.

As Belgnir closed the distance between himself and where he had heard the shriek, he began hearing something else. It sounded like something was making a lot of noise, almost like two very large beasts were fighting. "It sounds like the hydra is fighting something large. But what could be large enough in this forest to fight a hydra...? Of course, the Felaryan naga, Nahash was his name. He must be fighting the hydra, unless there is another large beast that could take on a hydra."

Belgnir quickened his pace more. "If Nahash is fighting a hydra, he might need help. The Felaryan naga might be large and one of the largest species of naga, but it's still a child and could have troubles fighting a hydra." Belgnir growled. "I can't believe I'm helping a Felaryan top Predator, and a naga of all creatures, but this naga really seems to want to change. It's hard to believe, but this naga might actually become a force of good. Such a power could come in handy, and it might actually be best for the naga to stay alive, for now. I know that the Elders might want this naga to be watched to make sure it doesn't become a danger, and make sure this naga truly sees humans as people when it's being raised by them."

Just as Belgnir began crossing the river at a shallow point and before he reached the battle raging in the distance, the battle seemed to stop. Only silence could be heard in the distance. "Did the naga fail?" Belgnir couldn't believe his own thoughts; he was actually slightly worried for the well being of a Felaryan naga. Then again, this naga was only five years old and saw humans as people, for the moment.

Belgnir drew both the blades. His own blade was in his left hand and his brother's was in his right. Belgnir was ready to fight a hydra to the death and would gladly do it with the two swords acting as one. Belgnir came upon the place where the battle of two giants had been fought. There he discovered a dead hydra lying on the ground. The hydra's main head was cracked open and leaking blood. A large bloody boulder about the size of the hydra's head was settled beside it. Belgnir's eyes soon spotted the second giant and it was indeed Nahash the Felaryan naga. Nahash was lying down on his back with Duncan positioned on top of the naga's shoulder. There were bit marks along Nahash's tail as well as some marks on his human half. There were fewer wounds on Nahash's human half, but they seemed more serious since that skin wasn't as tough as the tail. However, no vital parts seemed to be bitten. The naga looked like it could still pull through.

Belgnir looked back at the hydra. The hydra was an adult male and one of the large ones. The beast was much bigger than Nahash's human half but wasn't as long as Nahash if Nahash's tail were to be included in the length. The hydra of that size should have overpowered the naga, but Nahash still seemed to have managed and defeated it. "This is unbelievable. If Nahash can kill a hydra as his age, he's sure to be a very powerful force as an adult. I can only hope that's a good thing."

"You did really well this hunt Nahash," Duncan commended, "You did what no one else in our village could."

"Thank you...Father," Nahash said, smiling and wincing at the same time.

Belgnir was very surprised to hear the naga call the human hunter "father". It had to have been a great surprise for the Felaryan elf that showed little emotion to widen his eyes slightly and paused for even just a moment. However, he did speak up, "Actually it's quite a feat for him to kill a hydra. Even if he is a Felaryan, something of his age with a slight height disadvantage against a hydra should have not survived against a hydra. That was quite a feat indeed."

Duncan, still kneeling on the horizontal plane Nahash's shoulder made while he was lying on his back, looked in the direction of the voice and found that it came from the elf from before. Nahash turned his head as well. "You?" Duncan said mostly out of confusion for the sudden appearance, "Did you find what you were looking for?"

"I have. Then I heard the shriek of this hydra and the battle. I came to investigate," Belgnir answered. Belgnir notice Nahash wincing every time he breathed. "Is he hurt?" he asked Duncan.

"Yes, but I'm sure whether some of his ribs are broken or not."

"May I look at the area?" Belgnir this time addressed his question to Nahash, "I may not have healing powers, but I will still be able to tell whether they're broken or not."

"Yes," said Nahash

"Is it a particular side that hurts more of both sides?"

"My right." Nahash didn't want to say too much. More talking meant he'd have to breath sooner and breathing in hurt.

Belgnir approached Nahash's right side. "Could you pick my up with your palm and position me close to where it hurts the most? I may still have to touch the spot, but I don't want to stand on it if it's really broken," Belgnir requested.

Nahash answered by turning his right hand palm up. Belgnir stepped onto the blood covered hand and Nahash lifted him to the spot. Belgnir examined the spot and would discover that...

"You have some strong bones, Nahash," Belgnir said after a few moments, jumping up to the shoulder, so he wouldn't walk over the hurt area. This close to the chest, he could see the impressions the hydra's feet made. "But none are broken." Nahash smiled.

"That's good," Nahash said, wincing.

"Thank you," Duncan said, looking at the stoic face of the elf. "I imagine it will take a week or so for his chest to heal." He glanced at the large dead hydra. "At least he'll have enough food to sustain him."

"It might be quicker, if he doesn't move too much and just rests," Belgnir noted, "Nagas have strong healing rates." Duncan nodded, absorbing this information.

Jacob raced through the woods. He smiled as he reached the village once more. He quietly moved across the outside, not wanting to be found. Eventually he came to a large garden owned by the town herbalist. It was a father and daughter duo: Andrew and Bethany. They had moved to the village some years ago and were quickly accepted into the town.

"I hope they know how to mend bones on such a large being," Jacob thought as he moved to the small cottage that doubled as an office and home for them. He felt his face flush a little as he moved to the door. He always did when getting close to Bethany. Though she was a few years older than him, he still cared for her deeply and just wished he had the courage to tell her directly. He reached the door and knocked.

A moment passed and the door opened. An wrinkled face with a long gray beard and long gray hair looked out. "Ah Jacob, what may I do for you?" Andrew asked, moving aside, to let the hunter in. The old man was accustomed to treating hunters who hurt them selves while in the woods. Jacob walked into the room and heard the door shut behind him.

"Your knee hurt again?" came a soft voice from another room. Bethany walked out. Her black hair fell flat and strait, so she had it tied into a braid, reaching her waist. Her soft pale skin and blue eyes contrasted her hair perfectly. She wore a dress Sarah made that complimented her body perfectly.

"No, my nephew is hurt," Jacob answered. Both herbalists stopped in their motions.

"The small one or large one?" Andrew asked.

"Nahash," Jacob answered, before explaining the ordeal with the hydra. Neither healer said anything until Jacob was finished.

"All right, first sit down," Andrew ordered.

"But .. . " Jacob replied.

"No buts," Bethany said, taking Jacob by the arm. "By your own story, you were flung from a fast moving ride from a lot higher than a horse's back. We need to make sure you are unharmed." Jacob learned long ago not to argue with Bethany about her craft. So he sat down and felt Bethany start rubbing his head and asking if it hurt or not.

It was a quick exam and both ruled he was well, feeling he was damn lucky the bush broke the fall, otherwise he would probably be dead.

"Now, as for your nephew, if the bones are broken, there might not be much we can do," Andrew stated. "We do have some powerful pain killers used for knocking out horses, so that might help him move, but that's only if it was just a bruising and nothing more." Jacob nodded.

"I would like to go with you when you take the medicine," Bethany added, "I will be able to tell if it was a break or not." She moved away to get her bag, considering the conversation over.

"Thank you, for this and not fearing him," Jacob said rising up.

"Your father let us in with little issue fifteen years ago, my boy," Andrew replied, "You and your brother inherited his kindness there. So we trust you when you say Nahash is not dangerous. Well, to the people of this town anyway." Jacob smiled as Bethany returned and led Jacob to the stables. She got onto her horse and pulled Jacob on behind her.

"Which way?" she asked, taking her horse out into the open air.

"To the crossing of the stream," Jacob replied. Bethany nodded, knowing the water grass there made a good plant to use on upset stomachs. She pressed her horse's side and it started to gallop into the woods.

*****


Belgnir thought, as he moved, on the hunter's words. Considering the stance he took, protecting the slave and naga from his Lord's soldiers and the talk of "trees", it was clear he would welcome a new Lord. He would need to add this into the message and make the Elders. Maybe they could use the help of the humans of the village for the assault on the castle.

"And how close Nahash has come to his new family will also be needed to know," he thought, shaking his head in disbelief. If he had not heard the words himself, he would have called someone mad for thinking a naga could see a human as a parent. But he did and he hoped it would not change.

*******


Duncan watched as Nahash's massive chest rose and fell with his breaths. Nahash had learned by now slow breaths helped ease the pain.

"Nahash, how large will you become?" Duncan asked.

"I don't know father," Nahash answered, "Maybe only thirty more feet or possibly a hundred, if I end up like my father's father. He was really really big." Nahash paused as memories of his old life came back and tears filled his eyes. He pushed back the pain, remembering why they would never accept his brother and would kill his new parents.


"Nahash, I'm sorry for bringing up your old family," Duncan said. "I was just thinking of what you would look like as an adult." Nahash nodded.

"It's all right father," Nahash replied, as the sound of horse feet came towards them. Duncan stood up, preparing his bow in case it was an unfriendly encounter.

Jacob and Bethany appeared in view, waving at Duncan. Nahash glanced and was happy to see his uncle back. The horse did not move closer than ten feet to Nahash, so the pair dismounted and moved closer.

"We had a visit from the Elf from before," Duncan commented, "He said Nahash's ribs were not broken, only sprained."

"And you trust this Elf?" Bethany asked as Nahash opened his hand for them to stand on. He gently lifted them to his chest.

"I do in this matter," Duncan replied. Bethany said nothing in response, instead moved to where the bruising was starting to show. After a minute, she nodded.

"Well, he was accurate," Bethany said, "No breaks." She pulled from her bag, large balls of herbs. She turned to Nahash.

"Hello. I'm Bethany. These balls should stop the pain in your chest for a short time," she explained, "Open your mouth please." Nahash nodded and opened his large mouth. Bethany moved in and tossed the two balls in. Nahash swallowed.

"How long will they take?" Duncan asked.

"A few minutes, if they're effective," Bethany answered.

14533.content:
Sphinx- Sphinxes are a proud and regal race with the head and torso of a human fused with the lower body of a lion. With their great feathered wings on their backs, they are truly awe-inspiring. They often have long hair and passionate, fiery eyes.

Sphinxes can be surprisingly emotional, and are known to quickly switch from from mood to another. In spite of this, they are intelligent and think very logically, albeit rather rigidly. They tend to see themselves as superior to everyone else, and can be quite self-righteous at times. They are often used as symbols for justice because Sphinxes seem to hold that particular value strongly. They often act as a self-appointed judge, jury, and executioner, in matters that they see fit to preside over. Sphinxes are prone to defend causes with great passion, which can sometimes lead them to being fanatical about it. They are very prideful, and a sure fire way to commit suicide would be to insult one of them or their ideals.

Sphinxes of Felarya come in a range of sizes from 8 feet (head to ground) to 100 feet or more. They often have golden fur, hair, and eyes, and walk with a self confident swagger. They are skilled warriors and many make a living guarding places, people, and things that they feel is worthy of their protection.

In spite of their size, larger specimens are not as voracious as one would expect. Most sphinxes like hunting alone and will, if possible, get their prey from a group rather than cornering a single victim, as they feel it is more of a fair contest if the prey is allowed to counter their physical weakness with larger numbers. They also strongly despise sneak attacks and will always openly announce themselves before engaging an enemy.

Sphinxes store food they eat first in their human stomach, but once it becomes full, the contents are transferred to a second stomach, much larger, situated in their feline part. Sphinxes are dangerous on both the ground and in air, and some of them master a powerful healing and protective magic. They tend to live near mountain ranges and open fields, where they can make good use of their great, majestic wings.
