15231.content:
Felix closed his eyes. he had a feeling that the amarok was only sniffing him, because it was wondering what he was and judging whether he was edible or not. He had no doubt in his mind that once the amarok was done sniffing him, it would eat him. What else would such a creature do with humans. It was a giant wolf that more than likely eats humans. It is a mind-less beast that just so happens to be a carnivore after all. With it being just a cub, it might even be worse. Cubs know little about the world and this creature probably would only see Felix as a tasty treat and nothing more. Felix felt as though he was doomed and nothing could save him.

Suddenly, Felix felt something large and wet drag across his chest and face. The object felt strange to Felix due to its largeness, but Felix knew that it was the amarok's tongue. The amarok was surely tasting him and continuing to judge whether it should eat Felix or not. The tongue continued to lick Felix and when the tongue began to lick more rapidly, Felix thought that the amarok had grown fond of Felix's taste. "This it is," Felix thought to himself, "The amarok likes my taste now. It's not going to give me up. I'm going to be eaten and there's nothing I can do about it." Felix closed his eyes tighter. Felix shook with fear and a few tears were beginning to fall down. The tongue stopped its constant barrage of licks. Felix tensed up, knowing it was the end for him. However, that's not exactly what happened.

Before the jaws of the wolf could clamp down on him, Felix heard a high pitched whimper. Felix opened his eyes and could only see the massive pup's head filling his view. This startled Felix and he dragged himself backward a little. The pup didn't try to stop him, like Felix thought would happen. Instead, the pup let out another whine. Felix stared at the amarok pup, and was very confused. He examined the amarok's face and sure enough, it actually looked sad, completely with the irresistible puppy dog eyes. "The amarok is sad? But why is it sad?" Felix wondered, "What does it want from me? I thought it was going to eat me."

Felix just continued to stare at the large infant amarok who continued to whine and give Felix the sad puppy dog face. "It shouldn't be sad. I has me as a meal. Sure it's just been captured and it's far from its home most likely, but it's just an animal. Could it really understand such things?" Felix wondered.

The amarok took a step towards Felix and Felix had to take a few crawls back to cover the same distance covered by the amarok's leg to keep the same distance from the infant that there was before the amarok took a step. The amarok whimpered in response. Staring into the amarok's eyes, Felix saw desperation and sadness. "Why has it become sadder when I backed away from it? It must want something else from me other than use me for its meal. If it simply wanted to eat me, it would just eat me and not become saddened about me backing away. What the hell does it want?" Felix questioned

Felix decided to think about all the facts to try and think of a conclusion. "This amarok is an infant and William's soldiers have taken this amarok against its will to use as a weapon. The amarok is probably far away from is family and also homesick as well. Maybe even animals can feel that way. And infants need love and care from their family, especially the animals that care for their young. I'm sure the soldiers didn't treat the amarok too well," Felix thought.

Then it suddenly hit him. "Could the amarok want comfort from me?" Felix wondered, "That would explain why it's sadder when I back away and when I'm afraid of it, but why would an animal want comfort from something that's a different species and prey sized? Is it just because its an infant and desperate? If this is all true, then maybe I can make it out of this alive. Felix was in shock. He couldn't believe he was actually touching an amarok and it was allowing him to do so. Sure the amarok was an infant and adult amaroks were larger and more intimidating, the infant was still the largest creature Felix had ever seen. Felix noticed that the amarok looked as though it might back away. So Felix snapped out of his shock and began stroking the fur on the amarok's muzzle. It was clear the amarok liked this as its tail wagged , like a domestic dog. However, this was not domesticated dog. It was a wild animal, a wolf, and Felix still needed to be careful.

"If you like this, I think I know something else you love," Felix said as he pushed away from the amarok's head and walked to the amarok's side. The amarok whined and looked at Felix with confusion. "Relax, I'm not leaving," Felix tried assuring the amarok, but he didn't know if it could understand him. If he were to guess, he would guess that it didn't. Felix crouched down and put his hand under the amarok and started scratching its underbelly. The giant wolf pup's tail wagged faster than Felix had ever seen and looked like a blur. The amarok turned on its side for Felix and Felix was able to scratch more of the underbelly. The underbelly's fur was the same black as the rest of the amarok, but much softer. The only white fur the wolf had was a small tuft of white fur on the chest area. Felix looked at the amarok's head and saw its muzzle opened and it tongue sticking out with pleasure. Inari paused before she continued on any further. "It was because I let them, I'm searching for someone within these walls." Inari said as she went back to roasting the meat from the carts. For some reason she felt like she could trust this human. Which reminded her... "You never introduced yourself." Inari said suddenly, looking pointedly at Felix. Her two tails had began to wave about behind her as well. It wasn't like she couldn't find out herself, she just wanted to know who it was that would be her talking companion for the next few days, or weeks, depending on how fast she found the person it was that she was searching for.

Felix was a bit stunned from her earlier statement. "She let herself be caught? Just to search for someone? Why would she do that?" Felix thought to himself before Inari pretty much demanded a name. Felix shook his head to clear it. "S-sorry. Me name is Felix." Felix said, introducing himself to Inari. Felix was inwardly glad that Inari wasn't some mindless beast like what Lord William made them out to be. Although that begged the question, who exactly was it that she was searching for? "Um...you said you were searching for someone...who were you searching for?" Felix asked Inari curiously.

Inari knew what it was that Felix was thinking. It was kind of obvious from the reaction he had on his face after she said what it was that she did. But she refrained from answering his unspoken question as the boy introduced himself to her. His name was Felix. "Felix...that's a nice name." Inari said, pausing after she had said his name before she committed it to memory. Then Felix got the look like he was about to ask a question, and she payed full attention to him. His question turned out to be who it was that she was searching for. Inari thought about it. She wondered if she should tell Felix the answer. Even if she did feel like she could trust him, if she told him, it would probably put him in danger if he let it slip. "I don't know if I should tell you Felix. I mean, if I do, it might put you in danger. I need to know if you can keep your mouth shut, and not say anything about it accidentally." Inari said, the worry in her voice apparent. She was worried, but not about telling Felix oddly enough, she was worried for Felix himself. Odd that, as she had only just met the young boy.

Felix looked at Inari as she said his name. A strange feeling came over him when she said it as well. He couldn't quite understand it either, and before he could even begin to, Inari was already answering his question. So, the person she was looking for was either extremely dangerous, or extremely important...if not both. "You don't have to worry Inari. I know how to keep my mouth shut...I never talk to anyone anyways." Felix said, a little bit of sadness in his voice as he did so as well. In a sense, he was alone. All the other slaves were long since broken, their spirit gone, so Felix couldn't really talk to anyone about his dreams of freedom. All that would do would be to get him lashings, as a slave who told Lord William about anyone hoping to escape got whipped, and the slave an extra scrap of food.

Inari looked at Felix as he talked, and his assurance lifted the doubt that she had in her. However, she also heard the sadness in his voice when he said he didn't talk to anyone. This, more than anything, caused Inari to suddenly bring Felix into a hug, shocking him at the gesture. Not once had he been hugged by anyone, and he couldn't remember anything from his before five years ago. "Well, you have me to talk to now." Inari said before she released him and smiled at him. "The person I am trying to find..."

153111.content:
Inari looked around before she bent towards Felix and whispered in his ear. "The person I am trying to find is extremely important. I was sent here by an elder kitsune, one with the power to foretell the multiple paths of the ever changing future. She told me that within these walls, lay someone that will one day be able to overthrow the tyrant trying to chop down our forest." Inari said in a hushed voice, and Felix had a dim awareness that Lord William was also attempting to chop down a forest, but some type of mystic energy was scaring the soldiers away. 'Could it be kitsune magic?' Felix thought to himself, but pulled himself out of his thoughts to listen to Inari. "The only problem with this person is that the elder kitsune couldn't see who it was. I have no idea if it is male or female, young or old, slave or free. The only thing I DO know is that I am supposed to guard this person with my life, and bring them back to the elder kitsune, or if that is impossible, try to get into contact with another kitsune." Inari said, and Felix nodded his head. So, essentially, she was searching for any number of people in this building. "I doubt you can search as you are. Why don't I help you out? No one suspects a slave, and I have to go about this castle to do my duties." Felix offered, and Inari smiled at Felix. "I was hoping you would do that. It's great to know that there are still nice humans out here." Inari said as she scooted back and transformed back to her original, rather large form. "I'm done eating for now. Thanks for not running away Felix." Inari said in his head, and he smiled sheepishly at her. "You didn't really give me a chance you know." Felix said as he pointed to the wall of fire behind him. "Oh!...Uh...sorry?" Inari said, and Felix could just imagine a sheepish expression on her face. With a quick wave with one of her tail, the fire vanished, and Felix was free to go. "I'll be coming back around night time with dinner, so we can talk more then." Felix said to Inari as he started to push the cart out of the room. As soon as he walked out of the door with the cart, the guards just looked at him. "Well I'll be, looks like you didn't become lunch for the beast!" One of the guards said, and Felix just kept quite. He already knew that they had made a bet, and this was confirmed when a few coins exchanged hands, and Felix just pushed the cart back to where it belonged before he hurried off to continue with the rest of his duties.


Meanwhile, Inari was sitting in the cell, thinking about Felix, and wondering if he was the one she was supposed to guard. It would be great if that were true, but she would need to have proof before she jumped to the conclusion. Just because he was nice didn't mean that he was the one she was searching for. She was certain that she could handle anything these dumb humans could throw at her, but she would like it if she were able to complete her mission soon. Maybe she could also bring Felix with her when she and the person she was searching for escaped from this place.

154.content:
"The creature we have captured is a basilisk," Lord William explained.

"A b-b-basilisk?" Felix questioned nervously and frightened.

"Basilisks are powerful creatures that can turn people to stone and they have powerful venom in their fangs. Think of everything I could accomplish with such a powerful beast once I control it," Lord William replied.

"How are you going to control it?" Felix questioned.

"The same way I keep all you slaves in line. Soon it will know that I'm its master and it will obey me or it will suffer a terrible pain each time it disobeys," Lord William informed the slave.

"Won't that just make it mad at you? Don't you think it will want to kill you if it ever got out and realized you were causing its pain?" Felix questioned.

Lord William looked down at the boy and said, "Is it you're job to question my actions?" Lord William asked.

"No, but..." Felix began to argue, but when he saw the Lord's hand raise, Felix shut up.

"You are to feed and clean up after the basilisk," Lord William ordered, "It will need feeding today, and once the chains are set up, you are to come down here with food and water and feed it."

Before Felix could say anything else, the Lord left the prison chambers.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- ------------------------------------------

Felix came back down to the prison chambers. Felix was carrying a large bowl of water and one of the guards helped him with the deer. The guard helping him with the deer was Henry and he was one of the few guard fair and nice to the slaves. Felix was glad that Henry would be one of the guards guarding the basilisk.

As soon as they were down, Henry nodded to the other guard and the other guard began to fiddle with the locks. Henry saw Felix was shaking, but luckily none of the water was splashing out. "Felix, it will be alright. There is a chain wrapped around its neck. It will only be able to reach the light. As long as you don't pass out of the lite area, the snake won't be able to harm you," Henry tried to assure Felix.

"What about the eyes? It could turn me into stone," Felix argued.

"The eyes have been blindfolded. It can't turn you to stone," Henry informed Felix. The door was opened and Felix entered. Felix set the bowl on the ground and Henry handed the deer while saying, "If you need help, all you need to do is scream for it." With that, Henry closed the door and Felix turned around with the deer.

The cell room was large, but it was hard to tell because the torches on the other side weren't lite, this was probably because they didn't want to go near the torches that were in the basilisk's reach. There was a barred opening at the top of the cell at least a hundred feet up which shined a light from the outside that created a circle in the middle of the cell. Felix walked to the circle with the deer and set it on the ground.

Felix then left to get the water and when he turned to walk back to the circle, the basilisk's head was in the light. The head was far larger than Felix's body and it had the combined looks of a dragon and snake. The mouth was large and was probably full of razor sharp teeth, in actuality, it only had the two fangs. The snake head was on the ground and it was about the same height as Felix when it was on the ground. The basilisks eyes were blindfolded with a large red cloth.

Felix suddenly became very fearful of the basilisk and didn't move for the longest time. The basilisk kept darting its tongue out and it seemed to know exactly where Felix was. Felix didn't know it, but the basilisk were getting Felix's scent from the air when it darted its tongue out. Instead of that truth, Felix thought the basilisk wanted to eat and taste Felix.

"It has the deer right next to it. Why does it want me?" Felix wondered, "Maybe it enjoys human flesh more than deer." Felix shivered at the thought of dying slowly and painfully in the stomach of an over sized snake.

Felix began walking to the basilisk and he kept muttering to himself, "It's alright Felix, as long as you keep out of range, it can't eat you."

Felix held out the bowl in front of him and the snake's tongue hit the water first and the tongue began to lap up some of the water. Felix was a little relieved, because it seemed like it only wanted the water. Then as he started setting it down, the tongue darted out of the bowl and ran across his arm. Fear came over him and stood very still with his eyes closed. He thought the snake would wrap its tongue around him and bring him in, but the snake only licked him a few times and then went back to the water.

Felix set the bowl on the ground and the snake seemed to loose interest. The snake went to the deer and began licking the deer. During that time, Felix noticed the chains around the basilisk's neck were rusty. The chains could break off with the right amount of force. Felix thought about telling the guards, but all that was forgotten when the basilisk opened its mouth and sent two fangs into the deer before dragging into into the shadows. Felix freaked and ran to the door and pounded on it.

The guards opened the door and Felix ran out of it and the prison chambers. "Felix, what happened?" Henry asked worriedly, but Felix kept going.

"Stupid kid, scared of a baby basilisk whose chained up and blindfolded," the other guard commented.

"That basilisk may only be slightly older than a toddler, but it is bigger than any of us, Jensen," Henry commented, "I'd be scared if I was his age as well."

"Lucky for him he doesn't have to feed the thing every day," Jensen said.

"The basilisk like most other snakes digest their food slowly to only gain the energy when needed. They only need to feed about twice a week, but since this basilisk is just going to be lying around the whole time, it might only need to be fed once a week," Henry told Jensen, "However, that water needs to filled more often than that."

Felix never told them about the rusted chains and Felix forgot about it because of the basilisk eating the deer scared him. The basilisk had enough to strength to break the chains. It was only a matter of time when it would happen.

Felix backed away, hoping the basilisk would eat the deer like it usually did, but the basilisk slithered past the deer and towards Felix with its tongue darting in and out.

Felix quickly ran to the door, but the basilisk slithered past him and blocked the door with its tail. Felix thought about calling for help, but the fact that he was scared out of his mind and the fact that if the door opened the guards would have to climb over the snake's tail made it hard for Felix to scream out for help. 15422.content:
"Hmm, Felix still hasn't left the basilisk's cell yet...Maybe I'd better check up, in case something happened."

Henry grabbed hold of the keys on the side and began removing the locks on the door. After removing the final lock, he opened the door and saw the basilisk wrapped around Felix's body, well outside from the chains' limit.

"H...H-help..." Felix said, tears streaming down his face.

"Felix!" Henry whispered urgently.

Looking around, Henry saw no one else nearby. So he carefully entered the cell and climbed on top of the basilisk's body. The creature twitched slightly, but seemingly fell back to sleep. Henry worked his way until he was right next to Felix.

"Felix, don't cry. I'm here now, don't worry. Just listen very carefully, and do what I say."

Felix nods his head as Henry helps him out of the basilisk's grasp. It took several minutes to squirm out of the coils, but Felix manages to be set free as the two exit the cell. Henry reinserts the locks to the door as he faces the boy, sitting on the floor, crying.

"Felix, are you alright? You're unharmed, aren't you? What happened?"

"Y-yes...I'll be alright. Just, shaken is all... T-the chain was rusty, and...It broke."

"Felix, why don't you go back to the slaves' quarters. Get some rest, and I'll report about the broken chain to Lord William tomorrow."

Felix nodded as he ran as far away as he could to the slaves' quarters. Henry just looked back at the basilisk's cell. It was coiled around Felix, but didn't harm him in any way. It was intriguing for him, but he knew better than to question anything at the moment. It was not his place to question the basilisk's intentions, or its odd behavior. But if he had to guess, then it may have taken a liking for Felix. Henry chuckled at the thought as he resumed his watch.
-----
It was on the next day when they attached a new chain on the basilisk infant. Felix would still get very frightened when he saw the snake-like head move into the light. But then again, nothing bad happened the last time. Hopefully, nothing bad will ever happen to him. Felix refilled the bowl of water as he looked back at the basilisk. It was reaching out until the chain tugged it's head back, preventing the creature from moving any further. It began lapping up the water, then tried to move towards Felix. Felix was still scared though, but the sound of the chains did make him feel better. He quickly got out of the cell as fast as he could.

In the following weeks, it became routine for Felix to feed the basilisk, along with the other chores he had to do. Work, work, feed the creature, work, rest, torture, work, sleep. But the more time he spent with the basilisk, the more he began to feel less fear, and more sorry for the creature. This caused him to think back to when he was first 'captured' by it.

"It just nuzzled its head to me...Even though it licked me, it didn't eat me...Was it...Was it really just trying to show affection?"

Felix sat up on his bed, which was nothing more than a dirty blanket on the cold stone floor of his room. The idea of the basilisk showing affection kept bothering him, refusing to leave his mind. Maybe tomorrow, he could try and find out more about the basilisk himself.
-----
As Felix entered the cell, he refilled the water as usual. He waited as the basilisk emerged from the dark and lapped up the water. Felix gulped, thinking he has finally lost his sanity for doing this. He walked closer to the basilisk. The creature darted its tongue in the air, sensing Felix walk up closer to it. Felix walked up to the side of its head and gently placed a hand on it. The basilisk flinched at first, but seemed to calm down as it didn't feel any pain from Felix's touch.

"You must have been hurt badly, haven't you?" Felix said.

He gently rubbed the basilisk's head as it laid down on the ground.

"I bet you must be really lonely in here. And scared. Is that...Is that why you tried to get closer to me?" Felix asked.

There was no response as the basilisk stayed still on the ground. Felix continued to rub the creature's head, feeling some kind of comfort being able to talk to someone. He looks up at the basilisk.

"Well, I'm a little lonely too. That Lord William is no real Lord, but a tyrant. He's tortured us, trying to make us his slaves. But at least we have Henry. He'd never hurt us. He understands us, unlike most of the other soldiers in this place..."

Felix began to feel stupid, talking to the giant creature. He turned to walk back out the door. The tugging of the chains caught his attention, and he faced the basilisk again. But what he saw clearly surprised him. The red cloth the blinded the basilisk was wet...And tears were streaming down the side! Felix just stood there, watching the giant basilisk cry in front of him. Felix looked back at the cell door. He was happy that Henry was on guard again today. He could perhaps share this to him. But he looked at the crying snake on the other side. He was just as miserable as he was, until he came into his life. Should he just leave him all alone again? But then again, maybe Henry could share some insight on this...

“The creature that has been caught is a Naga.” The Lord replied. He straightened his back as he spoke, proud of the capture. Lord William continued, “You are to make sure that this creature survives its time whilst it is being trained.”

“Master, may I ask as to what a Naga is?” Felix chose his words carefully as he watched the Lord keeping his eye on the cell that the shrieking Naga lay within. Lord William smiled at Felix’s lack of knowledge. It made him look all the better.

“A Naga is a creature that has the body of a snake from the waist down. Basically, it has a snake’s tail. From the waist upwards, it has the body of a human but with the head of a snake as well. It is completely covered in scales that act as an armour.” Lord William looked down at Felix from the corner of his eye. “I hope you understand what that means towards the difficulty of this beast’s capture.”

“Perfectly well, Master.” Felix replied, inclining his head slightly.

“Good. Now as I said slave, you are to bring the Naga both food and water to ensure its survival. The cook has been informed and you are to take any leftover or stale meat that has been given the go ahead. This creature will learn that it will not get much decent food until it starts to show signs of progress.” The Lord explained. “Three times a day, you will fill up the cart with food and water from the kitchens and bring it to the Naga. If you neglect or forget, the Naga will be given yours. Understand?”

Felix nodded his head once in response. “How long do I have to perform each trip, Master?” Felix questioned.

“I don’t care how long it takes you ,slave!” Lord William spat, “Just as long as you get all your other tasks completed before you retire to the slave’s quarters. The Naga could have torn your arm and leg off, for all I care.” Felix shuddered at the thought. “Otherwise, it’s ten lashes for every task that you haven’t completed past midnight. If you are tired, you will carry on and won’t get to rest until you complete all your tasks.”

“I understand, Master.” Felix nearly whispered.

Lord William turned and glared at Felix, who could not look away even if he tried. Lord William approached Felix and bent over to stare him in the eyes. Felix froze as all he could see was the darkness that was Lord William. The Lord lowered his voice to a more menacing growl. “Remember this, slave. If the Naga dies whilst it is being trained, whether it is your fault or not, you will die along with it. If you are killed whilst looking after the Naga, you can be replaced. The Naga’s life is worth more to me than your existence.” Lord William straightened back up and turned on his heel before marching out of the chambers.

Felix watched as the hated Lord made his way out. The chains from the cell were rattling as screams of pain could be heard from both man and creature alike. Felix was knocked to the ground by a heavy blow to the back. He turned to look and saw a cart full of meat and water behind him. As he pulled himself to his feet, Felix saw a guard smiling at him.

“Better keep a better eye out there boy.” He stated. “Else, you won’t last five minutes in there with that thing.”

The metal cell door opened at some bruised, battered and bleeding soldiers clambered out. Felix’s blood turned cold as he saw several bodies being dragged out also. The guard laughed at Felix’s expression and beckoned for him to enter. Felix took a tight grip on the cart and pushed it into the cell. The metal door quickly closed behind him and was left in darkness, save alone for a few torches along the walls.

Felix made his way deeper into the cell, fighting the urge to run back to the door and beg to be let out. He knew he wouldn’t be allowed until he had fed the Naga. So all he could do was brave it out for now.

Felix heard the chains rattle from the distance and saw them glint in the light. One around the Naga’s neck and one around each wrist. Felix reminded himself to be aware of the tail; he could not see any form of restraint glinting from it.

As Felix approached, he saw that the Naga was...

“The beast itself is a freak of nature. It has no true title, but the beast is the off spring of a hydra and a kitsune,” Lord William said with a large grin on his face. Though, Felix didn't know what either of those creatures were and before Felix was able to ask, three men came in. They were soldiers, not just the castle guards.

“Sir, the beast is starting to awaken! Three of its heads are up and trying swipe at our men! Some of our mages have tried to put the sleep spell back over the beast, but it looked them in the eye with the kistsune head and they started to yell like mad men!” the lead soldier yelled out.

“Is it in the cell?!” Lord William asked, hoping the beast wasn’t loss in the castle.

“We were able to get its arms and hide legs chained in the cell. We were also able to get everyone out without an injury, but some of the men are saying disturbing things. My Lord, it might be best to have a healer take care of them before their assigned any new work.”

“Fine, fine.” Lord William then dismissed them. “Now seeing as how it’s affected my strongest mages, I might need to gather more.” Lord William then looked back at Felix. “It is your job to feed the beast. Your first assignment will be tonight.”

“Alright Lord William, but-” Lord William back handed Felix while wearing three gold rings, each with different jewels of varied sizes, leaving a nasty mark on Felix’s face.

"No buts. Now get!”

Felix bowed, so he wouldn’t get hit again, and left the room. The rings cut Felix’s face making it sting. Walking down the hall he saw two guards sitting in front of the old prison cell. Beyond them, was roaring, hissing, and yelling. Felix keep walking, not stopping to be late to his next chore, when he saw the travel cage, being pulled away from a larger set of doors that lead to the beast’s cell. It had bite marks, and bent bars. A new monster was in the castle, and he had to feed this one.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- -----

The beast was fully awaken, roaring at the walls in the cell. Its ten heads were mixed: nine hydra heads, attached to long scaly necks, connected to a large furry body. It used to have five heads, four of them being hydra heads, but after the run in with Lord William’s knights they were cut off. The hydra kitsune regrew one head in the battle, but if got cut off again. The head in the middle was different; it was a kitsune head with a large furry neck, thicker than the others. The forelegs were fox legs, but the foot hand a slight resemblance to a fox paw but with long finger-like claws sticking out of it, there was also an extra claw on the side of the paw making it seem more hand like. The hind legs were still covered in fur, but were more muscular then the front. The feet were scaly and seemed to be able to hold the whole body on them, if needed. Two tails came off the body, both large fox tails. The fur was a red that had a darker red tiger strips all over. The scales were a dark version of green that turned red, at the base of the necks.

The beast cursed itself for not having enough tails to distort reality, it needed five tails. With two tails, it was able to move things, and could use some spells that it’s never tried to do before. “Damn these creatures!” the young hydra kitsune thought. “And damn those sleeping arrows! If I ever get out of here, I’ll tear this whole place down!” The young beast tried to break the chains with pure muscle, but that didn’t work, neither did trying to chew, pull, or anything. The beast was full of rage for what the humans did, and with the hydra blood, it needed to go on a little rampage before it would calm down. Minutes turned into hours. By then, the hydra kitsune lied down regaining its strength. It muttered to itself, “Damn creatures. They probably put a spell on these chains.”

A small light came from another smaller set of doors. A large cart filled deer and a bowl of water came into the room. Four of the hydra heads came up at the sight of this, but what was pushing the cart was what got all the heads to come up and start growling. It was another one of those foul beasts. Though this one was smaller than the others, the hydra kitsune knew it was still the same creature due to its scent. All the heads watched, seeing what this one would do.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- -----

Felix walked into the beast’s cell, wanting to run out instantly, but the door shut and locked behind him. One of the guards had said that the beast wouldn’t reach him for a distance, but there was no determined measurement to its reach. Felix kept walking closer, hoping to be able to push the cart- That’s when Felix heard growling. Felix looked up to see all of the beast’s heads all staring him. Taking a close look at them Felix realized that the creature could eat him in one gulp, if it got a chance. Felix just stared at the heads as he walked forward. Felix thought of all the things this monster might be able to do.

One of the hydra heads lashed out at him. Felix wasn't quick enough. All he saw was a blur of white and red erupt from the darkness. Luckily, (though what could be considered luckily when the end result is a trip in a monster's mouth?) the beast didn't bite down on his body, but instead clamped down on him with mostly its lips. Felix's stomach summersaulted as his body was whipped upwards. The lips released him and his flipped in the air blindly grabbing for anything, but nothing was around to grab onto and even if there were, he would have been too disoriented. Before his body could hit the stone floor below, he heard a single snap of teeth and with that snap, his body hit the soft, saliva coated tongue of the beast and slid as its head tilted. He tried to grab onto the creature's teeth, but he couldn't get a grip. He kicked wildly, trying to stop himself, but the rags wrapped around his feet weren't good stoppers. If it weren't for his wild kicking, Felix would have been swallowed whole, because one of his kicks just so happened the hit the thing that dangled above one’s throat. It was extremely lucky of Felix, because he really didn’t even know what it was or what happened if he hit it. He was just trying to stop himself from sliding down the beast’s throat.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- -----

The small human kicked the kitsune hyrda’s uvula. It had no control over what happened next, the head snapped forward, opened up, and spit up the bile and the human out. The human fell from about twenty feet, and if he wouldn’t have landed on the dead deer in the cart, he might have had at least a broken bone, or maybe he would have fallen to his doom. The hydra head was still coughing up a terrible taste the drenched its tongue. The creature had enough control over the head to move it away from the food. The creature left it to its coughing and focused back on the human.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- ----

Felix didn’t hesitate, he rolled off the cart and ran for the exit. The kitsune hydra lashed out. The first head strike fell just a few feet short, making a loud thud sound. The second head came down right next him. Felix heard the thick chains and the beast yelp, but he did not looking back, still determined to get out of the beast’s cell. Felix reached the door and pounded. “Let me in! I’m done! I’m done!”

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- ---

It only needed ten more feet. Ten more feet and it would have had the wretched human. It clenched all of its eyes shut and growled wanting to pound all of his head on the stone floor they were lying on.

The door opened and the human escaped.

The creature stopped growling when it heard yelling just outside the door. Using its kitsune hearing, the beast heard what was being said.

“The beast tried to eat me!”

“Do you think Lord William will care if the beast tried to eat you? That cart is worth more than your excuse for a life!” The creature heard a loud smack. “…”

Felix collapsed onto his knees from the blow, carefully cupping his hand where the metal gauntlet hit the side of his face, the same place Lord William’s ring struck. Felix’s eyes immediately moistened with tears from the pain. He kept his head bowed in submit, because the worst thing that he could do was to look directly into their eyes and make the guards even angrier.

“Someone is going to get the cart. How else is Lord William’s little pet going to be fed?”

Felix continued to look at the floor. He hoped that he misheard the guard’s words. He hoped that when the guard said that someone had to get the cart back it didn’t mean him. He wished that he wouldn’t have to go back into the cell and face that monster anytime soon, or ever again for that matter. But Felix knew that these were only wishes and dreams running through his head. He knew what the guards were really saying to him and he knew that no matter what happened, even if he didn’t have to retrieve the cart, he would still have to go back in to feed the creature. He was a slave and he had to do what he was asked to do. He didn’t have any choice.

The guard’s boot kicked Felix’s side. Felix had felt harder kicks, but he knew the kick wasn’t meant to cause him serious pain. The kick was meant to just get his attention, but that didn’t make the kick painless.

“Did you hear me, slave?”

Felix stayed silent.

“Get up and get the cart back.”

“Me?” Felix still wished that he was mishearing the guard.

“It’s not my fault the cart is still in there. It’s your problem, slave.”

“But, I,” Felix looked at the other guard for help, but the other guard just stood there with a blank face that didn’t care and wouldn’t help. “But the monster tried to eat me. If I go in there-”

“It’s not our problem.”

“It will eat me.”

“Again, not our problem. Why else do you think Lord William chose a slave to feed that monster? Because no one would care if you are killed.”

“Please.”

The guard grabbed Felix’s wrist as tight as iron cuffs and pulled Felix onto his feet. With the force of the pull, Felix thought his arm was going to pop out, but luckily Felix only received a brief minimal amount of pain from the pull. But it didn’t end when Felix got up; the guard pulled again, but this time pulling Felix to the door.

Normally, Felix would have started obeying the guard with the fear of being punished even more. However, this wasn’t a normal situation. He knew that if he obeyed and went through with what he was told to do, he would die. He would have no chance against the giant beast and it would swallow him whole. For the first time in Felix’s five years of slavery, Felix said, “No!” Felix pulled back, trying to escape the guard’s grasp, but no matter how far he leaned back, the guard didn’t release him. He just dragged the young slave towards the door while the other guard unlocked it.

“No! You’ll kill me! It’ll kill me!”

“You’re getting that cart.”

“Please, don’t make me!”

The door opened and Felix could see the large fox head staring back at him. Felix pulled and thrashed, looking away from the terrible monster and towards the only way out of the dungeons. But he just couldn’t break free.

The guard twisted Felix’s wrist. Felix’s legs buckled and he screamed. The guard twisted it more. Felix continued his pleas, but the guard twisted till there was a crackling sound. Felix’s whole world became blurry and watery due to the tears.

“Get in there and this time, bring back the cart!”

The guard threw Felix in the cell and locked the door back up. Felix stumbled and fell on his broken wrist. Felix rotated onto his side and curled into a fetal position on the cold, rocky floor. He cradled his wrist against his chest, but of course, the pain didn’t go away. He felt nothing else but the pain. He couldn’t see anything but the blackness the pain caused. It drowned out all his other senses until it filled his entire body.

He only kept his eyes shut and wished that the pain would end soon, because he knew that he was well within the beast’s range. He knew it would eat him now and that he could do nothing about it. He just hoped his pain would go away once he died.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- ------

The hydra kitsune heard and saw the whole thing. The smaller human, the one that escaped, couldn’t escape the bigger human’s grip. The smaller human didn’t want to go back in the prison cell, it was absolutely terrified. The hydra kitsune heard the crack and knew it was the sound of a bone breaking. The bigger human threw the littler one in the cell and within the hydra kitsune’s reach. Not only was it smaller than the other humans, but the hydra kitsune noticed that the human appeared to be even more different. The human wore dirty rags for clothes. I put that thing in my mouth? The terrible after-taste of the creature kicked in and the hydra head tasting it had to spit the taste out as best as it could.

“Wait Marciana? That means that it…. She’s a girl.” “I’m Felix, nice to meet you Marciana.” Felix said, trying to be polite. The last thing he needs to do is insult a something that could kill him without even noticing.

Marciana noticed this but pretend it was nothing. “Now Felix, do we have a deal?”

Felix knew that if he didn’t take the deal he would be dead because he couldn’t do his chores, but he still didn’t trust Marciana “Alright, but I’m going to need to find a way for you to escape too. I don’t know of any way for you to escape, but the front door.”

“Uh Marciana, what would happen if you had more tails?” Before Marciana could give her answer there was a load knock on the door.

Marciana then turned all her heads to the door, and listened, “Are you still alive in there slave?”

Felix had forgot that he was suppose to get the cart. He had to think quick, but instead Marciana cover for him. Using some of her kitsune powers she made her voice sound like Felix’s, “I’m trying to find it. I think the monster destroyed it.” Felix looked at Marciana amazed; he never would have thought that she could mimic his voice.

“How do we know you’re not lying?” When the guard said this Marciana got an idea. She used one of her hydras head to eat everything off the cart, another one to remove the water bowl, and a third to pick up the cart itself. Once the head with the water put it down, Marciana threw the cart at the door Felix came in. it shattered into small pieces of wood, but the sound it made echoed throughout the cell. “What was that?!”

Marciana, picked Felix up and put him as close to the door as possible, and said, still in Felix’s voice, “I found the cart, but I don’t think Lord William will want it in pieces.” Felix looked back at Marciana, as she went back into the cell. He wanted to thank her, but the guards opened up the door to see the destroyed cart in front of it.

One of the guards said, “Shit, how the tamers are suppose to get in here?”

The second one looked at Felix and smiled, “Looks like you’re not going to get to do your other chores until this mess is cleaned up.” Felix then went in shock, behind the guards, was Sir George.

He looked at the leftover of the broken cart, then back at the two guards laughing at Felix’s situation. George then said, “Do you two think this is funny!? If you think this is so funny then the both of you do the slaves chores, as he cleans up this mess!” Both the guards jumped out of their skins. They looked at George before they bowed and walked away. “Slave, clean this mess and when you finish, tell the guards they are dismissed.” Lord William then walked away, closing the door. Felix looked over at Marciana.

“Who was he?” Marciana whispered, making it impossible for anyone other than Felix to hear.

“That was Sir George; he is the leader of the knights. He doesn’t care about anyone really. He just wants to get things done quickly.” Felix looked at Marciana and asked, “Can you heal my arm now?” Marciana lowered one of her hydra heads next to Felix and wrapping Felix’s arm with her tongue. Felix’s arm started to feel better; he could move his arm again. Marciana removed her tongue and Felix moved his arm around. This was the first time he had magic done to him. It was so strange and now his arm is so slimy. He looked at Marciana and saw her panting a bit.

“Now what did you ask me?” Marciana asked, hoping to restart the conversation they had earlier and get her breathe back. Felix may not know this, but that took a lot out of. She is luck that all she just has to regain her breathe; she usually needs to take a nap after doing something like that.

“Oh,” Felix was still looking at him arm and wondering about magic. “I think I asked you about having more tails.” Felix then turned and started to work on removing the broken cart piece by piece. Marciana got the idea that if Felix didn’t want to be beat, and then he would have to start working.

I can somewhat control lightening, but only if there’s a storm outside. I have seen three tailed kitsunes make small illusions like frog and rabbits and trick some hydras. I’ve never seen what four tails do, but a lot of kitsune have five tails. They can cast stronger spells, and do weird things with reality. Our grand elder have eight, but never uses any of his stronger powers.”

Felix was now about half way thru, “I was wondering, how where you born? I don’t want to sound rude, but Lord William said you were a mix of two creatures. How does that happen?”

Marciana knew what Felix was asking. “Felix I was born like every other being on this world. My parents loved each other and had me. 15533222222211.content:
Felix nodded, heading into the cell. He wondered if it was important that the beast was a girl. He decided to think about it later, and focus now on finding it, or her, and avoiding eye contact.

Finding her was easy, mainly because she was about five times his size. She stood in the middle of the room, her head hung low. Felix stopped and took in her features. Her scales were green, and her feathers were white. She did indeed have a chicken head, but the beak was longer and hooked, and there were two stubby horns growing from the back of her head. She also had a small, sharp horn on her beak, and Felix had heard from guards' discussions earlier that such a feature on things like dragons meant the were young, because they used such horns to break their eggshells. So, despite her size, Felix thought the cockatrice must be young.

He thought all this as he walked onward, pushing the cart. But what he failed to notice was what the creature lacked: a blindfold.

He walked close to the cockatrice, until he realized he had accidentally stepped over the safety line drawn by the guards earlier. Thinking little of it, he stepped back over while checking if the beast had woken up from her apparent sleep, and found himself staring right into her fiery orange eyes.

He was frozen solid, paralyzed all over by the cockatrice magic, unable to move back from across the line. The cockatrice stood up tall, all twenty or so feet of her, and stepped forward, examining the tiny creature that had entered her cell. As it was, she was actually more afraid of Felix than he was of her, because she was so young, eveything about this new place scared her. She seemed to sense that he was different, though, and began to feel an odd sort of desire to be with him, as if he meant safety. Felix, meanwhile, was terrified, and thought he was going to die.

His fear escalated when he saw the cockatrice move her head down to his level. Her piercing orange eyes still gazed into his, but he began to feel an odd sort of sadness in them. The cockatrice looked at him for a bit, but then the guards opened the door to ask what was taking him so long.

Suddenly, the cockatrice moved her head sideways and opened her beak wide. Felix got even more scared, and saw the cockatrice grab him in her beak. She held him by his torso, her beak only big enough to cover from his chest to his waist, and lifted him up. He began to gain control of his body when she took her eyes off him, but decided not to struggle. He was dead anyway. He just let his arms and legs hang limp from her beak, as he looked at the door, hoping the guards would help him.

But the guards took one look at the cockatrice, holding the boy in her beak and glaring towards them, and decided not to try and help the slave. One of them got paralyzed, though, and had to be dragged off by the second, luckier one.

The cockatrice, and Felix in her beak, watched them close the door. The cockatrice stayed still for a short while, during which Felix simply dangled his arms and legs, looking around the cell and wondering why the cockatrice hadn't killed him yet. Suddenly, the cockatrice began stepping backward, still holding him in her beak, and sat down at the far edge of the cell, away from the door. She lowered her head and gently released Felix, and the boy stood up shakily, looking away from the cockatrice. He noticed her curling her tail around, and simply watched as it looped around him and squeezed him gently, holding him in place.

"It is an elemental," the tyrant proclaimed proudly, a wicked smile on his lips. Felix held a blank look, confused.

"Er, what is that, milord?"

The lord seemed to roll his eyes, but stayed his hand. If the slave was to be responsible for the creature, he should at least know something of it.

"An elemental is a being with great ties to a field of natural magic. They are very powerful, and very dangerous." The man grinned wolfishly before continuing. "We have captured a young fire elemental,and it will be harnessed for my army. These are highly magical beigns, but they require physical substenance just as anything else. That is your job. You are to feed and maintain the creature. You will enter to feed it three times a day in addition to your regualr duties."

His face darkened, eyes cold.

"If this being is to die while under your care, you will join it swiftly, and painfully. Do you understand?"

Felix swallowed hard, and nodded wordlessly.

"Good," William siad, before his face contorted into a mask of disgust. "Now get out of my sight you worm. Your additional duties begin tomorrow."

Felix was sent scurrying away with a swift, painful kick, and, satisfied , the lord turned and chuckled.

**************************************************************************** ******************************************************************************** *************************************************************************

For once, Felix was glad he had been assigned to clean the library. Lord William's collection of musty, dusty tomes was extensive. Felix could remember his parents, if only barely. They had been travelling traders, and keeping logs and inventory was vital to any merchant. He had been learning the basics of literacy when his family had written him off as a poor investment and dumped him off at the nearest slave trader for a fatter purse. It was a painful memory, but the minimal skills he had acquired in reading and writing were now serving him well.

The slave had found a tucked away corner to pry open the ancient book, and in the dim light he had flipped through until finding his desired entry.

"El-em-ent-als," he muttered struggling through it. Most of it was words he had no hope in understanding. But the accompanying illustration was more than clear. It showed a humanoid figure, though covered in flames, or spiked rocks, or ice, gazing fiercly at the reader. Felix gulped.

"That's what he's got in there?" he though to himself, quietly putting th ebook away and hurrying to the sleeping quarters as the sun began to sink behind the horizon, las t glimmers of light pouring through the castle window, facing the sea.

**************************************************************************** ******************************************************************************** *************************************************************************

Felix awoke wordlessly at dawn, just like very other slave. He reported to the kitchens, as per his instructions. Waiting there was a cart, which the head cook loaded up with a stale loaf of bread and a couple slabs of putrid looking raw meat. Felix was confused. It looked a bit of a paltry meal for a monster, but he recalled Lord William saying it was young. Eventually, a mixture of courage and fear of the whip kicked in and the slave grabbed the cart and headed down to the dungeons.

He headed down the halls, drowning out the howls and moans of the dozens of suffering souls. A pair of guards passed him, conversing idly as if he didn't exist.

"I'm telling you Bert, I got a peek in there and that thing just looks like a red-headed kid! Not this monster everyone keeps making it out to be."

The second guard, Bert apparently, shook his head.

"No, I saw the group of soldiers who captured it coming back in. Only half them were there, and just about everyone left in the company had scorches or burns on em'. And Jakobs had to help unload the thing, he opened the door and got roasted like a pig on a spit. If it weren't for the mages, they all would've been killed. That thing is a monster."

Their opposite paths soon distanced Felix from the guards, and he had begun to sweat, his hands shaking slightly. Finally he came to the end of the hall, the biggest cell in the castle. A grim faced guard stood there, and wordlessly let him in. Trembling, Felix pushed the cart in, and peered into the gloom. The guards had been right. Off in one corner, chained to the wall, was what appeared to be a child his own age, a blazing mane of red hair atop their head. Steppping closer he saw it was.......

Felix soon saw that it was a girl, close to his age if he had to guess, in physical appearance anyways, he couldn't read the text in the book he had seen the pictures in to see if the elementals aged like humans, or if they aged faster, or slower. But all he saw was her eyes, filled with what he had to assume was fury, before a stream of fire shot towards him. Just having barely enough time to shove the cart in one direction, and himself in another, he barely avoided getting singed. "The next one won't miss. Let me go!" The girl yelled at Felix, who was suddenly a lot more afraid than when he had just entered the room a few seconds ago.

"I-I can't...I was-" He was about to say he wasn't the one who captured her, but he had to roll out of the way from another stream of fire.

"Don't lie to me human!" The girl continued to yell at Felix.

"I'm not!" Felix snapped at the girl. It was one thing to try to kill him, but to insinuate that he was lying was a bit much, especially coming from someone in the same situation as he was. "I'm like you, a captive!" Felix yelled right back at the girl.

Either she was too surprised at him, a human that had hardly any protection or any sort of weaponry in sight, yelling at her, a fire elemental that could more than likely roast him very slowly and painfully, or she had decided at that moment to calm down. Either way, Felix didn't get another stream of fire thrown at him. The girl didn't say anything to him after that, and just stared at him. The fury had never left her eyes, but then again, he couldn't tell if that was just how she always looked. For awhile, there was silence, then the girl sat down cross legged, her back against the wall.

"Hmph...If you're expecting an apology, don't hold your breath." The girl said.

'Oh great...I have to feed her every single day now? I may as well say my prayers now.' Felix thought to himself, holding the very top of his nose, the spot right between his eyes, as he forced himself to calm down. He had a nasty temper that he only managed to keep under control thanks to his very...imaginative mind. He always thought of ways Lord William and every other person that had hurt him for no other reason other than that he was an easy target, being a slave and all, dying a varied, and gruesome, death. Of course, he has to be careful when he thinks these thoughts, thanks to his mages. But for the most part, he was able to keep himself calm and obedient.

"I'm not gonna apologize for roasting that guard so you can just go ahead and leave already!" The girl said, her voice getting louder again.

Felix held up a hand. "That's not why I'm here." Felix said bluntly.

"And I'm supposed to believe you...how?" The girl asked Felix, though Felix probably didn't want to know why.

"Well...for one, I don't like most of the guards that work here, never have." Felix said, hoping that he wouldn't have to...

"Prove it then." The girl said, a smirk forming on her face, as if he couldn't. Felix really wanted to bring the palm of his hand up to his forehead...but he resisted the urge to do so. Sighing he slowly lifted his shirt up, and turned around, so she could see what it was that he meant. On his back were various scars, from whippings, to burn marks. "Hmm...those burns look like they are about...two months old...some of them anyways. A few of the other ones look to be a bit more recent. Those...guards did that to you? Hm..." For once, the look of fury had disappeared from her face, and a thoughtful one was on it instead. "Tell ya what. First off, tell me your name...assuming you have one of course. Might as well get the introductions over with, especially if you are going to listen to what I am about to tell ya."

Felix just looked at her with a confused look on his face when he turned back around with his shirt on and covering his back again. He was currently trying to wrap his head around the sudden change of attitude that had just happened. "Well? You have a name or what? You should know that making a lady wait is considered rude in most parts of the world." The girl said, looking a bit more annoyed.

"Felix. My name is Felix." He said, though wondering why he said that was beyond him. He just assumed that she only wanted his name.

"Felix huh? Well, normally I would say nice to meet you, being polite and all, but I think we can skip that. My name is Tonya." However, to Felix, it felt as if there was something else behind that little exchange of names.

"It's a kraken," Lord William told his slave.

Felix had heard about krakens from the tells of the sailors and military. Lord William's city and castle was near the ocean and those who would seek the city by either shipping supplies or a pit stop would tell tales of sea monsters. Felix didn't need to be out of the castle to hear the tales and he had heard of krakens. A kraken was a giant octopus that terrorized ships. They would often destroy ships and devour the occupants just because they could do so. Felix didn't know what a octopus looked like since he had never seen one, but he knew it had eight tentacles and a beak for a mouth. Those were the two main things sailors talked about when describing them as well as them having square pupiled eyes and being able to grow large enough to devour a whole ship, (but those were rare extremes. Usually krakens didn't live long enough to become that big.)

Felix's face turned pale upon hearing a kraken was in the large cage that was being wheeled down the dungeons. "From your expression, I can tell you've heard of krakens," Lord William stated while smiling at Felix's fear.

"Yes, Master, but only sailor stories and they tend to embellish..." Felix started.

"They don't embellish when it comes to sea monsters," Lord William interrupted, "The kraken in the cage right no could coil its tentacles around the high tower if it wanted to, and it is still not fully grown yet, not even close."

"It...it's s-s-still g-growing?" Felix questioned.

"Yes, and once it is grown and loyal to me, no navy would ever be able to defeat me. With a kraken at my command, no conqueror would dare attack by sea," Lord William said. The cage shook violently again and those pushing it stopped. "Don't stop pushing!" Lord William demanded, "Hurry up and get it water or it will die and it will be no use to me."

The men continued to push the cage only so they wouldn't make their lord any angrier. "It needs water to live, like fish?" Felix asked.

"It does need water to live, but it can also go on land for a certain duration of time. However, this one can't stay out of the water too long since it is still young," Lord William answered.

"How will it survive down here?" Felix asked. It wasn't that he was concerned about the monster's well being, he was just wondering what Lord William's plans of keeping the creature alive were.

"Underneath this castle, deep in the dungeons, there are underground rivers. The caverns are filled to the brim with water and there are many miles of tunnels under this castle, the city, and the ocean floor. When making the dungeon, we came across a large cave with the water system. The room is large enough that the water is an underground lake. This is where the kraken will stay, and the exits and passageways out of that cavernous room will be blocked off, until we need it to head for the ocean to fight. We know one of the paths that leads to the ocean," Lord William explained.

"My Lord, you know that krakens can squeeze through very small places, right?" a person pushing the cage said. It was true that krakens like other octopus had no bones and could squeeze through very small places if it had too.

"All small places are barred and each bar has dagger edges. It won't won't try to escape," Lord William told the man.

Eventually, they came upon a room that was deeper than Felix had ever gone in the dungeon before. The room was an extremely large cavern with a rocky ground. The rocky ground eventually dropped into a large and deep lake that filled the rest of the cavern up to the ground with still close to a hundred feet of air still left between the ceiling and water. Felix could see other pathways halfway filled with water and with daggered iron bars guarding them.

"Open the cage," Lord William ordered. The men hesitated and Lord William explained, "The kraken will be more concerned with trying to get to the water than trying to kill us. Now open the cage!"

The men released the hatch and the kraken bolted out and ran right into the lake and disappeared in the depths. The kraken had moved so fast that it was a blur to Felix and he couldn't get a clear image. The men pushed the cage out of the room and Lord William ordered, "Go get some barrels of fish for the kraken, slave. It is your job to look after the kraken and make sure it doesn't die. Otherwise, it will be your head, do I make myself clear?"

"Yes, my master," Felix replied.

"Then you will feed it now. Go get some barrels," Lord William ordered.

Felix did as he was told and left to get the barrels of fish in a cart and back to the cavern.

Felix pushed the cart filled with barrels of fish towards the edge. However he went slowly and cautiously because he didn't see the kraken and he had no idea how long its reach was. Felix stopped the cart a yard or so away from the edge and watched the water which was level with the edge. There was no movement in the dark waters and Felix didn't see the kraken anywhere.

Felix waited for a long time, but the kraken was still nowhere to be found. Felix took out a barrel and rolled it across the floor to the edge. The barrel hit the water and continued to float into the lake. The only movement was the ripples in the water from the floating barrel. Felix waited for a tentacle to shoot up and grab the barrel, but none came.

"Either its a trick, the creatures escaped, the creature is dead, or it doesn't know its food," Felix thought. Felix became worried once more not for the creature's sake but for his own. "If the creature doesn't eat and dies because of that, it will be my head. But what do I do."

Felix took another barrel and opened it. He took a fish out and tossed it close to the floating barrel. Felix stood and waited for a minute before and long tentacle came out of the water. The tentacle was just like the sailors told. It was thick with large suction cup like circles the size of Felix's head. (Actually in the stories that much larger, but this was a young kraken.) The only difference was that sailors would say that krakens were dark red, black, or brown but, the tentacle was dark purple. During the weeks the kraken had been held captive, it tried to find ways of escaping. Like octopus, kraken were very intelligent creatures and great puzzle-solvers, even at an early age. So, even if this kraken was only about a year old or so, it still was very intelligent. Krakens also live a longer time as well and have actually survived longer than humans if given the chance, but unfortunately, humans hunt them and kill them for sport and for food. Not many kraken live long enough to reach their full lifespan

The kraken looked all around the lake, but all the crevices and holes it would have normally fit through were blocked. The kraken would have been able to fit through the bars easily, but each bar had razor shape edges which made it impossible to get through without getting seriously cut. The kraken had to find a different way out. Eventually, the kraken came to the surface when no human was around. (It had memorized the humans' routines and knew about the time each human came in its prison.)

The kraken eventually found an opening, but there was a major problem. The opening was close to the ceiling on a wall and underneath the ceiling was dry land. The kraken would have to get on dry land and climb the wall. It would be easy enough to do so, but there was no grantee that there would be water on the other side of the opening. If there wasn't, the kraken was as good as dead. Was the kraken willing to try it.

The answer was yes, and it placed its tentacles on dry land and pulled itself out of the water. With the suction cups on each of the eight tentacles, the kraken was able to start walking up the wall towards the entrance. The kraken was still young and it didn't have time on it side. It couldn't stay out of the water as long as an adult kraken and the kraken was having troubles without oxygen form the water. The kraken had a strong will, though, and continued to try and prevail onwards. The kraken's tentacle made it to the opening and pulled it up to it. It needed water right then, but when its eyes revealed the other side of the opening, no water was to be found.

The kraken's strength gave away and it fell on the rocky ground before the lake. The kraken was too weak, it couldn't even lift a tentacle to make itself crawl to the lake. The kraken knew it was going to die. It have failed to escape and now it was going to die.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- -----------------------------------

Felix opened the door and pushed the cart in only to find the kraken on land. Felix stopped dead in his tracks fearing the kraken had came on land to eat him. The kraken's skin was black now and it was the strangest creature Felix had ever seen. The creature had eight tentacles like sailors had said and it had a large dome shaped head. The large dome shape was behind the creature and its eyes were directly above the center where all the tentacles met and in front of the dome. The octopus was on its side and Felix could see the beak on the bottom. It looked exactly like an over-sized octopus, but Felix didn't know that, because he never saw an octopus.

Felix stayed back, but when he noticed the way the octopus was sprawled on the ground, Felix began to remember what Lord William had said. "Krakens can't live a long time out of the water," Felix remembered, "It's dying and if it dies, Lord William will blame me and my head will be his. I have to save the beast or I will die as well!"

Felix didn't waste any time. He took the smallest barrel and dumped the fish on the ground before running to the edge. Once at the edge, he filled the barrel with water and rushed over to the kraken. He hoped that his plan would work, but he had no idea if it would since he knew practically nothing about krakens.

Felix came upon the kraken and didn't care that he was within inches of it. He was too afraid of what Lord William would do to him than the kraken since letting the kraken was a sure death for himself. Felix had to examine the creature before he could figure out where the gills were. Eventually, Felix found two pocket like shapes where the dome and the rest of the body met. Felix dumped water there and which caused the pockets to move and it's eyes with rectangular pupils to open. Felix ran back to the edge, filled the barrel, and dumped the water on the kraken again and again.

"Please let this work. Please don't let this beast die," Felix pleaded in his mind and to the gods he worshiped. However, in the back of his mind he thought the gods wouldn't answer. After all, they had never answered before and Felix was still a slave to an evil lord.

Eventually, the kraken moved a tentacle, stretched it out on the ground towards the water and tried pulling itself forward. "It's moving!" Felix exclaimed in his mind. Soon Felix found himself encouraging the creature by saying, "Come on, you can do it. Just keep going. You can't die on me, please." Eventually, Felix even found himself pushing on the back of the dome to try and keep the kraken moving. To his surprise, the kraken was much lighter than it should have been. (This was mostly because the kraken had no internal bones like other octopus.) Felix also found its skin soft, squishy, and slick. It was the strangest thing Felix had ever touched and he couldn't find the words to even describe the creature's skin. Felix also noticed that the creature's skin turned from a black color to very dark red. (This was because it was determined to make it to the edge. Determination, along with other emotions such as anger, were signified with a dark red color.)

The kraken eventually made it to the edge and fell into the lake. Felix fell to his knees, close to the edge of the water. Felix continued to look into the water to see if the kraken would make it, but the lake was deep and dark and Felix couldn't see too far down into the water. He had no idea if the kraken was alright.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------- ----------------

The kraken thought it was going to die for its stupid mistake, yet it did not die that day. It suddenly felt water by its gills and was able to breath the dissolved oxygen. The kraken opened its eyes to see a human helping it. The kraken didn't understand, all the humans it had met were terrible and evil creatures, but this one was helping it.

The human did everything to help it. The human poured water, encouraged it to get to the water, and even helped push when the kraken was weak from the lack of oxygen. Eventually, the kraken made it to the lake and could finally breathe! As the kraken caught its breath, it looked up at the human kneeling by the side. The human looked worried for its safety. The human had saved the kraken's life and it knew it had to repay the human somehow. However, the kraken knew nothing about humans and didn't know what it would want. It also had no idea how to communicate with the human. Humans seemed to speak to communicate, but krakens had a beak, and couldn't speak like humans. Besides, krakens communicated with body language and the colors of their skin. It had no idea if the human would know how to communicate.

It took a few minutes, but eventually, he saw two tentacles shoot out of the water. The tentacles stuck themselves to the land and They formed the C-shape around Felix again. "Please don't eat me. Please don't eat me," Felix kept repeating in his mind as the kraken's head came to the surface.

Felix backed up slightly when the kraken rose to the surface so that he wasn't right in front of the creature because he was still nervous of the creature. It was supposed to be a blood-thirsty monster after all and it was big enough to eat Felix if the kraken would want to. Felix stood still and watched the kraken as it looked at him. Felix and the kraken stayed in this position for a long time, doing nothing except staring at each other. Felix noticed that the kraken was a deep purple once more. "How can it change colors like that?" Felix wondered, "Is there a meaning to its color changings?"

Felix looked into the krakens large rectangular pupiled eyes next. The eyes were very alien to him, yet he found something familiar in the eyes. Felix saw an emotion in the monster's eyes that Felix knew all too well. he saw sadness and depression in the beast's eyes. Felix was to much in awe to do anything for a few minutes. "It... It's sad," Felix realized, "But, wouldn't that mean it has at least some intelligence?"

Felix studied the sadness in the kraken's eyes for a long time. Felix had been in the depressing castle under the rule of an oppressive lord for a long time and he knew many different levels of sadness. He usually knew what level of sadness people were in just by looking at their eyes, and Felix was trying to do that same thing with the kraken. He was surprised that he was successful in doing so. he had thought it would be hard to do so with such a different and alien creature to him, but it seemed as though the kraken was intelligent enough to have the same emotional depth has a human's.

Felix found the kraken to be at a level of sadness that matched Felix's emotions when he first arrived at the castle and had become a slave. Felix remembered that day. It was filled with confusion and depression he had troubles describing. He couldn't remember his family and suddenly found himself in a castle as a slave. He was only five years old and couldn't grasp the concept of slavery. All he knew was that people were ordering him to do things he didn't want to do and he was whipped or beaten when he refused or didn't do it correct. He was the lord's property and alone without anyone to care for him or even acknowledge his existence.it was a depression and loneliness that still haunted Felix and now he realized that the kraken was feeling the same way.

"The kraken and I feel the same. We're both alone, scared, and depressed. We're both trapped in this castle with an evil lord ruling over us. We're very much a like," Felix understood.

Felix noticed that the kraken was about to go back in the water. "Wait!" Felix commanded while holding his hands out. Felix had no idea if the kraken understood him, but the kraken stayed put and waited. Felix side stepped and pointed to the fish pile near him. "Don't you want the rest of the fish?" Felix asked. The kraken seemed hesitant at first, but two more tentacles came out of the water and attached themselves next to the other tentacles. Suddenly, the kraken puled itself so that it was vertically positioned at the edge. This made it so Felix was facing the underside of the kraken and the beak.

A tentacle on the otherside of Felix moved and Felix backed against the other tentacle. The moving tentacle set down on the fish pile and dragged it to its break. The kraken then set its body on the surface ate the fish pile under it. Felix looked at the place where the fish pile used to be and saw one fish was missed. Felix picked up the fish and when the kraken brought itself down to its normal level, Felix informed the kraken, "You missed one!"

The kraken stared at the fish in Felix's hand for a while before turning olive green and propping itself up vertically again. Suddenly, a tentacle pushed on Felix's back and pushed him towards the mouth. Felix became scared and tried to resist, but the tentacle was too powerful to push against. He eventually found himself at the beak and Felix feared that the kraken was going to fall on top of him and eat him like the pile of fish, but that event never came. As Felix waited and breathed heavily in a panicked state, the kraken just stayed in its position with its beak open.

After nothing had happened for a long time, Felix began to realize the kraken was not going to eat him. "It... It just wants me to feed it the fish," Felix thought, "Maybe it's because it would have troubles finding one fish and it would have to be out of the water longer than it needed to be. Or Maybe, it's a sign of trust. Maybe it's showing me it wouldn't harm me."

Whatever the reason was, Felix threw the fish in the kraken's beak and the beak slowly closed and the tentacle moved away from Felix's back. Felix backed away quickly and the kraken lowered itself down with only two tentacles on land. What did Felix do?

He then felt himself fall on the ground, stone this time. He looked to his left and found stairs. He also found hope of survival. He pushed himself up with shier willpower and slowly went to the stairs, the monster coming ever so closer. Felix tried to speed up but couldn’t do to pain through out his body. It stopped in it track when Felix heard the voice of William. “Boy! You have better not have feed it yet.” His voice echoed all the way down. It was quite for a second when Felix saw the monster flee under water and William continuing. “Damn it. Looks like he fell in… oh well. No big loss. I was wondering when this would have happen. I also ask myself, why is it so hard to brake a Leviathan?” Felix waited for a moment, his eyes shown realization, when he heard the door slam from William’s retreat. Felix looked up then to the waters. "Oh, Shit..." he said out loud. Felix thought on his options then.

"On one hand I go up and face Lord William and his wrath, Well on the other hand I stay down here with the..." He gulped. "the Leviathan..." Felix sat down. "Wait, its a Leviathan?, what I know on them is that they can whip out armies in seconds, this one must be a child, wait! a child, must have been just trying to play with me, wait, why?, its been down here and tortured for the last five year. But then again... Damn it! what Am I thinking!, I'm dead either way!, What the hell can I do damn it! I don't know which one's worse. Hell!"

info.brief_description: A young slave encounters another prisoner in the castle that isn't human!
info.description:
Okay. I just saw a trailer for a videogame that was made public three days ago. Well, three days ago today which is 5-21-09. The trailer was of Team Ico's next game. The trailer alone inspired me to think up this interactive. I don't want it to be like the game and I don't even know if this is the main primiss of the game since I've only seen a trailer. If you're intrested in the trailer look up Project Trico on youtube and you'll find it.

The story of this interactive:

A young ten year old slave is trapt into servitude for a nasty and evil lord who is very power hungry. One day, the lord's men captured something alive and very large. The creature is chained up in the prison cells and put in a dark and uncomfortable place. Feeding the creature becomes one of the young slaves many jobs, but the slave is very afraid of what the creature might be and only tosses the food in the room without looking at the creature. Little does the slave know that the creature is a mythical creature that may be the size of an elephant now, but it is only an infant.

If I end up deleting or editing a page I will always explain why I've done so.

1. I have no problems with violence, but please keep the fetishes away. Crushing and eating people is fine, because it is a giant mythical creature, but the creature and the characters shouldn't be turned on by such an act and the boy and creature can't do anything sexual, because he's only ten and the creature's an infant.

2. I've had some problems with chapter additions beening too short. You see, there is a limit of chapters per storyline. I didn't even know about this till I created Outcast, but there is a limit and having many short chapters only brings a story closer to the limit with little action involved. So, if you wish to know about how long I would like chapters to be, take a look at the first chapter which is slightly longer than the mimimun.

3. Another thing is that the creature imprisoned needed for be a child or younger. The story is not meant for the creature to be much older than Felix who is ten. So, about 12 or younger it about the age limit. The creature should be preferably an infant to its kind. So, creatures with longer lifespans than humans, like dragons, could be about ten years of age but an infant to its kind.

4. If you choose to add to the Felarya creatures, read about Felarya and the creature you choose. http://www.felarya.com/wiki/index.php?title=Main_Page (Be warned though, the sight has nudity and vore) The story doesn't take place in Felarya, but the creature (if you choose a Felarya creature), is from Felarya and will have the qualities of that species.

5. There are a few things that some people seem to forget after the first chapter. (This is most likely because after the first chapter, the reader gets to choose what kind of monster the creature is and it could get to a point were the choice is a good length away from the first chapter.) So, here are the two things. #1. The creature was rolled into the dungeons by a large wooden cages meant for elephants. This means that the creature is very large and since it is an infant to its kind from rule 3, the creature option has to be a large creature. Otherwise there wouldn't have been any need for such a large cage. Size changing creatures are an exception to this rule. #2. Though the creature comes in this cage, it is stored into a large cell made of stone and concrete with only two ways in, The large door used to push the cage in and the human door. Some people seem to believe the elephant cage is the creature's cell, but it is only the transport to its cell. Those were just two things I'd like to clear up if I didn't make it clear enough in the first chapter.
